articles.title: EPA Tells California It Has The âWorst Air Qualityâ In America, Threatens Highway Funds
articles.subtitle: In a new letter, EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler alleged the state has failed to âcarry out its most basic tasks under the Clean Air Act.â
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: The Trump administration escalated its political war with California on Monday, threatening to withhold federal funding for the stateâs highways unless officials dealt with what they referred to as the âworst air quality in the United States.â Andrew Wheeler, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said in a letter to Californiaâs Air Resources Board this week that the state had failed to address a backlog of air pollution control plans mandated by federal law. Unless the state takes action on about 130 plans, Wheeler said the EPA would begin a âdisapproval processâ that could impact billions in funding for its highways. âSince the 1970s, California has failed to carry out its most basic tasks under the Clean Air Act,â Wheeler wrote in a letter dated Sept. 24, which was first reported by The Sacramento Bee. âCalifornia has the worst air quality in the United States.â Wheeler requested a response from state officials by Oct. 10. The Bee notes that California was projected to receive around $19 billion in funding from the Federal Highway Administration from 2016 to 2020. The White House has locked horns with California over environmental issues for months. Last week, the Trump administration said it would revoke Californiaâs legal authority to set its own auto emissions standards, part of its effort to roll back strict emissions standards set by the Obama administration as a key part of its effort to tackle climate change. California sued the Trump administration shortly after the move was announced, joining nearly two dozen other states. The Trump administration has also been wielding the power of the EPA in recent months as a means to hit back at the stateâs efforts to set its own pollution and climate change standards, even as the White House has rolled back or eliminated dozens of environmental regulations. Last week, Trump said he planned to order the EPA to tell San Francisco it was in âtotal violationâ of federal regulations, citing used syringes and other pollution he said was linked to the stateâs homeless populations. Officials in the city fired back, saying there was no evidence to back up the presidentâs claims. The New York Times reported early Tuesday that Trump has been angered by Californiaâs efforts to circumvent his administrationâs rollbacks of environmental rules. The outlet said that in response, the White House has focused on efforts to punish the state. Wheeler wrote in his letter this week that the stateâs backlog of air pollution control plans had impacted up to 34 million Californians and that the agency was only moving to address decades of lapses in environmental monitoring. âOur foremost concern must be ensuring clean air for all Americans,â he wrote. âThat is our goal.â

articles.title: Steve Mnuchin: Giving Congress Whistleblower Complaint Would Set âTerrible Precedentâ
articles.subtitle: But some legal experts say withholding the complaint from lawmakers is a violation of the law.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said allowing Congress to see a whistleblower complaint that allegedly calls into question President Donald Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky would set a âterrible precedent.â But Democrats and some legal experts say granting Congress access to the complaint is required by law. Mnuchin, during an appearance on CNNâs âState of the Unionâ Sunday, defended Trump against reports that he repeatedly pressured Zelensky during a July phone call to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter. The House Intelligence Committee has opened an investigation into the complaint, including whether Trump withheld military aid from Ukraine as part of his efforts to get Zelensky to investigate Biden, a front-runner in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary. Michael Atkinson, the inspector general for the U.S. intelligence community, deemed the complaint credible and of âurgent concern,â he wrote in a letter earlier this month to House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.). But acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire, whom Trump appointed last month, reportedly said he does not believe the complaint meets the definition of âurgent concernâ and has refused to hand it over to Congress. âThere is a whistleblower who wants to bring this information â his whistleblower complaint â to Congress, and the White House is preventing that,â CNNâs Jake Tapper told Mnuchin on Sunday. âIf there really is nothing there, why shouldnât the White House just let Congress ... look at this whistleblower complaint?â Mnuchin responded, âI think that would be a terrible precedent.â âConversations between world leaders are meant to be confidential,â he continued. âAnd if every time someone for political reasons raised a question and all of a sudden those conversations were disclosed publicly â and when you disclose them to Congress, lots of times they leak into the press â then why would world leaders want to have conversations together?â There is no evidence to suggest the U.S intelligence official, who has not been publicly identified, filed the complaint due to political motivations. .@jaketapper presses Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on President Trumpâs call to Ukraineâs president and reports about their discussions about investigating Joe Bidenâs son. âI think things are being implied that just donât existâ #CNNSOTU pic.twitter.com/oni7mESXqt Biden has called on Trump to release a transcript of his phone call with Zelensky. Trump, who has denied any wrongdoing, told reporters Sunday that his conversation with the Ukrainian president was âperfectâ but he would consider releasing a transcript of the call. Whether Congress has the legal authority to see the complaint after Maguire refused to hand it over has been the subject of debate among some intelligence officials and legal experts. Though there are laws in place to protect whistleblowers who come forward, itâs unprecedented for the top national intelligence official to stop Congress from viewing a whistleblower complaint that the inspector general deems of âurgent concern,â reported The Washington Post. Maguireâs legal team argues that the complaint did not meet the legal standard of âurgent concernâ and he is therefore not required to submit it to Congress. Atkinson disagrees and has said he worries Maguireâs actions will deter future whistleblowers from coming forward. Democrats say the allegations against Trump, if true, amount to a U.S. president seeking assistance from a foreign government to help his reelection campaign. Though some Republicans, including Sen. Pat Toomey (Pa.), have said such a scenario would be highly inappropriate, other members of the GOP have defended Trumpâs actions. âIs it the position of the administration that it is acceptable for politicians to pressure foreign leaders to look into and investigate their political rivals?â Tapper asked Mnuchin on Sunday. Mnuchin said he wasnât on the call in question but said he has âno reason to believeâ Trump pressured Zelensky. But Tapper continued to press Mnuchin, asking him whether he would have found it âinappropriateâ if former President Barack Obama pressured a foreign leader to investigate Trumpâs eldest sons, Don Jr. and Eric, and their international business dealings. âIâm not going to speculate on that,â Mnuchin said. âWhat I do find inappropriate is the fact that Vice President Biden at the timeâs son [sic] did very significant business deals in Ukraine. I for one find that to be concerning.â Trump has claimed Biden called on a notoriously corrupt prosecutor in Ukraine to be removed from office to impede an investigation into a Ukrainian gas company, of which Hunter had been a member of the board.Â Ukrainian authorities have said they havenât found any wrongdoing by Biden. âI donât understand,â Tapper continued to grill Mnuchin. âSo itâs OK for Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump to do business all over the world, itâs OK for Ivanka Trump to have copyrights approved all over the world while President Trump is president, but while Vice President Biden was vice president, his son shouldnât have been able to do business dealings?â âAgain, I donât really want to go into more of these details,â Mnuchin responded, before Tapper interrupted him, stating that his comments were âsetting a precedent that the president is violating.â The Trump Organization, headed by the presidentâs eldest sons, has come under fire over its deals with foreign investors, which some government watchdog groups say violate the emoluments clause, a section of the Constitution that prohibits gifts to government officials.

articles.title: Trump âDoesnât Have Skill Set Or Experienceâ For China Deal, Fears Farm Union Head
articles.subtitle: Concerns emerge after Trump announces he doesnât need a trade deal until after the 2020 election and that âweâre not being affected.â
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: Strapped American farmers were reeling after President Donald Trump announced Friday he doesnât need a trade agreement with China until after the 2020 election. Chinese negotiators in Washington then abruptly canceled planned visits to farms in Nebraska and Montana to head back to China early. âFarmers are in serious, serious financial straits,â John Hansen, president of the Nebraska Farmers Union, told HuffPost Saturday. He said he fears Trump âdoes not have the skill set or the experience to fix thingsâ with China. Trump told reporters Friday there was no need to work out a trade deal with China before the 2020 election because the American economy is âvery strongâ â despite mounting fears about a recession. âIâm not looking for a partial deal; Iâm looking for a complete deal,â he said. âPeople know that weâre doing a great job. ... Weâre not being affected.â However, farmers are struggling. Net farm income in America has plunged by nearly halfÂ over the last five years from $123 billion in 2013 to $63 billion last year. Hansen said loan delinquencies and farm bankruptcies are up in his state. âIt hasnât been this bad since the early â80s,â he added. Farm organization leaders agree that America needed a new trade deal with China â but they havenât agreed with Trumpâs approach. National Farmers Union head Roger Johnson believes that the president has so badly botched negotiations that China is now a âlost marketâ and it will take âdecadesâ to repair the damage. China needs to be âheld to accountâ for trade relationships and behavior, Johnson said in aÂ KFGO radio interview last month. But he said that Trump would have been wiser to approach the worldâs second-largest economy with a team of allies. âI would ... argue that it would be far more effective if we did it with the rest of the world, instead of first ticking off the rest of the world and then trying to do it all by ourself,â said Johnson, whose organization represents some 200,000 family farms, ranches and fishing enterprises in 33 states. Hansen agrees that Trump needed a strategy involving other countries. âYou canât play the Lone Ranger,â he said. âBut what did Trump do?â Hansen asked. âInstead of isolating China, the first jump out of the chute he isolates America.â Even with a trade deal, farmers face a tough road, Hansen warned âIt takes a really long time to develop a market. It takes little time to destroy one,â he said. âItâs going to take years to rebuild â at best.â

articles.title: Justice Department To Open Facebook Antitrust Investigation, Source Says
articles.subtitle: Large tech companies have increasingly been on the defensive over lapses such as privacy breaches and outsized market influence.
articles.content: WASHINGTON, Sept 25 (Reuters) - The U.S. Justice Department will open an antitrust investigation of Facebook Inc, a person familiar with the matter said on Wednesday, marking the fourth recent antitrust probe of the social media company. Facebook also faces probes by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), a group of state attorneys general led by New York and the House of Representatives Judiciary Committee. Large tech companies, including Apple Inc, Amazon.com Inc and Alphabet Incâs Google, have increasingly been on the defensive in recent years over lapses such as privacy breaches and outsized market influence. Facebook has faced extra scrutiny tied to how it allowed its platforms to be used during the 2016 U.S. presidential election. The company, which owns one-time rivals Instagram and WhatsApp and has 2.4 billion monthly users, recently paid a $5 billion settlement for sharing 87 million usersâ data with defunct British political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica. Facebook declined to comment on Wednesday. Reuters and others reported in June the two federal agencies had divided up responsibility for the companies being investigated, with the Justice Department taking Google and Apple while the FTC looked at Facebook and Amazon. The Justice Department later said it was opening a probe of online platforms. It did not specify which ones, but said it would consider concerns raised about âsearch, social media and some retail services online.â Neither agency has revealed the focus of investigations into Facebook, though the Wall Street Journal has reported that the FTCâs probe is focused on the companyâs acquisitions. The worldâs largest social network has purchased nearly 90 companies since 2003, showed data from S&P Global. The Justice Departmentâs antitrust chief likewise told a tech conference in August that the government is looking at previously approved acquisitions as part of its broad review. This led some industry observers to question whether the two federal investigations would overlap. Lawmakers, in particular Sen. Mike Lee, chair of the SenateJudiciary Committeeâs antitrust panel, criticized the appearance of an overlap in a hearing last week. The agencies generally have a practice of meeting to decide who will investigate which matter but the FTC cannot probe certain areas, for example price-fixing. The probe into Facebook by the state attorneys general, announced earlier this month, is being led by New York and also includes Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Nebraska, North Carolina, Ohio, Tennessee and the District of Columbia. New York Attorney General Letitia James said that investigation would look into whether Facebookâs actions had endangered consumer data, reduced the quality of consumersâ choices or increased the price of advertising. (Reporting by Diane Bartz; Additional reporting by Katie Paul; Editing by Lincoln Feast and Christopher Cushing)

articles.title: Activists âShut Down D.C.â To Demand More Action On Climate Crisis
articles.subtitle: Protesters calling for a Green New Deal and other steps to combat climate change disrupted traffic in Washington on Monday morning.
articles.author: Jaâhan Jones
articles.content: Activists demanding a greater global response to climate change disrupted Monday morning commutes with protests in Washington, D.C. Ahead of the dayâs United Nations Climate Action Summit in New York, activists participated in âShut Down D.C.,â a coordinated act of civil disobedience designed to draw attention to the global climate crisis. A press release from the eventâs organizers said that Mondayâs protesters included labor organizations, the anti-war group Code Pink, Black Lives Matter and the environmental justice organization Rising Tide North America. The organizers said their goal was to âshut down the center of decision-making in the U.S. to demand the government immediately ends fossil fuel production, and enforces a swift and just transition to renewable energy.â Among their demands were the passage of the Green New Deal, additional measures to protect indigenous peopleâs land and a broad push toward climate justice. Pictures and videos posted to social media on Monday morning showed protesters halting traffic at a number of Washington intersections. D.C. police identified 14 locations that were blocked at some point, according to The Washington Post. Mondayâs protests come on the heels of a worldwide âclimate strikeâ on Friday, a series of protests in multiple countries that some called the âlargest climate rally ever.â

articles.title: Trump Claims He Halted Aid To Ukraine To Fight âCorruptionâ
articles.subtitle: The president confirmed to reporters at the United Nations that he froze millions of dollars in aid and called for other European nations to âput up money.â
articles.content: WASHINGTON (AP) â President Donald Trump ordered his staff to freeze nearly $400 million in aid to Ukraine a few days before a phone call in which he pressured the Eastern European nationâs leader to investigate the family of political rival Joe Biden, a revelation that comes as more Democrats move toward impeachment proceedings. Trump, in remarks to reporters at the United Nations on Tuesday, confirmed that he held up the aid but said he did so to fight corruption and urge European nations to share in helping out Ukraine. âAs far as withholding funds, those funds were paid,â Trump said. âThey were fully paid. But my complaint has always been, and Iâd withhold again and Iâll continue to withhold until such time as Europe and other nations contribute to Ukraine.â He named Germany and France as among the countries that should âput up money.â He also used the moment to again suggest that the Biden family inappropriately benefited from their ties to Ukraine. Trumpâs order was first reported by The Washington Post and was confirmed to The Associated Press by two people familiar with but not authorized to discuss private conversations. They spoke on the condition of anonymity. Late Monday, an influential group of freshmen Democrats who served in the military and national security before winning office said Trumpâs actions cut to the core of the countryâs defenses. Their views, as centrist lawmakers from previously Republican-held districts where Trump has been popular, hold sway with party leadership. At issue is a summer phone call with Ukrainian President Voldymyr Zelenskiy, in which Trump is said to have pushed for investigations into Biden. In the days before that call, Trump ordered the aid to Ukraine frozen. Trump has insisted he did nothing wrong and has denied that any requests for help in procuring damaging information about Biden were tied to the aid freeze. The United States began providing military aid to the government of Ukraine shortly after Russia illegally annexed Ukraineâs Crimean peninsula in 2014. With Ukraineâs new president still grappling with separatist rebels in the east, the aid has long been viewed as a measure of Washingtonâs determination to push back against Russian President Vladimir Putin. Democrats, and some Republicans, have urged the White House to be open about Trumpâs actions, which are at the center of a whistleblower complaint. But with no new information from the administration forthcoming, more than a dozen Democrats, including some in House leadership, added their names to those calling for impeachment proceedings. The sudden rush of activity shows the extent to which Trumpâs call to the foreign leader, and his subsequent comments about the conversation, are raising further questions about whether the president improperly used his office to pressure another country as a way of helping his own reelection prospects. âThese allegations are stunning, both in the national security threat they pose and the potential corruption they represent,â wrote the seven freshmen, who include a former Navy pilot, soldiers, officers and intelligence analysts. âWe do not arrive at this conclusion lightly,â the lawmakers wrote in a Washington Post op-ed. The lawmakers include Reps. Gil Cisneros of California, Jason Crow of Colorado, Chrissy Houlahan of Pennsylvania, Elaine Luria of Virginia, Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey, Elissa Slotkin of Michigan and Abigail Spanberger of Virginia. âThese new allegations are a threat to all we have sworn to protect. We must preserve the checks and balances envisioned by the Founders and restore the trust of the American people in our government. And that is what we intend to do.â Congress on Monday pressed for full disclosure of a whistleblowerâs complaint about Trump and pushed the White House to release a transcript of Trumpâs call with the Ukraine president. The president has acknowledged the phone call. On Monday, he said he didnât want to give money to Ukraine â if there were corruption issues. âItâs very important to talk about corruption,â Trump told reporters as he opened meetings at the United Nations. âIf you donât talk about corruption, why would you give money to a country that you think is, is corrupt?â Later Monday, Trump denied telling the Ukraine president that his country would only get U.S. aid if it investigated Bidenâs son. âI didnât do it,â he said. The fresh calls for impeachment proceedings come as House Democrats are heading into a closed-door meeting Tuesday with Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Pelosi and her leadership team on the various oversight committees are considering bringing forward a resolution that will put the House on the record on this matter, according to a Democratic leadership aide unauthorized to discuss the private talks. The aide was granted anonymity. Still, Democrats remained divided on moving forward with an effort to impeach Trump. Pelosi has resisted calls for impeachment and is sticking with her position that Congress must not start formal proceedings unless the American public demands it. However, Pelosi said Sunday that unless the administration provides more information to Congress by the scheduled Thursday hearing at the intelligence committee, its officials âwill be entering a grave new chapter of lawlessness which will take us into a whole new stage of investigation.â Trump has sought, without evidence, to implicate Biden and his son Hunter in the kind of corruption that has long plagued Ukraine. Hunter Biden served on the board of a Ukrainian gas company at the same time his father was leading the Obama administrationâs diplomatic dealings with Kyiv. Though the timing raised concerns among anti-corruption advocates, there has been no evidence of wrongdoing by either the former vice president or his son. The matter is under new scrutiny following the whistleblowerâs mid-August complaint, which followed Trumpâs July 25 call with Ukraineâs president. The person who filed the complaint did not have firsthand knowledge of the call, according to a person familiar with the matter. Lawmakers are demanding details of the complaint, but the acting director of national intelligence, Joseph Maguire, has refused to share that information, citing presidential privilege. He is set to testify Thursday before the House. âLetâs see the transcript,â said Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, about Trumpâs call with the Ukraine president. The chairmen of the House intelligence, Foreign Affairs and Oversight and Government Reform committees are threatening to subpoena Secretary of State Mike Pompeo if he does not produce information about whether Trump and his lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, inappropriately tried to influence the Ukraine government for political gain. Meanwhile, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York called on Republican Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to investigate the whistleblowerâs complaint. In a letter to McConnell, he said that the Republicansâ âsee no evil, hear no evilâ attitude toward the presidentâs actions âis unacceptable and must change.â Republican Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida doesnât think Trumpâs actions are grounds for impeachment, but said he wouldnât have called a foreign leader to discuss a rival. âI donât think he should have raised the topic of Joe Biden with the Ukraine president,â Rubio said. McConnell said Monday the matter is best left behind closed doors in the classified setting of the intelligence committee, though he did push into the spotlight his own role in securing the Ukraine aid. McConnell said he had been âpersonally pressuringâ the Trump administration this summer in calls to Pompeo and Secretary of Defense Mark Esper to release the U.S. aid money. Trump said Monday he may, or may not, release details or a transcript of the call but has stressed that foreign leaders should feel free to speak frankly with an American president without fear that the details of their conversations will later be disclosed. Hunter Biden was hired by the Ukrainian gas company Burisma Holdings in April 2014, two months after Ukraineâs Russia-friendly former president was ousted by protesters and as Bidenâs father was heavily involved in U.S. efforts to support the new pro-Western government. The move immediately raised concerns that the Ukrainian firm, whose owner was a political ally of the ousted president, was seeking to gain influence with the Obama administration. ___ Associated Press writers Alan Fram, Matthew Daly, Michael Balsamo, Laurie Kellman and Zeke Miller in Washington contributed to this report.

articles.title: Group Launches Fund To Protect Democrats In Swing States Who Support Impeaching Trump
articles.subtitle: The âImpeach The Motherf**ker Alreadyâ project aims to help reelect the lawmakers in 2020.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: Data for Progress, a left-learning think tank, is launching a project to raise money for Democrats from swing states who support impeaching President Donald Trump in an effort to protect their congressional seats in 2020. The âImpeach The Motherfucker Alreadyâ fund will benefit House Democrats whose support for impeachment could result in an even tougher uphill battle to reelection since their districts arenât staunchly Democratic and could swing red in 2020. At least 16 Democratic campaigns are poised to benefit from the project, with DFP considering adding more as additional lawmakers back impeachment. Contributions will be evenly divided among the campaigns, or individuals can choose how to allocate their donations, according to the fundâs website. âIf swing seat Democrats lose after supporting impeachment, the establishment will say they should have stayed silent,â tweeted DFP co-founder Sean McElwee. âWe have to make sure they have the resources to win.â A handful of the freshman lawmakers listed on the fund, including Reps. Katie Porter (Calif.) and Debbie Mucarsel-PowellÂ (Fla.), endorsed impeachment as early as June. Others voiced their support in July after Robert Mueller testified before Congress about his Russia investigation. Several more came out in support amid recent reports that Trump repeatedly pressured Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky in July to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a Democratic front-runner in the race to challenge Trumpâs reelection. Reps. Elissa SlotkinÂ (Mich.),Â Elaine LuriaÂ (Va.) and Abigail SpanbergerÂ (Va.) were part of a group of seven freshman House Democrats to pen an op-ed in The Washington Post on Monday urging Democratic leadership to open an impeachment inquiry in light of Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine. âIf these allegations are true, we believe these actions represent an impeachable offense,â they wrote. âWe must preserve the checks and balances envisioned by the Founders and restore the trust of the American people in our government.â After months of resisting calls to purse impeachment, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (Calif.) will reportedly announce a formal impeachment inquiry against Trump on Tuesday. DFP chose Democrats for the fund based on how strongly their districts supported Trump in 2016, which likely made them the most hesitant to endorse impeachment, McElwee told HuffPost. âThereâs been a lot of concern coming from the establishment of the party that [impeachment] is going to hurt our ability to win the House and I donât think thatâs true,â he said. âBut I do think ...Â there would be a powerful narrative coming out of the establishment like, âAh, we never should have impeachedââ if some of these Democrats lose reelection. The project, which raised over $3,000 within three hours of launching, was named for Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-N.Y.) and her rousing if controversial speech in January, in which she vowed Democrats would âimpeach the motherfucker.â âIt had a nice ring to it,âÂ McElwee said of the projectâs name. âWe want this to be something that is data-driven but we also want to convey the moral relevance of the issue, which is we need to impeach the motherfucker.â

articles.title: Ukrainian President Says He Doesnât Want To Be Involved With U.S. Elections
articles.subtitle: Asked whether he was pressured by Trump, President Volodymyr Zelensky told reporters on Wednesday that ânobodyâ pushed him.
articles.author: Jenna Amatulli
articles.content: During a meeting with President Donald TrumpÂ on Wednesday,Â Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky appeared to be uncomfortable with some of the claims made by Trump and flat-out said he did not want to be involved in U.S. elections. Trump and Zelensky sat before reporters to discuss aÂ call summary released earlier in the day from a phone conversation between the two on July 25. On that call, Trump asked Zelensky to âdo us a favorâ just after Zelensky thanked Trump for the military aid the U.S. provided to his country. The request carried an implicit threat that U.S. military aid to Ukraine was at stake if Zelensky did not comply â which is now the central element of theÂ Democratsâ effort to impeach the president. The July conversation included Trump asking Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden â a contender for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination â and his son Hunter, and to investigate a conspiracy theory that the Democratic National Committee servers that Russia hacked in 2016 to aid Trumpâs campaign were not actually hacked by Russia. Speaking in front of reporters Wednesday, Zelensky was asked if Trump had pressured him to investigate Biden. âI think you read everything.Â I think you read text.Â Iâm sorry, but I donât want to be involved to democratic open... elections,â Zelensky replied. âElections of U.S.A.Â No,â he said. âSure, we had, I think, good phone call.Â It was normal.Â We spoke about many things, and I â so I think and you read it that nobody pushed me.â Trump chimed in to say: âIn other words, no pressure.â Zelensky awkwardly begs not to be pulled into American election. pic.twitter.com/4egMjP89vF Later during their appearance together, Trump expressed hope that Zelensky and Russian President Vladimir Putin âcan get together and solve your problem.â Zelensky appeared uncomfortable and looked off into the distance as Trump spoke: OMG â get a load of the look on Zelenskyâs face as Trump tells him, âI really hope that you and President Putin can get together and solve your problem.â pic.twitter.com/IIefxLdXvB The âproblemâ Trump referred to is that Putin ordered his military to seize Crimea from Ukraine in the aftermath of the 2014 Ukrainian revolution, and then illegally annexed the country that year. With the approval of the European Parliament and NATO, Russia was condemned and suspended from the planned G-8 summit in Sochi in 2015. Following the suspension, the Russian Federation permanently decided to leave the G-8 in January 2017.

articles.title: Thousands, Including Trump, Rally In Texas For Indiaâs Prime Minister
articles.subtitle: Trump was greeted with a standing ovation by the Indian-American crowd that voted overwhelmingly against him in 2016.
articles.content: HOUSTON - U.S. President Donald Trump and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi shared a stage and showered each other with praise on Sunday at a âHowdy, Modi!â rally attended by upward of 50,000 people, a rare mass showing for a foreign leader on American soil. Trump, calling the gathering a âprofoundly historic event,â was greeted with a standing ovation by the Indian-American crowd and his speech was interrupted several times by roars of approval. The U.S. leader hailed the India-U.S. relationship and the Indian-American community as he reached out to an ethnic group that voted overwhelmingly against him in 2016. âYou uphold our values, you uplift our communities and you are truly proud to be American and we are truly proud to have you as Americans,â Trump the crowd. Modi began his talk inside the NRG Stadium, home of the Houston Texans football team, with a loud, âHowdy my friends!â In his remarks delivered in Hindi, Modi said that he was âimpatient to take the country to new heightsâ and that âtoday the buzz word in India is development.â The event has given Modi, a nationalist facing international criticism over a recent crackdown in disputed Kashmir, a chance to energize his relationship with Indian-Americans who are active political supporters. Jubilant supporters dressed in everything from ornate saris to simple dhotis and even a few cowboy hats waved American and Indian flags, chanted âModi! Modi!â and munched on concession stand snacks that included Indian staples of samosas and naan breads - along with nachos. âToday we celebrate our community and its importance in Houston and all America,â said Ketan Inamdar, who works in the administration of Houstonâs Democratic Mayor Sylvester Turner, and painted an American flag on his right cheek and an Indian one on the left. âTrump is very welcome here today. This event is to build harmony and love,â he said, standing just in front of the dais. âRace, religion and political parties donât matter today.â Houston is a rare Democratic stronghold in Republican-dominated Texas and serves as the economic anchor of a state that will be critical to Trumpâs 2020 re-election bid. Polls show tepid support by Indian-American voters, some 75% of whom voted for his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton, in 2016. But organizers of the âHowdy, Modi!â event that was kicked off with a 90-minute cultural program featuring 400 costumed dancers, were delighted to welcome Trump. âHis presence is an indication of his support and endorsement of the strengthening of Indiaâs relations with America,â said Preeti Dawra, a spokeswoman for the Texas India Forum that organized the event. âThis event is about strengthening those ties.â It was the first time Modi, who heads the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, addressed a large crowd in the United States, which is home to about 4 million Indian-Americans including about 300,000 in Houston and nearby Dallas, according to a Pew Research Center analysis of U.S. Census data. Some 19,000 people turned out for a similar event in New York in 2014, and Indian-American volunteers living in U.S. suburbs helped run a telephone blitz of voters in India in the run-up to Modiâs May re-election campaign. Modiâs visit to Houston comes ahead of this weekâs U.N. General Assembly in New York and amid a particularly tense time on the subcontinent. The Indian leader further strained long-simmering relations with Pakistan last month by revoking the partial autonomy enjoyed by Muslim-majority Kashmir, which both nuclear-armed countries claim. Modiâs move has been met by international criticism. Pakistan has condemned the crackdown and its Prime Minister Imran Khan warned it would drive more of the worldâs Muslims into extremism. Members of Indiaâs religious minority Sikh and Muslim groups planned noisy demonstrations near the stadium to protest Modiâs Kashmir policy. The U.S.-India relationship on trade and tariffs is rocky, though Trump and Modi appear to have strong personal ties. Devesh Kapur, director of Asia Programs at Johns Hopkins University, who has written a book on Indian-Americans, said that while the rally has symbolic value for both leaders, âitâs unlikely by itself to impact thorny trade issues ... but it canât hurt.â Kapur also forecast little improvement regarding Trumpâs standing with Indian-Americans. âThe Trump administrationâs hard-line policies on immigration ... have hardly endeared (him) to the community,â Kapur said. âAppearing with PM Modi might mildly help but certainly not reverse the communityâs overall pro-Democrat leanings.â

articles.title: More Than $350,000 In Jewelry Snatched From Trump Tower Apartments
articles.subtitle: Investigators suspect an inside job, a source told The New York Post.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: More than $350,000 in jewelry was stolen from two apartments in ManhattanâsÂ Trump Tower, police said on Monday. Two bracelets, a necklace, a ring and earrings worth $236,000 were taken from a 42nd-floor apartment while the female resident was away from June to early September, police said. A $117,000 diamond bracelet was stolen from a 59th-floor apartment while the resident, who owns an art gallery in the city, was on vacation in early September. Both thefts were reported to police early this month. As of Monday, investigators hadnât identified any suspects and were still looking into everyone who had access to the building. Itâs not clear if the thefts were related. There was no sign of a break-in at either place, a source told The New York Post, which was the first to report the story. Investigators suspect an inside job. âItâs not somebody breaking into the building or roaming the halls, trying the doors until they find one thatâs open,â a source told the newspaper. President Donald Trumpâs triplex penthouse and his Trump Organization headquarters are located in the same building. Trump stayed in his Fifth Avenue home on Sunday and Monday night for his visit to the United Nations. Jonathan Wackrow, a former Secret Service agent and CNN contributor, said the thefts raised concerns about a threat from an insider at Trump Tower, which is always protected by the Secret Service.

articles.title: Facebook Is Fine With Holocaust Denials If Politicians Make The False Claim
articles.subtitle: The site has decided to exempt politicians from abiding by its community rules.
articles.author: Ryan Grenoble
articles.content: If you violate Facebookâs rules, Facebook can force you to remove the offending content, or temporarily ban you, or permanently ban you. If a politician violates those same rules, Facebook now officially wonât do squat. In a speech at the Atlantic Festival in Washington Tuesday, Facebook Vice President Nick Clegg said the company will, by default, consider everything politicians post to be ânewsworthy contentâ that is governed by different rules than most of the rest of the site. âFrom now on we will treat speech from politicians as newsworthy content that should, as a general rule, be seen and heard,â Clegg said in aÂ blog. âThis means that if someone makes a statement or shares a post which breaks our community standards we will still allow it on our platform if we believe the public interest in seeing it outweighs the risk of harm.â In practice, this will mean denials that World War IIâs Holocaust occurred would be permitted â so long as it was a politician making the thoroughly bogus and discredited claim that Nazi Germany did not commit the genocide of an estimated six million Jews. Asked about such a claim, a Facebook spokesperson confirmed to HuffPost that it wouldnât be seen as breaking the siteâs community standards and would not be subject to fact-checking. The spokesperson told HuffPost the company decided to make the change ahead of upcoming elections globally and in the U.S. Under the policy, content posted by politicians doesnât have to be accurate or true. Indeed, for more than a year Facebook has exempted politicians from scrutiny otherwise applied by third-party fact-checkers. âWe do not submit speech by politicians to our independent fact-checkers, and we generally allow it on the platform even when it would otherwise breach our normal content rules,â said Clegg. âOf course, there are exceptions,â he added. âBroadly speaking they are two-fold: where speech endangers people; and where we take money, which is why we have more stringent rules on advertising than we do for ordinary speech and rhetoric.â Itâs unclear how serious Facebook is about enforcing that first exception. Earlier this month, Texas state Rep. Briscoe Cain (R)Â Â sent a death threat to his fellow Texan, former Rep. Beto OâRourke, on Twitter after the Democratic presidential candidate proposed a mandatory gun buyback of some semiautomatic weapons. Twitter deleted Cainâs tweet two hours later, explaining it violated the siteâs terms because it threatened violence. Asked Tuesday if Facebook would have done the same, the spokesperson declined to make a judgment.

articles.title: Trumpâs Land Boss William Pendley Pledges To Steer Clear Of Ex-Clients
articles.subtitle: The acting Bureau of Land Management director agreed not to participate in matters involving 57 entities and individuals following conflict of interest allegations.
articles.content: BILLINGS, Mont. (AP) â The Trump administrationâs top steward of public lands has recused himself from work involving dozens of former clients following conflict of interest allegations from Democratic lawmakers and environmental advocates, federal officials disclosed Wednesday. Acting Bureau of Land Management Director William âPerryâ Pendley is a former property rights attorney who has argued for selling off public lands and railed against what he has labelled the âtyrannyâ of the federal government. Pendley said in a Wednesday email to his staff obtained by The Associated Press that he wanted to set an example for the agencyâs 9,000 employees by avoiding the potential conflicts. He agreed not to participate in matters involving 57 entities and individuals â from farming and mining organizations to an energy company seeking to drill on land adjacent to Glacier National Park, according to documents released by officials. âI understand that preserving a culture of ethical compliance within the BLM begins with me,â Pendley wrote. âI have also established a rigorous screening process to ensure that I will remain in full compliance.â The recusals are generally effective for two years and retroactive to the date of his mid-July appointment. Democratic U.S. Sen. Jon Tester of Montana has sharply criticized Pendleyâs past calls to sell off public lands and called his appointment an end-run around the Senate because no confirmation hearings were held. Tester said in a statement that Pendleyâs recusal from decisions related to a disputed energy lease in Montana was a âpositive step,â but more answers were needed about his record. Others in Congress have voiced similar concerns. âThe fact remains that he has repeatedly advocated for selling off our public lands to the highest bidder, which should have disqualified him outright from leading the BLM,â Tester said. The BLM leader said last month that his longtime advocacy for selling public lands was irrelevant because his boss, Interior Secretary David Bernhardt, opposes the wholesale sale of public lands. The Trump administration already has moved to weaken protections for public lands, including easing restrictions on oil and gas exploration. BLM officials last week said the agency was moving its headquarters from Washington to an office building in Colorado that also houses oil and gas organizations, drawing criticism from environmental groups. Among Pendleyâs past clients when he ran the conservative Mountain States Legal Foundation was Solenex LLC, a Louisiana-based energy company that has been seeking to drill in the remote and mountainous Badger-Two Medicine area of northwestern Montana. The Badger-Two-Medicine area is considered sacred to the Blackfoot tribes of the U.S. and Canada, and Solenex is fighting in court against the Interior Departmentâs attempts to cancel an energy lease that that the company has held for decades. Tribal officials still hope to work with the Trump administration on the issue, but Pendleyâs recusals do not eliminate their apprehensions, said John Murray, historic preservation officer for Montanaâs Blackfeet Nation. âHe was 100 percent on the other side of the table,â Murray said. âThese guys do all kinds of lobbying and meeting and all this stuff behind closed doors.â The lengthy recusal list touches on some of the BLMâs major oversight responsibilities, naming organizations such as the National Mining Association and several state farm bureaus. Agency spokesman Jeff Krauss said that would not prevent Pendley from effectively leading the bureau. Three southern Utah counties that supported President Donald Trumpâs downsizing of two sprawling national monuments in the state also appear on the list. He was the attorney representing San Juan, Kane and Garfield counties when they sought to intervene in lawsuits by conservation and tribal groups challenging the presidentâs actions. A Pendley supporter in the state said criticisms of his past affiliations were unfair and that environmental groups would never be happy because they donât want anyone to touch public lands. âHeâs exactly what the BLM needs: A person that will manage public lands for the original purpose of multiple use,â Utah cattle rancher and Garfield County Commissioner Leland Pollock said.

articles.title: AP Source: Darrell Issa To Run For Duncan Hunterâs Seat
articles.subtitle: Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.) was indicted for allegedly using campaign funds for personal expenses.
articles.content: SAN DIEGO (AP) â Former California Rep. Darrell Issa plans to run against indicted fellow GOP Congressman Duncan Hunter, The Associated Press has learned. Larry Wilske, a retired Navy SEAL also running for Hunterâs seat, told the AP on Wednesday that Issa told him he will enter the race. Issa scheduled a news conference in Hunterâs San Diego-area district on Thursday. Wilske said he plans to drop out as result and support Issa. The former nine-term congressman formed an exploratory committee last month and was widely known to be considering a run in the staunchly Republican district east of San Diego. Issa retired from his long stint in Congress before the 2018 election in a neighboring district that he narrowly won two years earlier. Wilske said Issa, 65, is a safer bet that Hunterâs district will remain in Republican hands, and his many years in the House pave the way for him to become a ranking member on committees. El Cajon Mayor Bill Wells, who also was running for Hunterâs seat, said he too plans to bow out and back Issa. âI think heâs the one in the best position to win and get something done,â Wells said. âWe need to get back to the business of having a presence in Washington.â Hunter has said he has no plans to step down despite being indicted. He is scheduled to be tried in January for allegedly siphoning campaign money for personal use. The 42-year-old Marine combat veteran is also being challenged by Republican Carl DeMaio, a radio host and former San Diego city councilman with broad name recognition, and Democrat Ammar Campa-Najjar, who came within 3.4 percentage points of unseating Hunter in November. Issaâs entry is expected to make it one of the most closely watched congressional contests in the country. Republicans have a big advantage in voter registration in Californiaâs 50th district, which covers east San Diego County and a small part of southern Riverside County. Hunter won a sixth term last year, barely two months after he and his wife were charged with using more than $250,000 in campaign funds for personal expenses ranging from groceries to golf trips and family vacations. Margaret Hunter has pleaded guilty to one corruption count and agreed to cooperate with investigators. Hunter, whose father represented the district in Congress for 28 years, has pleaded not guilty and framed the charges as political attack by prosecutors sympathetic to Democrat Hillary Clintonâs 2016 presidential bid.

articles.title: U.S. Democracy Is âIn The ICUâ After Ukraine Mess, Says Former Ethics Chief
articles.subtitle: âAnd some of the hospital staff are trying to smother it with a pillow,â warns Walter Shaub.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: The former head of the U.S. Office of Government Ethics warned Saturday that American democracy is âin the ICUâ in the wake of Donald Trumpâs reported pressure on Ukraineâs president to become involved in the U.S. election by launching an investigation into his rival Joe Biden. Yet even as the republic gasps for survival in the intensive care unit, some politicians are out to âsmother it with a pillow,â Walter Shaub warned. Trump claiming this morning that his effort to strong-arm Ukraine was a âperfectly fine and routine conversationâ is a disturbing admission that his malfeasance has become âroutine.â Democracy is in the ICU, and some of the hospital staff are trying to smother it with a pillow. A series of Shaubâs tweets on the issue followed Trumpâs message Saturday morning defending his July call to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Yet several newspapers reported that Trump pressured Zelensky to launch an investigation into Biden and his son Hunter. Just weeks earlier, Trump had suspended some $400 million in military aid to the nation, The Washington Post reported, raising suspicions that Trump may have used the withheld funds to leverage compliance with his request that would help his reelection.Â (The Ukrainian foreign minister said Saturday: âI think there was no pressureâ in Trumpâs call to Zelensky.) A complaint filed by an American whistleblower in the intelligence community last month reportedly involved a troubling âpromiseâ Trump had made to a foreign leader.The complaint has not been released to congressional leaders, who are demanding to see it. Trump is now referring to the whistleblower as a âspy.âÂ Â (The Ukrainian foreign minister said Saturday: âI think there was no pressureâ in Trumpâs call to Zelensky.) Trump has alleged that Biden, while vice president, worked to shield a Ukrainian company linked to his son from a corruption probe. But a Ukrainian official said earlier this year that investigators found no evidence of any wrongdoing by Biden or his son. The latest revelations have triggered calls to impeach Trump if he indeed wielded U.S. might to mobilize a foreign power against U.S. citizens to affect an American election.Â Biden has called Trumpâs acts an âabuse of power.â Trump hasnât denied he discussed Biden with Zelensky and told reporters Friday: âIt doesnât matter what was discussed.â Shaub sees lack of action against Trump as a death watch for democracy. Our Lady of She Had a Good Run hospital, where our republicâs on death watch, is administered by Senators who love power more than they love America. Our electoral process is what makes us a republic, and theyâre fine with Trump soliciting a foreign power to harm it. #betrayal Stop, you partisans, you justifiers of malfeasance, you power-drunk politicians trading love of country for fealty to the corrupter. Elections canât keep us free if you let him solicit foreign interference. Unblind your eyes, unplug your ears, open your mouths and call it enough! https://t.co/CylKRSdFXM âWe havenât seen anything like this in my lifetime,â William Galston, a senior fellow in governance at the Brookings Institution, told The Washington Post. Trump âappears to be daring the rest of the political system to stop him â and if it doesnât, heâll go further.â

articles.title: Ukraine Minister Denies Trump Pressured Zelenskiy During Call: Report
articles.subtitle: Ukraineâs foreign minister said Ukraine was an independent state and would not take sides in U.S. politics even if âin theoryâ the country was in a position to do so.
articles.content: KIEV (Reuters) - Ukrainian Foreign Minister Vadym Prystaiko on Saturday denied suggestions U.S. President Donald Trump had put pressure on Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelenskiy during a phone call in July. In an interview with media outlet Hromadske, Prystaiko said Ukraine was an independent state and would not take sides in U.S. politics even if âin theoryâ the country was in a position to do so. He added that Kiev appreciated the assistance it received from Washington. On Friday reports by U.S. media outlets said Trump repeatedly pressured Ukraineâs president to investigate Joe Biden, one of Trumpâs chief political rivals, in a July phone call. The call featured in a classified whistleblower complaint that has sparked a political battle between Democrats warning of a national security threat and Republicans turning it into an attack on Biden, a frontrunner in the field of Democrats seeking to challenge Trump in the 2020 presidential election. Reuters has not confirmed details of the whistleblowerâs complaint. But a source familiar with the matter said it alleged âmultiple actsâ by Trump, not just a phone call with a foreign leader. The source requested anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue. Zelenskiyâs office has so far declined to comment on the allegations. âI know what the conversation was about and I think there was no pressure,â Prystaiko said. âThis conversation was long, friendly, and it touched on many questions, sometimes requiring serious answers.â Trump dismissed the Sept. 12 complaint from the whistleblower within the intelligence community as a partisan hit against him. Trump had spoken Zelenskiy less than three weeks before the complaint was filed. Trump is due to meet Zelenskiy during a United Nations gathering in New York. Prystaiko said Zelenskiy had the right to keep conversations with other leaders confidential. âI want to say that we are an independent state, we have our secrets,â he was quoted as saying in the interview. The July 25 call between the leaders is under investigation by three Democratic-led House committees, who want to know if Trump and his personal lawyer, Rudolph Giuliani, tried to pressure the Ukrainian government into aiding Trumpâs re-election campaign. The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday that Trump urged Zelenskiy about eight times during the call to work with Giuliani to investigate Biden and Bidenâs son. Reporting by Matthias Williams, editing by Deepa Babington and Ros Russell

articles.title: Trump Claims Ukraine Transcript To Be Released âÂ SilentÂ On Whistleblower Complaint
articles.subtitle: The phone call is at the center of an intelligence whistleblower complaint, but Trump made no mention of the complaintâs release.
articles.content: WASHINGTON (AP) â President Donald Trump says he has directed the release on Wednesday of the âunredactedâ transcript of his July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Trump has acknowledged that he discussed former Vice President Joe Biden in the call. Trump tweeted Tuesday that âYou will see it was a very friendly and totally appropriate call. No pressure.â Trumpâs reference to Biden on the call raised questions about whether the president improperly used his office to pressure another country as a way of hurting one of his chief Democratic rivals. On Monday, it was reported that Trump had ordered his staff to freeze nearly $400 million in aid to Ukraine a few days before a phone call with Zelensky. The call is at the center of an intelligence whistleblower complaint.

articles.title: Judge Orders Trump To Testify In Protestersâ Suit Accusing Trump Tower Guards Of Assault
articles.subtitle: One of the guards captured on videotape in a violent scuffle became Trumpâs director of Oval Office operations.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: A New York judge ordered President Donald TrumpÂ on Friday to provide a videotaped deposition for a lawsuit by protesters accusing Trump Tower guards of assault. One of the guards later joined Trumpâs White House staff and is currently working for the Republican National Committee. The lawsuit was filed by five activists against Trump and his guards who say there were attacked during a peaceful protest outside the Manhattan high-rise four years ago. They were demonstrating against then-candidate Trumpâs remarks about the Black Lives Matter movement and his comments that Mexican immigrants wereÂ âcriminalsâ and ârapists.â The jury in the case that begins Thursday needs the testimony to determine to what extent the guards directly reported to Trump, and if he authorized the actions against protesters. One of the three guards named in the suit, Keith Schiller, was head of security of the Trump Organization and later became director of Oval Office operations under Trump in 2017. After he left the White House that year, Schiller was hired by the Republican National Committee to advise on security for the 2020 convention, according to CNN. Trumpâs request to quash a subpoena to testify was rejected Friday by Bronx Supreme Court Judge Doris Gonzalez. âNo government official, including the executive, is above the law,â Gonzalez ruled. âPresident Trumpâs relationship with the other defendants is now central to plaintiffsâ prosecution of their claims under the theory of respondeat superior. As such, his testimony is indispensable.â Trump was ordered to provide the testimony by Thursday, but he can appeal or request a delay. During the 2015 confrontation outside Trump Tower, guards told protesters (some of whom were dressed in Ku Klux Klan robes) that the sidewalk was private property â itâs not â and pushed them away. Schiller was also captured on videotape (below) angrily ripping away protest signs and striking plaintiff Efrain Galicia in the head when he attempted to retrieve one of them. Schiller struck with âa closed fist on the head with such force it caused (him) to stumble backwards,â the lawsuit states. Schiller argued in an affidavit after the suit was filed that the protesters and their banners were blocking public access to the sidewalks and Trump Tower. He also claimed Galicia grabbed him from behind, and feared he was reaching for Schillerâs firearm. âI instinctively reacted by turning around ... and striking the person with my open hand,â he said, noting Trump was inside the building at the time. The plaintiffs are seeking an injunction to forbid the Trump security officials from interfering with public protests and are seeking damages. Trumpâs attorneys could not immediately be reached for comment.

articles.title: Ben Carson Defends Transphobic Remarks, Accuses Media Of âMischaracterizationsâ
articles.subtitle: He raised concern over âbig, hairy menâ infiltrating womenâs homeless shelters, The Washington Post reported.
articles.content: Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben CarsonÂ is defending transphobic remarks he made earlier this week, accusing the media of spreading âblatant mischaracterizationsâ of his statements, according to an email obtained by The Washington Post and Politico. In the memo sent to his staff amid backlash over the comments, Carson said he felt compelled âto set the record straight,â claiming the press had reported the story irresponsibly. âDuring a recent meeting with local staff in San Francisco, I made reference to the fact that I had heard from many womenâs groups about the difficulty they were having with womenâs shelters because sometimes men would claim to be women,â he said. âThis made many of the women feel unsafe, and one of the groups described a situation to me in which âbig hairy menâ would come in and have to be accepted into the womenâs shelter even though it made the women in the facility very uncomfortable.â Carson argued his âpoint was that we have to permit policies that take into consideration the rights of everybody, including those women.â His remarks in San Francisco about access to the shelters for homeless women were first reported on Thursday by the Post after sources at the session with HUD employees told the newspaper about what they heard. According to the story,Â Carson raised the concern about âbig, hairy menâ infiltrating the shelters, ostensibly referring to transgender women. He allegedly also complained that society no longer understood the dichotomy between men and women. One HUD staffer present told the Post that âthe sentiment conveyed was these were not women, and they should not be housed in single-sex shelters â like we shouldnât force people to accept transgender people in this context because it makes other people uncomfortable.â There were reportedly 50 people present at the meeting, one of whom walked out in protest of Carsonâs comments and drew applause from others. Following the report, Democrats including Reps. Joe KennedyÂ of Massachusetts and Jennifer WextonÂ of Virginia called on Carson to resign, slamming his remarks as âsickeningâ and ârevolting.â A spokesman for HUD did not immediately return HuffPostâs request for comment on Thursday,Â but told the Post that Carson âdoes not use derogatory language to refer to transgendered individuals. Any reporting to the contrary is false.â Carson has a poor record on transgender rights. His department has proposed changing the 2012 Equal Access Rule to allow federally funded shelters to turn away transgender people on religious grounds. Shortly after Carson took over the department in early 2017, HUDÂ removed links to documentsÂ that helped emergency shelters comply with agency regulations for serving homeless transgender people. Heâs also made crass comments to argue against transgender people in the military and letting transgender students use bathrooms that match their gender identities.

articles.title: Joe Kennedy III Launches Campaign To Primary Ed Markey for U.S. Senate
articles.subtitle: The member of the famed political dynasty launched a 2020 primary challenge against fellow Democrat Edward Markey in Massachusetts.
articles.content: Sept 21 (Reuters) - U.S. Representative Joseph Kennedy III, a member of the famed political dynasty, on Saturday launched a 2020 primary challenge against fellow Democrat Edward Markey for his U.S. Senate seat in Massachusetts. Kennedy, the 38-year-old grandson of former Senator RobertKennedy who was assassinated in 1968 while running for president, has served in the House of Representatives since2013. âThis isnât a time for waiting, for sitting on the sidelines, or for playing by rules that donât work anymore,âKennedy wrote on Twitter on Saturday. âThis is the fight of our lives, the fight of my generation â and Iâm all in.â Markey, 73, who had a long career in the House before filling a vacancy in the Senate in 2013, last won re-election in2014 by a comfortable margin. During his House career, Markey was one of a handful of lawmakers who led the fight for legislation, which narrowly passed the House in 2009, to bring down carbon emissions that contribute to climate change. Kennedy will bring his familyâs star power to next yearâs race, potentially giving Markey one of the toughest contests of his political career. Massachusetts is a strong Democratic state and the winner of the party primary next year is likely to win in the Nov. 3,2020, general election. Other members of the Kennedy family who have won Senate seats, in addition to Robert Kennedy, were his brothers John F.Kennedy and Edward Kennedy. John Kennedy subsequently was elected president in 1960. Edward Kennedy held his Senate seat for nearly 47 years until his death in 2009.(Writing by Daniel Wallis in New YorkEditing by Matthew Lewis)

articles.title: The Finnish President Looking âFinishedâ With Trump Is Twitterâs Newest Meme
articles.subtitle: Finnish President Sauli NiinistÃ¶ has joined the long list of people who have witnessed a Trump meltdown firsthand.
articles.author: Josephine Harvey
articles.content:
Finnish President Sauli NiinistÃ¶ was giving off âsend helpâ energy during a joint news conference with President Donald Trump on Wednesday. During what seemed to be an extended tirade, the president fired off an extensive tweetstorm before the meeting, then gave 17 minutes of monologues to reporters in an Oval Office meeting while Finlandâs president sat quietly. Trump then ranted at reporters at a joint White House news conference, including telling one reporter not to be ârudeâ when the journalist asked for an answer to his question. The Finnish president was cool and collected throughout, seeming at times a bit keen for it all to be over: The Finnish President telling trump that he doesnât want to be touched is amazing and incredibly uncomfortable #TrumpMeltdown pic.twitter.com/G0s3X1sfib At the beginning of the joint news conference, when Trump made a joke about âall the press that you attract,â NiinistÃ¶ was quick to reply: âThey are not after me.â And at one point, the Finnish president can be heard laughing at the moment some have called the pinnacle of the meltdown â when Trump, growing increasingly agitated, refused to answer Reuters White House reporter Jeff Masonâs question and demanded that he ask NiinistÃ¶ a question instead: Trump engages in contentious back and forth with @JeffMason1 after he dodges Ukraine question:

articles.title: In The End, Nixon Walked Away For The Good Of His Party. Would Trump?
articles.subtitle: Top Republicans worry that if his status becomes dire, heâll take the party down with him. Others worry he wouldnât stop with just the party.
articles.author: S.V. Date
articles.content: When the end came and Republicans told him they could not save him, President Richard Nixon agreed to walk away, in large measure for the good of his party. Forty-five years later, what might the GOP expect from its current president accused of trying to rig a presidential election in his favor, should Donald Trumpâs standing deteriorate to a similar level? âHe will burn it to the ground,â predicted one former Trump White House official. And therein lies a further complicating factor for Republicans in Congress and nationally as House Democrats ramp up their impeachment proceedings into Trumpâs coercion of Ukraine this summer to investigate his most feared Democratic opponent, former Vice President Joe Biden. Trumpâs loyalty to his party is viewed as paper-thin, at best. While Nixon was a lifelong Republican, having served as President Dwight Eisenhowerâs vice president and as a congressman and U.S. senator from California, Trump had little relationship with the GOP before he took it over by winning its presidential nomination in 2016. âAll Trump cares about is Trump,â said former Illinois Rep. Joe Walsh, one of three Republicans challenging Trump for the 2020 nomination. âHeâd take down the entire planet if it helped Trump.â Erick Erickson, a prominent conservative radio talk show host and blogger, said Republicans could try to persuade Trump into leaving by pointing out how Nixon eventually came to be seen as an elder statesman. âThat might induce him,â Erickson said, adding that the other option was right out of HBOâs âGame of Thronesâ series. âOtherwise, I think heâs going to re-create Daenerys Targaryen at Kingâs Landing.â In fact, Republican Party officials already have tried once to get him to leave the stage. In the days following the publication in October 2016 of the âAccess Hollywoodâ tape â in which Trump brags that his celebrity allowed him to grab women by the genitals with impunity â several wanted him to drop out of the presidential race and let running mate Mike Pence move to the top of the ticket. Trump not only refused but also threatened to take every Republican candidate down with him if the party tried to yank the nomination away from him. âHeâs rented the party for this entire ride,â said former Florida congressman (and former Republican) David Jolly. âI donât think he would be compelled by an argument for the good of the party.â Some top Republicans say that GOP senators will never request Trumpâs departure as their predecessors did with Nixon because Trump commands such undying loyalty from the partyâs voting base. âMoot question,â said GOP pollster Neil Newhouse. âSenate Republicans will never ask for it. His hardcore base will not leave him.â âThis is a long way from being anywhere near that situation,â added Ron Kaufman, a longtime Republican National Committee member from Massachusetts. âThereâs no analogy.â Although many Republicans see Trumpâs hold over his party as a great strength, Yale School of Medicine psychiatry professor Bandy Lee sees great danger in it to the country. âWe know that, in any situation, he will think of himself before anyone or anything elseâ she said. âIf it became a choice, there may be no limit to what he is willing to bring down in order to salvage his fragile sense of self.â   In November 1972, Richard Nixon won 61% of the popular vote and scored a sweeping Electoral College victory, 520-17, losing only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia in winning a second term. Within months, though, that victory began looking tainted as news reports, and then congressional investigations, showed that burglars paid by Nixonâs campaign had broken into the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate complex a mile west of the White House with the intent of wiretapping it. Nixonâs approval numbers at the start of his second term, at 68% in one Gallup poll, began to decline. They had fallen below 50% by the time the Senate began formal hearings into the break-in and cover-up in May, 1973, and close to 30% by the time Nixon fired Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox in the infamous âSaturday Night Massacreâ of Oct. 20, 1973. The number of Americans who wanted to see him removed from office, nevertheless, remained fairly low. Only 19% wanted him impeached and removed at the start of the Senate hearings. After the Saturday Night Massacre, that figure rose to and then plateaued in the mid-30s. That phenomenon only changed after the U.S. Supreme Court ordered Nixon to release a taped conversation from June 1972, in which he is heard participating in a discussion about ordering the FBI and CIA to end the investigation into the break-in as a matter of national security. Within days, the percentage of Americans who wanted Nixon removed jumped from the low 40s to 57 on Aug. 8, 1974, the day he announced his resignation in a televised address. In some respects, Democrats who want to impeach Trump have much more favorable circumstances than those who sought to remove Nixon. Trump has never been popular with the majority of Americans, either as a candidate or since taking office. His current approval percentages range from the high 30s to low 40s â where he has been pretty much his entire presidency. Further, Trump already released a rough transcript of the July 25 phone call with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky. It documents what Trump had already admitted verbally: that he asked Zelensky to investigate Biden after having blocked $400 million in congressionally approved aid to Ukraine. âI would like you to do us a favor, though,â Trump told Zelensky. âReally, this is all about the re-election of Donald Trump, and itâs another page out of the Nixon playbook,â Rice University presidential historian Douglas Brinkley said. âYou see Trump doing the same abuse of power in getting information on Biden.â News of Trumpâs language in the call rapidly pushed dozens of House Democrats who had opposed impeachment, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, into backing an opening of an inquiry. And that, in turn, has helped move public opinion from opposing impeachment to favoring at least the start of that process. The web site 538 has found a measurable swing in favor of impeachment, from 51% opposing it and 40% in favor in mid-September, to 47% in favor and 45% against it today. Brinkley said he has found the parallels between Nixon and Trump astonishing. Both abused the power of their office in efforts to win their re-elections, he said, and both then used their office and aides to try to cover it up. The big difference is that money from Nixonâs campaign fund paid the Watergate burglars â and he then he approved using such funds to buy their silence â while Trump used hundreds of millions of American taxpayer dollars as leverage against the Ukrainian president, he said. âItâs funny that everyone thought the modern Republican Party was the party of Reagan, but itâs really the party of Nixon. Itâs about cronyism and the destruction of your enemies,â Brinkley said.   Yet even opposing a fundamentally less liked president who has committed an arguably worse offense might not be enough for Democrats who hope to remove Trump from office. Nixon was contemplating resigning from the time he lost the Supreme Court decision on the âsmoking gunâ tape. But having his partyâs elder statesman, Arizona Sen. Barry Goldwater, come to the White House with the Republican leaders of both congressional chambers to tell him that he had maybe a dozen GOP senators still supporting him likely sealed his decision to step down. That, of course, was a different era. American politics in 2019 is not what it was in 1974. âItâs much, much different, the political environment,â said David Axelrod, the Democratic consultant who helped lead former President Barack Obamaâs 2008 campaign. During Watergate, Goldwater and other Republicans were much more inclined to cross their president than any GOP senators are today. At that time, Tennessee Sen. Howard Baker was the ranking member of the Senate committee investigating the Watergate scandal and played a key role in the probe. And then there are the differences between the two presidents and the media landscape, Axelrod said. âNixon was not nearly as brazen as Trump,â Axelrod said. âNor did he have Fox News and Breitbart.â Sam Nunberg, a longtime former political adviser to Trump, said a more important point is that Trumpâs hold over todayâs Republican Party base is far more complete than Nixonâs ever was. âIf the Senate Republicans approached the president to give the president a resignation ultimatum, the uproar by the president, conservative media and his supporters would lead to the near annihilation of the Republican Party in the 2020 election that would last for multiple future cycles,â Nunberg said. âIf Trump goes down, then the Republican Party goes down. This is not a symbiotic relationship. The Republicans need Trump. Trump can break them in half.â A more worrisome point, Trump critics say, is Nixonâs loyalty to his party and his country compared with Trumpâs. In the end, Nixon showed that both meant more to him than hanging onto the presidency â and it is not at all clear that Trump shares those priorities. âTrump has a lifetime of historical decisions that proves he only protects himself and his personal interests,â said Kendal Unruh, the former GOP activist who led the effort to dump Trump as the nominee on the floor of the 2016 convention. âHe actually enjoys burning things down. He rules by chaos because when everyone else is out of control, it puts him into control. He will continue to demand that those in the GOP yield to him their loyalty, and they will oblige.â Yet even if more damning facts emerge through the impeachment proceedings and enough Republicans come around to the view that continuing to support Trump is riskier to their political futures than abandoning him, that still leaves the question of how to get Trump to accept that decision. Lee, who along with a number of other mental health professionals wrote the book âThe Dangerous Case of Donald Trump,â said his recent behavior suggests he would be highly unlikely to follow Nixonâs precedent and leave office quietly. âDonald Trump could be the hardest to remove from office, refusing to accept any decision and inciting violence from his followers, if not wage a war that places the world in danger,â Lee said. She recommended approaching him gingerly, and said that making it seem that his prize for leaving would be nearly as âgrandioseâ as the presidency itself would be the only way of getting him to do so. âHow we handle the situation is critical from a psychological perspective,â she said. âIt needs to be done delicately.â

articles.title: Toxic Chemical Fumes May Be Behind Vaping Illnesses, Researchers Say
articles.subtitle: âThis is a public health crisis,â a lead researcher behind the Mayo Clinic study said.
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: The spate of mysterious lung illnesses linked to vaping are most likely caused by noxious chemical fumes, a team of doctors at the Mayo Clinic said Wednesday. The findings, published inÂ The New England Journal of Medicine, are the latest effort by health officials to determine why hundreds of people across the country have been hospitalized in recent months with dangerous and sometimes fatal lung issues. But the results are a far cry from a silver bullet and appear to only nullify initial reports that speculated patientsâ lungs were getting clogged and damaged by the oils that were being inhaled. âIt seems to be some kind of direct chemical injury, similar to what one might see with exposures to toxic chemical fumes, poisonous gases and toxic agents,â Brandon Larsen, a surgical pathologist at the Mayo Clinic in Arizona, said in a statement. The Mayo effort was the first formal study of tissue samples from patients who fell ill after vaping. Two of those samples came from people who died. âEveryone should recognize that #vaping is not a wise thing to be doing, and I think our research supports that,â says Brandon Larsen, M.D., Ph.D., the senior author of a Mayo Clinic study on vaping-associated lung injury. https://t.co/cFkQHkIwUJ @NEJM @CDCgov #pneumonitis #THC pic.twitter.com/YBfD7gkQDZ Larsen later told The New York Times the injuries resembled toxic chemical exposure and look similar to the lungs of âan unfortunate worker in an industrial accident where a big barrel of toxic chemicals spills, and that person is exposed to toxic fumes and there is a chemical burn in the airways.â The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last week it had confirmed the mysterious lung injuries in at least 805 people from 46 states.
