Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), who is running for president, introduced a bill Thursday that would invest billions of more dollars in affordable housing and other initiatives to prevent homelessness. The âEnding Homelessness Act,â which was co-sponsored by Sens. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.), Mazie Hirono (D-Hawaii) and Patty Murray (D-Wash.), would give an additional $13.27 billion over five years to create an estimated 400,000 affordable housing units. The funds would go to supportive housing, including homeless shelters and transitional housing, as well as housing vouchers for low-income families and local outreach services to homeless residents. Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.)Â introduced a similar bill in the House in March, whichÂ passed in committee and is expected to go to the House floor. âToo many people donât have a safe place to call home. We must act quickly to tackle our countryâs homelessness crisis head on,â Harris said in a news release. âThe women and men who woke up this morning on a bench or under an overpass cannot afford to wait.â The lack of affordable housing is a nationwide crisis, and California has one of the highest rates of homelessness. On any given day in January 2018, more than 500,000 people were homeless in the U.S., according to a federal report. Nearly a quarter of the nationâs homeless residents live in California. In the past two years, homelessness has spiked in Los Angeles, parts of which Waters represents, and the San Francisco Bay Area, where Harris is from and had served as district attorney. We have a homelessness crisis in Americaâand we must act quickly to tackle it head on.

Thatâs why Iâm working with @RepMaxineWaters to introduce the Ending Homelessness Act to direct $9.5 billion to eliminate chronic homelessness in America. https://t.co/mb9SL6UPT7 President Donald Trump went on a tear last month about homelessness in California, notably complaining about how people living in tents were ruining the âprestigeâ of San Francisco and Los Angeles. Some of Harrisâ fellow 2020 contenders have also zeroed in on homelessness in recent weeks, with former Housing Secretary JuliÃ¡n Castro and former Congressman Beto OâRourke both visiting California last month to speak with people in homeless encampments. The funds for Harrisâ and Watersâ legislation would be appropriated from mandatory emergency relief funding, according to a news release â but Harrisâ team said it was still to be determined, namely through processes in the Senate committee, exactly where the funds would be drawn from. âIn the richest country in the world, it is simply unacceptable that we have people living in the streets,â Waters said in a news release.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Hilariously Trolls Political Smear Calling Her A âCougarâ
articles.subtitle: Two discredited far-right conspiracy theorists were up to their old tricks. But she deftly dismissed them.
articles.author: David Moye
articles.content: A pair of thoroughly discredited political dirty tricksters attempted to smear Sen.Â Elizabeth WarrenÂ of Massachusetts as a âcougarâ on Thursday, and the Democratic presidential candidate responded hilariously âand truthfully â without getting catty. The two far-right conspiracy theorists who are already known for fraudulent claims â Jacob Wohl and Jack Burkman âÂ held a press conferenceÂ in Arlington, Virginia, featuring Kelvin Whelly, a former U.S. Marine in his mid-20s who claims he had a paid sexual affair with Warren, 70, that included bondage. Whelly claims he met Warren through a male escort website, Cowboys4Angels, and that their first tryst occurred on Aug. 8, 2018, in Massachusetts. But he offered no verifiable evidence to back up his story and Rolling Stone later reported that the Cowboys4Angels chief executive said, after checking his records, that âthis guy never worked for me.â Wohl and Burkman have made clear in the past their avid support for President Donald Trump, but even the pro-TrumpÂ Daily Caller noted that Whelly had a hard time keeping a straight face while discussing his allegations. Warren, meanwhile, won the day with a witty response that embraced her âcougarâ past, telling the world it made her who she is. Itâs always a good day to be reminded that I got where I am because a great education was available for $50 a semester at the University of Houston (go Cougars!). We need to cancel student debt and make college free for everyone who wants it. pic.twitter.com/fHasLm0j9P Twitter users thought Warrenâs cougar tweet was the catâs meow: Hands down the coolest tweet in presidential election history. pic.twitter.com/q0U1ZsnBq1 Best troll, really I must say I did not get the mastry of this tweet. Takes a little longer for some of us older folks to see strong women vs incel = flush. Well played, Senator, well played. pic.twitter.com/huj8zqE5f0 I am definitely voting for a Cougar!#Warren2020 Wohl, though only 21, already has defined the term âcheckered past.â As a teenager, the Southern California native was involved in financial scams and banned for life by the National Futures Association. In August, new charges of securities fraud were filed against him.

articles.title: Trump Brought Up Biden, Warren In A Call With Chinese President: Report
articles.subtitle: Sources told CNN that Trump brought up his rivalsâ political prospects and promised to stay quiet on the Hong Kong protests in the same call.
articles.author: Lydia OâConnor
articles.content: President Donald Trump brought up two of his potential 2020 opponents â former Vice President Joe Biden and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) â in a call with Chinese President Xi Jinping in June, sources familiar with the phone cal told CNN on Thursday. The report comes hours after Trump suggested, while speaking to reporters, that China investigate Biden, appearing to openly ask another foreign government to influence an American election despite Congress investigating Trump for doing the same thing with Ukraineâs president. According to CNNâs report on the June 18 call, Trump brought up the âpolitical prospectsâ of Biden and Warren, the latter of who had recently started rising in the polls. In that same call, he promised not to speak out on the ongoing Hong Kong protests as China and the U.S. negotiate a trade deal. A record of the call was moved to a highly secure server, CNN reported. The alleged conversation â and how it was archived â bears significant similarity to a phone call Trump had around the same time with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which Trump pressed the leader to investigate Biden while also reminding him that the U.S. had provided Ukraine with a lot of foreign aid. That interaction prompted a whistleblower to raise concerns about Trumpâs behavior, which has since sparked a formal House impeachment inquiry, which Trump has repeatedly denounced as a âwitch hunt.â The White House did not immediately return HuffPostâs request for comment, but officials told the press in June that the call with Xi involved discussion of âthe importance of leveling the playing field for U.S. farmers, workers, and businesses through a fair and reciprocal economic relationship.â

articles.title: Comedians Skewer Rudy Giuliani With Mock Subway Ads: âNeed A Lawyer? Call Crazy Rudyâ
articles.subtitle: He does back-channel deals, has no shame and âwill work for free!â the satirical signs pitch.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: A comedian duo created scathing prank New York City subway ads this week that looked familiar to commuters â but with a wicked twist on President Donald Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giuliani. âNeed a lawyer?â the ads asked. âCall Crazy Rudy.â The messages were a send-up of Giulianiâs over-the-top appearances on TV news shows as he peddles conspiracy theories, including about former Vice President Joe Biden and his son as he defends Trumpâs phone call pressuringÂ  Ukraineâs president to investigate the Bidens as he held up military aid to the nation. That July call has become the centerpiece of an impeachment inquiry. Giuliani will do âback-deal channels, cable news appearances, has no shameâ and âwill work for free!â pitch the mock ads. Davram Stiefler and Jason Selvig â of the comedy pair âThe Good Liarsâ â created the signs and hung them in trains on three lines Tuesday. They also created the CrazyRudyLaw.com site, which advises: âIn an effort to shield money from my wife during our divorce, Iâm willing to work for FREE! I only ask that you pick up the bar tab at the end of our session.â The website also promises that the former New York mayorâs appearances will be âunhinged, combative and fun!â The pair also set up an answering machine message for the number posted on the ad and website: (347) 687-0436. Stiefler and Selvig have a reputation for political high jinks. A year ago they posted â then removed â a video of them hounding Brian Kilmeade of âFox & Friendsâ outside a subway station and on the streets of New York. âThere are so many people out there who are so emotional,â Kilmeade told The Hollywood Reporter at the time. âHow much more are we willing to accept?â In August, Selvig posted âmissingâ posters for New York City MayorÂ Bill de Blasio while he was running for president. He was âlast seen embarrassing himself in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina,â the posters stated. âIf seen, please tell him to immediately return to New York and do the job he was elected to do.â There was also this: And this appears to be the duoâs latest:  Giuliani did not immediately reply to a request for comment. The âneed a lawyerâ messages were removed by the cityâs Metropolitan Transportation Authority because they werenât paid for or approved.

articles.title: Scope Of Trumpâs Ukraine Scheme Comes Into Focus As New Reports Emerge
articles.subtitle: The news stories detail steps the Trump administration allegedly took to coerce Ukraine into investigating Vice President Joe Biden.
articles.content: Two reports published Thursday evening shed light on the apparent reach of PresidentÂ Donald Trumpâs efforts to pressure Ukraine into investigating former Vice President Joe Biden and Bidenâs son Hunter. According to The Wall Street Journal, Trump ordered the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine removed from her post after his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, and others close to Trump complained she was undermining the administrationâs efforts to pressure Ukrainian leaders to investigate the Bidens. The ouster of Marie Yovanovitch on May 6,Â also referenced in the recent whistleblower complaint by a member of the U.S. intelligence community concerning Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine, came just months after Giuliani began pressing Ukrainian leaders for damaging information about the Bidens. Trump on Thursday told reporters he had heard âvery bad thingsâ about Yovanovitch, a respected foreign service official, prior to her removal.Â âI donât know if I recalled her or somebody recalled her but I heard very, very bad things about her for a long period of time. Not good,â he said. Yovanovitch was also the subject of an attempted smear campaign earlier this year by Trump allies who sent a packet of documents with misinformation about her to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Politico reportedÂ earlier this week. Debunked conspiracy theories about Hunter Biden also were included in those documents, according to the Politico story. Prior to Yovanovitchâs recall, conservative media outlets and the presidentâs eldest son,Â Donald Trump Jr.,Â accusedÂ her of being part of an alleged Ukrainian attempt to support Hillary Clintonâs 2016 presidential campaign. Trump also made threatening comments about Yovanovitch during hisÂ July 25 phone call with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky. âSheâs going to go through some thingsâ in the aftermath of her removal from the envoy post, Trump said,Â according to a White HouseÂ summary of the conversation released last week. Democrats now view Yovanovitch as potentially a key witness in the Houseâs impeachment inquiry into Trump. The false documents sent out about her âprovide further evidence of a concerted, external effort to conduct a disinformation campaign against a career U.S ambassador, who has been the subject of baseless attacks, including by the president himself,â Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) said in a statement on Tuesday. According to the second Thursday report, this one in The New York Times, two top U.S. diplomats drafted a statement for Zelensky that would have publicly committed him to carry out Trumpâs request for an investigation that would have involved the Bidens. Gordon D. Sondland, the ambassador to the European Union, and Kurt D. Volker, the envoy to Ukraine, prepared the statement, the Times said, citingÂ three people who were briefed on the matter.Â The alleged statement, according to the newspaper, would have served the purpose of pushing Ukraine leaders beyond their private pledges to launch the investigation, which would have focused on the energy company Burisma on whose board Hunter Biden served. Volker resigned from his post last week after he was implicated in the published whistleblower complaint which raised concerns that the pressure being applied on Ukraine by Trump for an investigation that included Joe Biden â the potential 2020 Democratic presidential nominee â represented an effort to have foreign officials meddle in the U.S. election. The complaint spurred the opening of the impeachment inquiry by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.). In the complaint, the whistleblower said that both Volker and Sondland spoke with Giuliani in an attempt to âcontain the damageâ³ done by Trumpâs requests to Ukraine. Volker testified before three House committees on Thursday as part of the impeachment inquiry.

articles.title: Rick Perry To Resign As Energy Secretary: Reports
articles.subtitle: The former Texas governor is expected to leave Trumpâs Cabinet by the end of the year.
articles.author: Antonia Blumberg
articles.content: Rick Perry is expected to resign by the end of the year as secretary of the Department of Energy,Â PoliticoÂ andÂ The Washington Post reported Thursday. Perry said earlier this week that heâd cooperate with lawmakers investigating an explosive whistleblower complaint about President Donald Trumpâs communications in July with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Perry has met with Zelensky at least three times, according to CNN. âWhile the Beltway media has breathlessly reported on rumors of Secretary Perryâs departure for months, he is still the Secretary of Energy and a proud member of President Trumpâs Cabinet,â Energy Department spokesperson Shaylyn Hynes said in a statement to HuffPost on Friday. âOne day the media will be right. Today is not that day.â Perry, who Politico reported will leave by end of November, had reportedly been planning an exit since mid-April, when several sources with knowledge of his plans told BloombergÂ that the former Texas governor was âfinalizing the terms and timing of his departure.â During his unsuccessful bid for the presidency in 2012, Perry had vowed to eliminate the Department of EnergyÂ (despite infamously forgetting the departmentâs name and uttering âoopsâ during a November 2011 debate). Roughly five years later, he was Trumpâs pick for energy secretary. Perry, an Air Force veteran and former âDancing With the Starsâ contestant, was initially unclear on what the department he was tasked with leading actually did.Â According to a New York Times report in January 2017, Perry believed his new job would entail championing the U.S. oil and gas industry, as heâd done during his 14 years as the governor of Texas. He quickly learned the roleâs primary responsibilities would involve overseeing nuclear weapons and nuclear waste, with very little pertaining to either fossil fuels or renewable energy. âIf you asked him on that first day he said yes, he would have said, âI want to be an advocate for energy,ââ Michael McKenna, a Republican energy lobbyist who advised Perry during his 2016 presidential campaign, told the Times. âIf you asked him now, heâd say, âIâm serious about the challenges facing the nuclear complex.â Itâs been a learning curve.â Unlike many other Cabinet members, Perry reportedly enjoyed amicable relations with Trump during his tenure as energy secretary. The president named Perry asÂ âdesignated survivorâÂ for the 2019 State of the Union address â a custom in which one Cabinet member hides in an undisclosed location during the address in case a catastrophe occurs in the House chamber. Trump also weighed Perry as a possible head for the Department of Veterans Affairs before ousting its secretary,Â David Shulkin, last year. Perry reportedly declined a request from Trump to take over as Department of Homeland Security secretary before Kirstjen Nielsen resigned earlier in Aprilï»¿. Perryâs departure is the latest major shake-up in the Trump administration and follows Nielsenâs resignation, as well as the departures of national security adviser John Bolton,Â Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats,Â Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta,Â Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and chief of staff John Kelly. CORRECTION: A previous version of this story stated incorrectly that Nielsen resigned this month. She resigned in April.

articles.title: âThis Is Insane. Trumpâs Gotta Go.â George Conway Ramps Up Call To Oust President.
articles.subtitle: Kellyanne Conwayâs husband lays out long argument for Trumpâs removal, then learns of his bombshell call asking Chinese president to launch Biden probe.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: After a lengthy, carefully reasoned argument about why âpathological narcissistâ Donald Trump must be removed from the White House, conservative lawyer George ConwayÂ tweeted urgently later Thursday: âThis is insane. Trumpâs gotta go.â The husband of White House counselor Kellyanne Conway was responding to news reports that Trump also urged Chinaâs President Xi Jinping in a phone call to investigate his political rival Joe Biden and Bidenâs son Hunter. A call to Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky to push him into similar action that would affect a U.S. presidential election is the focus of an impeachment inquiry. This is insane.  Trumpâs gotta go. https://t.co/3nSgVPNSZ3 Trump also told reporters Thursday that China should investigate Biden. Conwayâs âinsaneâ label for what has been transpiring with Trump followed a treatise Thursday in The Atlantic that Trump is unfit for office because heâs an extreme ânarcissistâÂ who puts himself ahead of the nation. âYou donât need to be a mental health professional to see somethingâs seriously off with Trump,â Conway wrote. And itâs only getting worse under the stress of a stumbling economy and an impeachment investigation, he warned. âNo president in recent memory â and likely no president ever â has prompted more discussion about his mental stability and connection with reality,â Conway wrote. He recounted several troubling reports since Trump took office, including former White House chief of staff John Kelly allegedly calling Trump âunhingedâ and an anonymous White House official writing of the presidentâs âinstabilityâ in The New York Times. The president is âvolatile and erraticâ â and âincapable of consistently telling the truth,â George Conway wrote. He quoted Times columnist Megan McArdle: âThis is not normal. And I donât mean that as in, âTrump is violating the shibboleths of the Washington establishment.â I mean that as in, âThis is not normal for a functioning adult.ââ A president should act as a âfiduciaryâ of the nation, who pursues the ââpublic interest in good faith republican fashion rather than pursuing his self-interest,ââÂ  Conway noted, quoting from a recent Harvard Review article. But Trump acts instead like an extreme â if not âpathologicalâ â narcissist who is convinced he is an exceptional human being and an expert on everything, despite evidence to the contrary, lacks empathy, and craves being the constant focus of admiration, Conway argued.Â The âfundamental life goalâ of an extreme narcissist âis to promote the greatness of the self, for all to see,â psychologist Dan McAdams has written in The Atlantic, Conway noted. âSimply put, Trumpâs ingrained and extreme behavioral characteristics make it impossible for him to carry out the duties of the presidency in the way the Constitution requires,â Conway argued. âIt would take entire books to catalog all of Trumpâs behavioral abnormalities and try to explain them .... But when you line up what the Framers expected of a president with all that we know about Donald Trump, his unfitness becomes obvious,â Conway wrote. âTo act as a fiduciary requires you to put someone elseâs interests above your own, and Trumpâs personality makes it impossible for him to do that,â Conway concluded. âFor Trump, Trump always comes first. He places his interests over everyone elseâs â including those of the nation whose laws he swore to faithfully execute. Thatâs not consistent with the duties of the president.â The answer to the Trump problem, Conway concluded, is impeachment. âIf Congress does its job and presents the evidence, those who are in denialâ about Trump âwonât be able to ignore the problem any longer,â he explained. âNot only because of the evidence itself, but because Donald Trump will respond in pathological ways â and in doing so, heâll prove the points against him in ways almost no one will be able to ignore.â Read Conwayâs piece in The Atlantic here.

articles.title: Newly Revealed Trump Administration Texts On Ukraine Appear To Show Clear Quid Pro Quos
articles.subtitle: Trumpâs call with the leader of Ukraine has prompted an impeachment inquiry as Democrats condemn what they call brazen efforts to extract political favors.
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: Newly released text messages sent by senior Trump administration officials appear to show clear instances of the White House brazenly pressuring Ukraine for political favors in exchange for cooperation from the U.S. government. The texts were released late Thursday by the chairs of three House committees, who wrote in a letter to colleagues that they had âgrave concernsâ after speaking with State Department officials as part of the chamberâs unfolding impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trumpâs July 25 call with the leader of Ukraine. The three chairs wrote that the shocking texts were âonly a subset of the full body of materialsâ that had been obtained, the entirety of which they planned to release in the coming days. (Read the full document at the bottom of this article.) The text message were largely sent by Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, and Kurt Volker, who was until last month the State Departmentâs special envoy to Ukraine, to Andriy Yermak, a top aide to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. In one instance that appears to be an overt quid pro quo, Volker texted Yermak just hours before the two presidents were set to speak. In the message, Volker said the White House would work to ânail down the date for [a] visit to Washingtonâ but only on the assumption that âPresident Z convinces trump he will investigate/âget to the bottom of what happenedâ in 2016.â Trumpâs July 25 call with Zelensky has become the flashpoint for a Democratic impeachment inquiry after a reconstruction of the call showed multiple instances of Trump pressuring his counterpart to investigate a prime political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden, and his son Hunter. In the texts, Yermak later wrote that the callÂ  âwent wellâ and that Trump and Zelensky had agreed on a visit to the U.S. Later in August, however, Yermak pressed Volker to nail down the date, saying that once it was locked in, Ukrainian officials would outline their âvision for the reboot of US-Ukraine relationship, including among other things Burisma and election meddling in investigations.â Hunter Biden served on the board of Burisma, a Ukrainian energy company, for five years, ending in early 2019. Yermak also texted Volker at the end of August expressing concern about a report Trump was withholding military aid to Ukraine. Trump canceled a planned visit to Poland to meet Zelensky a day later. The text messages also show concern among some Trump administration officials. In multiple instances, Bill Taylor, the top U.S. diplomat to Ukraine, expressed worry that the White House was withholding military aid until any investigations into Biden were launched. âAre we now saying that security assistance and WH meeting are conditioned on investigations?â Taylor asked Sondland on Sept. 1. Sondland later replied âcall me,â and itâs unclear what the pair discussed. But the issue came up again a week later: âAs I said on the phone, I think itâs crazy to withhold security assistance for help with a political campaign,â Taylor texted Sondland on Sept. 9, saying diplomacy had moved into his ânightmare scenario.â Sondland later rejects that characterization, saying Trump had âbeen crystal clear no quid pro quoâs of any kind.â The texts were attached to a letter condemning Trumpâs effort to minimize his call with Ukraine. It was signed by Democratic Reps. Adam Schiff (Calif.), chair of the House Intelligence Committee; Eliot Engel (N.Y.), chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee; and Elijah Cummings (Md.), who chairs the House Oversight and Reform Committee. The lawmakers expressed worry about the White House effort to delegitimize the impeachment inquiry, saying the Trump administration was âengaging in a campaign of misinformation and misdirection in an attempt to normalize the act of soliciting foreign powers to interfere in our election.â Trump has vehemently rejected claims that he did anything improper, referring to the inquiry as a âcoup.â On Thursday, the president publicly urged China to investigate the Bidens just moments after saying that âif they donât do what we want, we have tremendous power.â In the letter, the chairmen urged their colleagues to reject such claims, calling them âunethical, unpatriotic and wrong.â âWe hope every Member of the House will join us in condemning in the strongest terms the Presidentâs now open defiance of our core values as American citizens to guard against foreign interference in our democratic process,â they wrote. This article has been updated with details about the text messages.

articles.title: Wisconsin Governor Rips Sonny Perdue For Warning Small Dairy Farms Wonât Make It
articles.subtitle: âMake no mistake about it, Trumpâs administration is no friend to Americaâs dairyland,â Democratic Gov. Tony Evers said of the U.S. agriculture secretary.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: The Democratic governor of election battleground state Wisconsin slammed Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue for âlambastingâ small dairy farms by suggesting theyâre unlikely to survive amid President Donald Trumpâs trade war with China. âMake no mistake about it, Trumpâs administration is no friend to Americaâs dairyland,â tweeted Gov. Tony Evers. Some farmers and ranchers demanded Perdue be fired and replaced with someone who supports smaller independent operations rather than big corporations in Americaâs heartland. Perdue said Tuesday at the World Dairy Expo in Madison that he wasnât holding out much hope for the survival of family dairy operations with fewer than 100 cows. Farmers are bearing the brunt of Trumpâs trade war, and dairy exports to China fell 54% in the first half of this year.Â Wisconsin, which boasts on its license plates that itâs âAmericaâs dairyland,â has lost 551 dairy farms so far this year after losing 638 in 2018 and 465 in 2017, according to the state. Nearly 3,000 U.S. dairy farms folded in the nation last year â a decline of about 6.5%, according to U.S. figures. âNow what we see, obviously, is economies of scale having happened in America âÂ big get bigger and small go out,â Perdue said flatly.Â âI donât think in America we, for any small business, have a guaranteed income or a guaranteed probability of survival.â Evers complained to journalists Wednesday that Perdue âput the pox onÂ small farming in the state,â The Milwaukee Journal reported. âAre they struggling? Absolutely,â said Evers. âBut I think at the end of the day we need to get behind them rather than saying, âAh maybe you should go larger.â² I, frankly, resent that the Department of Agriculture secretary from the federal government came in and kind of lambasted them.â Darin Von Ruden, president of the Wisconsin Farmers Union who runs a 50-cow organic farm, complained to reporters that larger farms are ânot a good way to go,â The Associated Press reported. âDo we want one corporation to own all the foodÂ in our country?â Von Ruden asked. An organization of women in agriculture, Women Involved in Farm Economics,Â  demanded that Perdue be fired and replaced with someone who supports smaller farm and ranch operations, and not Big Ag corporations. âWith fewer and fewer places to sell our products and no support from our government to stop concentration in the agriculture market, farmers and ranchers are squeezed,â the groupâs president, Diane McDonald, told Nebraskaâs McCook Gazette. Cattle ranchers at a rally in Omaha on Wednesday, coordinated by the Organization for Competitive Markets, also called for Perdueâs firing, accusing him of promoting corporate meatpackers at the expense of American independent cattle ranchers. âThere is nothing natural or inevitable about consolidation in agriculture,â Claire Kelloway, a researcher at Open Markets Institute, said in a statement. âFarmers are pushed to get big or get out because of policies that enable predatory monopolies to strip wealth from farmers.â Perdue has the ability to âenact policies that would crack down on the abusive agriculture monopolies that are pushing out small producers and independent family farms,â Calloway added. Trump declared in July during a visit to Wisconsin â much to the surprise of farmers the president calls âhis patriotsâ â that âsome of the farmers are doing really well.Â  Weâre over the hump.â Rural areas were crucial to Trumpâs election in 2016. CORRECTION: An earlier version misspelled Claire Kellowayâs surname and misidentified the Organization for Competitive Markets.

articles.title: Pro-Trump Group Takes Credit For Video About Eating Babies At AOC Town Hall
articles.subtitle: âIt was us,â LaRouche PAC said on Twitter. âMalthusianism isnât new, Jonathan Swift knew that. Sometimes, only satire works.â
articles.author: Sebastian Murdock
articles.content: A stunt involving an alleged supporter of Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) ranting about eating babies to stop climate change was a hoax orchestrated by a right-wing group. LaRouche PAC, which supports President Donald Trump and believes, among other falsehoods, that climate change is a hoax, took credit for the bizarre stunt on Twitter. Video of the incident circulated Thursday night, after a woman wearing a shirt that said âSave the planet, eat the children,â stood up during a town hall event in Queens. âIâm so happy that you are really supporting a Green New Deal, but itâs not enough,â the unidentified woman told Ocasio-Cortez and the packed room. âEven if we were to bomb Russia, we still have too many people, too much pollution. So we have to get rid of the babies. Thatâs a big problem. Just stopping having babies is not enough. We need to eat the babies.â Despite the lawmakerâs attempts to calm the woman down, Trump retweeted it, calling Ocasio-Cortez âa wack job!â In its tweet, LaRouche PAC claimed the stunt was meant to be commentary similar to Jonathan Swiftâs famed satire on baby-eating, âA Modest Proposal.â âIt was us,â the group tweeted. âMalthusianism isnât new, Jonathan Swift knew that. Sometimes, only satire works.â Gizmodo, which first reported the video as a hoax, spoke to Matthew Sweet, an author who has written about the groupâs founder, Lyndon LaRouche Jr.: Sweet notes that the group did something similar to 1988 presidential candidate Michael Dukakis, spreading leaflets that he was mentally unwell and had visited a psychiatrist. The campaign made national headlines and Dukakis was forced to releaseÂ medical recordsÂ refuting the claim. Aside from yesterdayâs outburst, LaRouche PAC has been trying to get âeat childrenâ satire out in other street-level engagements to discredit the environmental movement. The group posted photos to Facebook on October 2 that shows people with signs like âEat the Children,â as well as other more earnest messages in support of Donald Trump. LaRouche PAC did not immediately return a request for comment from HuffPost.

articles.title: Secular Groups Claim Judge Crossed A Line By Giving Amber Guyger Her Bible
articles.subtitle: The Freedom From Religion Foundation accused Judge Tammy Kemp of violating church-state separation by proselytizing to the convicted former police officer.
articles.author: Carol Kuruvilla
articles.content: A secular advocacy organization has accused a Dallas judge of violating the separation of church and state by proselytizing to a convicted murderer in the courtroom during the final moments of a high-profile case. The Wisconsin-based Freedom From Religion Foundation (FFRF) said Thursday that Judge Tammy Kemp crossed an ethical line by sharing a Bible and Christian teachings about sin and salvation with Amber Guyger, a former Dallas police officer sentenced Wednesday to 10 years in jailÂ for the September 2018 shooting and killing of unarmed Black man Botham Shem Jean. Guyger, who is white, shot Jean in his own apartment, which she claimed she mistook for her own. Courtroom video shows the 204th District Court judge approaching Guyger with a Bible, which she says is her own. At that point, Guyger had already been sentenced, and the jury had been dismissed, The Associated Press reports. In the video, the judge,Â still dressed in her official robes, is seen opening the Bible and pointing to a verse. âThis is your job for the next month. Right here,â Kemp can be heard saying in the video. âJohn: 3:16. And this is where you start.â Kemp then reads the Bible verse aloud. The popular verse is considered by many Christians to be a summation of the faithâs teachings about salvation. The verse states, âFor God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.â Kemp recommends that Guyger read the entire book of John. The conversation continues for over a minute and Guyger can be seen nodding along. Guyger then rises and hugs Kemp, who embraces her back. After at least another minute of conversation and a second hug, Guyger is led away. FFRFÂ filed a complaintÂ Thursday with the Texas State Commission on Judicial Conduct, insisting that Kemp was promoting her personal religious beliefs while acting in her official capacity. âShe was in a government courtroom, dressed in a judicial robe, with all of the imprimatur of the state, including armed law enforcement officers, preaching to someone who was quite literally a captive audience,â FFRFâs letter reads. âDelivering bibles, bible studies and personal witness as a judge is an abuse of power.â FFRF is asking the commission to investigate Kempâs actions. Prosecutors had requested Guyger serve at least 28 years.Â She will be eligible for parole in five years. Earlier in the trial, Kemp permitted Jeanâs younger brother Brandt Jean to hug Guyger while delivering his victim impact statement. The younger brother said he forgave Guyger, doesnât think she should go to jail, and said he hoped she would dedicate her life to Jesus. FFRF said that while it is âperfectly acceptableâ for Brandt Jean to express religious beliefs in court, âthe rules are different for those acting in a governmental role.â HuffPost has reached out to Kempâs office for comment. Kemp ran as a Democrat during her bid for office in 2014, AP reports. During her campaign, she reportedly placed an ad in a local magazine where she called herself a âwoman of faith with strong Christian valuesâ and revealed that she and her husband had fasted and prayed about her decision to run. Rachel Laser, president of Americans United for Separation of Church and State, said that judges acting in their official capacity must not proselytize. âBy distributing a Bible and telling the defendant it is her âjobâ to read a religious text as sheâs on her way to prison, Judge Kemp has sent a message to all defendants who come before her that their religious beliefs could affect the outcomes of their cases and their sentences,â Laser told HuffPost. Monica L. Miller, legal director for the American Humanist Association, said that her advocacy organization isnât planning legal action over the issue at this time. But she said Kempâs behavior âobliteratedâ the line between church and state. âCompassion belongs in our courtrooms,â Miller said. âPersonal bibles, admonishments to follow John 3:16, and Christian privilege do not.â

articles.title: Trump Name-Calls Mitt Romney For Criticizing Ukraine, China Comments
articles.subtitle: The Republican senator from Utah said Trumpâs actions were âbrazen and unprecedented.â The president called him an âass.â
articles.author: Ryan Grenoble
articles.content: While many in the GOP hem and haw their way around impeachment, Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) isnât holding back. The former presidential candidate doubled down on his criticisms of President DonaldÂ Trump in a series of tweets Friday morning, calling Trumpâs âbrazen and unprecedentedâ calls for foreign meddling in the 2020 election âwrong and appalling.â Romney was among the first Republicans to speak out on the allegations, which first appeared in a whistleblower report alleging that Trump ordered aid to Ukraine withheld unless the country delivered him a political favor. In response, Trump mocked Romney, referencing the senatorâs failed 2012 presidential bid against incumbent President Barack Obama. âMitt Romney never knew how to win. He is a pompous âassâ who has been fighting me from the beginning, except when he begged me for my endorsement for his Senate run (I gave it to him), and when he begged me to be Secretary of State (I didnât give it to him),â the president tweeted. On Thursday, while attempting to defend his actions, Trump instead openly asked another foreign government, China, to also influence the 2020 election. Hours later, CNN reported Trump had brought up the âpolitical prospectsâ of former Vice President Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren while on a call with Chinese President Xi Jinping in June. âIf the President asked or pressured Ukraineâs president to investigate his political rival, either directly or through his personal attorney, it would be troubling in the extremeâ Romney said last week. âCritical for the facts to come out.â Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse (R) echoed that sentiment last Wednesday after he read the complaint. âThis [is] going to take a long time but thereâs obviously some very troubling things here,â Sasse told CNN at the time. âBut I think the partisan tribalism thatâs always insta-certain is a terrible idea. There are real troubling things here.â âRepublicans ought not just circle the wagons and Democrats ought not be using words like âimpeachâ before they know anything about the actual substance,â Sasse continued. Meanwhile, much of the rest of the Republican Party seems content parroting the same lines members used during the Mueller probe. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) on Wednesday baselessly accused DemocratsÂ of having âriggedâ the process, while House Republican Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) retreated to conspiracy theories and blamed it on âa deep state scheme.â

articles.title: Hereâs What Kurt Volker Told Congress About His Role In Trump-Ukraine Negotiations
articles.subtitle: The former special envoy to Ukraine told House investigators he wasnât aware Trump had pressured Ukraineâs president for dirt on Joe Biden.
articles.author: Antonia Blumberg
articles.content: Kurt Volker, the State Departmentâs former special envoy to Ukraine, on Thursday became the first witness to testify in the Houseâs impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump. In prepared remarks obtained FridayÂ by BuzzFeed News, Volker told members of Congress that during his tenure with the department he was unaware of the Trump administrationâs efforts to pressure the Ukrainian government into investigating former Vice President Joe Biden, Trumpâs potential 2020 opponent. But Volker turned over text messages to Congress that indicate he likely knew more than he acknowledged. The texts exchanges involved Volker, Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, and Bill Taylor, the top U.S. diplomat to Ukraine. Some of the messages were sent from Volker to Andriy Yermak, a top aide to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. In one of the messages,Â Volker texted Yermak just hours before Trump and Zelensky were set to speak. Volker said the White House would work to ânail down the date for [a] visit to Washingtonâ but only on the assumption that âPresident Z convinces trump he will investigate/âget to the bottom of what happenedâ in 2016.â Volkerâs name also appears several times in the whistleblower complaintÂ from a member of the intelligence community that sparkedÂ the impeachment inquiry. It claimed Volker advised Ukrainian leaders on how to ânavigateâ Trumpâs requests. The complaint focused on a July 25 call between Trump and Zelensky, during which the U.S. president pressured his Ukrainian counterpart to look into unsubstantiated allegations that Biden used his power as vice president during the Obama administration to kill an investigation into a gas company for which his son was a board member. Volker told investigators on Thursday that he was not âfully in the loopâ about Trumpâs intentions, that he was in Ukraine at the time of the call and that he was not subsequently shown a transcript of the conversation, according to The New York Times. Volker abruptly resigned from his State Department post last week without explanation and voluntarily agreed to appear before House investigators as part of their inquiry into whether Trump abused his power to pressure a foreign government for dirt on a political rival. The next witness in the inquiry is expected to be Marie Yovanovitch, the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.Â Trump reportedly recalled Yovanovitch after his personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani complained she was undermining the administrationâs efforts to pressure Ukrainian leaders to investigate the Bidens. articles.title: House Asks Mike Pence For Ukraine-Related Documents
articles.subtitle: The request is part of the chamberâs ongoing impeachment inquiry.
articles.author: Sara Boboltz
articles.content: Three House committees have asked Vice President Mike Pence to produce documents related to President Donald Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine as part of the chamberâs impeachment inquiry. The House oversight, intelligence and foreign affairs committee chairs sent a joint letterÂ on Friday asking Pence to comply with their request by Oct. 15. âRecently, public reports have raised questions about any role you may have played in conveying or reinforcing the Presidentâs stark message to the Ukrainian President,âÂ the chairs told Pence. The committees are currently investigating a request the president made of Ukraine, asking that country to dig up dirt on a potential 2020 opponent, Joe Biden, and his son Hunter Biden. Specifically, the chairs are seekingÂ âall documents and communicationsâ from this year relating to an April 21 call and a July 25 call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Reports have indicated that a member of the vice presidentâs staff may have been on the line at the time. A Sept. 1 meeting between Pence and Zelensky has also come under scrutiny. In their letter, the chairs cited an Oct. 2 report from The Washington Post stating that Trump repeatedly âusedâ Pence âin efforts to exert pressure on the leader of Ukraine at a time when [Trump] was using other channels to solicit information that he hoped would be damaging to a Democratic rival.â Pence spokeswoman Katie Waldman said in a statement that the letter âdoes not appear to be a serious requestâ but â[g]iven the scope, just another attempt by the Do Nothing Democrats to call attention to their partisan agenda.â But the letter to the vice president came with a warning: âYour failure or refusal to comply with the request, including at the direction or behest of the President or the White House, shall constitute evidence of obstruction of the Houseâs impeachment inquiry and may be used as an adverse inference against you or the President.â House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) announced a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump late last month, following a damning whistleblower complaint suggesting the president may have withheld security aid to Ukraine in exchange for political favors and attempted to cover it up. This article has been updated with comment from Waldman.

articles.title: Surging In The Polls, Elizabeth Warren Sets Her Sights On Californiaâs Primary
articles.subtitle: The Massachusetts senator is picking up steam in the Golden State as home-state Sen. Kamala Harrisâ polling numbers tumble.
articles.author: Igor Bobic
articles.content: SAN DIEGO â A new poll confirms that a tight three-way race is developing in Californiaâs key Democratic presidential primary, with one candidate showing impressive momentum: Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts. AÂ survey released Thursday by the Public Policy Institute of California showedÂ Warren the choice of 23% of likely primary voters, with former Vice President Joe Biden at 22% and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) at 21%. When the Democratic race was first taking shape in the spring, a Quinnipiac Poll had shown Warren in single digits in the Golden State, far behind Biden, Sanders and California Sen. Kamala Harris. Indeed, as Warrenâs support has surged in California â as it has nationally â the prospects for Harris in her home state have taken a hit, again reflecting national trends. Perhaps the new pollâs most striking finding is that Harris trailed well behind the pack with just 8% support, another sign of trouble for her struggling campaign. âWarren may well be a beneficiary of Harrisâ collapse,â said veteran California Democratic strategist Garry South. âSince her very impressive debut (as a White House candidate) in Oakland in January, Harris has done little in California to solidify whatever support may have been potentially there for her.â Voters like Cindy Henderson, an author who showed up to hear Warren speak Thursday as the candidate made her first campaign stop in San Diego, give a glimpse into the raceâs current dynamics. âI was actually a Kamala fan,â Henderson said. âJust something in the last two or three months, Iâm just kind of dropping off [on her]. I think sheâs not quite ready. I just donât think thereâs much depth yet. The more I hear and watch what Elizabeth does, itâs just like, OK, sheâs a rock star. Iâm loving her message.â Warren drew about 8,500 people for her rally in downtown San Diego. (A rally for Sanders was attended by an estimated 6,400 people at the same venue in May). Like most of Warrenâs audiences, her Thursday crowd was predominantly white â which aligns with how her support breaks down in public opinion surveys, as well. A UC Berkeley Institute of Governmental Studies pollÂ released in late September showed her leading the California race with 29%, with Biden at 21% and Sanders at 20%. But Warren trailed both of those two with Latino voters. Warren mostly stuck to her populist stump speech on Thursday, laying out her plans to take on Washington corruption, special interests and big corporations. She appeared to choke up at one point as she recalled the family struggles that marked her childhood in Oklahoma, including the time her mother lost her job. The story is a big hit with many voters, who cite it when discussing the candidate. At one point, after discussing her plan to break up big tech companies, Warren called out Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who told employees in recently leaked audio the company would âgo to the matâ to defeat her efforts. âAnd yes, Mark Zuckerberg, Iâm looking at you,â she said, to cheers and applause from the audience. The true contours of the Democratic battle will emerge in February when the narrative-driving nominating contests in Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina take place. But right around the corner comes primaries in 14 states on March 3, Super Tuesday. And California is the dayâs dominant contest, with 416 convention delegates allotted. Thatâs why so many of the main Democratic contenders are paying frequent visits to the state to meet with voters â as well as well-heeled donors. Also, early mail-in voting begins a month before the actual primary date. And conquering California presents unique challenges for a politician: itsÂ population is decidedly more diverse than that in the earlier-voting states, campaign ads are far more expensive than in those other locales and gaining media attention is difficult. In terms of having the money to compete, Warren and Sanders are well-primed as the race enters the final stretch before primary season. Warren raised $24.6 million in the third quarter, her campaign told supporters in an email Friday, and has $25.7 million cash on hand. Sanders, hospitalized earlier this week in Nevada because of a blocked artery, raised $25.3 million from July to September (his campaign didnât release a cash-on-hand figure). Their figures are especially impressive because both candidates have opted against holding fundraisers focused on big-dollar donors during the primary campaign. Bidenâs campaign, meanwhile, reported a lackluster $15.2 million raised over the past three months, far less than his second-quarter haul of $21.5 million. He could be in trouble if his fundraising continues to taper off. President Donald Trumpâs re-election campaign and the Republican National Committee announced raising a combined $125 million in the third quarter, a record-setting haul. His war chest will only grow as Democrats spend several months â and maybe more, in the case of a lengthy primary battle â determining their nominee. Warren dismissed Trumpâs haul on Thursday, telling reporters she didnât think âscooping up a bunch of money from rich people and buying a bunch of TV adsâ is âhow democracy works anymore.â She added: âI think itâs going to be about going out and building a grassroots movement.â Given Warrenâs steady rise in the primary race, the Oct. 15 Democratic debate in Westerville, Ohio, looms particularly large for her. As the frontrunner in several of the raceâs most recent national polls, sheâll likely have a bigger target on her back. Even as Warren received enthusiastic backing at her San Diego rally, interviews with some of the undecided voters at it underscored some of the doubts she still most overcome. Corinne Lytle-Bonine, an environmental consultant who voted for Sanders in the 2016 Democratic primary, acknowledged she was giving Warren a strong look this time around. âHaving the nomination be another old white man is a hard pill to swallow when it feels like women have been the ones really carrying the Democrats through 2018,â Lytle-Bonine said. She added that âI think Warren has some establishment credentials that Bernie doesnât, and may make her more electable in the general election.â Still, Lytle-Bonine questioned why Warren has been hesitant to acknowledge whether the middle class would see a tax hike if, as president, she would push into law âMedicare-for-Allâ government health care plan Sanders has introduced and that she supports. Several of Warrenâs rivals have criticized her for repeatedly dodging the question; sheâs brushed off the attacks as unfair Republican framing. âI wish that she wouldâ directly deal with that issue, Lytle-Bonine said. âI guess I donât know what is holding her back. I donât think itâs a hard answer to say âYes, weâll raise taxes, however, all of your out-of-pocket expenses (for health care) go away.ââ

articles.title: A Running List Of Republicans Criticizing Trumpâs Ukraine Scandal
articles.subtitle: Republicans are not as unified over the controversy as the president is insisting.
articles.author: Lydia OâConnor
articles.content: President Donald Trump insisted Friday that âthe Republicans are very unifiedâ in supporting him amid accusations that he improperly asked foreign leaders to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a 2020 political rival. But thatâs not entirely true. While the Democratic-controlled House begins an impeachment inquiry into Trumpâs conversations with the Ukrainian government about Biden, which were revealed after a whistleblower complaint, cracks are beginning to show in the Republican Partyâs front. Trumpâs public call Thursday for China to investigate Biden, too, appears to have pushed some members of the GOP over the edge. Hereâs a running list of Republicans who are speaking out about Trumpâs apparent attempts to compel foreign governments to aid his reelection campaign. Sen. Mitt RomneyÂ of Utah made the biggest splash Friday of any Republican so far when he slammed Trumpâs âbrazen and unprecedentedâ calls for foreign meddling in the 2020 presidential election as âwrong and appalling.â âWhen the only American citizen President Trump singles out for Chinaâs investigation is his political opponent in the midst of the Democratic nomination process, it strains credulity to suggest that it is anything other than politically motivated,â Romney said. The week before, Romney also spoke out about Trumpâs July phone call with the president of Ukraine. Vermont Gov. Phil Scott was the first Republican governor to publicly support an impeachment inquiry into Trump. The action is âappropriate,â he said in late September. âCongress has a solemn responsibility to every American to fulfill its role in our government system of checks and balances,â he said. Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker also told reporters in September that he supported an impeachment inquiry. âItâs a deeply disturbing situation and circumstance,â he said, âand I think the proper role and responsibility for Congress at this point is to investigate it and get to the bottom of it.â Republican Jim Steineke, the GOP leader of the Wisconsin State Assembly, took a stand against Trump on Friday after the president insisted on Twitter that he was right to ask other countries to investigate Biden. His behavior âcannot be normalized,â Steineke tweeted. Sen. Ben Sasse of Nebraska couldnât defend Trumpâs actions when speaking to reporters in September. âThereâs obviously some very troubling things here,â he said, though he stopped short of supporting an impeachment inquiry. âDemocrats ought not to be using the word âimpeachâ before they had the whistleblower complaint or read any of the transcript,â he added, referring to the July 25 call with the Ukraine president. But he also criticized Republicans for turning a blind eye. âRepublicans ought not to be rushing to circle the wagons and say thereâs no there there when thereâs obviously a lot thatâs very troubling there.â Rep. Will Hurd of Texas, one of several Republican lawmakers to announce in recent months that he wonât seek reelection, told CNN last week that copies of text messages exchanged among U.S. diplomats about Trumpâs actions âare indeed damning.â âI think this is serious stuff; these are serious matters,â he said. âThis has long-term implications on our foreign policy.â Trumpâs public call for China to investigate Biden, he added, âis terrible.â Maineâs Sen. Susan Collins, another fairly regular Trump critic, told reporters over the weekend that she couldnât stand by his comments about China. âI thought the president made a big mistake by asking China to get involved in investigating a political opponent,â she said. âItâs completely inappropriate.â She also said she expected the Houseâs impeachment probe would make its way to the Senate. âShould the articles of impeachment come to the Senate â and right now Iâm going to guess that they will â I will be acting as a juror as I did in the Clinton impeachment trial,â Collins said. Rob Portman of Ohio said there was no question as to whether Trump was wrong to bring Biden up with the Ukrainians. âThe president should not have raised the Biden issue on that call, period,â he told The Columbus Dispatch on Monday. âItâs not appropriate for a president to engage a foreign government in an investigation of a political opponent.â However, he also said he didnât view that as an impeachable offense. Portman, notably, was among a bipartisan group of senators in 2016 who wrote a letter to Ukraineâs president criticizing a Ukrainian prosecutor for corruption in his office. That prosecutor is the same one Trump has baselessly insisted Biden unfairly targeted because he was investigating a Ukrainian company for which his son, Hunter Biden, served on the board â the relationship at the center of Trumpâs request that Ukraine dig up dirt on the Bidens. This story has been updated throughout.

articles.title: House Subpoenas White House For Ukraine Documents In Impeachment Inquiry
articles.subtitle: The House Oversight Committee is demanding President Donald Trumpâs staff hand over documents related to the Ukraine scandal by Oct. 18.
articles.author: Antonia Blumberg
articles.content: The House Oversight Committee on Friday issued a subpoena to the White House for documents pertaining to the Trump administrationâs contacts with Ukraine. The subpoena comes amid the Houseâs impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump in the wake of an intelligence community whistleblower complaint that alleges the president abused his power to pressure Ukrainian leaders for damaging information about his political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden. The White House didnât immediately respond to a request for comment. The subpoena was addressed to Trumpâs acting chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, and signed by Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.), chairman of the House Oversight Committee; Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), chair of the House Intelligence Committee; and Rep. Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.), chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. It states that Mulvaneyâs failure to comply, even at Trumpâs behest, âmay be used as an adverse inference against you and the President.â âThe White House has refused to engage with â or even respond to â multiple requests for documents from our Committees on a voluntary basis,â the subpoena read. âAfter nearly a month of stonewalling, it appears clear that the President has chosen the path of defiance, obstruction, and cover-up.â The subpoena ends: âWe deeply regret that President Trump has put us â and the nation â in this position, but his actions have left us with no choice but to issue this subpoena.â The House oversight, intelligence, and foreign affairs committee chairs also sent a letter to Vice President Mike PenceÂ on Friday asking him to produce documents related to Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine. House investigators on Thursday heard from their first witness in the probe, Kurt Volker, who was the State Departmentâs former special envoy to Ukraine before he abruptly resigned last week. The House is looking into whether Trump was seeking a quid pro quo agreement from Ukraine when he asked the countryâs president in a July 25 phone call to investigate Biden. At the center of Trumpâs demand was the unsubstantiated allegation that then-Vice President Biden used his power to kill an investigation into a gas company for which his son, Hunter Biden, worked. Trump has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing in his interactions with Ukrainian leaders. Read the full letter below: 2019-10-04.EEC Engel Schiff to Mulvaney-WH Re Subpoena by Mollie Reilly on Scribd This is a developing story. Check back for updates.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders Suffered Heart Attack, Doctors Confirm
articles.subtitle: The presidential candidate was released from a Vegas hospital where doctors confirmed he was diagnosed with a myocardial infarction, known as a heart attack.
articles.author: Carla Herreria
articles.content: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has been released from a Las Vegas hospital three days after a heart attack, his doctors revealed in a statement through his presidential campaign Friday. The Democratic presidential candidate was first admitted to the hospital on Tuesday. His campaign hadnât disclosed any information on Sandersâ specific condition at that time, noting only that he âexperienced some chest discomfortâ and underwent an emergency heart procedure to have two stents inserted to relieve a blocked artery. The doctors who treated Sanders confirmed in their Friday statement that the senator suffered a myocardial infarction, otherwise known as a heart attack. Sanders posted a video with his wife two hours after his release was announced, thanking his supporters for their support and âwarm wishes.â âIâm feeling so much better,â he said from Las Vegas. âI want to thank the doctors, nurses, and staff at the Desert Springs Hospital Medical Center for the excellent care that they provided,â he said in a statement. âAfter two and a half days in the hospital, I feel great, and after taking a short time off, I look forward to getting back to work.â Video shows Sanders walking on his own out of the hospital while waving at cameras and cheering before getting into an SUV. âAfter presenting to an outside facility with chest pain, Sen. Sanders was diagnosed with a myocardial infarction,â Drs.Â Arturo E. Marchand Jr. and Arjun Gururaj said at Desert Springs Hospital Medical Center in Las Vegas. âThe Senator was stable upon arrival and taken immediately to the cardiac catheterization laboratory, at which time two stents were placed in a blocked coronary artery in a timely fashion,â the physicians said. âAll other arteries were normal.â Sanders is expected to attend the Democratic presidential debate in Ohio on Oct. 15. This article has been updated with a statement and video from Sanders. CORRECTION:Â An earlier version of this article said Sanders was hospitalized Wednesday. He went into the hospital Tuesday night.

articles.title: Treasury Watchdog Opens Investigation Into Handling Of Trump Tax Return Request
articles.subtitle: The inquiry could eventually reveal if the administration failed to follow regular procedures after Congress requested the presidentâs tax records.
articles.author: Arthur Delaney
articles.content: An internal agency watchdog will review whether the Trump administration failed to follow regular procedures when it denied a congressional request for President Donald Trumpâs tax returns. The acting inspector general for the Treasury Department, which oversees the Internal Revenue Service, will conduct the inquiry in response to a request from House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal (D-Mass.). Neal asked Monday for the inspector make sure Treasury and the IRS are âenforcing the law in a fair an impartial manner and no one is endeavoring to intimidate or impede government officials and employees carrying out their duties.â Acting inspector general Rich Delmar confirmed he would undertake the inquiry in an email on Friday, according to the New York Times. The IRS automatically audits the president and vice president every year, and over the summer a whistleblower complained to Congress that someone had tried to interfere with that audit. The tax whistleblower has received renewed attention as another whistleblowerâs complaint â that the president corrupted U.S. foreign policy for his own electoral benefit â has prompted Democrats to launch a formal impeachment inquiry in the House of Representatives. Neal quietly revealed the existence of the tax whistleblowerâs complaint in an August court filing that said a federal employee had come forward with âevidence of possible misconduct.â The Ways and Means Committee has sued the administration over its refusal to hand over copies of the presidentâs taxes under a federal law that says the Treasury secretary âshallâ do so. There will probably be plenty for the IG to investigate. The tax disclosure law has been on the books since 1924, and Democrats have contended in their court filings that the IRS has never before refused to hand over a tax return requested by a congressional tax committee. The IRS didnât hesitate to hand over tax material on President Richard Nixon, for instance, when lawmakers asked for it in the 1970s. Trump is the first president since Nixon to keep his taxes a secret. An internal IRS memo that surfaced earlier this year said the law gives the bureau no wiggle room to refuse requests. âI think the IG will focus on process,â said Steve Rosenthal, a senior fellow with the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center. âI think the IRS refusal was unprecedented and illegal and I think it didnât follow the ordinary course of any other request.â Another line of investigation could focus on Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchinâs decision to intervene in the tax return request, which is typically handled by the IRS without the Treasury secretary butting in. But if the IG finds that the Treasury Department failed to follow the law or its own procedures, the finding would likely have little practical effect, as the agency could simply ignore it. And the inspector would likely reach his conclusion after a long time, meaning not this year and possibly not next year, either. âIt will come much too late,â Rosenthal said.

articles.title: âThe President Is A Traitor,â Declares Former Pal Anthony Scaramucci
articles.subtitle: âI hear rank criminality. I hear pressure on diplomats coming from above to do things that are actually a revocation of the Constitution,â the former aide says.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: Anthony Scaramucci,Â longtime former friend and short-time White House communications director forÂ Donald Trump,Â called his former boss a âtraitor to the U.S.â who is struggling mightily to âgaslightâ America. âThe American president is a traitor to the United Statesâ for inviting foreign governments to meddle in U.S. politics, Scaramucci said Friday on CNN. (See the video above at 2:58). âThis is a full-blown disaster.â Trump has responded to the House impeachment inquiry, triggered by the revelation of his July 25 phone call pressing Ukraineâs president to investigate political rival Joe Biden, like âsomebody who doesnât have any principles or any morals,â Scaramucci said. âI hear rank criminality,â he explained. âI hear pressure on American diplomats coming from above to push them to do things that are actually a revocation of the Constitution.â But he also criticized Republicans who are doing nothing to call Trump out on his actions. âWe predicted [Trumpâs] meltdown ... what Iâm shocked by is that there are 53 senators who havenât really come out and spoken out,â he told CNNâsÂ Don LemonÂ in an interview Thursday (video below). âItâs reprehensible. James Madison is rolling in his grave.â Thereâs also a âlittle bit of sadness for the country,â he told Lemon. âWhen the Reuters reporter asks him a very simple question, âWhat did you want to get out of the phone call,â and he goes up like a Saturn 5 rocket and heâs doing it on the international news, thereâs a little bit of sadness for the country.â

articles.title: 2nd Whistleblower May Come Forward On Trumpâs Ukraine Call
articles.subtitle: Another official with more information on the White Houseâs Ukraine plans is thinking about filing a whistleblower complaint, The New York Times reports.
articles.author: Carla Herreria
articles.content: A second intelligence official with even more direct information on President Donald Trumpâs efforts to pressure Ukraine into meddling in the presidential election may come forward to Congress, The New York Times reported Friday night. This potential whistleblower reportedly has firsthand knowledge of the White Houseâs interactions with Ukraine and was interviewed by the intelligence communityâs inspector general during an investigation into the first whistleblowerâs complaint about a July 25 call with the president of Ukraine. The Times cited two people who had been briefed on the matter in its report. This second intelligence official is considering bringing their own whistleblower complaint to Congress, though they havenât yet done so. A potential second whistleblower would further implicate Trump. The first complaint said he abused his power by pressuring Ukraineâs president to dig up information on former Vice President Joe Biden, now a Democratic presidential rival. The report of a second government official with even more information may add fuel to the House impeachment investigation. Also on Friday night, the House Oversight CommitteeÂ issued a subpoenaÂ to the White House, ordering the Trump administration to hand over documents on its contacts with Ukraine. And earlier Friday, three House committees called on Vice President Mike Pence to submit similar documents. Government employees who work in intelligence may submit whistleblower complaints with a level of protection from criminal prosecution and retribution under the Whistleblower Protection Act.

articles.title: What, Me Worry? Marco Rubio Shrugs Off Trumpâs Call For China To Probe Biden As Joke
articles.subtitle: âRubio, thy name is cowardice,â George Takei responds on Twitter.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: Sen. Marco RubioÂ (R-Fla.) appeared so very unconcerned Friday about Donald Trump calling on China to investigate his political rival Joe Biden that he had a difficult time presenting a coherent defense. Trump, speaking to reporters outside the White House on Thursday, urged China to investigate the former vice president, just hours before CNN reported that he had raised the âpolitical prospectsâ of Biden â and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) â in a June phone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping. Trump also repeated his call to Ukraine to investigate Biden and his son â the exact request he made on a phone call in July that drew a whistleblower complaint, leading the House to formally launch an impeachment inquiry. Rubio suggested Trump was merely âneedlingâ the press Thursday. Rubio has been a longtime critic of Chinaâs autocratic government and its imprisonment and torture of dissidents. âI donât know if thatâs a real request or him just needling the press, knowing that you guys were going to get outraged by it,â he said at a Florida news conference. âHeâs pretty good at getting everyone fired up. The media responded right on task.â âI think he did it to ... provoke you. He plays it like a violin, and everyone falls right into [it]. Thatâs not a real request.â Former Acting U.S. Attorney General Sally Yates tweeted Friday that she believes Trumpâs remarks â proclaiming impeachable activities out loud â is a way to âhypnotizeâ the American public and normalize his behavior. Twitter wits had some other observations about Rubio.

articles.title: Escalating Impeachment Inquiry Rattles State Department
articles.subtitle: The department is reeling from daily revelations in the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, according to former senior officials.
articles.content: WASHINGTON (AP) â The State Department has been deeply shaken by the rapidly escalating impeachment inquiry, as revelations that President Donald Trump enlisted diplomats to dig up dirt on a political rival threaten to tarnish its reputation as a nonpartisan arm of U.S. foreign policy, former senior officials said Friday. A department where morale was already low under a president who, at times, has seemed hostile to its mission is now reeling from days of disclosures that place it at the center of an escalating political scandal, say former diplomats who fear that the turmoil will damage American foreign policy objectives around the world. âThis has just been a devastating three years for the Department of State,â said Heather Conley, a senior policy adviser at State under President George W. Bush. âYou can just feel there is a sense of disbelief. They donât know who will be subpoenaed next.â The first blow was the release of a rough transcript of the July 25 call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy in which the American president pressed for an investigation of the son of former Vice President Joe Biden. In the call, the president also disparaged the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, who was removed from her post in May amid a campaign coordinated by Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani. Thursday saw the release of text messages between Ukraine special envoy Kurt Volker and two senior diplomats as they scrambled to accommodate Giulianiâs campaign to leverage American support for Ukraine in a search for potential political dirt. âThis is only the latest in a large number of very damaging things that have been done to the State Department,â said Thomas Pickering, a former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and Russia under President George H.W. Bush. âIt represents a new low in basically ignoring and indeed punishing the people who have made a professional commitment to the country and Constitution.â With Washington in tumult over the escalating impeachment inquiry, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo toured southeast Europe on Friday, trying to ignore the furor back home. He did not respond to shouted questions on the topic from journalists at photo opportunities in Podgorica, Montenegro, and Ohrid, North Macedonia, and no questions were allowed at his scheduled press events in the two cities. His staff steadfastly refused to comment on the latest developments in the rapidly unfolding drama, including at a briefing for reporters at his last stop of the day in Athens. Earlier this week in Rome, Pompeo acknowledged for the first time that he had been on the July 25 phone call between Trump and Zelenskiy. House Democrats launched the impeachment probe over the Ukraine matter after a government whistleblower disclosed Trumpâs call with Zelenskiy and the push to have a foreign government interfere in U.S. elections by digging up dirt on Biden. Trump has sought, without evidence, to implicate Biden and his son Hunter in the kind of corruption that has long plagued Ukraine. Hunter Biden served on the board of a Ukrainian gas company at the same time his father was leading the Obama administrationâs diplomatic dealings with Kyiv. Though the timing raised concerns among anti-corruption advocates, there has been no evidence of wrongdoing by either the former vice president or his son. Trump has had a tense relationship with the State Department since he took office, repeatedly proposing to slash its budget, leaving key posts unfulfilled and choosing political appointees over career foreign service officers for ambassadorships to a greater degree than other recent presidents have. His ouster of U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch, a respected career officer, and his dismissal of her as âbad newsâ in the call left many diplomats dismayed. âThis is a workforce that already feels besieged and undercut and in a perpetual defensive crouch,â said Derek Chollet, a former senior policy adviser in the Defense Department and State Department. âThe lack of a vigorous defense of her is a signal that they are very vulnerable here. It just confirms their worst fears.â Conley, now a program director at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the State Department had settled down a bit under Pompeo following the chaotic early part of the administration under former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. But now, she said, diplomats are conflicted and confused because everything has happened outside normal channels, with no regard for long-held processes. Conley said that during her tenure at the department, even when there were disagreements between senior leaders, âthere was a respect for hierarchy and the process.â And when something went wrong, there was a chain of command and a process that protected people. But that has changed. âNo one knows whatâs going to happen next,â Conley said. âTheyâre all trying their best, but no one is untouched, no one is unharmed.â She said foreign leaders who come to Washington canât make progress on important issues because the Ukraine furor overwhelms the conversation, as it did during a visit by the president of Finland earlier this week. Other former officials and diplomats say U.S. standing around the world has been weakened. âEven a hint of the President using the power of his office to advance his personal interests in an upcoming domestic election will undermine the U.S. in diplomacy and military affairs significantly â especially with our NATO allies, who are following all of this closely with real concern,â said James Stavridis, a retired Navy admiral who was the top NATO commander in Europe from 2009 to 2013. âWe have come into a situation where not only unpredictability is the hallmark of the United States, but unreliability as well,â Pickering said. âThe wisdom and judgment that the United States was known for has been diminished.â

articles.title: Rock Climbers To Test Trumpâs Boast That His Border Barrier Canât Be Scaled
articles.subtitle: Climber Rick Weber has built a replica wall for a competition in Kentucky this month.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
