articles.content: Rock climbers plan to test President Donald Trumpâs boast that his new stretch of border barrier cannot be scaled by anyone. âMany in the climbing community were amusedÂ a couple of weeks ago when our POTUS held a press conference at a section of his latest border wall design â a series of parallel square steel posts with a 5-foot-high plate at the top,â climber and engineer Rick Weber wrote Friday in âRock and Iceâ magazine, noting that Trump described it as âimpossible to climb.â The president âboasted that âthe federal government tested the structure by having 20 skilled mountain climbers attempt to climb it, and no one could,ââ Weber wrote. But he added, âNo one in our climbing community knows any of these 20 mountaineers. I doubt if they exist.â Maya Madere, a sophomore at Stanford University who is the nationâs fifth-ranked woman boulderer (thatâs someone who climbs smaller rock formations without ropes), called Trumpâs claim that the barrier was tested by top climbers âpreposterous.â Trump is âfull of shit as usual,â sheÂ told The Daily BeastÂ last month. âDefinitely no well-recognized U.S. climbers have taken part in something like that,â climber Ross Fulkerson, a seven-time member of the U.S. national team, told The Daily Beast. But now Weber is arranging for climbers to test a replica of the barrier in a climbing competitionÂ on Oct. 11 and 12 in the Red River Gorge area of Kentucky. Entry is free and there will be prizes, he wrote. The dates overlap with an annual climbing event in the area known as Rocktoberfest. âTo declare something to be impossible to climb to a bonafide rock climber is to issue a challenge,â Weber wrote.

articles.title: Utility Giant Sets Up Critical Test For Top 2020 Democrats On Nuclear Power
articles.subtitle: As Duke Energy preps renewal requests for its reactors, itâs unclear how the leading candidates would rule on a major issue in carbon-free power.
articles.author: Alexander C. Kaufman
articles.content: One of the nationâs largest utilities last month announced plans to request new licenses for 11 nuclear reactors, setting up a critical new test for Democratic presidential candidates on how to achieve zero-carbon energy generation. Duke Energy, headquartered in Charlotte, North Carolina, said it plans to submit its renewal applications for reactors at six power plants in the Carolinas starting in 2021, which could put those decisions in the hands of a new White House if a Democrat unseats President Donald Trump next year. As it stands, itâs unclear where the top contenders for the Democratic presidential nomination would stand on relicensing. Despite intense focus on energy and climate policy, on which there are clear divisions among the candidates, the issue of nuclear power has largely been ignored in the Democratic debates. Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) and businessman Andrew Yang are all in, pledging to keep open safe plants and invest heavily in researching advanced reactors. On the opposite end of the spectrum is Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), who promised to halt construction on new reactors and issue a moratorium on nuclear plant license renewals. The views of the candidates in between are less certain. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) endorsed erstwhile climate candidate Jay Insleeâs proposal, which calls for keeping existing nuclear plants open. But at a CNN town hall last month, she vowed to start âweaning ourselves off nuclear energyâ with the goal of shutting down existing plants by 2035. Former Vice President Joe Biden, long a critic of the nuclear industry, proposed new funding for advanced reactors but hasnât taken a definitive position on extending the lives of existing nuclear plants. Warren and Biden, now the top two in several polls, gave âunclearâ responses to The Washington Postâs survey on nuclear energy.Â The Biden, Warren and Sanders campaigns did not respond to requests for comments on the record. The case for nuclear power as a source of low-carbon energy is fairly straightforward. Reactors currently produce 20% of the countryâs electricity, while hydroelectric, wind and solar power combined generate 17%. The only country that has significantly slashed emissions while remaining an industrial powerhouse is France, which converted over 70% of its power generation to nuclear after 1979. Halving global emissions in the next decade â which scientific projections say governments must do to avoid catastrophic warming â would require unprecedented changes to the worldâs energy systems. Itâs a lot harder to make those changes without at least maintaining existing nuclear reactors. The United States would need to increase renewable power generation from 0.6% to 2% per year to achieve net-zero emissions from the utility sector by 2050, according to calculations from assistant professor Leah Stokes of the University of California, Santa Barbara. To totally eliminate emissions from vehicles, the nationâs top source of planet-heating gas, the U.S. would need to double its electrical output and increase construction of renewable energy projects sevenfold âÂ  a mammoth undertaking, particularly when the worldwide buildout of renewable energy projects is in decline for the first time since 2001. But hitting that target by 2030 without adding new nuclear plants, as Warren has proposed, would require the deployment rate of renewable energy projects to increase 17 times faster than the current average. Under Sandersâ plan, which aims to decarbonize the energy sector while decommissioning nuclear reactors, it would need to be 25 times faster. The case against new nuclear plants is also fairly straightforward. Nuclear waste remains toxic for 250,000 years, roughly the same amount of time since early humans first evolved. Thereâs no good way to store spent fuel rods, despite recent progress in storing waste in remote underground caverns in Northern Europe and developing powerful lasers to alter atomic nuclei. That makes existing plants radioactive, literally and politically, particularly in a heated primary. Nevada, where the federal government has long stored waste in desert facilities and has proposed a controversial waste storage facility in Yucca Mountain, is an early-voting primary state, and nuclear storage is a top concern there. Nuclear plants are extremely expensive, both to build and operate. The only new nuclear plant under construction, in Georgia, is running about four years behind schedule, and its cost surged to $28 billion last year, double the initial estimate of $14.1 billion. And it could climb higher. South Carolina spent $9 billion on two new reactors only to abandon the project over costs and delays after hiking electricity rates in the state to cover nearly $4 billion of the cost overruns. Despite campaigning heavily in the early-voting Palmetto State, presidential hopefuls have yet to even remark there on that textbook pocketbook issue, said Tom Clements, an environmental activist in South Carolina. âThey have the gall to come here and they just ignore it,â he said of the costs. The high cost of building nuclear plants makes it impossible to compete with cheap fracked gas as coal plants are shuttered at a steady pace. Putting a price on carbon dioxide emissions â or, at the very least, eliminating fossil fuel subsidies â would make it easier for the industry to compete against gas. But nuclearâs carbon-free rivals are catching up. Wind and solar generators outcompeted nuclear plants in mid-2019 on both cost and construction speed, the annual World Nuclear Industry Status Report found. âStabilizing the climate is urgent, nuclear power is slow,â Mycle Schneider, lead author of the report, told Reuters. âIt meets no technical or operational need that low-carbon competitors cannot meet better, cheaper and faster.â Thatâs partly why no new reactors have been licensed in a quarter of a century. Itâs also why 59 of the countryâs currently licensed 97 reactors face retirement by 2040, including 11 whose credentials expire by 2025. But extending licenses on existing reactors is another story. âItâs like renewing your driverâs license. We donât view it as a litmus test,â said Neal Cohen, a vice president at the industry-backed Nuclear Energy Institute. âLicense renewal is not a controversial idea.â At a moment when HBOâs hit series âChernobylâ and the 2011 nuclear disaster in Fukushima, Japan, offer stark reminders of how destructive radiation can be, Clements took a markedly different view of extending licenses on reactors already relicensed once before. âThese reactors get older, the components age and there are safety risks associated with that,â he said. But Duke Energy instead pointed to the threat of inflaming the climate crisis with increased emissions. The utilityâs existing nuclear fleet âavoided the release of about 54 million tons of carbon dioxide â equivalent to keeping more than 10 million passenger cars off the road,â the company said. The move, moreover, was part of a broader announcement last month that Duke planned to halve its emissions by 2030 and zero them out by 2050. That, Duke spokesperson Rita Sipe said, is why the company is announcing the renewals now. The first reactors for which Duke plans to apply for renewals are at its Oconee plant in Greenville, South Carolina. Nuclear Regulatory Commission filings show the credentials for the three reactors there donât expire until 2033. But the company âprojects years into the future.â And the U.S. nuclear industryâs precarious outlook makes predictions difficult. Yet shoring up political support from a potential next president could be essential. And while a Duke spokeswoman declined to âspeak directly to the politics,âÂ South Carolina Democrats go to the polls at the end of February to decide whom that might be. Clarification: Duke Energy plans to start submitting renewal applications for nuclear reactors in 2021, not to submit them all that year.

articles.title: Rudy Giuliani Declares His Mission Is âTo Disrupt The Worldâ
articles.subtitle: Trumpâs personal attorney is doubling down on his defenses of the president as both are ensnared in an escalating House impeachment probe.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Attorney Rudy Giuliani, who has defended his client, President Donald Trump, in a series of cable news hits and off-the-rails conspiracy-mongering interviews, said Friday that his purpose is âto disrupt the world.â The former New York City mayor made the remark during a Fox News appearance, where he continued to spread unfounded corruption allegations aimed at former Vice President Joe Biden amid an escalating impeachment inquiry into the president. âMy mission is to defend my client in the best traditions of the legal profession,â Giuliani told host Martha MacCallum, adding that it is in Trumpâs âbest interestâ to âunravel the corruption in the Ukraine.â The lawyer has found himself ensnared in the House impeachment probe, which was fueled by Trumpâs repeated requests for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to aid both Giuliani and Attorney General William Barr in an investigation of Biden. An August whistleblower complaint called Giuliani a âcentral figureâ in the matter, and warned that Trumpâs action was a solicitation of election interference targeting the Democratic frontrunner. House lawmakers including Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.)Â subpoenaed GiulianiÂ on Monday for documents concerning Trumpâs effort to pressure Ukraine for help, which he has been ordered to produce by Oct. 15. On Thursday,Â former State Department special envoy for Ukraine Kurt Volker testified to congressional investigators that Giuliani had insisted that Ukraine agree to pursue probes of the 2016 election and a Ukrainian energy firm on whose board Bidenâs son once served, The New York Times reported. Text messages released the same day and published by The Washington Post revealed that U.S. diplomats believed Trump would not meet with Zelensky without first securing Ukraineâs commitment to the investigations. The communications also showed that Volker set Giuliani up with a Zelensky aide for a phone call, after which Trumpâs now-infamous July conversation with Zelensky took place.

articles.title: Trump Orders âSubstantialâ National Security Council Staff Cuts: Report
articles.subtitle: The president made the reported request as House lawmakers intensify their impeachment probe into his communications with Ukraine.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: As House lawmakers intensify their impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trumpâs alleged solicitation of election interference from Ukraine,Â he has ordered âsubstantialâ staff cuts within the National Security Council, Bloomberg News reported late Friday. The outlet cited five individuals familiar with the plan, some of whom described it as an effort to downsize the administrationâs foreign policy arm under Robert OâBrien, who was named national security adviser last month. The request was reportedly shared this week with senior NSC officials by both OâBrien and acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney. The White House did not immediately return HuffPostâs request for comment on the matter. The news comes amid mounting scandal over Trumpâs July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, during which he pressed Zelensky repeatedly to assist lawyer Rudy Giuliani and Attorney General William Barr with a corruption investigation of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden, based on unsubstantiated accusations. A whistleblower complaint filed in August by a member of the intelligence community states that Trump was essentially asking Ukraine to meddle in theÂ  2020 election by investigating a political rival. There remains no evidence of wrongdoing on the part of the Bidens. The complaint also states that âmultiple White House officialsâ said a transcript of the call was stored in a computer system managed by the NSC Directorate for Intelligence Programs, which is âreserved for codeword-level intelligence.â âAccording to information I received from White House officials, some officials voiced concerns internally that this would be an abuse of the system and was not consistent with the responsibilities of the Directorate for Intelligence Programs,â the complaint reads. âAccording to White House officials I spoke with, this was ânot the first timeâ under this Administration that a Presidential transcript was placed into this codeword-level system solely for the purpose of protecting politically sensitive â rather than national security sensitive â information.â Texts released on Thursday and published by The Washington Post give further insight into the role of Giuliani, American diplomats and Zelensky aide Andrey Yermak in facilitating Trumpâs communication. In one message,Â U.S. Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sonland mentioned NSC Senior Director Tim Morrison, though no specifics about Morrisonâs potential knowledge of the efforts are provided.

articles.title: Ex Bush Aide Says âBivalvesâ Have More Self-Awareness Than Trump Kids On Shady Deals
articles.subtitle: Eric and Donald Trump Jr. seem to be lobbing at Hunter Biden from a glass house, and donât even know it.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: As Eric and Donald Trump Jr. slam Joe Bidenâs son for serving on the board of a Ukrainian company while his dad was vice president, their international operations capitalizing on White House connections are âwarp speedâ unethical, declared a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush. âRest in peace, irony,â joked MSNBC host Joy Reid Saturday on âAM Joyâ after playing clips of the Trump brothers angrily ripping Hunter Biden. Reidâs guest David Frum quipped: âWhen you see poor Eric and poor Don Jr., you realize there are bivalves with more self-awareness than the Trump children.â They argue â without any evidence â that Joe Biden worked to block a corruption probe into an energy company whose board of directors included his son. Meanwhile, they profit from international operations stretching to as many as 30 nations still owned by their dad, the president. âPresidential families should behave themselves in more circumspect ways,â said Frum, who is also an author and writer for The Atlantic. âThe Trump family is so far and away the most corrupt in American presidential history that you really canât think of whoâs in second place.â Eric Trump last month slammed Hunter Bidenâs role in an international company. A day later he hailed a brand new housing complex development in Scotland for the Trump Organization, which is still owned by his dad. Just weeks earlier the Air Force launched an investigation into personnel spending tens of thousands of dollars at Trump Organizationâs Turnberry golf resort in Scotland during refueling layovers at newly favored nearby Prestwick airport. Both Reid and Frum referred to Ivanka Trump obtaining several Chinese trademarks for her private company â including for voting machines â last year even as she was dealing with Chinese officials in her role as a senior White House adviser. Trumpâs eldest daughter won three trademarks in 2017 on the same day she dined with Chinese President Xi Jinping at Mar-a-Lago.Â She was granted five trademarks early this year ahead of trade talks with the Chinese. âYou have Ivanka Trump getting Chinese trademarks for voting machines,â noted Reid. âYouâve got Donald Trump Jr. in Indonesia kicking off the sale of luxury condosâ â developed with a $500 million cash infusion from a China-ownedÂ construction business. âWhat is happening here?â Ivanka Trumpâs husband, Jared Kushner, meanwhile, met with senior officers of the Anbang investment operation in China âwith a view to get hundreds of millions of dollars to rescue his desperately failing project on Fifth Avenue,â noted Frum. Kushnerâs family members solicited Chinese investment in Beijing in 2017 with a presentation including photos of their very own White House adviser and the president â and promises that Chinese could get special U.S. investor visas if they pumped money into the Kushner family business. The president complaining about corruption in government is like âhearing Al Capone complain about mob activity in Chicago,â quipped Reidâs other guest, Elizabeth Spiers, former editor of the New York Observer, which Kushner once owned. Check out the discussion in the video above.

articles.title: 2nd Whistleblower Comes Forward On Trumpâs Dealings With Ukraine: Attorneys
articles.subtitle: The intelligence official is said to have firsthand knowledge of details cited in the first whistleblowerâs complaint against Trump.
articles.author: Nina Golgowski
articles.content: A second whistleblower whoâs said to have firsthand knowledge of allegations of misconduct involving President Donald Trump and Ukraine has come forward to speak with the intelligence communityâs inspector general, two attorneys representing the whistleblowers have said. Attorney Mark Zaid told ABC NewsÂ Sunday that this intelligence official, whom his firm is also now representing, is able to speak directly about the details cited in a first whistleblowerâs complaint against Trump regarding his July 25 phone call with Ukraineâs president. Fellow attorney Andrew Bakaj also confirmed the development on Twitter, adding that their D.C. firm represents âmultiple whistleblowersâ in connection to the complaint against Trump. Zaid said he does not know if this second individual is the same officialÂ reported by The New York Times on Friday, or if it is an additional one. That official was reportedly interviewed by Intelligence Community Inspector General Michael Atkinson during an investigation into the first whistleblowerâs complaint. An additional account of Trumpâs communications with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky could potentially add credibility to that offered by the first whistleblower. The original complaint relies on secondhand knowledge but is supported by a summary of Trumpâs call with Zelensky. Trump, whoâs accused of inappropriately pressuring Zelensky to investigate one of his 2020 presidential rivals, former Vice President Joe Biden, has attempted to cast doubt on the account. Heâs described his call with Zelensky as âabsolutely perfectâ and âtotally appropriate.â

articles.title: NBCâs Chuck Todd Slams Sen. Ron Johnson For Pushing Fox News âPropagandaâ
articles.subtitle: The âMeet The Pressâ host accused the Republican lawmaker of evading his questions to âmake Donald Trump feel better.â
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: NBCâs Chuck Todd interviewed Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wisc.) about President Donald Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine, the center of an impeachment inquiry into the president, and things quickly got heated. During Sundayâs episode of âMeet The Press,â Todd asked Johnson why he said he âwincedâ when a U.S. ambassador told him that aid to Ukraine was contingent on an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden, who is a frontrunner in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But Johnson, a member of the Senate foreign relations committee, dodged the question and instead pushed a conspiracy theory about the origins of Robert Muellerâs Russia investigation. âWhat does this have to do with Ukraine?â Todd interrupted. âI have no idea why a Fox News conspiracy propaganda stuff is popping up on here.â Johnson responded by defending Trump and his supporters for being âupsetâ with the media. âThis is not about the media,â Todd cut in, growing visibly frustrated. âSenator Johnson, please. Can we please answer the question that I asked you instead of trying to make Donald Trump feel better here that youâre not criticizing him? Iâm just trying to ask a simple question.â Johnson then acknowledged that he was upset to hear military aid was being withheld until Ukraine committed to investigate Biden. âI didnât want those connected,â he said. âBut hereâs the salient point of why I came forward: When I asked the president about that, he completely denied it. ... He said, âIâd never do that.â So that is the piece of the puzzle that I am here to report today.â He added that heâs not trying to âdefendâ or âdenounceâ Trump, but that he simply wants the truth. âWeâre only dealing with the facts that we have, not the facts that you wish them to be,â Todd said. âYouâre making a choice not to believe the investigations that have taken place.â Johnson was part of the delegation, along with Energy Secretary Rick Perry, that traveled to Ukraine in May for the inauguration of the countryâs new president, Volodymyr Zelensky. After the visit, Johnson told The Wall Street Journal that he told Trump that he was confident in Zelensky as a leader. Trump later pressed Zelensky during a July phone call to look into Biden. A U.S. intelligence official filed a whistleblower complaint in August regarding the call and alleging the White House tried to cover it up. Trump claims Biden, as vice president, demanded the notoriously corrupt prosecutor general in Ukraine be fired for the purpose of impeding an investigation into a Ukrainian gas company where his son, Hunter, served on the board. No evidence has been brought to light to suggest this and Ukrainian authorities have cleared Biden of any wrongdoing. A 2016 bipartisan letter signed by Johnson and several other Republican senators expressed concern over Ukraineâs âentrenched corruptionâ and echoed Bidenâs support for reforming the prosecutor generalâs office. During a subsequent interview with Todd on Sunday, Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) said heâs âdeeply scaredâ by Republicansâ defense of Trump in the wake of the whistleblower complaint. âThat interview was just a giant green light to the president of the United States to continue to solicit foreign interference in presidential elections,â Murphy said of Johnsonâs exchange with Todd. âThis entire country should be scared that at a moment when we need patriots, what we are getting is blind partisan loyalty.â

articles.title: Pompeo Not Complying With Impeachment Inquiry, Senior House Democrat Says
articles.subtitle: Rep. Eliot Engel, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, subpoenaed the secretary of state in September.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is not complying with a subpoena issued as part of the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, said Rep. Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.), chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Engel is one of three House Democrats â along with House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff of California and House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings of Maryland â leading the impeachment inquiry. âHeâs not complying with the inquiry so far,â Engel said of Pompeo during an appearance on CBSâs âFace The Nationâ on Sunday. âWeâre hoping that there are discussions that are ongoing and weâre hoping that he will comply.â Pompeo has defended the presidentâs push for Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a front-runner in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. He acknowledged last week that he was one of several U.S. officials on the line during Trumpâs July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. The call became the subject of a subsequent whistleblower complaint filed in August by a U.S. intelligence official that prompted House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) to open a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump. Engelâs committee issued a subpoena for Pompeo on Sept. 27 that requested he make five State Department officials available for depositions and turn over a slew of documents related to Trumpâs Ukraine dealings.Â The deadline for those documents was Friday. In response, Pompeo accused Engel of trying to âbullyâ and âintimidateâ department officials and claimed the records requested are potentially privileged and restricted. Engel said Sunday that Pompeoâs accusations of intimidation are âlaughableâ given the ânumerous complaintsâ from State Department staffers who have alleged that the Trump administration has discriminated against them. âPeople who were summarily let go or fired because they were deemed to be the wrong political persuasion or the wrong ethnic persuasion,â Engel told CBS. âI find it really laughable that the secretary of state suddenly has this great concern for the State Department.â The State Department did not immediately respond to HuffPostâs request for comment.

articles.title: Republican On House Intelligence Committee: âWhy Should I Careâ About 2nd Whistleblower?
articles.subtitle: âIt does not matter,â Rep. Chris Stewart said about a second whistleblower coming forward with information on Trumpâs Ukraine call.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: Rep. Chris Stewart (R-Utah), a member of one of the three House committees investigating President Donald Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine, said heâs ânot at allâ concerned that a second whistleblower has come forward. Attorneys representing the first whistleblower, a U.S. intelligence operative whose identity has not been publicly released, confirmed Sunday that a second person has corroborated some of the allegations regarding Trumpâs July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. During Sundayâs episode of âFox News Sunday,â host Chris Wallace reported that the second whistleblower presented the inspector general for the intelligence community with firsthand information about the call. âDoes that concern you?â he asked Stewart, a member of the House Intelligence Committee. âWell, actually, not at all,â Stewart said.Â âOne of our concerns has always been there hasnât been firsthand knowledge of this. The first whistleblower â virtually everything he accused was second and thirdhand knowledge.â âBut Chris, it does not matter,â he continued, adding that he believed the second whistleblower would only confirm the call happened. âWhy should I care at all what his perspective ... of this transcript is?â Wallace reminded Stewart that the first whistleblower expressed concern over more than just the phone call and alleged Trump may have withheld military aid in an effort to get Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, his potential Democratic opponent in the 2020 election. âBut Chris, thatâs just not true,â Stewart said of the first whistleblowerâs accusations, claiming Trump never used military aid as a âquid pro quo.â The whistleblower complaint prompted House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) to announce a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump, who has defended his conversation with Zelensky as âperfectâ and last week called on China to investigate Biden as well. He has claimed that his interest in investigating Biden is about âcorruptionâ and has nothing to do with the 2020 election. âCan you tell me of any other instance during the time President Trump has been in office where he asked a foreign leader to investigate a specific American on the issue of corruption?â Wallace asked Stewart on Sunday. The congressman responded that Attorney General William Barr had done so. âNo, no, no,â Wallace interrupted. âI said President Trump. Can you tell me of another instance where President Trump on a conversation ... has publicly or privately asked a foreign leader to investigate a specific American?â Stewart claimed thereâs âno differenceâ between Trump and Barr asking a foreign leader to investigate an American on allegations of corruption.

articles.title: Jim Jordan Doesnât âThinkâ Trump Did Something He Actually Did On Camera
articles.subtitle: The GOP congressman repeatedly claimed that the president wasnât serious when he said China should investigate Joe Biden.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) repeatedly denied on Sunday that President Donald Trump was serious about his public call for China to launch an investigation of former Vice President Joe Biden, despite the fact that he proposed the idea on camera. During an appearance on ABC Newsâ âThis Week,â Jordan dodged multiple questions over whether it is appropriate for the president to seek assistance from a foreign government in probing his political rival, claiming it was just the media being âall spun upâ about it. âI donât think he really meant go investigate,â he told host George Stephanopoulos. âDo you think China is going to investigate him?â âI donât know if China is going to investigate him,âÂ Stephanopoulos replied. âI know the president asked China to investigate him.â Though there is now an escalating impeachment inquiry into the president â fueled by evidence that he pressured Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in July to investigate Biden and his son over unsubstantiated corruption allegations â Jordan asserted that he knows China wonât take part. Stephanopoulos again pushed the congressman to answer the question. âWhy canât you answer yes or no, do you think itâs appropriate?â he asked. âBecause I donât think thatâs what he did,â Jordan said. âI donât think thatâs what he did.â As Trump left the White House on Thursday on his way to Florida, he told reporters, âChina should start an investigation into the Bidens, because what happened in China is just about as bad as what happened with Ukraine.â There was no sign he was joking, and Trump has made no remarks indicating it was not a genuine suggestion. There remains no evidence of any wrongdoing on the part of the Bidens, though Trump allies like Jordan have continued to support the president despite the release of a whistleblower complaint that has roiled the White House. The report, which was filed by a member of the intelligence community in August, cites Trumpâs contact with Ukraine as a proof he âis using the power of his office to solicit interference from a foreign country in the 2020 U.S. election.â On Sunday, Andrew Bakaj, the whistleblowerâs attorney, confirmed on Twitter that he and his legal team are representing âmultiple whistleblowers in connectionâ with the complaint.

articles.title: White House Officials Absent From Sunday Shows As Ukraine Controversy Grows
articles.subtitle: Trumpâs facing an impeachment inquiry and not a single White House official signed on to answer questions about it.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: As Sunday morning political talk shows debated and discussed the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump and his dealings with Ukraine, there was a glaring absence from their lineups: White House officials. Last week, senior White House adviser Stephen Miller defended Trump on âFox News Sunday.â Secretary of State Mike Pompeo gave interviews to ABCâs âThis Weekâ and CBSâs âFace the Nationâ the week before. This week birthed several major developments regarding impeachment and Trumpâs push for foreign leaders to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, his potential Democratic opponent in the 2020 presidential election. But not a single White House official made the Sunday morning rounds this week on theÂ âbig fiveâ networks: ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox and CNN. The White House did not immediately respond to HuffPostâs request for comment. Jake Tapper, host of CNNâs âState of the Union,â said Sunday that his show invited the White House to participate, but it did not offer a guest. Trumpâs personal attorneys,Â Rudy Giuliani and Jay Sekulow, as well as top Republicans in the House and Senate were also invited but either declined or did not respond, he said. A spokesperson for Fox News said the network was unable to book a White House official for Sundayâs program. âWe reached out for relevant White House guests and we were told they were unavailable, so we went with bipartisan members of the House Intelligence committee leading the impeachment inquiry,â the spokesperson told HuffPost in a statement. ABC, CBS and NBC did not immediately respond to HuffPostâs requests for comment about whether White House officials also snubbed their programs. The lack of White House officials on Sunday shows didnât stop Trump and his allies from rolling out his defense. Republican lawmakers appeared ready to push the White Houseâs narrative on Sunday, shrugging off news that a second whistleblower had come forward with firsthand information about Trumpâs July call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, the center of the impeachment inquiry. Rep. Chris Stewart (R-Utah), a member of the House Intelligence Committee thatâs investigating Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine, told âFox News Sundayâ that heâs ânot at allâ concerned about a second whistleblower. Giuliani appeared on Fox News late Sunday morning, where he shouted at host Howard Kurtz for pushing back on his Ukraine conspiracy theories. âCould you just listen for one second?â Giuliani shouted at Kurtz, who later shook his head in disbelief. âYou donât let me get a sentence out. You contradict me immediately.â Itâs unclear whether ABC, CBS and NBC refrained from inviting Giuliani on their programs Sunday after Bidenâs campaign sent a letter to the âbig fiveâ networks last week urging them to not invite the former New York City mayor as a guest. âGiving Rudy Giuliani valuable time on your air to push these lies in the first place is a disservice to your audience and a disservice to journalism,â a pair of top Biden advisers wrote in the letter. Trump, whose White House hasnât given a press briefing in months, fired off a spate of tweets during the Sunday morning shows that attacked Democrats and doubled down on his call for Biden to be investigated. âIt is INCREDIBLE to watch and read the Fake News and how they pull out all stops to protect Sleepy Joe Biden and his thrown out of the Military son, Hunter,â the president tweeted. âAs lawyers & others have stated, as President, I have an OBLIGATION to look into possible, or probable, CORRUPTION!â None of the Republican guests on this weekâs Sunday morning talk shows offered a direct answer when asked if there was a record of Trump asking foreign leaders to investigate any other American besides Biden on corruption. This article has been updated to include comment from Fox News.

articles.title: 2020 Democrats Demand Answers In Botham Jean Witness Death: âHorrificâ
articles.subtitle: Joshua Brown, a key witness in the trial of ex-Dallas police officer Amber Guyger, was shot dead on Friday.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Democratic presidential candidates are demanding answers following the death of a key witness in the trial of Amber Guyger, a white former Dallas police officer convicted of killing an unarmed 26-year-old Black man in his own home. Joshua Brown, 28, was gunned down on Friday night at South Side Flats, an apartment complex where he was a neighbor to Botham Jean, The Dallas Morning News reported. In September 2018, Guyger shot Jean to death, claiming she entered the wrong unit and mistook him for an intruder. She later pleaded not guilty. On Wednesday, Guyger, 31, was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Now, politicians want to know what happened to Brown. âIâm heartsick for Joshua Brownâs family and friends,â Massachusetts Sen.Â Elizabeth Warren tweeted Friday. âHe bravely stepped forward and testified to bring some justice for Botham Jean, and peace for his family. We need answers â and Joshua Brown and his family need justice.â Warrenâs message echoed that of California Sen. Kamala Harris, who praised Brownâs âselflessness and courage,â and offered prayers for his family and community. âWe demand answers,â she said. New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, former Texas Rep. Beto OâRourke, former Housing and Urban Development SecretaryÂ JuliÃ¡n Castro, billionaire hedge fund manager Tom SteyerÂ and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg have also spoken out, disturbed by the second killing. In his remarks, Castro called for âa transparent investigation the people of Dallas can trust.â During Guygerâs trial, she claimed that upon seeing Jean, she said, âLet me see your handsâ before she shot him. However, Brown,Â who lived across the hall, testified that he did not hear her say any such commands, instead describing the sound as âtwo people meeting by surprise,â according to the Morning News. Jeanâs death sparked outrage as yet another example of lethal use of force by law enforcement on a person of color. In a Facebook post on Saturday, Lee Merrit, the lawyer for Jeanâs family, said the slaying of Brown âunderscores the reality of the black experience in America.â âA former athlete turned entrepreneur â Brown lived in constant fear that he could be the next victim of gun violence, either state sanctioned or otherwise,â he wrote. âWe have more work to do deal with the constant threats to our community both from within and without. Brown deserves the same justice he sought to ensure the Jean family. The Dallas County criminal justice system must [be] mobilized to identify his killer and see that he is held accountable for this murder.â This article has been updated with Buttigiegâs statement. CORRECTION: This article initially referred to Booker as a senator from New York. He represents New Jersey.

articles.title: John Brennan: CIA Would Call U.S. âVery Corruptâ If It Were Another Country
articles.subtitle: âItâs no longer a democracy if an autocrat has it in his hands,â the former CIA director warned.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Former CIA Director John Brennan said on Sunday that if the political turmoil plaguing the White House were happening in another nation, the American intelligence community would offer a grim assessment. âWe would look at it as a very corrupt government that is under the sway right now of this powerful individual who has been able to just corrupt the institutions and the laws of that country,â he told NBC Newsâ Chuck Todd during a âMeet the Pressâ appearance. Brennan, who is now a senior national security and intelligence analyst for NBC, raised alarm over Republicansâ refusal to speak out against President Donald Trump, who allegedly sought foreign interference in the 2020 election, according to a whistleblower complaint filed in August by an anonymous member of the intelligence community. Prior to Brennanâs interview, Todd spoke with Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wisc.), who stonewalled his questions and launched into a conspiracy-laden defense of the president in which he took aim at Brennan, who is a frequent critic of Trump. His remarks strayed so far from the topic at hand that a visibly exasperated Todd slammed the senator for peddling Fox News âpropagandaâ on air. Brennan, who subsequently hit back at Johnsonâs remarks, cautioned that he is part of the problem. âItâs no longer a democracy if an autocrat has it in his hands, and people like Johnson and others are putty in his hands, which means that the democratic principles on which this country [was] founded are eroding right now,â Brennan said. At the center of scandal swirling around Trump is a July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in which he pressed Zelensky to assist both Attorney General William Barr and lawyer Rudy Giuliani with a probe of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, based on unsubstantiated corruption accusations. At the time of the discussion, U.S. aid to Ukraine was being withheld. On Friday, The Wall Street Journal reported that Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, described the situation to Johnson as a quid pro quo in which the aid was contingent on an agreement to investigate the Bidens. Johnson told the Journal that he then confronted Trump about the matter, and Trump denied that was the case. Appearing uncomfortable with any suggestion of a deal, Johnson told the Journal heÂ âwincedâ at the notion. âMy reaction was: Oh, God. I donât want to see those two things combined,â he said. On Sunday, Johnson refused to further explain this concern, claiming Trumpâs administration has been âsabotaged from the day after election.â

articles.title: Colin Powell: Republicans Terrified Of Speaking Out Need To âGet A Gripâ
articles.subtitle: The former secretary of state is urging members of the GOP to adopt a see-something, say-something approach on Trumpâs behavior.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Former Secretary of State Colin Powell, a self-described moderate Republican, is warning the GOP to âget a grip on itselfâ and stand up to President Donald Trump rather than worrying about the political ramifications. âRight now, Republican leaders and members of the Congress â both Senate and the House â are holding back because theyâre terrified of what will happen to any one of them if they speak out,â Powell told CNNâs Fareed Zakaria during an interview at Ohioâs New Albany Community Foundation last week that aired Sunday. âWill they lose a primary?â As Democrats escalate their impeachment inquiry into Trumpâs alleged solicitation of foreign interference in the 2020 election, Powell urged Republicans to place the nationâs best interest ahead of party politics. âWhen they see things that are not right, they need to say something about it because our foreign policy is in shambles right now, in my humble judgment, and I see things happening that are hard to understand,â he said. âThe Republican party has got to get a grip on itself,â Former Secy. of State Colin Powell on the state of the current GOP. âRepublican leaders and members of the Congressâ¦ are holding back because theyâre terrified of what will happen [to] any one of them if they speak out.â pic.twitter.com/zkCScy8uA1 On Friday, Trump conceded that House Democrats âhave the votesâ to move forward with impeachment, though he remains confident Senate Republicans would hold firm in their support for him. âTheyâre all in line,â the president said of Democrats. âBecause even though many of them donât want to vote, they have no choice. They have to follow their leadership. And then weâll get it to the Senate, and weâre going to win.â At the center of the Houseâs inquiry is an August whistleblower complaint released last month in which a still-anonymous member of the intelligence community flagged a phone call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. A summary of the July call revealed that Trump repeatedly pressed Zelensky to aid lawyer Rudy Giuliani and Attorney General William Barr with a corruption probe of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter. The request was based on unfounded allegations, and there remains no evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens, though Trump has attempted to create suspicion of his political rival ahead of the election. On Sunday, Andrew Bakaj, the whistleblowerâs attorney, confirmed in a tweet that his firm and legal team are now representing multiple whistleblowers connected to the report.

articles.title: Dozens Of Former National Security Officials Pen Letter Defending Ukraine Whistleblower
articles.subtitle: The letter, signed by 90 former officials, stressed the importance of protecting the whistleblowerâs identity, The Wall Street Journal reported.
articles.author: Sanjana Karanth
articles.content:
Ninety former national security officials penned an open letter Sunday to the public defending the whistleblower in the Trump-Ukraine scandal, stressing the importance of protecting the person and their identity. The letter is signed by ex-national security officials who served under both Democratic and Republican presidents, including President Donald Trump himself, The Wall Street Journal first reported. The whistleblower remains anonymous, though itâs been revealed that the person works in the U.S. governmentâs intelligence community. âA responsible whistleblower makes all Americans safer by ensuring that serious wrongdoing can be investigated and addressed, thus advancing the cause of national security to which we have devoted our careers,â the former officials, including former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, former CIA Director John Brennan and former Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, wrote in the letter. New: 90 former national security officials who served under Dem and GOP presidents, including Trump, publish open letter saying whistleblower followed the law and deserves protection + anonymity.

âA responsible whistleblower makes all Americans safer.â
 https://t.co/wACj12ZP34 pic.twitter.com/PMsrmqMuRV The letter comes as Trump and his allies denounce the whistleblowerâs complaint regarding the presidentâs July 25 phone call with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky. The complaint, which cites several unnamed senior White House officials, accuses the president of pressuring Zelensky to investigate 2020 election rival Joe Biden, whose son Hunter previously had business dealings in Ukraine. The complaint led the HouseÂ to launch a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump. A summary of the call released by the White House largely corroborates the whistleblowerâs allegations. Trump, who has repeatedly described the call as âperfect,â later said on camera that both Ukraine and China should investigate Biden for unsubstantiated claims of corruption. Trump has pushed a conspiracy theory suggesting the rules for whistleblowers used to require firsthand information and changed before the Ukraine whistleblower came forward.Â But experts, including the intelligence communityâs inspector general who reviewed the complaint, said whistleblowers have always been allowed to report on secondhand information. The president has also falsely accused the whistleblower of âtreasonâ because of the complaint, making veiled threats that the whistleblower should be âdealt withâ in violent ways. Trump has repeatedly said he âdeservedâ to meet the whistleblower and find out the personâs identity. The former officials who penned the letter said they âapplaud the whistleblower.â âAs such, he or she has by law the right â and indeed the responsibility â to make known, through appropriate channels, indications of serious wrongdoing,â they wrote. âThat is precisely what this whistleblower did; and we applaud the whistleblower not only for living up to that responsibility but also for using precisely the channels made available by federal law for raising such concerns.â They said a whistleblower should be âprotected from certain egregious forms of retaliation.â âWhatever oneâs view of the matters discussed in the whistleblowerâs complaint, all Americans should be united in demanding that all branches of our government and all outlets of our media protect this whistleblower and his or her identity,â they wrote. Federal law says Intelligence Community Inspector General Michael Atkinson cannot disclose the whistleblowerâs identity without the personâs consent, unless it is âunavoidable during the course of the investigation.â The law also says the whistleblower should not face any âaction constituting a reprisal, or threat of reprisalâ unless the whistleblower falsified the report. Members of Congress, including Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), have been trying to keep the whistleblowerâs identity anonymous as lawmakers in the House Intelligence Committee work with the whistleblowerâs attorneys to set up a meeting. The whistleblowerâs lead attorney, Andrew Bakaj, wrote in a Sept. 29 letter that the whistleblowerâs lawyers have âserious concernsâ about their clientâs safety. Earlier Sunday, Bakaj and fellow attorney Mark Zaid confirmed that they are representing a second whistleblower from the intelligence community who they say has firsthand knowledge of Trumpâs misconduct cited in the original whistleblowerâs complaint. Several former national security officials who were named in the letter posted on Twitter about their decision to sign it. âAll Americans should be united in demanding that all
branches of our government & all outlets of our media protect this whistleblower & his or her identity.â

90 former senior national security officials sign new open letter to the American people: https://t.co/OUlUyLs68u ð¬ Whistleblowers have every right to securely discuss their concerns with proper authorities and be protected when they do so. https://t.co/gIfMnGKqnN âWhatever oneâs view of the matters discussed in the whistleblowerâs complaint, all Americans should be united indemanding that all branches of our government and all outlets of our media protect this whistleblower and his or her identity.â https://t.co/UN73P6Lokr

articles.title: Trump Allies Pressed Ukraine Over Gas Firm
articles.subtitle: The affair shows how those with ties to Trump and his administration were pursuing business deals in Ukraine that went far beyond advancing the presidentâs personal political interests.
articles.content: KYIV, Ukraine (AP) â As Rudy Giuliani was pushing Ukrainian officials last spring to investigate one of Donald Trumpâs main political rivals, a group of individuals with ties to the president and his personal lawyer were also active in the former Soviet republic. Their aims were profit, not politics. This circle of businessmen and Republican donors touted connections to Giuliani and Trump while trying to install new management at the top of Ukraineâs massive state gas company. Their plan was to then steer lucrative contracts to companies controlled by Trump allies, according to two people with knowledge of their plans. Their plan hit a snag after Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko lost his reelection bid to Volodymyr Zelenskiy, whose conversation with Trump about former Vice President Joe Biden is now at the center of the House impeachment inquiry of Trump. But the effort to install a friendlier management team at the helm of the gas company, Naftogaz, would soon be taken up with Ukraineâs new president by U.S. Energy Secretary Rick Perry, whose slate of candidates included a fellow Texan who is one of Perryâs past political donors. Itâs unclear if Perryâs attempts to replace board members at Naftogaz were coordinated with the Giuliani allies pushing for a similar outcome, and no one has alleged that there is criminal activity in any of these efforts. And itâs unclear what role, if any, Giuliani had in helping his clients push to get gas sales agreements with the state-owned company. But the affair shows how those with ties to Trump and his administration were pursuing business deals in Ukraine that went far beyond advancing the presidentâs personal political interests. It also raises questions about whether Trump allies were mixing business and politics just as Republicans were calling for a probe of Biden and his son Hunter, who served five years on the board of another Ukrainian energy company, Burisma. On Friday, according to the news site Axios, Trump told a group of Republican lawmakers that it had been Perry who had prompted the phone call in which Trump asked Zelenskiy for a âfavorâ regarding Biden. Axios cited a source saying Trump said Perry had asked Trump to make the call to discuss âsomething about an LNG (liquefied natural gas) plant.â While itâs unclear whether Trumpâs remark Friday referred specifically to the behind-the-scenes maneuvers this spring involving the multibillion-dollar state gas company, The Associated Press has interviewed four people with direct knowledge of the attempts to influence Naftogaz, and their accounts show Perry playing a key role in the effort. Three of the four spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation. The fourth is an American businessman with close ties to the Ukrainian energy sector. A spokeswoman for the U.S. Energy Department said Perry, a former Texas governor and Republican presidential candidate, was not advancing anyoneâs personal interests. She said his conversations with Ukrainian officials about Naftogaz were part of his efforts to reform the countryâs energy sector and create an environment where Western companies can do business. The Trump and Giuliani allies driving the attempt to change the senior management at Naftogazt, however, appear to have had inside knowledge of the U.S. governmentâs plans in Ukraine. For example, they told people that Trump would replace the U.S. ambassador there months before she was actually recalled to Washington, according to three of the individuals interviewed by the AP. One of the individuals said he was so concerned by the whole affair that he reported it to a U.S. Embassy official in Ukraine months ago. Ukraine, a resource-rich nation that sits on the geographic and symbolic border between Russia and the West, has long been plagued by corruption and government dysfunction, making it a magnet for foreign profiteers. At the center of the Naftogaz plan, according to three individuals familiar with the details, were three such businessmen: two Soviet-born Florida real estate entrepreneurs, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, and an oil magnate from Boca Raton, Florida, named Harry Sargeant III. Parnas and Fruman have made hundreds of thousands of dollars in political donations to Republicans, including $325,000 to a Trump-allied political action committee in 2018. This helped the relatively unknown entrepreneurs gain access to top levels of the Republican Party â including meetings with Trump at the White House and Mar-a-Lago. The two have also faced lawsuits from disgruntled investors over unpaid debts. During the same period they were pursuing the Naftogaz deal, the two were coordinating with Giuliani to set up meetings with Ukrainian government officials and push for an investigation of the Bidens. Sargeant, his wife and corporate entities tied to the family have donated at least $1.2 million to Republican campaigns and PACs over the last 20 years, including $100,000 in June to the Trump Victory Fund, according to federal and state campaign finance records. He has also served as finance chair of the Florida state GOP, and gave nearly $14,000 to Giulianiâs failed 2008 presidential campaign. In early March, Fruman, Parnas and Sargeant were touting a plan to replace Naftogaz CEO Andriy Kobolyev with another senior executive at the company, Andrew Favorov, according to two individuals who spoke to the AP as well as a memorandum about the meeting that was later submitted to the U.S. Embassy in Kiev. Going back to the Obama administration, the U.S. Energy Department and the State Department have long supported efforts to import American natural gas into Ukraine to reduce the countryâs dependence on Russia. The three approached Favorov with the idea while the Ukrainian executive was attending an energy industry conference in Texas. Parnas and Fruman told him they had flown in from Florida on a private jet to recruit him to be their partner in a new venture to export up to 100 tanker shipments a year of U.S. liquefied gas into Ukraine, where Naftogaz is the largest distributor, according to two people briefed on the details. Sargeant told Favorov that he regularly meets with Trump at Mar-a-Lago and that the gas-sales plan had the presidentâs full support, according to the two people who said Favorov recounted the discussion to them. These conversations were recounted to AP by Dale W. Perry, an American who is a former business partner of Favorov. He told AP in an interview that Favorov described the meeting to him soon after it happened and that Favorov perceived it to be a shakedown. Perry, who is no relation to the energy secretary, is the managing partner of Energy Resources of Ukraine, which currently has business agreements to import natural gas and electricity to Ukraine. A second person who spoke on condition of anonymity also confirmed to the AP that Favorov had recounted details of the Houston meeting to him. According to Dale Perry and the other person, Favorov said Parnas told him Trump planned to remove U.S. Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch and replace her with someone more open to aiding their business interests. Dale Perry told the AP he was so concerned about the efforts to change the management at Naftogaz and to get rid of Yovanovitch that he reported what he had heard to Suriya Jayanti, a State Department foreign service officer stationed at the U.S. Embassy in Kyiv who focuses on the energy industry. He also wrote a detailed memo about Favorovâs account, dated April 12, which was shared with another current State Department official. Perry recently provided a copy of the April memo to AP. Jayanti declined to provide comment. Favorov also declined to comment. On March 24, Giuliani and Parnas gathered at the Trump International Hotel in Washington with Healy E. Baumgardner, a former Trump campaign adviser who once served as deputy communications director for Giulianiâs presidential campaign and as a communications official during the George W. Bush administration. She is now listed as the CEO of 45 Energy Group, a Houston-based energy company whose website describes it as a âgovernment relations, public affairs and business development practice group.â This was a couple of weeks after the Houston meeting with Favorov, the Naftogaz executive. Giuliani, Parnas and Baumgardner were there to make a business pitch involving gas deals in the former Soviet bloc to a potential investor. This time, according to Giuliani, the deals that were discussed involved Uzbekistan, not Ukraine. âI have not pursued a deal in the Ukraine. I donât know about a deal in the Ukraine. I would not do a deal in the Ukraine now, obviously,â said Giuliani, reached while attending a playoff baseball game between the New York Yankees and Minnesota Twins. âThere is absolutely no proof that I did it, because I didnât do it.â During this meeting, Parnas again repeated that Yovanovitch, the U.S. ambassador in Kyiv, would soon be replaced, according to a person with direct knowledge of the gathering. She was removed two months later. Giuliani, who serves as Trumpâs personal lawyer and has no official role in government, acknowledged Friday that he was among those pushing the president to replace the ambassador, a career diplomat with a history of fighting corruption. âThe ambassador to Ukraine was replaced,â he said. âI did play a role in that.â But Giuliani refused to discuss the details of his business dealings, or whether he helped his associates in their push to forge gas sales contracts with the Ukrainian company. He did describe Sergeant as a friend and referred to Parnas and Fruman as his clients in a tweet in May. As part of their impeachment inquiry, House Democrats have subpoenaed Giuliani for documents and communications related to dozens of people, including Favorov, Parnas, Fruman and Baumgardnerâs 45 Energy Group. Baumgardner issued a written statement, saying: âWhile I wonât comment on business discussions, I will say this: this political assault on private business by the Democrats in Congress is complete harassment and an invasion of privacy that should scare the hell out of every American business owner.â Sargeant did not respond to a voice message left at a number listed for him at an address in Boca Raton. John Dowd, a former Trump attorney who now represents Parnas and Fruman, said it was actually the Naftogaz executives who approached his clients about making a deal. He says they then met with Rick Perry to get the Energy Department on board. âThe people from the company solicited my clients because Igor is in the gas business, and they asked them, and they flew to Washington and they solicited,â Dowd said. âThey sat down and talked about it. And then it was presented to Secretary Perry to see if they could get it together. âIt wasnât a shakedown; it was an attempt to do legitimate business that didnât work out.â In May, Rick Perry traveled to Kyiv to serve as the senior U.S. government representative at the inauguration of the countyâs new president. In a private meeting with Zelenskiy, Perry pressed the Ukrainian president to fire members of the Naftogaz advisory board. Attendees left the meeting with the impression that Perry wanted to replace the American representative, Amos Hochstein, a former diplomat and energy representative who served in the Obama administration, with someone âreputable in Republican circles,â according to someone who was in the room. A second meeting during the trip, at a Kyiv hotel, included Ukrainian officials and energy sector people. There, Perry made clear that the Trump administration wanted to see the entire Naftogaz supervisory board replaced, according to a person who attended both meetings. Perry again referenced the list of advisers that he had given Zelenskiy, and it was widely interpreted that he wanted Robert Bleyzer, a Ukrainian-American businessman from Texas, to join the newly formed board, the person said. Also on the list was Robert Bensh, another Texan who frequently works in Ukraine, the Energy Department confirmed. Gordon D. Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, and Kurt D. Volker, then the State Departmentâs special envoy to Ukraine, were also in the room, according to photographs reviewed by AP. The person, who spoke on condition of anonymity due to fear of retaliation, said he was floored by the American requests because the person had always viewed the U.S. government âas having a higher ethical standard.â The Naftogaz supervisory board is supposed to be selected by the Ukrainian presidentâs Cabinet in consultation with international institutions, including the International Monetary Fund, the United States and the European Union. It must be approved by the Ukrainian Cabinet. Ukrainian officials perceived Perryâs push to swap out the board as circumventing that established process, according to the person in the room. U.S. Energy Department spokeswoman Shaylyn Hynes said Perry had consistently called for the modernization of Ukraineâs business and energy sector in an effort to create an environment that will incentivize Western companies to do business there. She said Perry delivered that same message in the May meeting with Zelenskiy. âWhat he did not do is advocate for the business interests of any one individual or company,â Hynes said Saturday. âThat is fiction being pushed by those who are disingenuously seeking to advance a nefarious narrative that does not exist.â Hynes said the Ukrainian government had requested U.S. recommendations to advise the country on energy matters, and Perry provided those recommendations. She confirmed Bleyzer was on the list. Bleyzer, whose company is based in Houston, did not respond on Saturday to a voicemail seeking comment. Bensh also did not respond to a phone message. As a former Texas governor, Perry has always had close ties to the oil and gas industry. He appointed Bleyzer to a two-year term on a state technologies fund board in 2009. The following year, records show Bleyzer donated $20,000 to Perryâs reelection campaign. Zelenskiyâs office declined to comment on Saturday. In an interview Friday with the Christian Broadcasting Network, Perry said that âas God as my witnessâ he never discussed Biden or his son in meetings with Ukrainian or U.S. officials, including Trump or Giuliani. âThis has been a very intense, a very focused push to get Ukraine to clean up the corruption,â Perry said in the interview. âI canât go in good faith and tell a U.S. company, go and invest here, go and be involved if the corruption is ongoing.â He did confirm he had had a conversation with Giuliani by phone, but a spokeswoman for the energy secretary declined to say when that call was or whether the two had discussed Naftogaz. ___ Biesecker and Lardner reported from Washington. ___ Follow Associated Press investigative reporters Desmond Butler at http://twitter.com/desmondbutler, Michael Biesecker at http://twitter.com/mbieseck, and Richard Lardner at http://twitter.com/rplardner ___ Contact APâs global investigative team at Investigative@ap.org.

articles.title: White House Ordered Not To Destroy Records Of Trumpâs Interactions With Foreign Leaders
articles.subtitle: Judge Amy Berman Jackson also demanded preservation of all records of officials attempting to âreturn, âclaw back,â âlock downâ or recallâ information.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: A federal judge has ordered the White House not to destroy records relating to President Donald Trumpâs interactions with foreign heads of state, some of which have become the focus of a formal impeachment inquiry. U.S. District Judge Amy Berman JacksonÂ issued the orderÂ Thursday to safeguard records of Trumpâs âmeetings, phone calls, and other communications with foreign leadersâ â as well as ârecords reflecting policies and practicesâ regarding such record-keeping. The judge also ordered the preservation of âall records of efforts by White House or other executive branch officials to âreturn, âclaw back,â âlock downâ or recall White House records.â A lawsuit against Trump and the Executive Office of the President demanding the records be safeguarded was filed in May, long before the impeachment inquiry, by watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, the National Security Archive and the Society for Historians of American Foreign Relations. It argued that the White House was ignoring the Presidential Records Act, which requires the presidentâs official records to be preserved. The law, âenacted in the wake of President Nixonâs resignation and attempt to seize control of his presidential records, reflects Congressâs judgment that presidential records are owned by the United States on behalf of the American people,â the suit states. The suit was filed after media reports that no records existed for at least five Trump meetings with Russian President Vladimir Putin, one meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong UnÂ and a meeting with Saudi Prince Mohammad bin Salman. A July phone call by Trump to Ukraineâs president pushing him to launch an investigation into his political rival Joe Biden and his son â while he was suspending aid to the nation â is now the focus of a House impeachment inquiry. Trump on Thursday also called on China to initiate a probe of the Bidens. The whistleblower complaint that triggered the inquiry alleges that senior White House officials attempted to âlock downâ records of Trumpâs phone call to keep it hidden. In light of that information, the lawsuitâs lawyers requested a temporary restraining order. But Jackson opted not to issue one after government attorneys finallyÂ âvoluntarily agreedâ in a court filing on Wednesday to âpreserve the material.â

articles.title: Twitter Users Turn Trumpâs New Nickname For Nancy Pelosi Right Back At Him
articles.subtitle: The presidentâs latest attempt at taunting the House speaker didnât exactly go as planned.
articles.author: Ed Mazza
articles.content: President Donald Trump tried to break out a new nickname for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.). Instead, critics are using it on him. Trump has repeatedly and without evidence accused House Intelligence Committee ChairÂ Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), who is leading the impeachment inquiry, of treason, a federal crime that carries a potential death sentence. Now, Trump is claiming the speaker is âevery bit as guilty,â accusing her of âhigh crimesâ and âtreason.â He also called her ânervous Nancy,â a nickname he attempted briefly in June but quickly abandoned. He tweeted: Trump was slammed over the baseless accusations, with critics accusing him of trying to distract from the ongoing impeachment probe involving his demand that the Ukrainian president investigate 2020 rival Joe Biden. And many pointed out that someone appears to be getting nervous â but itâs not Pelosi:

articles.title: Russian Embassy Boasts Of Trumpâs Reported Dismissal Of Moscow Role In UK Poisoning
articles.subtitle: Russiaâs embassy in the U.K. said the report that Trump doubted Kremlin involvement in a nerve agent attack on an ex-Russian spy was âthe best evidence.â
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: The Russian Embassy in Britain gloated in a tweet Sunday that President Donald Trump reportedly disputed Moscowâs involvement in a nerve agent attack in England â despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary amassed by British intelligence. The tweet boasted that Trumpâs doubt about a plot to poison a former Russian spy and his daughter was the âbest evidence that no evidence of Russian involvement exists.â The embassyâs tweet linked to an article published Sunday in The Guardian reporting that Trump informed former British Prime Minister Theresa May in a tense phone call last year that he didnât believe the Russian government was involved in the poisoningÂ of a former Russian spy and his daughter in Salisbury. The newspaper cited a report in The Washington Post that Trump âharanguedâ May about Britainâs contribution to NATO â then disputed Russian involvement in the murder attempt. Sergei Skripal, his daughter, Yulia, and at least one police officer were poisoned last year by the Soviet military-grade nerve agentÂ Novichok.Â Known Russian agents were seen on security video in an area where British officials believe the attack was launched. They claimed they were on vacation. The Skripals survived after weeks of hospitalization. Scottish National party member Stephen Gethins, a member of the Foreign Affairs Select Committee, told The Guardian that the evidence of Russian involvement in the poisoning âis overwhelming; It was an appalling chemical weapons attack that should horrify us all.â Information about Trumpâs call with May included in a Post story on Friday recounting a string of stunning or embarrassing Trump interactions with foreign leaders that left some staffers âhorrified.â The newspaper, citing unnamed sources, said staffers were shocked by how Trump fawned over Russian President Vladimir Putin. He told the Russian leader â responsible for what American authorities have called sweeping interference in the 2016 U.S presidential election, a great leader, and apologized for not calling earlier.

articles.title: âFox & Friendsâ Host Slams Trumpâs Abandonment Of Syrian Kurds
articles.subtitle: Co-host Brian Kilmeade, joined by Sen. Lindsay Graham, criticized the presidentâs move to withdraw support for Kurdish fighters ahead of a Turkish military assault.
articles.author: Jenna Amatulli
articles.content:
âFox & Friendsâ host Brian Kilmeade criticized President Donald Trump Monday for withdrawing support for Kurdish fighters and removing troops from northeastern Syria ahead of a Turkish military assault. âWhat kind of a message is that to the next ally that wants to side with us?â asked Kilmeade, normally a reliable Trump defender, who explained the Kurds have been loyal American allies. âI hope the president will rethink this.â Co-host Steve Doocy chimed in to argue that Trumpâs move fulfills a campaign promise to end wars in other countries. To that, Kilmeade responded: âAbandon our allies? Thatâs a campaign promise?â âAll we did is arm them and they did all the work. And now we say, âGood luck. Good luck surviving,ââ said Kilmeade. âDisaster.â Brian Kilmeade fights with his co-hosts over Trump throwing Syrian Kurds under the bus: âWhat kind of message is that to the next ally that wants to side with us? ... All we did is arm them, and they did all the work. And now we say âgood luck. Good luck surviving.â Disaster.â pic.twitter.com/ktyDqsM4lS The White House announced on Sunday that Turkey would soon invade northern Syria, putting the Kurdish fighters â an ethnic group led by the Syrian Democratic Forces who have been longtime allies with the U.S. campaign against the Islamic State group â on unsure ground. U.S. troops âwill not support or be involved in the operationâ and âwill no longer be in the immediate area,â White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said in a statement after a call between Trump and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Turkey will take custodyÂ of foreign fighters captured in the U.S.-led campaign against the Islamic State held by American-supported Kurdish forces, Grisham added. Turkey sees Kurdish forces as a terrorist insurgency, and has long wanted the U.S. to sever ties with the group. Trump announced in December 2018 that heâd be withdrawing troops from Syria, but relented after fierce criticism. The announcement led Jim Mattis to resign as defense secretary and then-national security adviser John Bolton to take steps attempting to protect the Kurds. Trumpâs new decision to abandon the Kurds has already sparked backlash beyond Fox News. A Syria Kurdish official told NBC that âthe Americans are traitors.â âThey have abandoned us to a Turkish massacre. We can no longer fight against ISIS and have to defend ourselves. This could allow ISIS to return to the region,â the official said. Also on âFox & Friends,â House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) said Trumpâs decision compromises Americaâs promise to allies. âThe thing I believe is if you make a commitment and someone is fighting with you, America should keep its word,â McCarthy said. Sen. Lindsay Graham (R-S.C.) also called into the show to say that Trumpâs âimpulsiveâ and âirresponsibleâ decision to abandon the Kurds has âundone all the gains weâve madeâ and âthrown the region into further chaos.â âIf Iâm an ISIS fighter, Iâve got a second lease on life,â said Graham, normally one of the presidentâs most vigorous defenders. âTo those who think ISIS has been defeated, you will soon see.â He added: âI like President Trump. Iâve tried to help him. This to me is just unnerving to its core. To say to the American people, âISIS has been destroyed in Syriaâ is not true.â Lindsey Graham calls in to Fox & Friends & calls Trumpâs decision to abandon the Kurds âimpulsive.â

âI hope Iâm making myself clear how shortsighted & irresponsible this decision is in my view,â he says. âThis to me is just unnerving to its core.â pic.twitter.com/URH0DVA1bo Despite the criticism, Trump doubled down with a series of tweets. âThe United States was supposed to be in Syria for 30 days, that was many years ago,â the president wrote. âWe stayed and got deeper and deeper into battle with no aim in sight.â He went on: âThe Kurds fought with us, but were paid massive amounts of money and equipment to do so. ... it is time for us to get out of these ridiculous Endless Wars, many of them tribal, and bring our soldiers home. WE WILL FIGHT WHERE IT IS TO OUR BENEFIT, AND ONLY FIGHT TO WIN.â He added in another tweet: âWe are 7000 miles away and will crush ISIS again if they come anywhere near us!â

articles.title: Trump Defends Decision To Abandon Kurdish Allies Fighting ISIS In Syria
articles.subtitle: âTurkey, Europe, Syria, Iran, Iraq, Russia and the Kurds will now have to ... figure the situation out,â the president tweeted.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: President Donald Trump on Monday defended his widely condemned decision to greenlight a Turkish military operation that jeopardizes the lives of U.S.-allied Kurdish forces fighting the self-described Islamic State in northern Syria. In an extraordinary shift in U.S. foreign policy, the White House released a statement late Sunday announcing that American forces would âno longer be in the immediate area,â allowing Turkey to invade northern Syria. Any captured ISIS fighters are now the responsibility of Turkey, the White House added. The Kurds, an ethnic group, lead the Syrian Democratic Forces, the main ally of the U.S. in Syria.Â The Turkish government, however, considers them to be terrorists.Â Middle Eastern and foreign policy experts have warned that allowing Turkey to invade northern Syria will result in a genocide against the Kurds. But Trump, in a series of tweets Monday, essentially told the Kurds that the United States has supported them for years, but now theyâre on their own. âThe United States was supposed to be in Syria for 30 days, that was many years ago,â the president wrote. âWe stayed and got deeper and deeper into battle with no aim in sight.â âThe Kurds fought with us, but were paid massive amounts of money and equipment to do so,â he continued. â[I]t is time for us to get out of these ridiculous Endless Wars, many of them tribal, and bring our soldiers home.
