WE WILL FIGHT WHERE IT IS TO OUR BENEFIT, AND ONLY FIGHT TO WIN.â Trump added that itâs now up to Turkey, Europe, Syria, Iran, Iraq, Russia and the Kurds to âfigure the situation out.â âThey all hate ISIS, have been enemies for years,â he tweeted. âWe are 7000 miles away and will crush ISIS again if they come anywhere near us!â In a statement Sunday, the SDF said a Turkish invasion would âdisplace our peopleâ and could âresult in many civilian casualties.â The forces warned that Trumpâs decision to withdraw support in northern Syria will reverse the progress theyâve made on defeating ISIS and make the war-torn country a âpermanent conflict area.â Several senior Republicans pushed back on Trumpâs plan to desert the Kurds. âI hope Iâm making myself clear how shortsighted and irresponsible this decision is in my view,â Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told âFox & Friendsâ on Monday. âThis, to me, is just unnerving to its core.â Trump called for the complete withdrawal of U.S. forces in Syria last December, but he ultimately reversed his decision following backlash from American intelligence officials, foreign allies and U.S. lawmakers, including Graham. This story has been updated with a statement from the Syrian Democratic Forces.

articles.title: Mitch McConnell Criticizes Trumpâs Syria Decision
articles.subtitle: The Senate majority leader joined other Republicans who are speaking out against the presidentâs decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Syria.
articles.author: Antonia Blumberg
articles.content: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Monday criticized President Donald Trumpâs decision to withdraw support for Kurdish allies in northern Syria ahead of Turkeyâs planned invasion of the region. The White House announced on Sunday that it would effectively allow Turkey to invade northern Syria by withdrawing U.S. troops from the region. The decision startled some members of Congress, including Republicans, who warned such a move could precipitate a genocide of the Kurds and lead to the return of the self-described Islamic State (also known as ISIS) in the region. âI urge the President to exercise American leadership to keep together our multinational coalition to defeat ISIS and prevent significant conflict between our NATO ally Turkey and our local Syrian counterterrorism partners,â McConnell said in a statement. Trump defended his decision, which he made against the recommendations of the Pentagon and State Department. âThe U.S. has done far more than anyone could have ever expected, including the capture of 100% of the ISIS Caliphate,â the president falsely claimed in a Monday tweet. âIt is time now for others in the region, some of great wealth, to protect their own territory.â Trump also tweeted that he would âtotally destroy and obliterateâ Turkeyâs economy if the country took any action he considers âoff limitsâ in the wake of the U.S.âs withdrawal. In a bipartisan statement, Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) and Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.)Â on Monday requested Trump send a representative to appear before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to defend the move. âThe Administration must come before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and explain to the American people how betraying an ally and ceding influence to terrorists and adversaries is not disastrous for our national security interests,â the senators said. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a frequent cheerleader of the president, called the decision âshortsightedâ and âirresponsibleâ in a phone interview with âFox & Friendsâ on Monday. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) in a statement called Trumpâs decision ârecklessâ and âmisguided.â âThe Presidentâs decision to withdraw U.S. forces from Northern Syria is a deeply disturbing development that betrays our Kurdish allies who have been instrumental partners in our mission to eradicate ISIS,â Pelosi said. âDespite what the President might say, ISIS remains a serious threat. This reckless, misguided decision undermines the efforts by our brave servicemembers and our allies to end ISISâs tyranny.â This is a developing story. Check back for updates.

articles.title: Kamala Harris Announces Ambitious 6-Month Paid Family Leave Plan
articles.subtitle: Advocates hope this will finally get candidates talking about a key economic and health policy.
articles.author: Emily Peck
articles.content: Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) announced a plan on Monday that would guarantee workers up to six months of paid family and medical leave, the most generous such policy proposal in the Democratic presidential field. Harris is unveiling her plan, part of what she calls a âchildrenâs agenda,â as her 2020 campaign is struggling. The proposal is more aspirational than practical, as six months of leave exceeds anything currently under consideration or on offer in the U.S. â the only developed country that doesnât guarantee new mothers paid time off. Still, by calling attention to the issue, Harris could help bring paid leave to prominence on the 2020 agenda, from which itâs been largely absent. âI hope this is a turning point. I have been deeply disappointed in how little discussion there has been,â said Vicki Shabo, senior fellow for paid leave policy and strategy at New America, a liberal think tank. Shabo has been frustrated that womenâs economic issues have gotten short shrift during the 2020 campaign so far â barring a few questions on the pay gap. Perhaps Harrisâ agenda will move the needle, Shabo said. âThis might start a domino effect among candidates.â Paid maternity and paternity leave and time off for caregiving are not just womenâs issues, of course. And as the population ages, these concerns will become even more critical to working Americans. But the 2020 candidates have forgone the conversation on leave to focus on single-payer âMedicare for allâ and other health insurance issues â perhaps forgetting that in order for working Americans to access health care, theyâll need the time off to go to the doctor or recover from medical procedures. âGuaranteeing six months of paid leave will bring us closer to economic justice for workers and ensures newborn children or children who are sick can get the care they need from a parent without thrusting the family into upheaval,â Harris said in a statement. Under Harrisâ proposal, workers who make $75,000 or less would receive their full salary while taking time off to deal with a serious health condition; caring for an infant or newly adopted child; addressing military caregiving and leave; or addressing domestic violence, harassment, sexual assault or stalking. The leave could be taken as a block of time or intermittently, as needs arise. Harrisâ policy would also guarantee job protections to workers and offer support to small businesses that must give workers time off. Sheâd pay for the leave with a payroll tax shared by employers and employees, as well as by levying penalties on companies that fail to close their pay gaps (an earlier Harris proposal). All the Democrats vying for the presidential nomination who are members of Congress have co-sponsored the Family Act, a bill that would give workers 12 weeks of paid time off. The Family Act has been kicking around for the past few years; Harris is the first Democrat in the race to go significantly beyond it. Her proposal was influenced by paid leave policies in a handful of states that have already learned a critical lesson about wage replacement. For example, Californiaâs paid leave law, in effect for more than a decade, initially only offered 55% wage replacement. That made it next to impossible for low-income workers to take time off. The state has since increased wage replacement. The lesson: If you donât give low-wage workers most of their income, they wonât take the time off. Six months of leave in the United States is still pretty much unheard of, even though research has found it to be a good amount of time for moms and babies to be home together or for children to be home with a loving caregiver. âThis is the first time weâve seen a major presidential candidate, but also a U.S. Senator, talk about a family leave policy that is supported by medical evidence,â said Katie Bethell, executive director at Paid Leave for the United States, an advocacy group. The American Pediatric Association, Bethell noted, recommends six months of leave. Bethell said her group has spoken to all the Democratic contenders and offered Harrisâ team help in crafting its policy. Polling theyâve done shows that paid family leave is an important issue to Democratic voters â particularly Black and Hispanic voters. Putting a paid leave policy under the umbrella of a childrenâs agenda is significant, Bethell said. Half of families with children at home use paid leave for reasons beyond taking care of new babies, according to Bethell. âTheyâre using it to take care of seriously ill kids or for income replacement when a parent is seriously ill,â she said. Harris also uses an inclusive definition of âfamily memberâ that goes beyond blood relatives â a critical issue for LGBTQ workers in particular. The childrenâs agenda also includes a pitch to expand access to high-quality preschool, an effort to cut child poverty and a proposal to create a federal Bureau of Children and Family Justice.

articles.title: Republicans, Foreign Policy Experts Condemn Trumpâs Decision To Abandon Kurds
articles.subtitle: Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina called it âa stain on Americaâs honor.â
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: President Donald Trumpâs decision to withdraw support for Kurdish allies in northern Syria ahead of Turkeyâs planned invasion of the region drew forceful backlash from both Republicans and Democrats, as well as foreign policy experts. The Kurds lead the Syrian Democratic Forces, the main ally to the U.S. in fighting the self-described Islamic State in Syria. Turkey has long wanted the U.S. to end its support for the Kurds, an ethnic group the Turkish government views as terrorists. The White Houseâs announcement Sunday to allow Turkey to invade northern Syria startled some members of Congress, who warned such a move could lead to a genocide of the Kurds and allow ISIS to creep back into the region. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a frequent cheerleader of the president, split with Trump on his Syria decision, calling it âshortsightedâ and âirresponsibleâ during a phone interview with âFox & Friendsâ on Monday. Graham, who helped to convince Trump to reverse his decision last December to withdraw U.S. forces from Syria, tweeted Monday that abandoning our Kurdish allies would be âa stain on Americaâs honor.â He said he plans to introduce a Senate resolution opposing and asking for a reversal of Trumpâs decision if he moves forward with it. Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah echoed his fellow Republicanâs concern. Several other Republicans also spoke out about the sudden shift in U.S. foreign policy. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy urged the U.S. to âkeep its wordâ with its foreign allies during an appearance Monday on âFox & Friends.â âThis is a terribly unwise decision by the President to abandon our Kurdish allies, who have been our major partner in the fight against the Islamic State,â Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) said in a statement. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) called Trumpâs decision a âgrave mistake.â Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.), a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called the move âpositively sinister.â Brett McGurk, the former U.S. envoy to the global coalition fighting ISIS, blasted Trump for demonstrating âa complete lack of understanding of anything happening on the ground.â âTrump made a similarly impulsive decision when I was managing the policy,â tweeted McGurk, who resigned last year when Trump announced plans to abruptly withdraw American troops from Syria.Â âTrump tonight after one call with a foreign leader provided a gift to Russia, Iran, and ISIS.â Daniel Drezner, a professor of international politics at Tufts University, accused Trump of âscrewing over a local ally that has done pretty much everything the U.S. has asked.â Trump appeared to address some of the concerns over his decision to withdraw support in northern Syria, tweeting Monday that he would âtotally destroyâ Turkeyâs economy if its leaders did anything he considers to be âoff limits.â âThe U.S. has done far more than anyone could have ever expected,â he wrote. âIt is now time for others in the region, some of great wealth, to protect their own territory. THE USA IS GREAT!â This is a developing story. Check back for updates.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Has A Plan For Brett Kavanaugh
articles.subtitle: The Democratic 2020 presidential candidate is targeting misconduct in the federal judiciary, including the Supreme Court.
articles.content: Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) unveiled a plan to reform federal judicial misconduct on Monday, a day after the one-year anniversary of Brett Kavanaughâs controversial confirmation to the Supreme Court. âItâs time to ensure that judges do not hear cases where they have conflicts of interests, strengthen our nationâs ethics rules for judges, and ensure accountability for judges who violate these rules,â the 2020 presidential candidate wrote in her announcement of the plan for an impartial and ethical federal judiciary. Warrenâs plan includes closing a loophole that allows federal judges to escape investigations for misconduct when they resign from office or are elevated to the Supreme Court â a loophole that Warren hasÂ railed against in the past. âMy plan extends the authority of the Judicial Conference to former judges so that individuals under investigation cannot simply resign from the bench to avoid accountability,â Warren said. âThis provision would allow the judiciary to reopen the investigations into Alex Kozinski,Â Maryanne Trump-Barry,Â Brett Kavanaugh, and any other judge who benefited from this loophole.â Kozinski was a judge on the federal 9th Circuit accused in 2017 by at least 15 law clerks of sexual misconduct. But, as Warren noted, the investigation into Kozinskiâs behavior was dropped when he retired. Trump-Barry, President Donald Trumpâs sister, resigned as a federal appellate judge in April, ending a probe into whether she violated judicial conduct rules by participating in the Trump familyâs alleged tax fraud schemes. When Kavanaugh rose to the Supreme Court, sexual assault and perjury complaints against him were dismissed. âThe basic premise of our legal system is that every person is treated equally in the eyes of the law â including judges,â Warren said on Monday. âOur judiciary only functions properly when it lives up to this promise, and it risks eroding its legitimacy when the American people lose faith that judges are ethical and fair-minded.â Warren also unveiled several proposals she hasnât mentioned publicly before. They includeÂ prohibiting judges from deciding for themselves whether they should recuse themselves from a case due to conflict of interest;Â requiring Supreme Court justices to give written explanations of their decisions when a party asks for a recusal; andÂ giving strong disciplinary tools to judicial ethics watchdogs, such as allowing them to take away nonvested pension benefits from judges. Warrenâs plan also proposes extending the Code of Conduct for United States Judges to the Supreme Court, which is currently not covered by such guidelines. Explaining the need for this provision, Warren cited the 83 ethics complaintsÂ lodged against Kavanaugh that were dismissed upon his confirmation to the Supreme Court, as well as the lack of action after Supreme Court Justice Clarence ThomasÂ failed to disclose paymentsÂ his wife received from a conservative judicial activist group. âBecause the Supreme Court is not covered by a Code of Conduct, no procedure exists to file new complaintsâ against Kavanaugh, Warren said. She added thatÂ âquestions are often raised about the behavior of Supreme Court Justices, such as Justice Thomasâs 13 years of financial disclosures that failed to list $690,000 in payments to his wife from the Heritage Foundation, a right-wing judicial activist group â but these actions are beyond the scope of current rules.â Such lack of oversight, Warren said, has gone on for long enough. âThese changes will not only allow us to ensure accountability for bad actors, including reopening inquiries into the conduct of offenders like Brett Kavanaugh,â she wrote. âThey will also hold the vast majority of judges who act in good faith to the highest ethical standards, and in the process, begin to restore accountability and trust in a fair and impartial federal judiciary.â Warrenâs plan comes almost exactly a year after the Senate voted 50-48 to confirm Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, following explosive allegations that he sexually assaulted at least three women when he was younger.

articles.title: Cory Booker Wants To Be More Than Every Voterâs 3rd Choice
articles.subtitle: The New Jersey senator, once the king of the political stunt, just pulled one off to save his 2020 presidential campaign. But can he do more?
articles.content: MANCHESTER, N.H. â It is early September, and Cory Booker is telling me he is done with stunts. When the New Jersey senator and 2020 Democratic presidential candidate was a council member and then mayor of Newark, one of his major goals was to bring attention to the problems of his poor, majority-minority 277,000-person city â a feat he often excelled at with his outsize charisma and his savvy use of social media. Booker once held a hunger strike in the courtyard of a housing project to protest gang violence. He started a feud with Conan OâBrien after the late night host joked about wanting to flee Newark. He was one of the first Democrats ever to complete the food stamp challenge. But now, in a campaign-rented recreational vehicle departing the New Hampshire Democratic Party Convention and heading north toward the Maine border, Booker says he doesnât need to turn himself into a shiny object for the benefit of the media. âWhen I became mayor of a city that everybody was trying to get away from, or when I was trying to beat a machine, getting attention was what I needed to do,â Booker says. âI got very good at getting this small city â maybe bigger than some cities that other people are mayors of â my job was to get resources and attention.â But âwhen I became a senator, my first year, I wouldnât do interviews, I didnât talk in caucus,â he continues. âI didnât need to draw attention to myself as a United States senator. What I wanted to do was to pass criminal justice reform, work across the aisle.â The Booker campaign is seemingly pursuing the same heads-down approach, doing everything you are supposed to do to win a presidential nomination: barnstorming through Iowa and New Hampshire; building up ground games to rival those of the leading candidates; generating big â if not game-changing â moments at debates; and releasing policy papers that earned plaudits from wonks. Heâs garnered more endorsements from state legislators than any other candidate has. The other campaigns are watching for his breakout moment. Sure, the Booker team members are frustrated with his place in the polls. But they are, perhaps surprisingly, Zen about the future of the race and their manâs place in it. âWe just have to keep raising money, and I will be the nominee,â Booker says, confident enough that he openly muses about what kind of general election campaign he would run.Â (He wants to go to states you donât expect Democrats to campaign in during the general, like South Carolina and West Virginia.) âOrganize like hell and hope you get hot at the end,â is how his campaign manager Addisu Demissie described the campaignâs strategy in a conference call with reporters in the spring. Booker recently expressed it in emoji form: turtle emoji, greater-than sign, rabbit emoji. Just two weeks later, that tone radically changed: The Booker campaign announced it needed to raise $1.7 million in 10 days to give him a hope to compete. Instead of quietly making this appeal to top donors, the campaign put their desperation on full blast. The team leaked a memo from Demissie to NBC News, then held a press conference call to discuss it. âIf weâre not able to build the campaign organization, which means raise the money that we need to win the nomination, Coryâs not going to continue running and consuming resources that are better used on focusing on beating Donald Trump,â Demissie told the reporters on the call. The alarmist tone of the note immediately generated skepticism among both reporters and the other campaigns, leading them to believe it was a carefully orchestrated political stunt to generate attention and dollars from a candidate that had no real intention of quitting. (Demissieâs memo included a preemptive rebuttal of this argument, noting, âThis isnât an end-of-quarter stunt or another one of those memos from a campaign trying to spin the press.â) In the end, Bookerâs campaign succeeded. It raised $1.7 million in the final 10 days, the most successful 10-day period of his campaign to date, and hit more than $6 million in the quarter overall. Booker also qualified for the next two presidential debates. Stunt or not, the episode raised a larger question: Just how did Cory Booker find himself in this position in the first place? ***** Booker has been receiving presidential hype since before he even entered the Senate, when he dazzled the national press with heroic anecdotes from his term as mayor: He ran into a burning building to save a constituent and, guided by Twitter, went around shoveling the sidewalks and driveways of elderly residents after snowstorms. In 2012, the Obama campaign regularly deployed him as a surrogate. The Clinton team did the same in 2016, and strongly considered him for vice president, to the point where Clinton-Booker placards had been printed. In the summer of 2018, The New York Times identified him â along with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, former Vice President Joe Biden, California Sen. Kamala Harris and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren â as one of the five leading contenders for the Democratic nomination. Suffice it to say, the first eight months of the Booker campaign have fallen short of those expectations. Voters in the early states, ticking off which candidates theyâre considering, routinely list Booker as the second or third choice, often behind Warren or Biden. But, if you look at the horse race numbers from those same polls, only between one out of every 100 and one out of every 20 voters considers him their top choice. Even in the areas where he theoretically should excel â with black voters, with young people â Booker polls, at best, in the high single digits. Jim Demers, a former New Hampshire state legislator who is now a top Booker adviser â his duties include driving the aforementioned RV â said Bookerâs campaign at the moment resembles former President Barack Obamaâs at the same point in 2007. (Demers would know, since he was Obamaâs New Hampshire campaign chair.) âThe size of the field has made it very difficult to process the candidates beyond the two or three who had the highest name recognition right now,â Demers said, dismissing candidates who have spiked in the polls before Labor Day. âThe real voters start paying attention. This is movement time.â Demers is right: With just a few debates left, the number of chances to make a shock-and-awe impression to move the polls is dwindling, and the top three candidates â Biden, Warren and Sanders â have displayed vulnerabilities aplenty without another candidate rising to challenge them. If itâs movement time, then time is running out for Booker to be more than everyoneâs second or third choice. ***** That morning in September, Booker strolls onto the stage at Southern New Hampshire University at 10 a.m. Biden spoke before him and failed to rouse the still-drowsy crowd. Booker begins with a version of his stump speech, which opens with the story of how his family, turned away from buying homes in a suburb of Newark because they were Black, was eventually able to purchase one with the help of white activists inspired by the civil rights movement. About three minutes into the speech, Bookerâs lines start generating audible cheers from the crowd. Six minutes in, Booker delivers one of his favorite lines â âWe gotta beat Donald Trump. But beating Donald Trump is the floor. It is not the ceiling.â â and the applause and cheers are loud enough that he has to pause before continuing. By the 10-minute mark, Booker has the crowd echoing another one of his signature lines â âWe will riseâ â in a call-and-response pattern. He leaves to a standing ovation. In a different race, one where there werenât more than a dozen candidates still running, the post-event headlines might have focused on Bookerâs strong performance. But Booker isnât running in that race. Heâs running in the race where Warren got a standing ovation that lasted more than two minutes before she even said a word, and where her picture was splashed across the top of the New Hampshire Union Leader the next morning. After his speech, a pair of cable news interviews and a gaggle with reporters who peppered him with questions about his low standing in the polls â âWe do not want to win the summer news cycle, we want to win the election,â he says â Booker is off to a volunteer thank-you event at a pub across the street from the arena. Outside, he greets a group of volunteers from People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, one of whom is wearing a cow outfit and holding a sign declaring: âClimate change cow says: Go vegan or we all die.â âMy vegan people!â he calls out, before taking a selfie with the group. (While Booker is a vegan, the PETA group members say they have been attending events with all the candidates to talk to voters about how a vegan diet can help the environment.) Inside is a gathering of relatively rare creatures in Democratic politics: Booker loyalists. While Warren, Biden, Harris, Sanders and even the unorthodox entrepreneur Andrew Yang have their legions of devoted online followers, Booker does not. Itâs a puzzling development for a man who came to national attention, in no small part, because of his ability to grab attention on Twitter. âI donât know anybody who doesnât like Cory Booker,â said one Democratic operative, requesting anonymity to speak candidly about one of the partyâs brightest lights. âBut he isnât anybodyâs first or second choice. There are only so many voters of so many persuasions, and his ability to draw those voters is limited when he doesnât have a core constituency of his own.â Bookerâs campaign, during its scramble to raise the self-imposed requirement of $1.7 million, seemed to acknowledge his difficulty building a uniquely loyal constituency. Many of its email pleas focused not on helping Booker win but simply on keeping him in the race.Â And many of the big names who endorsed keeping Booker in the race â former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams, Iowa Auditor Rob Sand and D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser â have not actually endorsed his candidacy. âIt would be a loss for not only our party but for our country if someone like him was shut out of this race because he couldnât raise enough money to compete,â Demissie wrote in one email. Booker asked for donations even âif you havenât settled on a candidate but you think I bring an important perspective to this campaign.â Talking to the assembled Booker supporters, there is no uniform reason for their support: Some like his emphasis on combating gun violence, others his promise to unify the country, another says he could replicate Obamaâs path to victory in 2008. But they all have one thing in common: They have met Booker in person. The Booker campaign hopes a lot more voters can do the same. During one trip to the Hawkeye State in early June, Booker stopped in Keokuk, Iowa, an 11,000-person city on the Mississippi River in the stateâs far southeastern corner, where he gathered 50 people at a coffee shop, and then hung around to take selfies, record videos for friends of attendees who couldnât make the event, listen to the whispered concerns of seniors and eventually leave with a piece of coffee cake he would give to a staffer. (The frosting wasnât vegan.) He then spent 40 minutes at a house in nearby Burlington, where a group of less than a dozen women discussed the closure of a Planned Parenthood in the city. âEach one of the people here is going to tell 20 people about what happened,â said Tom Courtney, a former Iowa state senator who hosted the event. âIn Iowa, this is what it takes,â Courtney continued. âBernie doesnât do it. Joe hasnât done it so far. Right now, theyâre winning on name recognition. But once the rubber hits the road, thatâs not going to cut it.â Booker is betting a lot on Iowa. Even Demers acknowledged one of the two candidates from New England â Sanders or Warren â is more likely than not to win the New Hampshire primary. That leaves Iowa as Bookerâs only major chance to make an impact before African American voters â a key part of his theoretical winning coalition â begin voting in larger numbers in Nevada and then South Carolina. Booker said he personally considers his teamâs Iowa operation â he has 50 paid employees in the state â to be as strong as any campaignâs, save Warrenâs. Ditto with his team in New Hampshire, where he has 30 staffers on the ground. Back in Manchester, Booker makes his way through the crowd, feeling the love, grabbing peopleâs phones to quickly snap a selfie. (Booker always takes the selfies himself. âYou can always take the picture quicker than they can,â he says. âMost people donât know the volume down button on iPhones is a picture taker.â) Booker delivers a quick speech to the gathered supporters. âWe are building this campaign brick by brick by brick!â he exclaims. âWeâre going to make sure the next president of the United States is bald!â ***** Bookerâs next stop in Manchester is at Brookside Congregational, part of the liberal-leaning United Church of Christ, with a Black Lives Matter sign out front and a crowd of about 30 inside. Bookerâs here for a question-and-answer session sponsored by the Granite State Organizing Project, which is focused on criminal justice reform, affordable housing and immigration. The questions start coming, and they are coming from the left end of the political spectrum. Throughout the campaign, Booker has announced his occasional âfrustrationâ with the primary conversation. He first shared it onstage at an event with Al Sharptonâs National Action Network and has repeated it several times since. I asked Booker to explain what he meant. âI get people asking me about Greenland!â Booker said, referring to Trumpâs desire to purchase the North Atlantic island. âThat same week, Title X funding was being cut. Nobody asked me about that.â âIt frustrates me, as the guy who lives in the inner city, when people ask â almost as a litmus test â first, it was âIs Donald Trump a racist?â Then, it was âIs he a white supremacist?ââ he continued. âThatâs not the issue. The issue is we have a problem with white supremacy in this country. And yeah, heâs a problem. But the bigger problem is white supremacy in this country. And whatâs your plan for that?â Bookerâs annoyance, at times, can seem a little convenient. He entered the race under fire from the left because of his support for charter schools, his past embrace of technology companies and his ties to his home stateâs powerful pharmaceutical industry. But itâs the newer debates that seem to get under his skin. He bristles when he thinks progressives are getting ahead of the country, and complicating both campaigning and governance. Questions about whether prisoners should be allowed to vote annoy him, he has said, because the focus should be on getting people out of prison in the first place. The overall effect is that Booker is in a bit of a never-never land, ideologically. Heâs assembled a liberal voting record in the Senate, but declines to engage in either an out-and-out race to match Sanders on the left or the name-and-shame tactics Warren employs against Facebook and other modern-day malefactors of great wealth. But he also declines to engage in the hippie-punching many of the moderate candidates frequently deploy â think Colorado Sen. Michael Bennetâs criticisms of âMedicare for All,â or Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobucharâs attacks on proposals to wipe away student debt. At the church, the litmus test question is about defunding Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Booker doesnât directly engage, turning down the opportunity to provide a quick sound bite that would please activists and the media. Instead, he turns in a 15-minute answer that touches on the âdeep hypocrisyâ of some devout Americans, âthe radical work of love,â cruelty to animals, environmental racism and the water crisis in Flint, Michigan, and ultimately the fear Latinos living in Bookerâs inner-city neighborhood in Newark feel. âAll the issues weâre talking about are deeply interrelated,â Booker says. The crowd is nodding, listening intently. But just a few minutes later, Booker has the once-somber crowd in stitches. Heâs recounting the story of his clash with OâBrien, noting he once banned the late night host from Newark Liberty International Airport, and their faux-feud ended with then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton forcing them to negotiate a truce. The abrupt switch from wonky and serious to gut-busting points to another critique of Bookerâs campaign frequently tossed around in D.C. circles: that heâs âgoofy.â Booker has at times embraced this, giving interviews about his love of Star Trek and making a surprise appearance at Comic-Con. But some operatives think it undercuts Bookerâs more serious moments. It, along with Bookerâs general love of hope-and-change-and-love-and-togetherness rhetoric, presents another challenge the Booker team is striving to overcome. Booker routinely tells audiences to watch âStreet Fight,â the Oscar-nominated documentary depicting his first rough-and-tumble campaign against then-Newark Mayor Sharpe James, to get a taste of how he would handle a campaign against Trump. âIâm a guy thatâs really good at pulling people together for a common cause,â Booker says. âThat doesnât mean I donât stand my ground. Iâm not a kumbaya guy.â But even as Booker tells voters to turn on Netflix and watch an 83-minute-long testament to his toughness, he canât help but sprinkle in a joke. He typically notes âStreet Fightâ lost the Academy Award for Best Documentary that year to âMarch of the Penguins.â âPenguins arenât even that cute,â he tells audiences, in another line that usually wins laughs. âIâm cuter than a penguin.â ***** Last Tuesday morning, the Booker campaign held a conference call to announce it hadÂ raised $6 million, with a third of that coming after their desperate ask for more cash. With that funding it was able to hire 40 more staffers, in the early states and at its headquarters in Newark. Demissie insisted again that most voters were undecided. After the success of their big fundraising ask and in the service of âradical transparencyâ â a radical transparency that did not extend to releasing the campaignâs average donation size or cash-on-hand number â he said they were setting a $3 million fundraising goal for the month of October. âWeâve seen in the last 10 days that voters want Cory to be one of their choices,â Demissie said. âIf you tell people the truth, and you let them know what you need, theyâll come to your aide, because they want Cory to be in this race until the end.â Whether they want him to win is an entirely different matter.

articles.title: Judge Rejects Trump Challenge To New York Tax Return Turnover
articles.subtitle: The judge said he cannot endorse such a âcategorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity from judicial process.â
articles.content: NEW YORK (AP) â A federal judge rejected President Donald Trumpâs challenge to the release of his tax returns for a New York state criminal probe, saying on Monday that he could not grant such a âcategorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity.â Trumpâs lawyers notified the judge that they will immediately appeal the ruling. Judge Victor Marrero called Trumpâs claim of a broad immunity âextraordinary.â âAs the court reads it, presidential immunity would stretch to cover every phase of criminal proceedings, including investigations, grand jury proceedings and subpoenas, indictment, prosecution, arrest, trial, conviction, and incarceration,â Marrero wrote. âThat constitutional protection presumably would encompass any conduct, at any time, in any forum, whether federal or state, and whether the President acted alone or in concert with other individuals.â The judge said he âcannot endorse such a categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity from judicial process as being countenanced by the nationâs constitutional plan, especially in the light of the fundamental concerns over excessive arrogation of power that animated the Constitutionâs delicate structure and its calibrated balance of authority among the three branches of the national government, as well as between the federal and state authorities.â Lawyers did not immediately respond to email requests for comment in responce to the ruling. The returns had been sought by Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus R. Vance Jr. His office is investigating the Trump Organizationâs involvement in buying the silence of two women who claimed to have had affairs with the president. Trumpâs lawyers have said the investigation is politically motivated and that the quest for his tax records should be stopped because he is immune from any criminal probe as long as he is president. Last week, Justice Department lawyers in Washington urged Marrero to delay deciding the issue. Vance began his probe after federal prosecutors in Manhattan completed their investigation into payments that Trumpâs former personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, arranged to be paid to porn actress Stormy Daniels and model Karen McDougal to keep them silent during the presidential race. The Trump Organization later reimbursed Cohen. Cohen is serving a three-year prison sentence.

articles.title: Trump Threatens To âTotally Destroyâ Turkeyâs Economy Should It Act Inappropriately
articles.subtitle: The president warned he will take action should the country do anything that he considers âoff limitsâ in his âgreat and unmatched wisdom.â
articles.author: Nina Golgowski
articles.content: President Donald Trump said on Twitter Monday he will âtotally destroy and obliterateâ Turkeyâs economy if the country takes any action that he considers âoff limitsâ after announcing U.S. forces will withdraw from Syria. Trumpâs threat followed the White House announcing on Sunday that Turkey will invade Northern Syria in a campaign against the self-declared Islamic State.Â Republicans have since blasted this decision as a âgrave mistakeâ and âa disaster in the making.â As I have stated strongly before, and just to reiterate, if Turkey does anything that I, in my great and unmatched wisdom, consider to be off limits, I will totally destroy and obliterate the Economy of Turkey (Iâve done before!). They must, with Europe and others, watch over... âThe U.S. has done far more than anyone could have ever expected, including the capture of 100% of the ISIS Caliphate. It is time now for others in the region, some of great wealth, to protect their own territory,â Trump added. The White Houseâs decision has been widely criticized as jeopardizing the lives of U.S.-allied Kurdish forces by leaving them in the Kurdish-controlled regionÂ to fend for themselves. This comes after they helped the U.S. defeat the Islamic State in Syria. The Kurds are considered to be a terrorist organization by the Turkish government. Withdrawing U.S. troops, therefore, places them at even greater risk, the Kurdsâ Syrian Democratic ForcesÂ warned in a statement that accused the U.S. of abandoning its responsibilities âin the war on terror.â The U.S. withdrawal âwill have a serious impact in the fight against terrorism and will have deep impact on the political situation and international efforts to end the crisis and resolve it politically,â the SDA said. âWe hope our US partners will reverse this decision & not abandon our combined effort in NE Syria,â the SDA added on Twitter, with the hashtagÂ #TurkeyIsNotOurFriend. A number of Republicans have been quick to publicly criticize Trumpâs decision, includingÂ  Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) who called it a âdisaster in the making.â Trump had announced a similar American troop withdrawal from Syria last December but backtracked after facing similar condemnation. Then-Defense Secretary Jim Mattis resigned in protest of Trumpâs decision.

articles.title: Twitter Users Drag Trump For Touting His âGreat And Unmatched Wisdomâ
articles.subtitle: âDidnât the Wizard of Oz speak of his âgreat and unmatched wisdomâ or something like that?â one person wondered.
articles.author: David Moye
articles.content:
President Donald Trump, a self-proclaimed âstable genius,â showed on Monday his humility knows no bounds when he threatened Turkey not to do anything that goes against his âgreat and unmatched wisdom.â On Sunday night, the White House announced that U.S. forces would âno longer be in the immediate area,â allowing Turkey forces to invade northern Syria â a move that endangers Kurdish forces who have been U.S. allies and that sparked fierce criticism from even some of Trumpâs staunchest defenders. On Monday, the president warned Turkey not to do anything he considers âoff limits,â lest he destroy their economy. As I have stated strongly before, and just to reiterate, if Turkey does anything that I, in my great and unmatched wisdom, consider to be off limits, I will totally destroy and obliterate the Economy of Turkey (Iâve done before!). They must, with Europe and others, watch over... ....the captured ISIS fighters and families. The U.S. has done far more than anyone could have ever expected, including the capture of 100% of the ISIS Caliphate. It is time now for others in the region, some of great wealth, to protect their own territory. THE USA IS GREAT! Some Twitter users took note that the hyperbolic phrasing went beyond even typical Trump hyperbole â and was reminiscent of lines from beloved movie musicals. Didnât the Wizard of Oz speak of his âgreat and unmatched wisdomâ or something like that? pic.twitter.com/tbuiw7rVI0 itâs like tweets from the Wizard of Oz https://t.co/ugiaK8Py1n âI, in my great and unmatched wisdomâ

Oh yeah, very normal stuff here. https://t.co/5VZc0Te2rP A few begged to differ with the presidentâs assessment of his own abilities. #BREAKING Man Who Went Broke Running Casinos Brags Of His âGreat And Unmatched Wisdomâ âI cannot tell a lie.â 
- George Washington

âI cannot tell the truth.â
- Donald Trump

âI cannot tell the difference.â
- Republicans Some wondered if the tweet was actually sent out by the president since it was spelled correctly. This tweet is not mis-spelled, and has complete sentences; therefore, someone helped you with it.  Whoever it was is probably trying to get you removed under the 25th Amendment, because this tweet is totally bonkers. Others wondered if there was a particular reason for the timing of the tweet: It is Putinâs birthday today. Was this your gift to him?

articles.title: Meghan McCain Rips GOPâs âFeckless, Unpatriotic Cowardsâ In Scathing Takedown
articles.subtitle: The âViewâ co-host slammed any Republican backing Trumpâs decision to step aside as Turkey prepares to invade Syria.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Meghan McCainÂ added her voice to the growing chorus of conservatives condemning the Trump administrationâs decision to step aside as Turkey gears up to invade Syria â a potential death sentence for the Kurdish fighters who have been an American ally in the battle against ISIS. âRight now weâre just saying weâre just going to leave [the Kurds] and abandon them,â the co-host of ABCâs âThe Viewâ said Monday. McCain blasted as âfeckless, unpatriotic cowardsâ fellow Republicans and current White House officials who were âmad that President [Barack] Obama pulled out of Iraqâ but have been mum about the administrationâs Sunday night announcement. McCainâs comments, which she admitted diverged from the showâs talking points and were âa little bit rogueâ on her part, were met with applause from the studio audience. White House press secretary Stephanie GrishamÂ issued the Sunday nightÂ statementÂ after President Donald Trump talked by telephone with Turkish President Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan. The statement said that Turkey will soon move into northern Syria and that U.S. troops will neither support nor be involved in the operation. Furthermore, they âwill no longer be in the immediate area.â âI cannot believe this is where weâre at diplomatic-wise,â a clearly indignant McCain said. âWhat message is this sending to our allies and to our American troops who have fought and diedâ as part of the effort in Syria to defeat the Islamic State. She also wondered if the move was spurred by a âwag the dogâ impulse to distract attention from the impeachment inquiry into Trump. Although some GOP leaders have been silent on the administrationâs new policy, some of Trumpâs staunchest backers, such as Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), are publicly urging Trump to reconsider. In aÂ series of tweets Monday morning, Graham called the decision âa stain on Americaâs honor,â warning that it has âsent the most dangerous signal possible âÂ America is an unreliable ally and itâs just a matter of time before China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea act out in dangerous ways.â Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) on Monday afternoon added himself to this list of avid Trump supporters breaking with him on this issue and urging a reversal. The Kurds â who have partnered with the Syrian Democratic Forces, becoming a dependable defense against the Islamic State in northern Syria â are considered a terrorist group by Turkey. With the U.S. presence gone from the region, the Kurds will be left vulnerable to attack. In his initial reaction to the harsh criticism of the new policy announcement, Trump on Monday issued a threat to Turkey on Twitter, vowing that if the nation âdoes anything that I, in my great and unmatched wisdom, consider to be off limits, I will totally destroy and obliterate the Economy of Turkey.â

articles.title: Susan Collins Voted To Confirm Kavanaugh A Year Ago. Mainers Havenât Forgotten.
articles.subtitle: Many felt betrayed by the senator, and theyâre taking action ahead of next yearâs election.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: On a warm October morning in 2018, busloads of women converged on Capitol Hill and made their way to Sen. Susan Collinsâ office. The Maine Republican was ostensibly on the fence about whether to vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court in light of several sexual misconduct allegations against him. Dozens of sexual assault survivors and their allies lingered outside Collinsâ door, hoping for a chance to explain why supporting Kavanaugh would be a monumental mistake. But Collins was busy that day, her staff said, poring through the FBIâs limited investigation into the accusations against him. The next day, Collins delivered a marathon speech from the Senate floor announcing she would vote for Kavanaugh, cementing a spot on the bench for President Donald Trumpâs second Supreme Court nominee. For some of her constituents, Collinsâ vote was an awakening. The most senior Republican woman in the Senate, a self-proclaimed pro-choice moderate, had just sung the praises of an accused sexual predator whose anti-abortion views could jeopardize the landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade decision. Others â those more familiar with Collinsâ recordÂ âÂ were less surprised: The four-term senator often hid behind her âmoderateâ cloak, but rarely broke with the Republican Party on votes where she could make a difference. In the end, Collinsâ support for Kavanaugh appeared to spark a nearly universal sentiment among Mainers who opposed his confirmation, whether they were longtime political activists or speaking out for the first time: betrayal. A year later, that feeling continues to enrage and mobilize many Maine voters. Though Collins hasnât yet formally announced her reelection campaign, sheâs amassed several Democratic challengers, including Maine House Speaker Sara Gideon; Betsy Sweet, a womenâs rights advocate and a former Maine gubernatorial candidate; and attorney Bre Kidman. Kidman, who uses the pronouns them and they, was one of the sexual assault survivors from Maine who traveled hundreds of miles to Washington last year in an attempt to persuade Collins not to vote for Kavanaugh. On the one-year anniversary of his confirmation, Kidman returned to Washington, where they joined hundreds of people outside the Supreme Court protesting Kavanaugh, including Rep. Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.), who introduced a resolution last month calling for his impeachment. âItâs not just about sexual assault. Itâs not just about a political move,â Kidman told HuffPost. âItâs about her not listening to us and I donât think anyone is going to let her forget it.â âLast year, I was nervous to beg my senator to do the right thing,â they added. âAnd this year, Iâm coming for her job and nerves be damned.â Hundreds of Collinsâ critics protested in Washington and across Maine on Sunday. In Bar Harbor, more than a dozen women staged a die-in for 43 minutes â the length of Collinsâ Kavanaugh speech on the Senate floor âÂ  in one of Maineâs most scenic parks, eliciting encouragement from tourists and local passersby. âPeople who werenât really active in the last election are ready to go knock on doors,â said Gail Leiser, a member of Indivisible MDI, a local chapter of the progressive movement that organized the demonstration. âThey have that sense of betrayal.â Collins has âalways been a wolf in sheepâs clothing,â she added. âSheâs always presented as a moderate, but would always toe the party line. A lot of people couldnât see that. But a lot of people have been awakened. What she says and what she does are two different things.â Additional protests unfolded across Maine on Sunday, from one outside Collinsâ house in Bangor, to one 130 miles southwest at Portland City Hall. Dini Merz, a co-founder of the progressive political action committee Mainers for Accountable Leadership,Â spoke at the Portland event. She came out as a sexual assault survivor a year ago while urging Collins to vote ânoâ on Kavanaugh. âElection after election, she has said sheâs pro-choice, that she believes in the right of women to have integrity over their own body,â Merz told HuffPost. âYet she was the pivotal vote in putting onto the Supreme Court someone with a known history of being restrictive of womenâs bodies. Everything he does on that court that confirms that is an albatross around her neck.â Within weeks of Collinsâ vote for Kavanaugh, a crowdfunding campaign raised millions of dollars toward whoever would become Collinsâ Democratic challenger in 2020. Collinsâ vote also proved lucrative for herself; she raised more money that quarter than any other fundraising period of her career, though the vast majority came from out-of-state. In the year since Kavanaughâs confirmation, several states have passed sweeping anti-abortion laws. Some of these Republican-led states hope the restrictive laws will force the Supreme Court to reconsider Roe v. Wade, which effectively made abortion legal nationwide. The Supreme Court announced Friday it would hear an abortion case this term â its first since the retirement of swing justice Anthony Kennedy last year. The case has stoked fears among womenâs rights advocates that their reproductive rights are on the chopping block. Still, Collins â whose office did not respond to a request for comment â has said she has no regrets over her vote to confirm Kavanaugh. In fact, she appears to have really embraced it despite the majority of her constituents having opposed it at the time. She sent out mailers accusing âfar left extremistsâ of attacking her over her vote, and attended a fundraiser in California where she was hailed the âhero of the Kavanaugh confirmation.â On Monday, Sweet, one of Collinsâ Democratic challengers in the 2020 race, delivered a petition to Collinsâ Portland office with over 1,200 signatures demanding she push for the FBI to reopen its investigation into Kavanaugh. âWhat Susan Collins did is just another slap in the face to women who feel they arenât believed or taken seriously,â she told HuffPost. âNo oneâs forgotten. ... This is still so raw for them.â

articles.title: In Turkey Vs. Kurds Dispute, Trump Chooses The Side Where He Has A Condo Complex
articles.subtitle: The administration is letting Turkey move into northern Syria to wipe out the Kurds, who have long fought Islamic State terrorism alongside the U.S.
articles.author: S.V. Date
articles.content: WASHINGTON â Donald Trumpâs abandonment of one of the United Statesâ strongest allies in the fight against Islamic State terrorists also happens to reward the authoritarian ruler of Turkey, where the U.S. president personally profits from the Trump Towers in Istanbul. It is not known whether the residential and commercial complex has ever come up in the various private conversations between Trump and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan since Trump took office. Seven years ago, Erdogan, then the countryâs prime minister, attended the grand opening of the twin skyscraper project, and Trumpâs elder daughter Ivanka praised him for doing so. âThank you Prime Minister Erdogan for joining us yesterday to celebrate the launch of #TrumpTowers Istanbul!â Ivanka Trump, now a top White House aide, wrote on April 12, 2012. The White House announced late Sunday night, without consulting U.S. allies in Europe or members of Congress, that Trump had agreed in a phone call with Erdogan to let Turkey occupy a strip of northern Syria, which is currently controlled by ethnic Kurds.Â The Kurds, who in recent years have proven to be the United Statesâ most effective allies in the fight against ISIS terrorists, have a centuries-old dispute with Turkey over their right to self-rule. Critics of the president said the announcement was exactly the sort of problem they have been highlighting since Trump announced his candidacy. âWeâve warned for years that Trumpâs decision to hold onto his business empire, particularly the properties in places like Turkey, would one day lead to a national security decision shrouded by his conflicts of interest,â said Jordan Libowitz, communications director for the watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington. Trump promised during his campaign that he would separate himself from his family business, which holds licensing deals with Trump-branded hotels, golf courses and condominiums all over the world. He reneged on that pledge and continues to profit from the Trump Organization, the holding company that owns the various elements in Trumpâs portfolio. A financial disclosure that Trump filed in May claims he earned between $100,001 and $1 million from the Istanbul project in the past year, the same range he claimed for the previous year. In a June 2017 filing, Trump claimed heâd earned between $1 million and $5 million from the project in the preceding 12 months. Exactly how much income the Istanbul project brings him, and how much of a tax write-off it generates, cannot be determined because Trump has refused to make his tax returns public, breaking with four decades of post-Watergate precedent. White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said Monday that Trumpâs decision had nothing to do with the Trump Towers Istanbul building complex. âOf course not,â she said. Whether the White House press office can reliably represent Trumpâs statements or views, however, is unclear. On Aug. 15, for example, Grisham described as âinaccurateâ a report that Trump was encouraging Israel to prohibit Democratic Reps. Ilhan Omar, of Minnesota, and Rashida Tlaib, of Michigan, from entering that country. Within an hour, Trump tweeted: âIt would show great weakness if Israel allowed Rep. Omar and Rep.Tlaib to visit.â Previously, Trumpâs press office had denied that Trump knew about his former lawyerâs payment to a porn star to buy her silence about an affair she said heâd had with her. In fact, Trump had conspired with Michael Cohen to make the $130,000 payment, and then wrote checks from the White House to repay him. The White Houseâs decision on Turkey this week has been criticized by the Kurds, by human rights groups and by Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. Apart from the Istanbul project, Libowitz said Turkish officials, including the trade minister, the defense minister and the ambassador to the United States, have made 14 separate visits to Trumpâs hotel a few blocks from the White House since his inauguration. âWe unfortunately have to ask how much he was influenced in this decision by his personal profits from Turkey,â Libowitz said. Robert Weissman, president of the liberal group Public Citizen, said itâs impossible to know whether Trump was guided primarily by his personal interest in his Istanbul project â or, alternatively, by pressure from Erdogan based on keeping secret details about the murder of U.S.-based journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed by Saudi Arabian government assassins in Istanbul last year. âBut a potential slaughter is in the making, and the sad truth is that it may be due in substantial part to Trump wanting to protect his licensing fees,â Weissman said.

articles.title: Pat Robertson: Trump Is âIn Danger Of Losing The Mandate Of Heavenâ
articles.subtitle: The right-wing televangelist tore into Trumpâs decision to leave Kurdish fighters in Syria to fend for themselves as Turkey prepares to invade.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Right-wing televangelist Pat RobertsonÂ once heralded President Donald TrumpÂ as âGodâs man for the job.â Now, he says the president is âin danger of losing the mandate of heaven.â On Monday, the Christian Broadcasting Network founder and â700 Clubâ host delivered an uncharacteristically strong rebuke of the White Houseâs announcement that it will stand by as Turkey prepares to invade northern Syria, leaving the American-allied Kurdish forces vulnerable to attack. Slamming the decision, Robertson said he is âabsolutely appalled that the United States is going to betrayâ the fighters, who have partnered with the Syrian Democratic Forces in the battle against the self-described Islamic State. Continuing, Robertson invoked the 2018 murder of Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed in Turkey allegedly at the behest of Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. âThe President, who allowed Khashoggi to be cut in pieces without any repercussions whatsoever, is now allowing the Christians and the Kurds to be massacred by the Turks,â Robertson said. âAnd I believe â and I want to say this with great solemnity â the president of the United States is in danger of losing the mandate of heaven if he permits this to happen.â Robertson, who initially showed little concern for Khashoggiâs death in relation to U.S.-Saudi relations, telling his audience that âyou donât blow up an international alliance over one person,â has also been a known defender of the presidentâs since before he was elected. Robertson and CBN have scored a handful of interviewsÂ with Trump, giving the network a level of access not afforded to most media outlets, as the president often just speaks via Twitter and occasionally on Fox News. Through CBN, Trump has no doubt been able to reach evangelical voters within his base. At times, Robertson has appeared to address these supporters, too, even attempting to explain away TrumpâsÂ âAccess Hollywoodâ tape scandal when, just a month before Election Day, audio emerged of Trump bragging about groping women. Instead of unequivocally condemning the remarks, Robertson praised Trump as being âlike the phoenixâ who would rise from the blow dealt to his campaign. But for Robertson, who is known for spreading hateful views including homophobia and Islamophobia on-air, Trumpâs stance on Syria crossed a line. The televangelistâs remarks add to the outcry from a growing list of conservatives and foreign policy experts who have expressed shockÂ at the White Houseâs announcement, warning it spells danger for both the U.S. and the Kurds.

articles.title: After Stumbles, White House Aims To Hone Impeachment Defense
articles.subtitle: Trump aides are honing their approach after two weeks of what allies have described as a listless and unfocused response to the impeachment probe.
articles.content: WASHINGTON (AP) â As House Democrats fire off more subpoenas, the White House is finalizing a high-stakes strategy to counter the impeachment threat to President Donald Trump: Stall. Obfuscate. Attack. Repeat. Trump aides are honing their approach after two weeks of what allies have described as a listless and unfocused response to the impeachment probe. One expected step is a letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rejecting the inquiry because Democrats havenât held a vote on the matter and moving to all but cease cooperation with Capitol Hill on key oversight matters. The strategy risks further provoking Democrats in the impeachment probe, setting up court challenges and the potential for lawmakers to draw up an article of impeachment accusing Trump of obstructing their investigations. But as lawmakers seek to amass ammunition to be used in an impeachment trial, the White House increasingly believes all-out warfare is its best course of action. âWhat they did to this country is unthinkable. Itâs lucky that Iâm the president. A lot of people said very few people could handle it. I sort of thrive on it,â Trump said Monday at the White House. âYou canât impeach a president for doing a great job. This is a scam.â House Democrats, for their part, issued a new round of subpoenas on Monday, this time to Defense Secretary Mark Esper and acting White House budget director Russell Vought. Pelosiâs office also released an open letter signed by 90 former national security officials who served in both Democratic and Republican administrations, voicing support for the whistleblower who raised concerns about Trumpâs efforts to get Ukraine to investigate political foe Joe Biden. âA responsible whistleblower makes all Americans safer by ensuring that serious wrongdoing can be investigated and addressed, thus advancing the cause of national security to which we have devoted our careers,â they wrote. âWhatever oneâs view of the matters discussed in the whistleblowerâs complaint, all Americans should be united in demanding that all branches of our government and all outlets of our media protect this whistleblower and his or her identity. Simply put, he or she has done what our law demands; now he or she deserves our protection.â The House Intelligence, Oversight and Foreign Affairs committees are investigating Trumpâs actions pressing Ukraine to investigate Biden and his son, potentially interfering in the 2020 election. The former vice president, for his part, has accused Trump of âfrantically pushing flat-out lies, debunked conspiracy theories and smears against me.â Trump also withheld hundreds of millions of dollars in military assistance to Ukraine. The White House has struggled to communicate its message beyond Trumpâs angry public proclamations and an endless stream of tweets. Indeed, top officials were absent from the Sunday talk shows, and the sole White House official to appear in public on Monday dodged questions on the inquiry. Asked whether he believed the president was joking or in any way not serious when he suggested publicly that China should investigate the Bidens, Larry Kudlow, Trumpâs top economic adviser, responded: âI donât honestly know.â Trump and his teamâs initial strategy had been to try to undermine the credibility of the intelligence community whistleblower who first raised questions about Trumpâs conduct with Ukraine, just as they tried to undercut special counsel Robert Mueller and his team. They stressed that the whistleblower had only second- or third-hand information and alleged that the person misrepresented the presidentâs efforts. But now a second whistleblower has come forward to corroborate the information, and a cache of text messages echoes the concerns that have been laid out. As the impeachment inquiry ramps up, the White House plans to reprise its past response to congressional oversight: open scorn. The presidentâs aides have ignored document requests and subpoenas, invoked executive privilege â going so far as to argue that the privilege extends to informal presidential advisers who have never held White House jobs â and all but dared Democrats to hold them in contempt. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo blew a Friday deadline for complying with a subpoena. But he said over the weekend that the State Department had sent a letter to Congress as its initial response to the request. He also indicated a new willingness to comply, saying: âWeâll obviously do all the things that weâre required to do by law.â The letter to Pelosi has been delayed as aides work to finalize legislative and communications plans to go along with the legal strategy. At the same time, Trumpâs campaign, which has reported a fundraising surge since the impeachment inquiry, held a curiously timed briefing call with reporters Monday to trumpet its efforts to overhaul the delegate selection process to ensure there is no drama at the Republican National Convention. Trump campaign officials said the effort had nothing to do with concerns about fending off a primary challenge. ___ Follow Colvin on Twitter at https://twitter.com/colvinj , Miller at https://twitter.com/zekejmiller and Lemire at https://twitter.com/JonLemire

articles.title: House Democrats Mull Hiding Whistleblowerâs Identity From GOP During Testimony: Report
articles.subtitle: Democrats are allegedly considering steps like having the Ukraine whistleblower testify remotely to protect the individual, according to The Washington Post.
articles.author: Sanjana Karanth
articles.content: House Democrats are allegedly working to mask the Ukraine scandal whistleblowerâs identity from Republican lawmakers who are President Donald Trumpâs allies in a potential effort to ensure the individualâs safety during testimony at a time when the president is actively trying to expose the person who wrote the bombshell complaint that sparked an impeachment inquiry. Among the protocols Democrats are considering to protect the anonymous intelligence official include having the whistleblower testify remotely with an obscured appearance and voice, three unnamed officials familiar with the discussions told The Washington Post on Monday. Other potential steps, according to the Post, include having the whistleblower testify behind a partition or testify via audio only. HuffPost could not independently confirm the considerations. The alleged discussions represent a growing divide and lack of trust between parties in the House as the chamberâs Foreign Affairs, Oversight and Intelligence committees investigate Trumpâs actions pressuring Ukraine to investigate political rival Joe Biden and his son while the president withheld nearly $400 million in approved U.S. military aid to the country. The committee investigations are part of the impeachment inquiry, which House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced Sept. 24 after reports surfaced of the whistleblowerâs complaint andÂ a summary of Trumpâs July 25 call to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was released by the White House that corroborated the whistleblowerâs report. The Postâs report about potential steps to mask the whistleblowerâs identity comes a day after 90 former national security officials who served under both Democratic and Republican presidents signed an open letter defending the whistleblower and stressing the necessity of protecting the individualâs identity. âWhatever oneâs view of the matters discussed in the whistleblowerâs complaint, all Americans should be united in demanding that all branches of our government and all outlets of our media protect this whistleblower and his or her identity,â the letter stated. âSimply put, he or she has done what our law demands; now he or she deserves our protection.â The whistleblowerâs attorneys have also voiced concern for their clientâs safety, specifically after Trump falsely accused the individual of âtreasonâ despite the whistleblower going through the appropriate channels to relay concerns. The president made veiled threats that the whistleblower should be âdealt withâ in violent ways and has repeatedly demanded to meet the individual and find out the personâs identity. âYou know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart with spies and treason, right?â Trump said, according to audio reported by the Los Angeles Times. âWe used to handle it a little differently than we do now.â Trumpâs Republican allies in Congress and conservative media have joined the president in dismissing the whistleblower, accusing the individual of being politically biased. âThatâs Washington speak for, âThey were out to get the President,ââ tweeted Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), the ranking member on the House Oversight Committee. As part of their investigation, House Democrats also issued subpoenas on Monday to Defense Secretary Mark Esper and acting White House budget director Russell Vought. The Pentagon and the Office of Management and Budget have until Oct. 15 to comply. The House has already sent out several other subpoenas, including to the White House, Vice President Mike Pence,Â Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giuliani and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Pompeo missed the Friday deadline for complying with his subpoenaÂ but said over the weekend that the State Department had sent a letter to Congress in response to the request. Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, which is helping to lead the impeachment inquiry, warned last week that any stonewalling by the White House will be considered obstruction of justice.

articles.title: Trump On Turkey: âI Have A Little Conflict Of Interest ... Itâs Called Trump Towersâ
articles.subtitle: The president, in his own words in 2015, zeroes in on a problem linked to his order to abandon Kurdish allies to a Turkish assault in Syria.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: As even Republican lawmakers and foreign policy experts reel over Donald Trumpâs unilateral decision to abandon Kurdish allies to an assault from Turkey in Syria, the president himself apparently has an explanation: âI have a little conflict of interestâ concerning Turkey. Trump made the comment in a Breitbart News interview in December 2015 during his presidential campaign when asked how he would handle Turkey and Syria. âI have a little conflict of interest âcause I have a major, major building in Istanbul,â Trump boasted in response. âItâs a tremendously successful job. Itâs called Trump Towers â two towers, instead of one, not the usual one; itâs two. And Iâve gotten to know Turkey very well. Theyâre amazing people, theyâre incredible people. They have a strong leader.â He said then that the situation was âcomplicated,â adding, âI thrive on complicated.â Trump did not reveal what he would do in the region if he were to become commander in chief. Trump still profits from Trump Towers in Istanbul, and the âstrong leaderâ then was the same as now: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Though his continuing business interest in Istanbul is widely known, his own admission that it represents a conflict of interest is startling. Critics have long argued that Trump, as presidents traditionally do, should divest from his businesses to avoid conflicts of interest that threaten to put his personal benefit ahead of the nationâs. In a late Sunday phone call with Erdogan, Trump suddenly agreed to let Turkey occupy a strip of northern Syria, currently controlled by ethnic Kurds who have been Americaâs most effective allies in battling the so-called Islamic State. Now supporters fear a U.S.-enabled slaughter of the Kurds, who have a centuries-long dispute with Turkey over self-rule. âEveryone was absolutely flabbergasted by this,â retired Adm. James Stavridis said Monday on MSNBC, referring to the Pentagon perspective on Trumpâs action. âNobody saw it coming, and that is a real problem when youâre trying to conduct not only foreign policy ... but also military operations. That kind of whipsawing effect is extremely detrimental, not only in this tactical situation but strategically, as our planners try and prepare in other theaters, from North Korea to Afghanistan.â (See the video above at 9:18.) White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said Monday that Trumpâs decision had nothing to do with the Trump Towers Istanbul complex. Check out Trumpâs Breitbart interview about his âconflict of interestâ below. The section on Turkey begins at the start. CORRECTION: A previous version of this article stated that Trump owns Trump Towers in Istanbul. Rather, according to The New York Times, he licensed his name to the developers for a fee.

articles.title: Trump Claims Poll Numbers Have Zoomed 17 Points As He Defends Abandonment Of Kurds
articles.subtitle: And the U.S. military âdid not have ammunitionâ when he âtook over,â he explained.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: In a fractured White House news conference Monday, President Donald Trump claimed poll numbers supporting him have jumped 17 percentage points. Thatâs despite an impeachment inquiry and the uproar over his decision Sunday night to draw down U.S. troops asÂ Kurdish allies face a Turkish incursion into Syria. Itâs not known which poll, if any, Trump was citing. Trump also insisted that the U.S. military had no ammunition when he âtook overâ as commander in chief, and he characterized the Kurds and the Turks as ânatural enemies.â He presented the wide-ranging remarks before signing a trade agreement with Japan. The president called the HouseÂ impeachment inquiryÂ into his activities a âscam.â He added: âAnd the people are wise to it. And thatâs why my polls went up, I think they said, 17 points in the last two or three days. Iâve never had that one.â The impeachment inquiry was launched last month. Its focus is a July 25 phone call from Trump to Ukraineâs president pressing him to launch an investigation into political rival Joe Biden. The request was made as Trump was withholding military aid to Ukraine. Polls from CNN/SSRS, Monmouth, Quinnipiac, Reuters/Ipsos, Economist/YouGov, as well as new HuffPost/YouGov polling, actually reveal growing support for impeachment. As of last week, polls generally found support for impeachment tying or modestly outstripping opposition. As for Trumpâs performance rating, last weekâs Monmouth University poll found 41% of Americans approved of his job performance, and 53% disapproved, showing little change. As for his controversial decision on Syria, Trump appeared resigned Monday to inevitable fighting between Turkey and the Kurds because theyâre ânatural enemies.â He seemed surprised to note that a historian said Monday that theyâve been fighting for âhundreds of years.â He boasted that ISIS was defeated, thanks largely to him, particularly because he supplied the U.S. military with ammunition when it had none. âWhen I took over our military, we didnât have ammunition,â he explained. âI was told by a top general, maybe the top of them all: âSir, Iâm sorry, sir, we donât have ammunition.â I said, âI will never let another president have that happen to him or her. We didnât have ammunition.ââ

articles.title: Kevin McAleenan, Homeland Security Chief, Shouted Off Stage At Georgetown Event
articles.subtitle: Activists said the acting secretaryâs appearance at a law school conference would have given the Trump administration a âplatform to spread hatred.â
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: Kevin McAleenan, the acting secretary of homeland security, was shouted off stage at an immigration event at Georgetown Universityâs law school on Monday. A group of protesters interrupted McAleenan for about 8 minutes at Georgetownâs annual Immigration Law and Policy Conference, leaving the official visibly frustrated as he tried to read a speech about the Trump administrationâs hard-line policies on the southern border with Mexico. Activists bearing a sign reading âStand with Immigrantsâ shouted âHate is not normalâ and âWhy are you listening to this crook?â as others read off the names of migrant children who have died in Customs and Border Protection custody. After the third interruption, McAleenan thanked the eventâs organizer and left the stage. The Department of Homeland SecurityÂ lambasted the activists in a statementÂ Monday, saying attendees âwould have learned more about DHSâs successful strategy to work with international partners to reduce unlawful migration and end the exploitation of children by smugglers and cartelsâ if the acting secretary had been allowed to speak. âThe First Amendment guarantees all Americans the right to free speech and assembly.
