Unfortunately that right was robbed from many who were scheduled to speak and attend todayâs event at Georgetown,â DHS said in the statement. âUnfortunately the Acting Secretary and the audience did not get the opportunity to engage in a robust dialogue this morning due to the disruptions of a few activists.â Credo Action, the group that organized the protest, rejected any criticism of its actions however, saying institutions that feature Trump administration officials could âexpect to hear from us.â âNo Trump henchmen should be given a platform to spread hatred or defend the racist, xenophobic policies put into place by Donald Trump and Stephen Miller,â Nicole Regalado, Credoâs campaign director, said in a statement. âInstitutions that elevate the architects and enforcers of Trumpâs hate and normalize that cruelty can expect to hear from us.â President Donald Trump and his immigration officials have faced years of criticism over their handling of migrants at the southern border, including the governmentâs family separation policy and its recent decision to force asylum seekers to wait in Mexico. The White House also said last month it planned to slash the U.S. refugee resettlement program by nearly half. McAleenan has become one of the most public faces of that effort after replacing former Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, who was forced out in April by a president unhappy with the governmentâs efforts to stop the flow of migrants across the border. McAleenan has reportedlyÂ grown more isolated in the departmentÂ despite his work to uphold Trumpâs policy agenda. In an interview with The Washington Post, he broke with the president to say the family separation policy was âwell intendedâ but that it âwent too far.â Credo Action organized an open letter before his appearance Monday requesting his invitation be withdrawn, and a separate petition signed by hundreds of Georgetown students and faculty also made such a request. âWe cannot have rule of law unless the legal academy distinguishes between raw power and legally constrained governance,â Heidi Li Feldman, a law professor at Georgetown, said in a statement. âAs a teacher and scholar of American law, I reject the use of Georgetown University Law School as a vehicle for legitimizing fundamental and pervasive lawless government policies and activities.â

articles.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Tears Into Republicansâ âJust A Jokeâ Defense Of Trump
articles.subtitle: âWhen Republicans say our nationâs laws are âjust a joke,â they mean it,â the Democratic lawmaker tweeted.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) on Monday night used Twitter to criticize the Republicans who defend some of President Donald Trumpâs controversial assertions as being âjust a joke.â The lawmaker tweeted a CNN Politics articleÂ that detailed multiple times Trump has made a wild statement, only for it to be downplayed by his high-profile GOP supporters as nothing more than a gag â the latest being Trumpâs suggestion that China should investigate his potential 2020 rival Joe Biden. âWhen Republicans say our nationâs laws are âjust a joke,â they mean it,â Ocasio-Cortez wrote. âThey treat our country as a joke, our communities as a joke, and our future as a joke. For the GOP, as long as the rich get richer, they are happy to play games with American lives.â Ocasio-Cortez was last week caught up in a bizarre hoax â reportedly orchestrated by the pro-Trump, right-wing LaRouche PAC group â in which a purported supporter ranted at her during a town hall event about eating babies in a bid to beat the climate crisis.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Visits Michiganâs Most Polluted ZIP Code
articles.subtitle: The Massachusetts senator toured an area visited three times by former fellow presidential candidate Jay Inslee, whose climate policy she has adopted.
articles.author: Alexander C. Kaufman
articles.content: Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren visited Michiganâs most polluted ZIP code for the first time last week. The Massachusetts senator toured a community center and a school in the 48217 ZIP code in southwestern Detroit, where playgrounds sit sandwiched between the Great Lake Stateâs only oil refinery and car manufacturing plants. Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) guided the Sept. 29 visit, of which the campaign shared video with HuffPost. âWhatâs that smell?â Warren says at the start of the video, turning to Tlaib in the backseat of an SUV. âThatâs what my people smell every day,â the congresswoman says. âI thought the smell was normal. I really did. I didnât realize that it was killing us.â Just as gobbling fatty snacks at the Iowa State Fair is a rite of passage for top-tier presidential hopefuls, a pilgrimage to the 48217 is now becoming a touchstone for any contender who wants to be taken seriously on the nationâs environment. Warren, citing a packed scheduled, passed on a chance to visit the area in July, when community activists invited all 20 candidates participating in the second round of Democratic primary debates in Detroit. Of the three who agreed to come â former Rep. Beto OâRourke of Texas, former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro and Washington Gov. Jay Inslee â only Inslee, then running as the raceâs long-shot climate candidate, showed up. It was Insleeâs third time in the 48217. Warren, a potential front-runner for the Democratic nomination, said sheâd adopt much of Insleeâs book-length stack of climate proposals when the Evergreen State governor dropped out to run for reelection at home in August. Now sheâs covering the same ground, visiting the kind of frontline community that could lend her credibility as her campaign courts older Black voters, a key demographic to winning the nomination. The area, crisscrossed by highways and choked by air emissions, made a powerful backdrop for Warren just days after releasing a meaty proposal to restore union membership. The policy outline came out just as the United Auto Workers union was preparing for a long-haul strike against Detroit giant General Motors. After photographing legally questionable flaring â when excess gas is vented into the air and burned â at the Marathon Petroleum Corp. refinery next door to the Kemeny Recreation Center, Warren drove by Salina Elementary School, where Tlaib says officials only recently installed air filtration systems to protect students from cancer-causing particulate matter spewed from the neighboring AK Steel plant. âThese big corporations have enough muscle with the government that they squeeze it to get tax breaks. So the cost of running these schools and keeping these roads paved fall disproportionately on you,â Warren says to a trio of activists. âSo youâre not only paying the cost in terms of what you breathe, what your children breathe, your bodies â youâre also paying the cost out of pocket.â

articles.title: Ex-Rudy Giuliani Aide: âHe Looks Like A Right-Wing Conspiracy Nutâ
articles.subtitle: âThere was an old Rudy and a new Rudy,â said Ken Frydman, who worked on the former New York City mayorâs 1993 campaign.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Ken Frydman, a former campaign press secretary to President Donald Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, on Monday said his former boss now âlooks like a right-wing conspiracy nut.â âThere was an old Rudy and a new Rudy,â Frydman, who worked on Giulianiâs successful 1993 New York mayoral campaign, told MSNBCâs Ari Melber. âThe old Rudy listened because he wanted to win,â he explained. âThe new Rudy doesnât listen anymore because he won and you canât tell him anything he doesnât know.â âI donât think, as many people think, heâs unhinged or suffering from dementia,â Frydman said. âI think that he is zealously trying to protect his golden goose, frankly, the president.â But Frydman said Giuliani is ânot doing a good jobâ because he is ânot telling the truth and itâs clear that he is fumbling and bumbling in his attempts to do that.â Frydmanâs comments echoed those he made in a scathing op-ed that The New York Times published earlier Monday,Â and are in stark contrast to an article he wrote for the New York Daily News in 2018 in which he said he still respected Giuliani for âplaying hardball like he always has.â In the Times article â titled âWhat Happed to Rudy Giuliani?â â Frydman lamented how ââAmericaâs Mayor,â as Rudy was called after Sept. 11, is today President Trumpâs bumbling personal lawyer and henchman, his apologist and defender of the indefensible.â He accused Giuliani of now doing Trumpâs âdirty workâ in âtrying to cover up the Ukrainian cover-up and attacking a Democratic presidential front-runner, Joe Biden, and his son, Hunter.â âWatching and reading Rudyâs ferocious lying for Mr. Trump, whether on Fox or CNN, forced me to re-examine his last 25 years, especially the profiteering from Sept. 11,â Frydman wrote. âBut Ukraine was the coup de grÃ¢ce. We who admired him for so long expected much more from Rudy Giuliani and his legacy.â Check out the full interview above and the Times op-ed here.

articles.title: âIt Was Like A Rallying Cryâ: Bernie Sanders Campaign Surges Ahead After Heart Attack
articles.subtitle: The Vermont senatorâs presidential campaign and top supporters say they are buoyed by a wave of support following the 78-year-oldâs hospitalization.
articles.author: Daniel Marans
articles.content: Less than a week after suffering a heart attack, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) addressed hundreds of campaign staffers on Monday afternoon to offer his gratitude for their work and assure them he is more committed than ever to winning the Democratic presidential nomination. âIronically, I will tell you that I feel more strongly about the need for a political revolution today than I did when I began,â he said, according to the campaign. The mood amongst the staffers who were on the brief call was boisterous,Â according to three people who were on the call who requested anonymity to speak without authorization. One of the campaign aides described being moved by Sandersâ reminder that their campaign â which boasts the slogan, âNot me. Us.â â was about the hopes and dreams of millions of working people seeking a better life. âYou work so fucking hard on these things, that itâs good to hear the person you work for have this really kind of humbling approach to it all,â the aide said. âHe said âDonât take your eye off the ballâ in a way that really got people moving.â The call embodied the broader response that the campaign has had since Sanders was hospitalized late Tuesday night with chest pain that ended up being a âmyocardial infarction,â or heart attack: That Sanders is well on his way back to full health, that his fight for Medicare for All is more personal than ever, and that he has no plans to slow down his campaign. âThe working class Americans who are the core of Bernieâs movement wake up each day and battle adversity of all kinds, and we believe they will be drawn even closer to the senator as he continues to fight for a shared vision to transform our country so it works for all of us â not just the wealthy and well-connected,â Sanders campaign manager Faiz Shakir said in a statement on Monday. Sanders, 78, was treated in Las Vegas, Nevada, with the insertion of two stents to unclog one of his arteries. On Friday, he emerged from the hospital alongside his wife Jane with a triumphant fist in the air, recorded a video for his supporters on social media, and returned home to Burlington, Vermont. He and his wife took a walk in the rain on Monday, which CNN captured on camera. In addition to facing the politically tricky task of persuading primary voters that a septuagenarian heart attack survivor is up to the task of winning the White House, the Sanders campaign is already working to quiet skepticism of its immediate response to his ailment. Nearly three days passed between Sandersâ hospitalization and the announcement on Friday that he had suffered a heart attack. Sandersâ team maintains that they provided the accurate medical information as soon as it was available; they were not sure of the diagnosis until he was discharged from the hospital. In keeping with a mid-September promise, Sanders will be releasing his full medical records in the near future, though the campaign did not provide any additional details about timing. The Sanders campaign did its best to continue with business as usual in the days following his hospitalization. Over the weekend, the campaign dispatched three of its co-chairs â former Ohio state Sen. Nina Turner, California Rep. Ro Khanna and San Juan, Puerto Rico, Mayor Carmen YulÃ­n Cruz â to barnstorm the early primary states with a packed schedule of events. And early Monday morning, the campaign released Sandersâ plan to get corporate money out of politics, including the cash-riddled presidential nominating conventions. Sanders will have his first chance to demonstrate his vitality at the fourth Democratic presidential debate in Westerville, Ohio, on Oct. 15. The Vermont senator does not have any public events planned prior to the debate; he canceled a scheduled appearance at an LGBTQ town hall on CNN this Thursday. In the meantime, the campaign is keen to showcase the strength of Sandersâ support network, which appears to have been inspired by his hospitalization to redouble their efforts on his behalf. The campaign announced on Sunday that its staff and volunteers had met its goal of making 1 million phone calls to voters in Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, South Carolina and California in ten daysâ time. According to an aide, the campaign experienced a spike in volunteers on Wednesday after news of Sandersâ hospitalization broke, pushing the phone call tally up to 1.3 million. The figure is not surprising given the frenzy of emotion among his supporters following his hospitalization. A number of Sanders partisans with significant social media followings downplayed the significance of the stent procedure and highlighted the speed of Sandersâ recovery. And the campaign racked up 8,000 donations on Wednesday, according to co-chair, Rep. Ro Khanna of California. One of the donors was RoseAnn DeMoro, the former executive director of the National Nurses United union, and a prominent campaign supporter, who chipped in $100. âIt was like a rallying cry. It was incredible,â DeMoro said of the outpouring of support for Sanders. âThatâs the difference between having a movement as opposed to just a campaign.â Sanders supporters, many of whom have lost faith in more conventional politicians, are famously passionate in their support for Sanders. The prospect that a health scare could damage his standing in the polls prompted so much renewed involvement due to supportersâ belief that Sanders is uniquely equipped to defeat Trump and solve the countryâs problems, according to Jim Zogby, a pollster and top Sanders surrogate. âPeople all of a sudden woke up and said, âBernie might not be in the mix â this canât be,ââ said Zogby, who also runs the Arab American Institute. âHe comes back to an invigorated campaign with a staff and a support base that has doubled down in their efforts to make this happen. Because they realize that for them â and for me â heâs the critical choice.â Calls for SandersÂ to drop out of the race â however few they were in number â only riled up Sandersâ supporters, many of whom already firmly believe that the established media and political classes will stop at nothing to prevent Sanders from winning. The Thursday release of âRising Up,â a five-minute video created by Matt Orfalea, a Sanders activist not affiliated with the campaign, added to the dramatic âus versus themâ narrative that has long animated Bernie World. Orfaleaâs video, which many called an advertisement, showed numerous clips of pundits, reporters and comedians mocking Sanders on a series of topics, juxtaposed with footage of him doing the opposite âÂ greeting supporters with a smile, listening sympathetically, speaking to crowds of diverse voters. The spot, which featured some of the do-it-yourself charm of the 2016 campaign, earned plaudits from prominent Democrats who are not supporting Sanders but are nonetheless sympathetic to claims of media bias against him. In just a few days, the video racked up over 6.3 million views on Twitter alone â far more than Sandersâ first official campaign ad, which came out days earlier. âItâs something that deeply resonates and it was released at the perfect moment, when Bernie needed it the most,â Rebecca Katz, a progressive strategist who is not aligned with any presidential candidate, said of the video. âItâs the kind of things voters donât just watch but also share.â A question on the minds of some poll watchers is nonetheless how Sandersâ heart attack affects the campaign of Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, 70, a fellow progressive who has surpassed Sanders in national and early primary-state polls. In a gesture of solidarity, Warrenâs campaign bought dinner on Wednesday for Sandersâ staff at his campaign headquarters in Washington. The Warren campaign declined to comment for this story. But two prominent Warren supporters suggested that Sandersâ continued presence in the race could only help her candidacy. Adam Green, a co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, which has endorsed Warren, argued that the presence of another left candidate is mutually beneficial. It increases the legitimacy of their shared ideas, and is liable to dissuade super-rich donors from erecting a super PAC to take out either one of them, he posited. âIf you knock one out, you help the other,â Green said of such a scenario. âAnd if you run ads hitting both of them, you just elevate them as the two most clear and transformational progressives.â Murshed Zaheed, a partner at the progressive communications firm Megaphone Strategies who previously worked for former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.), echoed Greenâs sentiments, likening it to a progressive race to the top. âThereâs no coincidence that both of them are smashing the neoliberals in this race in terms of fundraising,â said Zaheed. âCompetition makes each one better.â

articles.title: Supreme Court Weighs Major Gay, Transgender Employment Rights Cases
articles.subtitle: Justices are set to hear two hours of arguments in three related cases, with LGBTQ rights activists planning demonstrations outside the courthouse.
articles.content: WASHINGTON, Oct 8 (Reuters) - The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday wades into a major LGBT rights dispute over whether a landmark decades-old federal anti-discrimination law that prohibits employment discrimination on the basis of sex covers gay and transgender workers. The justices, a day after kicking off their new nine-month term, are set to hear two hours of arguments in three related cases, with LGBT rights activists planning demonstrations outside the courthouse. The Supreme Court delivered an important gay rights decision in 2015 legalizing same-sex marriage nationwide. Its dynamics on LGBT issues, however, changed following the 2018 retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy, a conservative who backed gay rights in major cases and wrote the same-sex marriage ruling. At issue is whether gay and transgender people are protected under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which forbids employers from discriminating against employees on the basis of sex as well as race, color, national origin and religion. The legal fight focuses on the definition of âsexâ in Title VII. The plaintiffs, along with civil rights groups and many large companies, have argued that discriminating against gay and transgender workers is inherently based on their sex and consequently is illegal. The courtâs 5-4 conservative majority includes two justices appointed by President Donald Trump, whose administration has argued that Title VII does not cover sexual orientation or gender identity. The arguments present the court with its first major test on gay and transgender rights since Trump appointed conservative Justice Brett Kavanaugh to replace Kennedy, with the four liberal justices sympathetic to LGBT rights. Kavanaugh, whose approach to gay rights is unclear, could provide a pivotal vote. A ruling in favor of the plaintiffs would give gay and transgender workers greater protections, especially in the 28 U.S. states that do not already have comprehensive measures against employment discrimination. A ruling against the plaintiffs would mean gay and transgender people in those states would have few options to challenge workplace discrimination. The court will hear two cases about gay people who have said they were fired due to their sexual orientation. One involves a former county child welfare services coordinator from Georgia named Gerald Bostock. The other involves a New York skydiving instructor named Donald Zarda. He died after the case began and the matter is being pursued by his estate. The third case involves a Detroit funeral homeâs bid to reverse a lower court ruling that it violated Title VII by firing a transgender funeral director named Aimee Stephens after Stephens revealed plans to transition from male to female. Rulings in the cases are due by the end of June. Trump, a Republican with vigorous support among evangelicalChristian voters, has pursued policies taking aim at gay and transgender rights. His administration has supported the right of certain businesses to refuse to serve gay people on the basis of religious objections to gay marriage, restricted transgender service members in the military and rescinded protections on bathroom access for transgender students in public schools. Trumpâs Justice Department and the employers in the cases have argued that Congress did not intend for Title VII to cover gay and transgender people when it passed the law. Conservative religious groups and various Republican-led states back the administration. Big business, typically eager to avoid liability in employment disputes, is backing the LGBT plaintiffs. More than 200 companies, including Amazon, Alphabet Incâs Google and Bank of America Corp, joined a friend-of-the-court brief asking the justices to rule in favor of the plaintiffs. (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley and Andrew Chung)

articles.title: Senator Lindsey Graham Invites Rudy Giuliani To Testify Before Congress
articles.subtitle: The Senate Judiciary Committee chairman says he wants to give the presidentâs attorney the opportunity to air his âconcernsâ about Ukraine.
articles.author: Igor Bobic
articles.content: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) on Tuesday invited Rudy Giuliani to testify about what he called âdisturbing allegationsâ brought forward by President Donald Trumpâs personal attorney regarding âcorruption in Ukraineâ and the firing of a prosecutor there. âGiven the House of Representativesâ behavior, it is time for the Senate to inquire about corruption and other improprieties involving Ukraine,â Graham wrote in a tweet, inviting Giuliani to appear before his panel. Giuliani and Trump have repeatedly made the unsubstantiated allegation that former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination to face Trump in 2020, pushed for the firing of Ukrainian prosecutor Viktor Shokin while Biden was in office in order to shield Ukranian energy company Burisma, which his son Hunter Biden served on the board of. However, there is no evidence Biden intentionally tried to help his son by urging Shokinâs ouster, and both Bidens have denied any wrongdoing. Biden and others in the Obama administration have said theyÂ urged for Shokinâs dismissalÂ because he was accused of neglecting corruption in his office and for failing to bring corruption cases. The calls for reforms to Ukraineâs prosecutor generalâs office at the time also came from other nations, as well as a pair of Republican senators â Rob Portman of Ohio and Ron Johnson of Wisconsin. Giuliani has found himself ensnared in the House impeachment probe, which was fueled by Trumpâs repeated requests for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to aid both Giuliani and Attorney General William Barr in an investigation of Biden.Â Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee last week subpoenaed Giuliani for documents dating back to January 2017 regarding his communications with Ukrainian officials. Itâs not clear yet whether Giulianiâs testimony would occur in a public or private setting. The former New York City mayor has not said whether he will comply, but an appearance in public could be risky for him. Democrats are eager to cross-examine the presidentâs personal lawyer about his role in the controversy, as Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), a 2020 presidential candidate and Judiciary Committee member, made clear on Tuesday: Sens. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Cory Booker of New Jersey, two other candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination next year, also serve on the panel. Democrats have alsoÂ written to Graham requesting he invite Barr and other senior Trump administration officials to testify about the matter, but the GOP chairman has resisted, characterizing the move as an effort to smear Trump.

articles.title: How Instagram Became A Hotspot For Vile Conspiracies And 2020 Disinformation
articles.subtitle: The platformâs latest influencers are election hoaxers and conspiracy theorists.
articles.content: Instagram is poised to be one of the worst breeding grounds for political fake news ahead of the 2020 election, and hardly anyone is paying attention. The Facebook-owned platform has largely escaped the leery eye cast upon its parent company and Twitter, which have taken most of the blame for housing foreign disinformation campaigns in 2016.Â ButÂ Instagram was âperhaps the most effective platformâ that the Internet Research Agency â Russiaâs Kremlin-linked troll farm â used to target voters in the last election, according to a report commissioned by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. And as one of the fastest-growing social media platforms, Instagram has around 1 billion active users (more than three times as many as Twitter) and is a go-to source for political news among Gen ZersÂ â most of whom will be old enough to vote next year. By following just one conspiracy-minded account on Instagram, users can wind up viewing dozens more â all promoted by a platform that is designed to keep them on the app even if it means distributing propaganda to do so. âInstagram has skated by,â said Paul Barrett, an adjunct law professor at New York University and author of the report âDisinformation and the 2020 Election.âÂ âPeople donât realize the potential for sliding into the swamp of disinformation on Instagram.â I wanted to see firsthand how political disinformation performs on Instagram, so I created a new account and searched for profiles promoting QAnon â the viral, far-right conspiracy theory movement that baselessly claims thereâs a deep-state cabal of Satanic, liberal pedophiles trying to take down Trump. It wasnât hard to find them. The first QAnon profile I saw had nearly 60,000 followers, and after I clicked on it, Instagram took the reins and recommended dozens more for me to follow. So, I followed them. As I did, more and more Instagram-recommended QAnon accounts appeared in their place, like a digital conveyor belt of hyperpartisan fringe content. Hereâs a quick glimpse of what I saw next on my âExploreâ page â the algorithmically curated collection of public posts that Instagram customizes for each user. Thatâs outside the feed of posts directly from accounts Iâd followed at Instagramâs suggestion, which featured images such as these: The point here is not that Instagram has a QAnon problem. (Although, as The Atlantic first observed, it does.) The point is that Instagram, like other major platforms, rewards sensational clickbait with algorithmic promotion â thereby incentivizing people to produce more of it. Itâs a mutually beneficial relationship: Greater user engagement ultimately means more ad revenue for Instagram and a larger audience for fake news creators. And by recommending such content, Instagram also legitimizes it, especially as more and more people turn to social media sites including Instagram for their news. âAs long as the algorithm tends to favor sensationalistic or outrageous or negative material, then â perhaps completely inadvertently â the platform is, in a sense, encouraging purveyors of disinformation to take advantage of it,âÂ  Barrett said. Instagram has been secretive about how, exactly, its algorithm works, so itâs difficult to know much about it with any degree of certainty. But itâs easy to envision how the algorithm could take an undecided voter seeking information about a certain conspiracy theory, for example, and pull them into an echo chamber of political disinformation. Russiaâs Internet Research Agency garnered 187 million user engagements on Instagram, far exceeding its 77 million engagements on Facebook and 73 million on Twitter. Instagramâs ability to outperform its parent company in this way âmay indicate its strength as a tool in image-centric memetic (meme) warfare,â the Senate report noted, warning that Instagram âis likely to be a key battlegroundâ going forward. Memes are an increasingly popular vehicle for disinformation: Theyâre punchy, easy to make, instantly impactful and appealing across generations. Theyâre also flourishing on Instagram, which was designed specifically to share images. The site is crawling with hoax memes pushing misleading or blatantly false messages about political leaders and their supporters, as well as democratic institutions â and theyâre not going anywhere. Social media companies âare motivated to spread all types of memes, good or bad,â meme expert Jennifer Grygiel told HuffPostâs âBetween The Lines.â Theyâre reluctant to act as gatekeepers â even when it comes to malicious content â because they âare motivated by the bottom line, which is to drawing your time and attention,â Grygiel said. Instagram told HuffPost in a statement that âfighting misinformation is criticalâ and that it had âlearned many lessons from 2016.âÂ But rather than banning posts that promote fake news altogether, the company has started demoting them on a case-by-case basis. It recently expanded its reporting tool to allow users to flag misinformation that they encounter on the platform. Those with the latest version of the app will see âfalse informationâ at the bottom of a list of reportable items, including nudity, pornography, self injury and other options. If Instagram determines that a post has been correctly flagged as misinformation, it wonât delete it. Instead, it will just limit the postâs reach by hiding it from the public âExploreâ feed. Thatâs why each of the following posts â which contain provably false information â were still online at the time of this articleâs publication, more than a week after I reported them. Thus far, Instagram has actually been more aggressive in its crackdown on vaguely âsexually suggestiveâ content than it has on flagrant political disinformation. Its refusal to remove verified falsehoods is perhaps best illustrated by its approach to doctored videos including âdeepfakesâ and âshallowfakes,â which present another growing challenge in the age of online disinformation. Not long after Facebook declined to take down a video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi that was edited to make her seem drunk, a pair of deepfakes of Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg popped up on Instagram, in which Zuckerberg appeared to claim that he owns people and controls their future. Instagram left them up, along with deepfakes of several other public figures. Experts have cautioned that the decision by major social media companies to allow maliciously distorted videos and other forms of fake news on their platforms could be disastrous for democracy. What if a deepfake falsely showing a presidential candidate doing something scandalous were to go viral on the eve of the election? Generally speaking, social media algorithms are designed to amplify content that will keep users engaged for as long as possible. We use Instagram, YouTube, Twitter and other sites for free in exchange for our attention, which is the commodity those platforms sell to advertisers. This could mean that while scrolling on Instagram youâll see lots of cute animal photos, a bunch of workout videos or, depending on your presumed interests, a barrage of propagandist memes â whatever the algorithm predicts will keep you around longest. Content promoting fake news often becomes popular on its own due to its sensational nature, but algorithms can easily boost it into virality. Tech companies are capable of preventing this from happening, although very few do so proactively. Take YouTube, for instance. Toward the end of 2018 through early 2019, a string of news articles and reports detailed how the Google-owned site was profiting by driving people down rabbit holes of increasingly extreme disinformation, which was having a radicalizing effect on some viewers. The media hype caught the publicâs attention, which sent YouTube into damage control mode. In late January it announced that it would adjust its algorithm to stop recommending videos promoting harmful misinformation; since then, views for such videos have been cut in half. This chain reaction provided a clear case study of how media coverage of a shadowy issue could spark public outrage, in turn threatening to spook big-spending advertisers and, ultimately, compelling a powerful tech giant to change its policies. Instagram has managed to escape such furor because thereâs been very limited reporting on its role as a disinformation network, which is partly due to the fact that it abruptly shut down its public API (Application Programming Interface) last year amid the fallout of Facebookâs data privacy scandal. Simply put, this has made it near-impossible for researchers to gather meaningful data about the spread of fake news and extremist content on the platform. Without such data, thereâs less for journalists to report on, and consequently, less pressure on Instagram to make changes. In lieu of media coverage, public pressure and fleeing advertisers, thereâs really nothing that can hold online intermediaries accountable for the content they choose to host or amplify. Talk of tech regulation in the U.S. has been aggressively countered with concerns about censorship. And as it stands, Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a law passed in 1996, shields platforms from liability for things their users post. As a result, platforms are free to decide what content they will and wonât allow, and to implement policies that can be as vague and as inconsistently enforced as they wish. For now, Barrett stressed, public awareness of the abundance of fake news on Instagram â and the companyâs role in spreading it â is crucial. âItâs really important for people to know whatâs happening,â he said, âso that theyâre skeptical of what they see on Instagram in the same way that theyâre gradually starting to question some of what they see on Facebook.â

articles.title: Witness In Trump-Ukraine Scandal Ordered Not To Appear Before Congress
articles.subtitle: The State Department blocked Gordon Sondland, U.S. ambassador to the European Union, from testifying before a House impeachment panel.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: The State Department blocked a top U.S. diplomat from giving a scheduled deposition Tuesday before a House panel conducting the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump. Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, is a witness to Trumpâs efforts to persuade Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a front-runner in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary race. Sondland is âprofoundly disappointedâ that he wonât be able to testify Tuesday and hopes the issues raised by the State Department will be resolved promptly, his attorney Robert Luskin said. âAmbassador Sondland believes strongly that he acted at all times in the best interest of the United States, and he stands ready to answer the Committeeâs questions fully and truthfully,âÂ LuskinÂ said in a statement. The Trump administrationâs directive came just hours before Sondland was scheduled to meet for a closed-door session with staff of three Democratic-led House committees. Trump tweeted that heâd âloveâ to have Sondland, a former hotel executive who donated $1 million to Trumpâs inaugural committee in 2017, testify Tuesday if not for âa totally compromised kangaroo court.â House Intelligence Committee Chair Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) said during a press conference on Capitol Hill that efforts by Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to block testimony and withhold documents are âevidence of obstruction.â Schiff added that Sondland had âdeeply relevantâ text messages on a personal device that he provided to the State Department, which then refused to hand them over to Congress. Schiff, along with the chairs of two other House committees leading the impeachment inquiry, later announced they will subpoena Sondland for his testimony and documents. âAmbassador Sondlandâs testimony and documents are vital, and that is precisely why the Administration is now blocking his testimony and withholding his documents,â the committee chairs said in a statement. In his diplomatic role, Sondland helped Ukraine ânavigateâ Trumpâs demands for investigations into Biden and a debunked conspiracy theory regarding the 2016 cyberattack against the Democratic National Committee, according to a whistleblower complaint filed in August by a U.S. intelligence official. That complaint, which accuses Trump of seeking foreign assistance in helping his reelection campaign and possibly using military aid to Ukraine as leverage, has become the center of an impeachment inquiry into the president launched by the House last month. Trump has defended his July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky asking him to investigate Biden, claiming the conversation was âperfectâ and denying that he used American aid as âquid pro quo.â Kurt Volker, the State Department special envoy to Ukraine until his resignation last month, told members of Congress last week that he was unaware of Trumpâs efforts to urge Ukraine to look into Biden. But text messages between himself, Sondland and Bill Taylor, the top U.S. diplomat to Ukraine, raise questions about his story. In the series of texts Volker provided to Congress, Taylor wrote to Sondland in September that he believes âitâs crazy to withhold security assistance for help with a political campaign.â Several hours later, Sondland responded: âBill, I believe you are incorrect about President Trumpâs intentions. The President has been crystal clear no quid pro quoâs of any kind. ... I suggest we stop the back and forth by text.â Before replying to Taylorâs text, Sondland called Trump, who assured him the quid pro quo claim was false, The New York Times and NBC News reported Tuesday. Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) revealed to The Wall Street Journal last week that Sondland told him in August that aid was being delayed until Ukraine agreed to open the investigations. âAt that suggestion, I winced,â Johnson told the newspaper. He said he called Trump to express his concern but the president denied it was true. This article has been updated to include House committee plans to subpoena Sondland and details of texts involving Sondland.

articles.title: Texas Judge Defends Hugging, Gifting Bible To Botham Jeanâs Killer
articles.subtitle: Judge Tammy Kemp noted that her Christian outreach to Amber Guyger happened after the trial was over.
articles.author: Carol Kuruvilla
articles.content: A Dallas judge says her decision to hug and share Christian teachings with a convicted murderer in her courtroom was appropriate because she did so after sentencing had occurred in the case. Judge Tammy Kemp received heated criticism from some secular groups for how she acted during the final moments of Amber Guygerâs trial. Guyger, a former Dallas cop, wasÂ sentenced last week to 10 years in jail for killing her neighbor, Botham Shem Jean. The critics said the district court judge violated church-state separation by giving Guyger her Bible and sharing Christian teachings about sin and salvation â all while still wearing her official robes. In an interview with The Associated Press on Monday, Kemp said her actions were appropriate because they occurred after court proceedings had ended. Her gestures were not included as part of the official trial record. âI didnât do that from the bench,â she told the AP. âI came down to extend my condolences to the Jean family and to encourage Ms. Guyger because she has a lot of life to live.â Courtroom video shows Judge Tammy Kempâs interactions with Amber Guyger after the ex-copâs sentencing. Guyger, a 31-year-old white woman, shot and killed Jean, a 26-year-old Black man, in September 2018 in Jeanâs apartment. She claims that as she was returning from work she mistook Jeanâs apartment for her own, which was directly underneath, and thought he was an intruder. After Guygerâs sentencing last Wednesday, Kemp allowed Jeanâs younger brother, Brandt Jean, to hug Guyger while delivering a victim impact statement. The younger brother said he forgave the ex-cop, didnât think she should go to jail and hoped she would dedicate her life to Jesus. With the jury dismissed, Kemp came down from the bench to offer condolences to Jeanâs parents, which she told The New York Times is something she often does for bereaved families. She then walked over to speak to Guyger. âShe asked me if I thought her life could have purpose,â Kemp told the Times. âI said, âI know that it can.â She said, âI donât know where to start, I donât have a Bible.ââ Kemp, a devout Christian who keeps a Bible in her chambers, said she responded, âWell, hold on, Iâll get you a Bible.ââ Kemp retrieved the Bible from her office and returned to the courtroom, still dressed in her official robes. She opened the book to John 3:16, a verse often cited by Christians as a summation of the faithâs teachings about salvation. âThis is your job for the next month. Right here,â Kemp can be heard saying in courtroomÂ video. âJohn: 3:16. And this is where you start.â âIf she wanted to start with the Bible, I didnât want her to go back to the jail and to sink into doubt and self-pity and become bitter,â Kemp told the AP. âBecause she still has a lot of life ahead of her following her sentence and I would hope that she could live it purposefully.â Guyger then asked Kemp for a hug. The judge told the Times that she has hugged defendants many times in the past, but usually after they successfully completed probation or drug treatment. Kemp told CBS Dallas Fort Worth that Guyger aske her twice before she agreed to the hug. The judge said she stands by her decision to hug the woman and now regrets her initial hesitation. She said she had âno role to represent the state during a victim impact moment.â She added that she did not pray with Guyger or ask the woman to pray. âAs a Christian, I believe Iâm commanded to offer her love and compassion just as Brandt Jean did,â Kemp told CBS. Kemp was elected to the bench in 2014. She has attended the same Dallas church for 25 years and serves as a deaconess. The Wisconsin-based Freedom From Religion Foundation (FFRF)Â filed a complaintÂ Thursday with the Texas State Commission on Judicial Conduct, arguing that Kemp was promoting her personal religious beliefs while acting in her official capacity. The American Humanist Association and Americans United for Separation of Church and State have not taken legal action over the matter, but representatives from both groups told HuffPost last week that they also view Kempâs actions as a violation of church-state separation. On Tuesday, FFRF lawyer Andrew Seidel dismissed Kempâs defense of her actions as a ânonstarter.â Seidel pointed out that the judge was still in her courtroom, wearing her official robes and in the presence of armed guards while proselytizing to Guyger. Seidel said he understands that the end of the trial was very emotional for those present â but he doesnât think that excuses Kemp. âSheâs bringing her personal religion into her courtroom, which is exactly what the Constitution doesnât allow,â he said.

articles.title: Acting CBP Commissioner: Harassment Of Journalists By Agents Is âUnacceptableâ
articles.subtitle: The condemnation comes just days after a passport screening official allegedly asked a reporter four times if he writes âpropaganda.â
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Acting Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Mark Morgan spoke out against harassment of journalists after a reporter said he was asked repeatedly by a customs officialÂ whether he writes âpropaganda.â âUnequivocally, let me say that any journalist that is stopped and harassed and treated improperly because theyâre a journalist is absolutely unacceptable â unequivocally,â Morgan said during a Tuesday press briefing at the White House. Defense One editor Ben Watson reported last week that a passport screening official at Dulles International Airport in Virginia questioned him incessantly while holding on to the document. Watson said that after identifying himself as a journalist, the official asked four times, âYou write propaganda, right?â On Tuesday, Morgan urged anyone who has faced such treatment to immediately report it to either the agencyâs Office of Professional Responsibility or the Department of Homeland Security Inspector Generalâs Office. âWe can disagree all we want,â he added, clarifying that âdisrespect doesnât mean disagreement.â âAnd thereâs a little thing in the country called freedom of speech, so anything that we do that would impede that, weâre going to hold people accountable. Itâs unacceptable â 100%,â Morgan said. Watson said of the incident that he initially denied the officerâs claims that he wrote âpropaganda,â then answered affirmatively âfor the purposes of expediting this conversationâ before he was handed back his passport. Watson has filed a civil rights complaint as a result, though he has yet to receive an update on the matter. He told HuffPost that Morganâs latest statement is a step in the right direction. âWe are encouraged by the acting commissionerâs remarks today, and the overall positive and pragmatic responses this incident has generated,â Watson said Tuesday over email. On Saturday, a CBP spokesperson told HuffPost the agency is aware of the âallegedÂ inappropriate conduct at Washington Dulles International airport and we are investigating the allegation.â Several similar cases of alleged harassment have been reported throughout the past year. British journalist James DyerÂ tweeted in August that he was derided as a member of the âfake news mediaâ by a CBP agent at Los Angeles International Airport. In February, CBP issued an apology to BuzzFeed News reporter David Mack for an agentâs âinappropriate remarksâ made at New York Cityâs JFK Airport. According to the outlet, Mack was targeted with an aggressive line of questioning over his coverage of President Donald Trump.

articles.title: Lindsey Graham Vows âSanctions From Hellâ On Turkey If It Invades Syria
articles.subtitle: The Republican senator warned the action would be âdevastatingâ for Turkey.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) is vowing to hit Turkey with âsanctions from hellâ if it carries out its plan to invade northern Syria. Delivering his warning in a tweet Tuesday, Graham said congressional action would be âwide, deep, and devastating.â The threat comes just two days after the Trump administration announced it would step aside as Turkey gears up to move into the region, leaving American-allied Kurdish fighters to fend for themselves. Graham has spoken out vociferously against President Donald Trumpâs decision, which was announced Sunday, slamming it as a betrayal of the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, an alliance of local militias battling the self-declared Islamic State. The senator is one of several prominent Republicans â in addition to foreign policy experts â who say that if U.S. troops pull out of northern Syria, Turkey would unleash attacks on Kurdish forces, whom it regards as terrorists. The United States partnered with Kurdish forces and other local militias in 2015 to fight ISIS in northeastern Syria. Since then, around 1,000 U.S. troops have been stationed in the area backing the SDF. On Monday, Graham urged Trump during a âFox & Friendsâ interview and on social media to reconsider his decision, calling it âa disaster in the makingâ and âa stain on Americaâs honor.â He also noted that he hopes the potential sanctions against Turkey âwould be veto-proof.â Trump has not backed down from his decision, but tweeted on Monday that he would âtotally destroy and obliterateâ Turkeyâs economy if it âdoes anything that I, in my great and unmatched wisdom, consider to be off-limits.â On Tuesday, Trump defended the policy shift, tweeting, âin no way have we Abandoned the Kurds, who are special people and wonderful fighters,â and praising U.S.-Turkey relations. Continuing, he asserted that âany unforced or unnecessary fighting by Turkey will be devastating to their economy and to their very fragile currency.â However, the same day, Turkish Vice President Fuat Oktay said the country would not bow to pressure from the U.S. âWhere Turkeyâs security is concerned, we determine our own path, but we set our own limits,â he said, according to The Associated Press.

articles.title: Ex-White House Chief Of Staff: Trump Impeachment Inquiry Is âWarrantedâ
articles.subtitle: âClearly lines have been crossed,â said Andrew Card, who served during George W. Bushâs presidency.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: Andrew Card, a former chief of staff to then-President George W. Bush, has come out in support of the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump. âI do think that an impeachment inquiry is warranted,â Card said during an appearance Monday on MSNBC. âClearly lines have been crossed.â Card, who also served as Transportation Secretary during George H.W. Bushâs presidency, said heâs not sure yet whether Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine amount to an impeachable offense. âI want people to calm down, take a look at it, donât call a molehill a mountain,â he said, suggesting Democrats were drawing conclusions prematurely. âThis is a serious process. ...Â I do want the impeachment process, if itâs going to go forward, to be done deliberately, without hyperbole.â House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) announced the opening of a formal impeachment inquiry last month after a whistleblower report filed by a U.S. intelligence official surfaced. In the complaint, the whistleblower alleged Trump pressured Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a front-runner in the Democratic presidential primary race. The whistleblower, whose identity hasnât been released to the public, accused Trump of seeking foreign assistance to help his reelection campaign and possibly using American aid to Ukraine as leverage. Trump has denied any wrongdoing and said his phone call with Zelensky was âperfect.â

articles.title: Melania Trump Said Sheâs âDedicated To Helping Children,â And It Didnât Go So Well
articles.subtitle: âSheâs STILL talking about this? I assumed this initiative had been abandoned â for obvious reasons,â one person fired back on Twitter.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Melania Trump faced accusations of hypocrisy â yet again â for her âBe Bestâ initiative on Monday. In an anti-drug address at the Drug Enforcement Administration headquarters to mark Red Ribbon Week, the first lady claimed her program (launched last year) is âdedicated to helping children and ensuring that we are doing all we can to take care of the next generation.â âWhether it is showing a simple act of kindness, providing care where there is a need or teaching something valuable, âBe Bestâ promotes the positive actions happening in our communities and around the globe, and helps children understand what it means to live healthy lives,â Trump said. Trumpâs speech focused on her programâs work to tackle the opioid abuse epidemic, alongside its missionÂ to increase childrenâs well-being and online safety. But critics on Twitter were quick to explain why they couldnât take the initiative seriously, given the conduct of her husband, President Donald Trumpï»¿, and his administration:

articles.title: Hillary Clinton Tells Trump Not To âTemptâ Her To Run For Office Again: âDo Your Jobâ
articles.subtitle: The president taunted the former first lady on Tuesday, imploring her to enter the 2020 race and âsteal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren.â
articles.author: Jenna Amatulli
articles.content: Hillary Clinton had a biting response to a tweet from President Donald Trump on Tuesday after he suggested she enter the 2020 presidential race âto try and steal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren.â After the president taunted Clinton unprovoked and called her âcrookedâ yet again, she fired back a tweet that simply said: âDonât tempt me. Do your job.â Trump references Clinton often in his tweets, with mentions of her cropping up in his missives as frequently as every few weeks. Itâs rare that Clinton responds to Trumpâs tweets about her these days. During the 2016 campaign, she tagged Trump many times and addressed him by name in her tweets, but in the last few years sheâs usually refrained from doing either. Clinton confirmed in March that she had no plans to run in the 2020 election, telling New York station News 12 that sheâs ânot running, but Iâm going to keep on working and speaking and standing up for what I believe.â Despite not running, Clinton noted that she wasnât âgoing anywhereâ and vowed to âhelp the Democrats win back the White Houseâ in 2020.

articles.title: Trumpâs Big Ad Buy Has Democrats Spooked
articles.subtitle: Democrats think the presidentâs reelection campaign is wasting money, but are worried about just how much money the president can afford to waste.
articles.author: Kevin Robillard
articles.content: WASHINGTON â Democratic strategists are increasingly fretful about President Donald Trumpâs reelection war chest, worried the presidentâs campaign will be able to define any potential nominee before the partyâs nominee can assemble the money necessary to fight back. Trumpâs campaign, along with the Republican National Committee, announced earlier this month they raised more than $125 million, and has more than $156 million on hand. Trumpâs campaign, because of its partnership with the RNC and state Republican parties, is able to bring in much more from a single donor than the $5,600 haul Democrats can take in. That will change when Democrats settle on a nominee. But the partyâs operatives are worried the Trump campaign will be able to exploit their cash advantage in the coming months, when the Democratic field is squabbling among itself, to damage a potential nominee before they can make a general election pitch. A multimillion-dollar ad buy from the Trump campaign that started last week is helping cement those fears, even as operatives remain skeptical it will deal much damage to former Vice President Joe Biden, its intended target. âWhen you look at what is at his disposal, you see a massive campaign war chest, a right-wing media infrastructure and a White House that he has increasingly weaponized,â said Jesse Ferguson, a Democratic strategist who worked for Hillary Clintonâs 2016 presidential campaign. âPut those all together, and he has the capacity to run the biggest propaganda and disinformation campaign in American history. Thatâs the real fear.â Adding to the problem: a host of Democratic donors and groups who have promised to spend big on the general election have so far done little to attack Trump before the Democratic nominee is settled. Democrats believe the president, who trails the leading Democratic candidates in way-too-early public opinion polling, is vulnerable on a host of issues, especially health care and the perception Trump does more to help the wealthy than the middle class. âIt is good that there are a lot of progressive organizations who are starting to make plans for ad and field funding for the general election, but we canât entirely cede the battle to Trump in the meantime and need to be hitting him now,â said Eddie Vale, a Democratic strategist who previously worked for labor unions. âWe need to be starting to make the case against Trump on the economy, health care and immigration now â like Priorities USA is doing â especially in the states, so our nominee isnât starting from scratch after Trump having months of spending domination.â Another Democratic strategist, who requested anonymity to criticize powerful groups within the party, was blunter: âThere are a number of groups that have made grandiose promises to what theyâre going to do counter Trump while weâre in the primary. So far, most of them havenât done more than send their press release.â So far, Priorities USA, the partyâs biggest super PAC, has spent $2.5 million on digital ads attacking Trump and promoting voter registration, with much of the spending focused on the four states strategists in both parties see as key to Trumpâs reelection chances: Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin and Florida. The group spent over $190 million on the 2016 election, and plans to spend $100 million before a nominee is selected this time around. But other potential big spenders have been quiet. Democratic operatives have saidÂ former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg would spend at least $500 million to defeat Trump. Right now, he has no immediate spending plans. Future Majority, a nonprofit with goals to spend $60 million to improve the Democratic Partyâs brand in key swing states, has spent a fraction of that so far. American Bridge aims to spend $50 million to help Democrats keep down Trumpâs margin among rural voters, but little has gone out the door so far. The Trump campaign launched a $10 million ad buy attacking Biden over unsubstantiated allegations he sought his sonâs business interests in Ukraine, and attempting to defend Trump for allegations he withheld military aid from the Ukranian government to pressure them to reopen an investigation into Biden. (The latter is now the subject of the U.S. Houseâs impeachment inquiry.) The campaign has begun airing the ads in the first four voting states in the Democratic 2020 presidential primary process â Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina â in an apparent attempt to damage Bidenâs chances of winning the nomination. âThey lost the election, now they want to steal this one,â the narrator says in one of Trumpâs ads. The Biden campaign and other strategists downplayed the direct impact of the buy. Biden allies think there is little chance the ad â which includes the disclaimer the Trump campaign is funding it â would sway Democratic primary voters who loathe the president. And Democratic strategists also questioned how well-targeted the ad was. It included a national cable television buy, which is usually associated more with attempts to change the media narrative around an event than with winning over swing voters. âThe Trump campaign and the RNC have essentially unlimited funding to do whatever they want to do,â said Mark Riddle, the executive director of Future Majority. âBut the real question is whether or not heâs breaking through to anyone beyond his base.â Riddle said he isnât as worried about Trumpâs ad buy as other Democrats, but acknowledges the party might need to respond if Trumpâs approval ratings move up or support for an impeachment inquiry declines. âIf we start seeing Trumpâs numbers going up, and his narrative is taking hold, then it might be time to shift something,â Riddle said. Amanda Terkel contributed reporting.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders: âI Was Dumbâ To Ignore Heart Attack Warning Signs
articles.subtitle: The Vermont senator and Democratic presidential candidate hopes his recent hospitalization will be a lesson to the public.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) admitted on Tuesday that he mishandled his health before being hospitalized last week with a heart attack. Now, heâs urging the public to watch out for the warning signs. âI must confess that I was dumb,â the Democratic presidential candidate told reporters outside his home in Vermont ahead of a cardiologist appointment. Sanders noted that at some points on the campaign trail he was leading three to four rallies in a single day, adding that âin the last month or two, [I] just was more fatigued than I usually have been, and I should have listened to those symptoms.â âSo if thereâs any message that I hope we can get there, [itâs] that I want people to pay attention to their symptoms,â he said. âWhen youâre hurting, when youâre fatigued, when you have pain in your chest, listen to it.â On Oct. 1, the 78-year-old underwent an emergency heart procedure in Las Vegas to treat a blocked artery with two stents, having noticed something was wrong when he experienced chest discomfort. Hours after his release on Friday, Sanders shared a taped statement on Twitter, announcing that he was âfeeling so much betterâ and thanking his supporters âfor all of the love and warm wishes that you sent me.â Meanwhile, Sandersâ campaign has hit the pause button with no scheduled events until his planned appearance at the fourth Democratic debate on Oct. 15 in Westerville, Ohio.

articles.title: More Details Emerge About How White House Officials Reacted To Trumpâs Call With Ukraine
articles.subtitle: The presidentâs July 25 call with Ukraineâs President Volodymyr Zelensky reportedly sent shockwaves through the White House.
articles.author: Antonia Blumberg
articles.content: Two new reports published on Tuesday shed light on the alarm raised in the White House by PresidentÂ Donald Trumpâs efforts to pressure Ukraine into investigating his political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden. Trumpâs July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has prompted two whistleblower complaints, a House impeachment investigation and widespread concern across party lines. The intelligence official who filed the first of the complaints wrote in a two-page memo that a White House official was âvisibly shakenâ after listening in on the call, according to ABC News. âThe official, who listened to the entirety of the phone call, was visibly shaken by what had transpired and seemed keen to inform a trusted colleague within the U.S. national security apparatus about the call,â the whistleblower wrote in the memo. The memo noted that the official âdescribed the call as âcrazy,â âfrightening,â and completely lacking in substance related to national security.â The official also told the whistleblower that he or she suspected the administration was taking unusual steps to restrict access to documents pertaining to the call. Subsequent reports have indicated the White House did take âremarkable stepsâ to prevent Trumpâs conversations with foreign leaders from being made available to White House officials. According to the second Tuesday report, at least one National Security Council official and a number of White House aides and lawyers were alarmed after the call and were aware that it might have overstepped the bounds of normal foreign policy. Trump had ordered that almost $400 million in military aid for Ukraine be withheld roughly a week before his phone call with Zelensky. During the conversation, Trump asked the Ukrainian president to investigate unsubstantiated allegations that Biden used his power as vice president during the Obama administration to kill an investigation into a gas company for which his son worked. A National Security Council official alerted White House lawyers about concerns over potential fallout from the call, CNN reported, citing three sources familiar with the matter. As concern mounted at the White House, national security lawyers initially moved to block access to a transcript of the call by storing it in a code-word classified server, a move usually reserved for the most sensitive materials pertaining to national security. Trump has denied any wrongdoing in his negotiations with Ukraine, calling all his conversations with the countryâs leaders âperfect.â The president also dismissed the first whistleblowerâs complaint because he said it contained only secondhand knowledge. A second whistleblower who is believed to have firsthand knowledge of the allegations has since come forward to speak with the intelligence communityâs inspector general.

articles.title: The Trump Administration Wants Restaurant Servers To Do More Work For Less Pay
articles.subtitle: The Labor Department acknowledges in an analysis that its new proposal on tipped workers might accomplish just that.
articles.author: Dave Jamieson
articles.content: The Trump administration is trying once again to tweak the rules that govern how tipped workers are paid. This time, their proposal would probably result in servers doing more nontipped work and at a lower pay rate than previously required. On Monday, the Labor Department rolled out a new proposed âtip ruleâ clarifying how employers can divvy up gratuities among their staffs. While most of the plan had been hashed out last year in a compromise with congressional Democrats, it includes a separate recommendation that has angered worker advocates: the elimination of the â80-20 rule.â In most states, it is legal to pay servers and bartenders a sub-minimum wage, sometimes as low as $2.13 per hour, so long as tips get their hourly rate up to the regular minimum wage.Â Under the 80-20 rule, a tipped worker can be required to do nontipped work at the lower rate â like folding napkins and filling up salt shakers â so long as it doesnât eat up more than 20% of the shift.Â If it does, then the worker would have to be paid the full minimum wage â at least $7.25 per hour, depending on the state â for that time. The 80-20 rule has been around since the late 1980s. The administration of George W. Bush tried to gut it at the end of his presidency, but the administration of Barack Obama quickly restored it. The Labor Department, now headed by recent Trump appointee Secretary Eugene Scalia, wants to get rid of that explicit 20% time limit. Instead, the rule would simply require that the nontipped work be done âcontemporaneouslyâ or âwithin a reasonable time immediately before or afterâ the tipped work. So long as an employer met that vague criteria, there would be no precise cap on the nontipped work if the administrationâs proposal becomes final. For those who support strong workplace regulations, the language of the proposed rule is far too squishy and could lead to abuse. âUnfortunately, today, DOL is proposing regulations that make it perfectly legal for employers to take advantage of tipped workers,â Judy Conti, with the left-leaning National Employment Law Project, said in a statement. âWe are extremely disappointed, though not surprised, that DOL is again doing the bidding of corporate America rather than the workers it is supposed to protect.â The 80-20 rule is just the sort of regulation that employer groups and the Trump administration would hate, since it requires restaurants and other tipped businesses to keep track of the work employees are doing to avoid lawsuits. The Labor Department says dropping the rule would âeliminate this monitoring costâ and save employers money. Under Trump, the agency stopped enforcing the rule last year, but the new proposal would go a step further by doing away with it. Itâs not a stretch to assume servers and other tipped workers will lose out on the deal â in fact, the Labor Departmentâs own analysis suggests that likelihood. In its proposal, the agency acknowledges workers will spend more time on lower-paying duties: The removal of the twenty percent time limit may result in tipped workers such as wait staff and bartenders performing more of these non-tipped duties such as âcleaning and setting tables, toasting bread, making coffee, and occasionally washing dishes or glasses.â â¦ Tipped workers might lose tipped income by spending more of their time performing duties where they are not earning tips, while still receiving cash wages of less than minimum wage. Whatâs more, workers in the back of the house who are paid a full minimum wage could end up hurt by the rule as well, the agency notes. Thatâs because employers would have an incentive to shift nontipped work away from those employees to the tipped workers earning a lower pay rate: Consequently, employment of workers currently performing these duties, such as dishwashers and cooks, may fall, possibly resulting in a transfer of employment-related producer surplus from those non-tipped workers to tipped workers who work longer hours. Even though servers could end up doing lower-paying work â and bussers and dishwashers could lose work hours â the proposalâs authors do see a potential winner in that scenario: Employers that had been paying the full minimum wage to tipped employees performing related, non-tipped duties could potentially pay the lower direct cash wage for this time and could pass these reduced labor cost savings on to consumers. [emphasis added] The proposal did not estimate how much less money servers might earn, or how many fewer hours back-of-the-house workers might have as a result of the proposal. Democrats plan on asking the Labor Department why a projection was not included, according to a spokesperson for Rep. Bobby Scott (Va.), chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor. Democrats and the Trump administration have been at odds over tipped workers for years. The administration has wanted to give employers more leeway in how they can divide up gratuities, steering more of the money to back-of-the-house staffers â a move that could lower restaurantsâ labor costs by transferring some wages, in the form of tips, away from servers. Initially, the administration proposed language that would have allowed employers to do whatever they wanted with tips, including keeping them for the house. After an outcry from liberals and worker groups, the Labor Department under then-Secretary Alexander Acosta agreed to rework the rule. The version released Monday forbids management from keeping gratuities for itself, but Democrats in Congress are not pleased with the repeal of the 80-20 rule that was added to the new proposal. Sen. Patty Murray (Wash.), the ranking Democrat on the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, said it âappears to betray the compromiseâ they had struck last year on tips. As for Scalia, who was confirmed late last month, Murray said he âis already proving exactly what I feared: that heâll really serve as a Secretary of Corporate Interests.â

articles.title: Trump Court Pick Ignores Senatorsâ Questions About His Role In Ukraine Scandal
articles.subtitle: Democrats asked Steven Menashi, a White House legal aide, what he knew about the presidentâs potentially impeachable offenses. He didnât respond.
articles.author: Jennifer Bendery
articles.content: WASHINGTON â White House legal adviser Steven Menashi, who is also President Donald Trumpâs nominee to a lifetime seat on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit, is ignoring questions from Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee about what he knew about Trumpâs efforts to pressure Ukraine to investigate his potential 2020 rival, former Vice President Joe Biden. Menashi, 40, has been a White House attorney for more than a year, which means he could know details about Trumpâs July 25 phone call to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which TrumpÂ urged Zelensky to probe Bidenâs family during a discussion on U.S. military aid to Ukraine. He could also know details about the subsequent whistleblower complaint that corroborated the conversation that took place in that phone call. He could also have been involved in the White Houseâs apparent cover-up of all of it. All 10 Democrats on the committee wrote to Menashi last month with detailed questions about what he knew about that phone call, the bombshell whistleblower complaint and whether he advised Trump on either matter. They gave him until Oct. 7 to respond. He never did. Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), the ranking member on the committee, says the committee should deny Menashi a vote until he answers their questions. âSteven Menashi has left questions unanswered about his work at the White House, including his involvement in the White Houseâs response to the whistleblower complaint,â Feinstein told HuffPost in a Tuesday statement. âMr. Menashi is seeking a lifetime appointment to the court, so his record must be thoroughly examined. The committee shouldnât vote on his nomination without all of the facts. He must stop evading our questions.â A White House spokeswoman did not respond to a request for comment on whether Menashi should respond to the senatorsâ questions. Itâs not a great look for Menashi, who already irritated Republicans and Democrats in his confirmation hearing by refusing to answer questions about what issues heâs worked on at the White House. Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.), for one, told HuffPost last month that he is âreal doubtfulâ about supporting Menashi because of the way he disregarded senatorsâ questions. âMy thought is, look, if heâll treat a United States senator the way he treated us, I wonder how he would treat the people,â Kennedy said at the time. It only takes one Republican on the committee to vote no to tank a nomination, assuming all Democrats vote no. Other GOP committee members, including Sens. Lindsey Graham (S.C.) and Thom Tillis (N.C.), have not responded to requests for comment on whether they will support Menashi. Progressive groups, meanwhile, are trying to sink Menashiâs nomination over hisÂ long record of opposing and undermining equality for communities of color, women and LGBTQ people. Among other things, Menashi hasÂ denounced womenâs marches asÂ sexual assault, opposed the âradical abortion rightsÂ codified in Roe v. Wade,â and spread the Islamophobic myth that Gen. John Pershing executed Muslim prisoners in the Philippines in 1913 with bullets dipped in pig fat. Protesters filled the hall outside his Senate confirmation hearing last month and got arrested as they shouted âTitle IX is on the line!,â a reference to Menashi serving as legal counsel to Education Secretary Betsy DeVos when she rolled back Title IX protections for survivors of sexual assault on campuses. A spokesman for Graham, the committeeâs chairman, did not respond to a request for comment on whether Menashi needs to answer Democratic senatorsâ questions. Itâs not clear if or when Graham will schedule Menashiâs committee vote.

articles.title: Trump Lover Flashed Gun At Elizabeth Warren Supporter: Police
articles.subtitle: Police say Joseph Schumacher followed an 18-year-old woman in Moorhead, Minnesota, while harassing her over her Warren bumper sticker.
articles.author: David Moye
articles.content: A Donald Trump supporter in Moorhead, Minnesota, was arrested on felony charges Monday after police say he trailed a woman with an Elizabeth Warren bumper sticker on her car and flashed a gun at her. The 18-year-old woman was driving when the suspect, 27-year-old Joseph Schumacher of West Fargo, North Dakota, pulled up next to her in his own vehicle and yelled at her about the bumper sticker, according to a release from the Moorhead Police Department. Wanting to make sure the woman knew where he stood on the political spectrum, Schumacher pointed toward his own pro-Trump bumper sticker while continuing to voice âhis difference in national political views,â the statement continued. The harassment continued for a few blocks, Moorhead Police Capt. Deric SwensonÂ told the Minneapolis Star-Tribune. âThe victim initially thought it wasnât going to be serious,â Swenson said. âThen things escalated seriously.â The woman said when Schumacher drove ahead of her, he held up a handgun he had inside his vehicle,Â according to Valley News Live. The woman then called 911 to report the incident. A short time later,Â cops found Schumacher, searched his car and found a loaded handgun in the center console,Â according to The Smoking Gun. Police said a passenger in Schumacherâs vehicle confirmed the story told to them by the victim. Schumacher wasÂ arrested on two felony counts of making terroristic threats, as well as misdemeanor weapons charges. He was booked into custody at the Clay County Jail and due in court on Tuesday.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Is Right. In The 1970s, Pregnant Teachers Didnât Keep Their Jobs.
articles.subtitle: Back then, teaching was the national model for discriminating against pregnant workers and getting away with it.
articles.content: Sen. Elizabeth Warrenâs presidential campaign is on the offensive against a report that questions a compelling piece of her origin story: her account of being pushed out of her first teaching job because she was six months pregnant. Although the reports donât contain evidence that Warren is lying, they show there is no written evidence she was fired from her elementary school job and they open the door to the possibility that she voluntarily resigned to raise a family. Whatâs missing, though, is a crucial fact about the time period when Warren says she was shown the door: In 1971, teaching wasnât just another profession where women experienced pregnancy discrimination. It was the national model for how employers could systematically discriminate against pregnant workers and get away with it.
