School districtsÂ around the country followedÂ plain-as-day policies that terminated pregnant teachers or forced them to take unpaid leave, usually around the fifth month of pregnancy when they were obviously pregnant. A National Education Association survey in 1970 found thatÂ a majority of school districts had such a policy, and that most of those policies came with no guarantee that a teacher would get her job back after giving birth. That placed school teachers on the front lines of the fraught legal and cultural battles for better protections for working women, writes legal historian Deborah Dinner. National womenâs groups took up the treatment of pregnant teachers as an organizing cause. Womenâs legal advocates recruited teachers as civil rights test cases. The Supreme Courtâs first pregnancy discrimination case, argued in 1973, pitted three pregnant teachers against a âfive monthâ policy. That case, and the questions it left unanswered, became the basis for the landmark Pregnancy Discrimination Act of 1978. In other words, when a pregnant Warren left her teaching job, pregnancy discrimination against teachers was rampant, controversial and inextricable from the much larger battle on the overall status of working women. The question isnât why her school board would lie about forcing her out â itâs why wouldnât it? Warrenâs story of being shuffled out of her first teaching job goes like this:Â In 1971, she was a teacher â her dream job â at a special-needs school for public school students at Riverdale Elementary in New Jersey. In April, when she was pregnant but not obviously, the school renewed her teaching contract for another year. By the summer, she was six months pregnant â âvisibly pregnantâ â and the job was no longer hers. âThe principal did what principals did in those days: wished me luck, showed me the door, and hired someone else for the job,â she said at a recent town hall. In some recent appearances, she has dropped the âshowed me the doorâ line, but she defended her characterization in an interviewÂ with CBS News. âWhen someone calls you in and says the job that youâve been hired for for the next year is no longer yours, âWeâre giving it to someone else,â I think thatâs being shown the door,â Warren said. The Washington Free Beacon, a conservative outlet, cast doubt by noting that Warren had once described her exit differently: â[I] said, âI donât think this is going to work out for me.â I was pregnant with my first baby, so I had a baby and stayed home for a couple of years,â she said in a 2007 interview. (Warren told CBS that she wasnât comfortable opening up about the discrimination aspect until recently.) And it pointed to contemporaneous reports from 1971 that also paint her exit as voluntary. A local news item said Warren was âleaving to raise a family,â while another said the school board hired Warrenâs replacement after she âresigned for personal reasons.â Of course, what really matters here is whether Warren had a choice to keep her job at all. And to read just those two news items is to miss the reality that in 1971, it was the de facto or actual expectation in the majority of American school districts that a teacher who became pregnant would resign. âVoluntary resignationsâ were many teachersâ only alternative to automatic dismissal â and Warrenâs school district was reportedly no exception. âThe rule was at five months you had to leave when you were pregnant. Now, if you didnât tell anybody you were pregnant, and they didnât know, you could fudge it and try to stay on a little bit longer,â Trudy Randall, a retired Riverdale Elementary teacher, told CBS. âBut they kind of wanted you out if you were pregnant.â Certainly, by 1971, Warrenâs principal would have known that to openly fire her because she was pregnant was to court trouble. âIn the early 1970s,â the country at large was embroiled in a âmajor cultural and legal debate over the rights of pregnant workers,â according to a history of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act published in the Yale Journal of Law & Feminism. The American Federation of Teachers denounced mandatory pregnancy dismissals at its annual convention in 1970. By the next year â the year Warren left her job â the federation and the National Organization for Women were coordinating local name-and-shame campaigns against school boards with retrograde policies. One district that found itself under fire was a school board in New Jersey, the state where Warren had worked. In 1972, the state civil rights commission slapped down a policy forcing teachers to leave school at five months pregnant. An Associated Press story from that time reported the ruling to mean âpregnant teachers can no longer be automatically forced out of New Jerseyâs classrooms.â Because teaching was one of a few career options reliably available to women, the treatment of pregnant schoolteachers was at the heart of the broader societal clash over pregnant workers.Â Schools were also a special battleground because teaching jobs were mostly government jobs â it gave pregnancy discrimination against teachers the sheen of authority. Among the very first federal cases against pregnancy discrimination was brought in 1973, by a Minnesota teacher named Margo Seaman, who sued her school district for forcing her, when she was seven months pregnant, to take a semesterlong leave of absence. Seaman was able to stay in her job but lost her fight for back pay, in no small part because her teacherâs union had capitulated in 1971 to a policy âproviding for permanent âterminationâ of a teacher after five months of pregnancy, with no guarantee of reinstatement.â And in 1974, the Supreme Court took up its first pregnancy discrimination suit, which the legal professor Nicholas PedrianaÂ called âa typical early pregnancy discrimination caseâ: âPublic school teachers who became pregnant were required to take maternity leave beginning in the fifth month of pregnancy.â The case,Â Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur, involved three teachers from two school districts in Ohio and Virginia who were pregnant in 1970 or 1971 and were forced to take many months of unpaid maternity leave with no guarantee of getting their jobs back. In a 7-2 decision, the Supreme Court ruled that the five-month rule was arbitrary and unconstitutional. The questions that case left unanswered â namely, whether pregnancy discrimination was a form of gender discrimination and subject to an even wider array of civil rights laws â led eventually to the passage of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act. At the heart of all of these legal fights and retrograde school board policies were traditional ideas about gender, Dinner writes: the notion that pregnancy, a visible sign of womenâs sexual activity, wasnât classroom-appropriate; that pregnant women couldnât work without endangering their health and their pregnancies; and that new mothers shouldnât work but focus on their families. Those ideas started to crumble in the 1970s. But they still persist, and, making it all the more difficult to dismiss Warrenâs story, they still result in routine pregnancy discrimination against professional women today. Today, the idea of putting a visibly pregnant CEO on the cover of a magazine is still considered trailblazing. Today, the idea that pregnant women place special burdens on their co-workers is still pervasive. Pregnant women often find themselves âmommy tracked,â and paid or promoted less than their peers for equivalent work based on the assumption that their futures belong to their families. âPregnancy discrimination remains pervasive, especially for women in low-wage and physically demanding jobs,â said Dina Bakst, co-founder and co-president of A Better Balance, a national legal advocacy organization for womenâs rights. âIt is a key barrier to gender equality in the workplace, often snowballing into devastating economic consequences for women.â And it is still prevalent in the teaching profession. Religious schools, for instance, have fought for and often won the legal right to fire pregnant teachers who are unmarried or who conceive using methods, like IVF, opposed by some faiths. Denine Hasan, who is a New Jersey schoolteacher like Warren was, said she wasnât at all surprised by Warrenâs account. Hasan says that she, too, was shuffled out of her position when she became pregnant â during the 2012-13 school year. Like Warren, she wasnât outright fired. Instead, she says, she was assigned to a new school, given unprecedented negative reviews and treated with hostility or punished when she asked for medically recommended accommodations for her high-risk pregnancy. Officials informed Hasan, who was not tenured, that her contract would not be renewed when she went on maternity leave. (The Asbury Park School District has not admitted wrongdoing, and didnât immediately respond to requests for comment.) âI donât think I would get pregnant again. Because youâre just fearful. Whatâs going to happen? Am I going to lose my job?â Hasan told HuffPost. âWomen are always viewed differently than men,â she continued. âIts natural for us to bear children, and then to be put in situations where now weâre losing jobs because weâre doing something thatâs natural. Itâs like we canât win.â Emily Peck contributed reporting

articles.title: Russian Operatives Popped Champagne, Said They âMade America Greatâ After Trump Win
articles.subtitle: A report from the GOP-led Senate Intelligence Committee says that Russian trolls celebrated success on election night 2016.
articles.author: Ryan J. Reilly
articles.content: Russian social media trolls working to boost the candidacy of now-President Donald Trump celebrated the real estate mogulâs win on election night 2016 with champagne, according to a message disclosed in a new report from the Republican-led Senate Intelligence Committee. According to the committeeâs report, released Tuesday, an employee of Russiaâs Internet Research Agency sent a message indicating that they âuncorked a tiny bottle of champagneâ when they found out that Trump had won. âWe uttered almost in unison: âWe made America great.ââÂ The exchange was highlighted by Bloomberg. Robert Muellerâs extensive special counsel investigation laid out a mountain of evidence showing Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. Like the Mueller investigation, the new report from the Intelligence Committee found that the Internet Research Agency âsought to influence the presidential election by harming Hillary Clintonâs chances of success and supporting Donald Trump at the direction of the Kremlin.â Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.), the chairman of the committee, said in a statement Tuesday that Russia is âwaging an information warfare campaign against the U.S. that didnât start and didnât end with the 2016 electionâ and that their goal was to âsow societal discord and erode public confidenceâ in government. Trump has been publicly skeptical of intelligence community conclusions about Russian interference in the 2016 election because he believes it takes away from his victory.

articles.title: California Takes New Steps To Stop Black Women From Dying In Childbirth
articles.subtitle: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill requiring implicit bias training for health care providers serving pregnant people.
articles.author: Sarah Ruiz-Grossman
articles.content: California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill Monday aiming to address the issue of Black women dying in childbirth at disproportionately high rates compared to their white peers. The legislation, authored by California state Sen. Holly Mitchell (D), will require hospitals and clinics in the state to implement implicit bias training for all health care providers working in perinatal services. Sponsored by NARAL, Black Women for Wellness and other groups, the bill also requires the stateâs health department to track and publish additional data around pregnancy-related deaths in an effort to better understand the issue. The U.S. has the worst maternal mortality rate among all developed countries. And the risk of pregnancy-related deaths is three to four times higher for Black women than for white women, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Most pregnancy-related deaths in the United States are fully preventable â and they can happen up to a year after a person gives birth, according to a recent CDC report. âBlack women do deserve better,âÂ Mitchell, who is a Black mother, said in a news release last month. âBias, implicit or explicit, should no longer impact a womanâs ability to deliver a full-term baby or to survive childbirth.â âI charge Black women to ask their provider before selecting an obstetrician, âHave you gone through implicit bias training? Because I want to increase the likelihood of my survival when delivering this baby,ââ she added. The issue of Black maternal mortality garnered new attention recently after tennis star Serena Williams and singer BeyoncÃ© publicly discussed the difficulties and complications they faced in childbirth. Lawmakers â including Rep. Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.) and Democratic presidential candidates Sens. Kamala Harris (Calif.), Cory Booker (N.J.) and Elizabeth Warren (Mass.) â have also raised alarm about the high rates of maternal mortality in the U.S, specifically for Black women. âThe best studies that Iâve seen put it down to just one thing: prejudice,â Warren said at a forum in April. âDoctors and nurses donât hear African American womenâs medical issues the same way as they hear the same things from white women.â

articles.title: Habitually Dishonest Trump Pushes His Biggest Lie Yet About The Democrat He Fears Most
articles.subtitle: Trumpâs accusations against Joe Biden turn reality on its head. Bidenâs Ukraine efforts were more likely to hurt his sonâs company, not help it.
articles.author: S.V. Date
articles.content: Nearly three years and some 7,000 falsehoods into his term and now under threat of impeachment, President Donald Trump continues pushing one of his biggest lies yet: That Joe Biden while vice president intervened overseas on his sonâs behalf. âSleepy Joe Biden â¦ forced a tough prosecutor out from investigating his sonâs company by threat of not giving big dollars to Ukraine,â Trump wrote in a statement he posted on Twitter last month. âThe Biden family was PAID OFF, pure and simple!â he wrote Sunday. Yet Trumpâs claims about Biden are not only unfounded, but a review of the timeline shows they turn facts and recent history on their head â a black-is-white, night-is-day reinterpretation to advance Trumpâs political goal. âItâs pretty hard to wrap your head around,â said Robert Weissman, president of the liberal group Public Citizen, adding that trying to understand Trumpâs claims on the topic first requires âa re-read of âAlice in Wonderland.ââ Biden had been pushing for anti-corruption reforms in Ukraine since shortly after he became vice president in 2009 â not as a freelance effort, but as part of the entire U.S. government and its Western alliesâ attempts to improve the business climate for investment there and nudge the country away from Russia. Bidenâs son Hunter did not join the Ukrainian energy company Burismaâs board until 2014. And the push to increase corruption investigations in Ukraine was likely to hurt Burisma, not help it. Thatâs because the probes were being thwarted to protect Burismaâs owner when Joe Biden told Ukrainian officials that $1 billion in loan guarantees would be blocked if the countryâs prosecutor general at the time was not fired. That prosecutor, Viktor Shokin, was generally regarded as corrupt and unwilling to press cases against politically connected targets. Following the vice presidentâs ultimatum, Shokin was ousted in March 2016. âDonald Trump is so terrified of facing off against Joe Biden in 2020 that he committed an unprecedented abuse of power and threw his presidency into free fall by trying to force Ukraine to spread a universally debunked, right-wing conspiracy theory about him,â said Andrew Bates, a spokesman for Bidenâs presidential campaign. âNow heâs melting-down on television and publicly begging other foreign countries to bail his flailing campaign out with lies.â Yet for Trump, attacking Biden while simultaneously trying to enmesh him in a previously separate conspiracy theory that absolves both Trump and Russia from questions about foreign meddling in the 2016 election has become an obsession, one top longtime Trump adviser told HuffPost. Not only is Trump making baseless remarks about it in public and on Twitter, he has dispatched the Justice Department, the State Department and his private lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, to travel the globe to prove it true. âHeâs a one-man wrecking crew,â the adviser said on condition of anonymity. âI donât know why he just doesnât get over it. Everybody wishes he would knock it off.â Trumpâs White House did not respond to HuffPost queries for this story. Authoritarianism expert Ruth Ben-Ghiat, meanwhile, said that Trumpâs increasing willingness to use his executive branch agencies to further his re-election campaign and to block investigations into him has dangerous historical parallels â such as Italian strongman Benito Mussolini in the 1930s. âMussolini did this before he shut down an investigation that was ruining him by declaring dictatorship,â said Ben-Ghiat, a New York University history professor. âThe openness of it all is the next stage of declaring you are above the law.â   Trump and his top advisers decided last year that Biden would be his toughest general election opponent in 2020, and Trump long has been frequently attacking him in Twitter statements and public comments. But earlier this year, that desire to hurt Bidenâs candidacy merged with a sweeping conspiracy theory that Giuliani began pushing that wove together many of the presidentâs longtime angsts â a unified Trump grievance theory, of sorts. According to this scheme, as described on various right-wing internet pages and talk radio hosts, Russia did not actually interfere in the 2016 election to help Trump but was only made to look as if it had by forces in Ukraine loyal to former President Barack Obama. They worked to get GOP consultant Paul Manafort elevated to run Trumpâs campaign in the spring of 2016 so they could then reveal his corruption later that summer, forcing Trump to fire him. Proof of all this, according to these conspiracy theorists, will be revealed when the Democratic National Committee server that was hacked in 2016 is found in Ukraine, possibly along with Democratic nominee Hillary Clintonâs 33,000 deleted emails. (The theory fails to explain why Obama and his supposed Ukrainian operatives did not publicize the Trump campaignâs connections with Russian spies before the election, rather than only afterward, thereby allowing him to win.) Not a single part of the conspiracy theory has any basis in fact. But Trump embraced it because, the White House adviser said, it meshes with his unwillingness to accept that Russia helped him win the 2016 election. Not only did Trump bring up the far-fetched theory during the now-infamous July 25 telephone call with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky, but he dispatched Attorney General William Barr to find evidence for it, which Barr has been doing much of this year during unpublicized trips overseas, including one last month to Italy. Ironically, Trumpâs readiness to accept Giulianiâs debunked conspiracy theory as fact is now likely to get him impeached by the House. âIf he continues to focus on that white whale, itâs going to bring him down,â former Trump homeland security adviser Tom Bossert told ABC News last month. âItâs not only a conspiracy, it is completely debunkedâ¦. The DNC server and that conspiracy theory has got to go, they have to stop with that, it cannot continue to be repeated in our discourse.â That debunked theory, of course, was one of the topics during that July 25 phone call â which wound up triggering the House impeachment inquiry after a whistleblower filed a complaint accusing Trump of soliciting campaign help from Ukraineâs president. That account was then backed up by a rough transcript of the call that Trump ordered released late last month. Additional whistleblowers are now corroborating concerns about the call, as well. How much those accounts are even relevant at this point is unclear. Trump has repeatedly defended his decision to hold up $400 million in aid to Ukraine and to then ask Zelensky to investigate Biden. Last week on the White House South Lawn, he asked a second country to target Biden and his son. âBy the way, likewise, China should start an investigation into the Bidens, because what happened in China is just about as bad as what happened with â with Ukraine,â he said before climbing aboard a Marine helicopter on his way to Florida. Democrats are proceeding under the notion that merely asking for that assistance is an impeachable abuse of power. And so far, at least a few Republican senators â 20 of whom would be needed to remove Trump from office â are giving signals that they might agree. âI thought the president made a big mistake by asking China to get involved in investigating a political opponent. Itâs completely inappropriate,â Sen. Susan Collins of Maine saidÂ over the weekend. She added that she would not comment further: âShould the articles of impeachment come to the Senate, and right now Iâm going to guess that they will, I will be acting as a juror as I didâ in the 1999 impeachment trial of then-President Bil Clinton.   Trump, despite the impeachment inquiry he has sparked, seems undeterred. He continues to repeat his false accusations against Biden, and even had his campaign put $10 million into a TV ad to repeat them on national television. (At least one cable network has refused to run the ad because of its blatant falsehoods.) Yet as galling as Trump critics find the false corruption accusations is the fact that Trump has the audacity to make them. Since taking office, Trump has steered his campaign, his party, other Republican candidates and groups, lobbyists with business before the executive branch and foreign governments to use his hotels and golf courses, from which he personally profits. Currently, he is pushing the U.S. government to host the next G-7 meeting at his own golf resort in Doral, Florida â which would put tens of millions of American taxpayer dollars into his own pocket, as well. Both actions are a dictionary definition of corruption â using an official position to enrich oneself â and Trump is doing them out in the open. âThis is not just the most corrupt president but the most blatantly corrupt,â said Jordan Libowitz, an official with the watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington. Public Citizenâs Weissman said that Trumpâs Orwellian insistence that Americans believe him, rather than the evidence of their own eyes, is even more corrosive to democracy. âThereâs a deeper problem in the corruption of our language, and the corruption of our notion of reality, and the corruption of our idea of truth,â he said. And while ethics groups agree that Hunter Bidenâs work overseas in the years that his father was vice president created at least the appearance of a conflict of interest for his father, Trump, they say, has little standing to criticize it. Not only does his elder daughter, son-in-law and two adult sons continue to benefit financially from Trumpâs presidency, but Trump himself continues to benefit from projects in countries affected by decisions he makes as president. This week, for example, Trump was informed that Turkey intended to move into northern Syria to attack Kurdish forces who had been critical allies in the U.S. war against Islamic State terrorists in Syria and Iraq. Trump responded by deciding to withdraw U.S. troops from the area and then inviting Turkeyâs authoritarian ruler, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to visit the White House next month. Trump has a licensing deal with Trump Towers Istanbul that has provided him as much as $7 million over the last three years â a business arrangement Trump himself conceded was a âconflict of interestâ before he was elected. Libowitz said Turkish officials had also made 14 visits to Trumpâs hotel near the White House â more than by any other country. âIf President Trump wants to talk about corruption, weâre all for that,â he said. âBut talk of corruption starts at home, or in this case, five blocks from his home.â Trump, nevertheless, appears unfazed by sinking poll numbers and rising public support for his removal from office. On Monday, during a White House photo opportunity, he appeared to lump House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and House Intelligence Committee chairman Adam Schiff, both California Democrats, into the conspiracy against him. âThey should really be looked at very strongly because what they did is unthinkable.Â  What they did to this country is unthinkable,â he said. âItâs so important that we get to the bottom.â

articles.title: Women On Twitter Share Pregnancy Discrimination Stories For Elizabeth Warren
articles.subtitle: In the wake of scrutiny over the presidential candidateâs own story of losing her job, the senator urged other women to come forward. So they did.
articles.author: Josephine Harvey
articles.content: Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) is standing firm in the face of scrutiny, and so are her supporters, who are sharing their own stories on Twitter of when they faced discrimination because of pregnancy. The 2020 presidential candidate tweeted Tuesday to reiterate that she had been edged out of her first teaching job when she became pregnant. She had been responding to unsubstantiated accusations that she had actually voluntarily resigned. âWe can fight back by telling our stories. I tell mine on the campaign trail, and I hope to hear yours,â she added. The conservative website Washington Free Beacon on Monday surfaced the minutes from an April 1971 board of education meeting showing a unanimous vote to extend Warrenâs teaching contract, two months before her exit in June. This does not necessarily contradict Warrenâs story, which is that her contract was renewed in April but that by June, when she was six monthsâ pregnant, the principal âshowed her the door.â âWhen someone calls you in and says the job that youâve been hired for for the next year is no longer yours â âWeâre giving it to someone elseâ â I think thatâs being shown the door,â Warren told CBS News on Monday. The Washington Free Beacon also cast doubt on Warrenâs account by noting she had once described her exit from the job differently in a 2007 interview, when she said:Â â[I] said, âI donât think this is going to work out for me.â I was pregnant with my first baby, so I had a baby and stayed home for a couple of years.â When asked to explain this, Warren told CBS she wasnât comfortable delving into the discrimination aspect publicly until later in her career. On Tuesday, after Warrenâs tweets, people on Twitter shared their own experiences of job discrimination due to pregnancy, or those of their friends and family. Here are some of those stories: Yep. In the late 90s, after 3 years of stellar reviews/promotions, I was suddenly fired within a month of telling my boss I was pregnant. They said I lied when Iâd called in sick one day (morning sickness), but went to visit family later. I was young+scared, so I didnât fight it. Do you have a similar story of job discrimination due to pregnancy? Get in touch with HuffPostâs Amanda Terkel.

articles.title: Jimmy Carter Urges Trump To âTell The Truth ... For A Changeâ
articles.subtitle: The former president wants the impeachment inquiry to carry on, and he criticized the Trump administrationâs refusal to comply with the House investigation.
articles.author: Carla Herreria
articles.content: Former President Jimmy Carter wants President Donald Trump to step aside and allow the House impeachment investigation to continue. âMy advice to him would be to tell the truth, I think, for a change,â Carter, 95, suggested in an interview Tuesday on MSNBC. âAnd also to cut back on his Twitter feeds and give the House of Representatives and also the Senate and, I would say, the general public the evidence that â that we need to form a case, either for or against him,â he added. Earlier Tuesday, the White House refused to cooperate with House Democrats in their impeachment inquiry into Trumpâs interactions with Ukraine. Officials in the Trump administration would not comply with lawmakersâ requests for documents and interviews involving Trumpâs July 25 call with Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which he repeatedly asked him to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, one of Trumpâs 2020 presidential rivals. Carter described Trumpâs refusal to cooperate with the investigation âa departure from custom, and a departure from what American people expect.â âAnd I think thatâs one of the main things that Americans are now considering, is the fact that the White House is trying to stonewall and not provide adequate information,â he told MSNBC. In the past, Carter has expressed both approval and criticism for Trump and his administration. In June, Carter suggested that Trump was an illegitimate president who actually âlost the election and was put into office because the Russians interfered on his behalf.â However, in March 2018, well before Trumpâs call with Zelensky was made public, Carter said heâd prefer if Trump wasnât impeached over the special counselâs investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election campaign. Carter spoke with MSNBC from Nashville, days after he fell at home and sustained an injury that required stitches on his forehead.

articles.title: White House Refuses To Cooperate With Impeachment Inquiry; Constitutional Crisis Looms
articles.subtitle: An eight-page letter to House leaders, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, said that the White House will not cooperate with the inquiry into President Trumpâs actions.
articles.content: The White House is pushing back against the House impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump by refusing to cooperate with lawmakersâ demands for documents and interviews related to the investigation, setting up a constitutional crisis. The eight-page letter, signed Tuesday by White House counsel Pat Cipollone, also accused Democratic lawmakers of using the investigation to overturn the 2016 election results and demanded they abandon all impeachment efforts. The administrationâs letterÂ â which consisted more of the presidentâs political attacks than substantive legal arguments â alleged that Democrats have denied Trump the right to âsee all evidence, to present evidence, to call witnesses, to have counsel present at all hearings, to cross-examine all witnessesâ and to object to âthe examination of witnesses or the admissibility of testimony and evidence.â âPresident Trump and his Administration reject your baseless, unconstitutional efforts to overturn the democratic process. Your unprecedented actions have left the President with no choice,â the letter stated. âIn order to fulfill his duties to the American people, the Constitution, the Executive Branch, and all future occupants of the Office of the Presidency, President Trump and his Administration cannot participate in your partisan and unconstitutional inquiry under these circumstances.â The letter is addressed to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), House Foreign Affairs Chairman Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.) and House Oversight Chairman Elijah Cummings (D-Md.). Those three committees are in charge of the impeachment inquiry. In response, Pelosi said Tuesday that the letterâs allegations are âmanifestly wrongâÂ and constitute the White Houseâs latest âunlawful attempt to hideâ the Trump administrationâs efforts to pressure foreign governments to intervene in the 2020 elections. âThe White House should be warned that continued efforts to hide the truth of the Presidentâs abuse of power from the American people will be regarded as further evidence of obstruction,â Pelosi said in a statement. âMr. President, you are not above the law. You will be held accountable.â The White Houseâs refusal to cooperate at all is almost sure to wind up in court. âThe White House says there is nothing wrong with pressuring a foreign government to intervene in a US election,â Schiff tweeted in response to the Cipollone letter, which also attacked the congressmanâs character. âThey say: they will not cooperate with an impeachment inquiry unless itâs on their terms. They mean: the President is above the law. The Constitution says otherwise.â The letter is the latest uptick in the political battle over Trumpâs July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. A reconstruction of the call released by the White House shows Trump repeatedly pressuring his counterpart to investigate one of his main political rivals, former Vice President Joe Biden, and his son Hunter Biden. The call took place shortly after Trump ordered his aides to block military funding to the country, as detailed in a complaint filed by a whistleblower from the intelligence community. The call prompted Pelosi to finally launch an impeachment inquiry into Trumpâs behavior, although the president has vehemently denied any wrongdoing and moved to delegitimize the effort. House committees have issued multiple subpoenas as part of their investigations, which have already produced bombshell documents.Â Officials who received subpoenas include Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Vice President Mike Pence, Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Office of Management and Budget acting Director Russell Voughtï»¿. The House Oversight Committee also subpoenaed the White House for Ukraine-related documents. Just after the White House released the letter Tuesday, the House announced that it had subpoenaed Gordon Sondland, the U.S. European Union ambassador, for both documents and a deposition. Trump blocked Sondland earlier that day from testifying to lawmakers about the presidentâs communications with Ukraine. Last Thursday, the chairs of three committees released text messages they obtained from Kurt Volker, who was until last month the U.S. State Departmentâs special envoy to Ukraine. The missives appear to show clear instances of the Trump administration pressuring Ukraine for political favors. Axios reported that the White House wants congressional Democrats, particularly those holding vulnerable seats, to go on the record in support of impeachment. Republicans will reportedly also have more sway over the inquiry once it is formalized. Pelosiâs office has so far resisted those calls. On Oct. 3, she wrote a letter to House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) reiterating that House committees had the âfull authority to conduct investigations for all matters under their jurisdiction, including impeachment investigations.â âThere is no requirement under the Constitution, under House Rules, or House precedent that the whole House vote before proceeding with an impeachment inquiry,â Pelosi wrote. âWe hope you and other Republicans share our commitment to following the facts, upholding the Constitution, protecting our national security, and defending the integrity of our elections at such a serious moment in our nationâs history.â Republicans have thus far stood by Trump and moved to minimize the fallout from the call. GOP lawmakers who have fallen out of lockstep have been immediately castigated by their party. Read the letter below: This article has been updated with Rep. Adam Schiffâs response, a House subpoena being sent to a former ambassador, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosiâs response.

articles.title: ICE Moved 700 Women Out Of A Detention Center And Wonât Tell Lawyers Where They Are
articles.subtitle: Some of the women have serious medical issues, and lawyers worry they could die in detention.
articles.author: Angelina Chapin
articles.content: Immigration and Customs Enforcement moved more than 700 women, some of whom have critical medical conditions, out of a Texas detention center in September without giving their lawyers any way of finding them, according to immigrant rights attorneys. Starting on Sept. 20, the women being held at the Karnes County Residential Center were sent to other centers around the country so that the facility could be used to detain families. More than two weeks later, their lawyers from the Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services (RAICES) have no idea where the majority of these women are being held, and they canât find any updated information in ICEâs online detainee tracking system. The inability to track these immigrants could have fatal consequences if their health continues to deteriorate, according to Andrea Meza, the director of family detention services at RAICES. âIâm really fearful that their conditions could worsen,â Meza said. âI donât want them to be in another ICE press release about death in detention.â The situation highlights a common problem for migrants in ICE custody: They can be transferred between facilities with little notice and yet their new locations are not promptly updated in the system. If their existing lawyers and family members canât find them, they may have to go through their cases without legal representation, especially in remote areas where legal counsel is sparse. And those with serious health issues could die if advocates who donât know where their clients were transferred are unable to fight for their right to medical treatment. An ICE official told HuffPost that âComprehensive medical care is provided to all individuals in ICE custodyâ adding that staffing includes registered nurses,Â licensed mental health providers, a physician and access to 24-hour emergency care. The official acknowledged that the women at Karnes had been transferred to other facilities, but did not explain why their locations were not showing up in the online system. HuffPost reported that while at Karnes, some of the immigrants were allegedly being denied lifesaving care, such as cancer and HIV treatment, and that suicidal patients were not receiving psychiatric counseling. One woman with cancer in her uterus said she had not received medical treatment for more than two months. Another immigrant, who is HIV positive, said she was not getting her medication or being evaluated by a doctor, even as her symptoms worsened. A doctor told HuffPost that anyone with a serious physical illness requires constant medical visits to stop their disease from rapidly progressing. The lack of medical care in immigrant detention facilities is well-established. SevenÂ immigrants have died in ICE detention centers this year, and six minors have diedÂ in Border Patrol centers, in many cases because they didnât receive proper medical help for their illnesses. The online system that tracks ICE detainees is notoriously faulty. While in most cases ICE is not legally required to inform lawyers when their clients are being transferred, that information is supposed to be accessible via the agencyâs online ICE Detainee Locator within roughly 24 hours of a personâs relocation according to Andrew Lorenzen-Strait, who formerly worked as a deputy assistant director for custody programs at ICE. But according to lawyers who rely on the system to track their clients, the locator is unreliable. Kate Lincoln-Goldfinch, a Texas-based immigration attorney, said the tool only helps her find detainees 50% of the time, in part because names and birthdates are often entered incorrectly, making detainees impossible to search. It can take up to a few weeks for someone who is transferred to a new facility to show up in the system, which means families are often left wondering whether their loved ones have been deported back to life-threatening situations in their home countries, Lincoln-Goldfinch said. âI think FedEx does a better job of tracking its packages than ICE does of tracking the people it detains,â Lincoln-Goldfinch said. Other lawyers have complained that the locator doesnât load properly, or that it will show âno results foundâ for someone who is still in ICE custody. Meza said the latter is happening for roughly 100 of the women who were recently transferred from Karnes, and that another 660 of them show up in the system as still being detained at the facility even though they have been moved. Aside from the medical concerns, Meza worries that these women wonât have legal representation if RAICES canât help them find lawyers near the new detention centers, which may be in remote areas, and share the information theyâve already collected about their cases. With legal assistance, immigrants are five and a half times more likely to not be deported, according to aÂ 2015 study from the University of Pennsylvania Law Review. There are aÂ record number of immigrants currently being held in detention, which is undoubtedly putting strain on a tracking system that didnât work well to begin with. But in addition to logistical issues that might exist, immigration advocates say the administration has a record of dehumanizing asylum-seekers and is likely not prioritizing a locator that would help lawyers keep their clients in the U.S. Before splitting up families last summer under its zero tolerance policy, the government had no system in place to track the whereabouts of the separated parents and children. âWe know the whole for-profit prison system is putting money before peopleâs humanity,â said Meza. âItâs just a matter of time before we see the next death in ICE custody.â CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story misstated a statistic on the value of legal counsel. The fact is that immigrants are five and a half times more likely to not be deported if they have legal assistance.

articles.title: Montgomery, Alabama, Elects Its First Black Mayor
articles.subtitle: Steven Reed won the mayoral vote in the majority-Black city known as a flashpoint in the struggle for civil rights.
articles.author: Sanjana Karanth
articles.content: Montgomery has elected Steven Reed to become the Alabama capitalâs first Black mayor, a landmark in a city known for heroic stands and violent clashes during the civil rights movement. Reed, who has been Montgomery Countyâs probate judge since 2012, won the election with about 67% of the vote in Tuesdayâs mayoral runoff against TV station owner David Woods, WSFA-TV reported. Reed will replace Todd Strange, whoâs been Montgomeryâs mayor since 2009 and was not running for reelection. âLet the record show that this is what we can do, as a community, as a city, and let this go far beyond Montgomery, let it go far beyond Alabama and let it go far beyond this nation,â Reed said Tuesday night at his victory party, saying the election showed âwhat we can do when we come together in this city and we build around positivity, around opportunity and all the things that tie us together versus those that keep us apart.â âTonight isnât the end. Tonight is the beginning,â added Reed, who local media said was also Montgomery Countyâs first Black probate judge. âTonight sent a signal, not just to all of us here in Montgomery, all of us in Alabama; it sent a signal throughout this country about what kind of community we are right now, not what we were.â According to the U.S. Census Bureau, about 60% of the population is Black in the city of about 200,000. The Alabama capital was integral to the Black communityâs voting rights movement, making Reedâs win a fitting milestone in its 200-year history. Among the cityâs marks on the civil rights struggle was theÂ Montgomery bus boycott of 1955, a nonviolent protest to desegregate the cityâs public transit system, sparked by the arrest of Rosa Parks after she refused to give up her seat for a white man. In 1961, the city became a flashpoint again when a mob attacked Freedom Riders at the Greyhound bus station. Montgomery was also home to Martin Luther King Jr., who grew in prominence as a pastor at Dexter Avenue Baptist Church and helped organize the bus boycott, eventually leading the civil rights movement nationwide that would influence lawmakers to pass the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Montgomery was the final destination on theÂ four-day march from Selma, Alabama. That same year, lawmakers passed the Voting Rights Act, a year after the Civil Rights Act became law. Several museums and memorials in the city commemorate civil rights history. The Equal Justice Initiative opened the National Memorial for Peace and Justice and the Legacy Museum last year to pay tribute to thousands of lynching victims. âThis is a historic day for our nation,â said Karen Baynes-Dunning, interim president and CEO of the Southern Poverty Law Center, a civil rights legal organization based in Montgomery. âThe election of Steven Reed â¦ symbolizes the new inclusive & forward thinking South that so many have worked to achieve.â Reed will be sworn in Nov. 12, according to The Montgomery Advertiser. The publication said the mayor-elect wants to focus on food deserts and poor water quality in the city, as well as implementing a universal pre-K program and expanding the police force. He received an endorsement from presidential candidate Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), according to WSFA-TV.

articles.title: Minneapolis Mayor Responds To Trump Twitter Attacks: âYawnâ
articles.subtitle: Jacob Frey said he doesnât have time to be âtweeting garbageâ as the mayor of a city, so heâs surprised the president has time while governing a nation.
articles.author: Josephine Harvey
articles.content: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey (D) is the latest target of President Donald Trumpâs Twitter rage â and the mayorâs response suggests that heâs rather tired of it all. âYawn...â Frey began in a tweet reply Tuesday, after the presidentâs reelection campaign accused him of âabusing his powerâ and attempting to âextortâ the campaign by âconjuring a phony and outlandish bill for security in an effort to block a scheduled Keep America Great rallyâ in Minneapolis. The president chimed in by calling the mayor a âlightweight.â âWelcome to Minneapolis where we pay our bills, we govern with integrity, and we love all of our neighbors,â the mayor politely clapped back. The Trump campaign called Frey a âradical leftist mayorâ and accused him of conjuring up excessive security charges to pressure the Target Center, the site of Thursdayâs planned rally, into effectively trampling on Minnesota residentsâ First Amendment rights to gather and yell in support of the president. âFreyâs city government preemptively informed the Target Center that it would be responsible for $530,000 in security and other costs related to the event. The Target Center attempted to pass the costs on to the Trump campaign under threat of withholding the use of the arena,â the statement said. After another tweet from Trump about how he stands âstrongly & proudlyâ with âgreat Police Officers,â Frey told the president that the charges were necessary to pay those officers for their extra laborÂ â and that Trump could afford it: In a press conference later that day, Frey told reporters that he woke up to a âsurpriseâ that morning when he discovered the president was tweeting about his city and him. âI wake up every single morning with not a lot of time on my hands because Iâm doing things like filling potholes and making sure our city has enough affordable housing,â the mayor said. âI donât have time with a city of 430,000 people to be tweeting garbage out, so itâs kind of surprising when the president of the United States, a country with 327 million people, has the time to do this himself, so I donât know where the guy gets the time,â he added. Mpls mayor @Jacob_Frey on Trumpâs Twitter attacks: âIâm doing things like filling potholes & making sure our city has enough affordable housing ... I donât have time to be tweeting garbage out, so itâs kinda surprising when POTUS has the time to do this himself.â pic.twitter.com/Hn1NpoWYMV Frey also fired back at the Trump campaignâs accusation that security for an Obama rally at the same venue in 2009 cost significantly less. âThere are significant expenses associated with a campaign rally from Donald Trump,â he said. By contrast, the Obama event focused on health care policy, he said. It was not an election rally. According to the mayor, the security costs for the Trump event were calculated by a standard methodology used to estimate costs of previous major events like the 2018 Super Bowl and Final Four, the Star Tribune reported. The public safety expenses were expected to be around $400,000 and the remainder would be the result of lane closures, traffic control and various other costs. Should the rally go ahead â and the campaign has said it will âÂ this wonât be the first time the Trump campaign has caused fiscal concerns for local officials. The campaign has an outstanding bill for more than $470,000 from a February rally in El Paso, Texas. Nine other cities across the country have complained that they were not reimbursed for services provided by local police and fire departments, totaling more than $840,000, according to a study by the Center for Public Integrity. El Paso confirmed to ABC News on Tuesday that its bill was still outstanding. Minneapolis seems to have taken note, as an El Paso spokesperson said Minneapolis officials had reached out to them regarding the bill.

articles.title: Nancy Pelosi Calls Trumpâs Bluff: âYou Are Not Above The Lawâ
articles.subtitle: The White House refused to cooperate with the impeachment inquiry, calling it an âunconstitutionalâ effort to overturn the 2016 election.
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) castigated President Donald Trumpâs refusal to cooperate with Congressâ impeachment inquiry on Tuesday, saying the White House was trying to make âlawlessness a virtueâ and pledging to hold the administration accountable. âThe American people have already heard the Presidentâs own words â âdo us a favor, though,ââ Pelosi said in a statement, referencing the whistleblower complaint that led her to formallyÂ open the impeachment inquiry last month. âThe Presidentâs actions threaten our national security, violate our Constitution and undermine the integrity of our elections. The White House letter is only the latest attempt to cover up his betrayal of our democracy, and to insist that the President is above the law.â .@realDonaldTrump, you are not above the law. You will be held accountable. #TruthExposed https://t.co/elMCHdLYlK Her response came just hours after White House counsel Pat Cipollone sent Pelosi and other top Democrats an eight-page letter accusing them of waging a âpartisan and unconstitutionalâ effort to overturn the 2016 election. âPresident Trump and his Administration reject your baseless, unconstitutional efforts to overturn the democratic process. Your unprecedented actions have left the President with no choice,â read the letter addressed to Pelosi, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.) and House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings (D-Md.). âIn order to fulfill his duties to the American people, the Constitution, the Executive Branch, and all future occupants of the Office of the Presidency, President Trump and his Administration cannot participate in your partisan and unconstitutional inquiry under these circumstances.â Trump and his team have been embroiled in scandal following the whistleblower complaint, which discussed a July phone call in which the president repeatedlyÂ pressured Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate one of his main political rivals, former Vice President Joe Biden, and his son Hunter Biden. The July call came shortly after Trump ordered his administration to withhold millions of dollars in military fundingÂ for Ukraine. Democrats have cast the discussion as a clear demand for a political favor in exchange for that military funding. Trump has vehemently rejected that characterization, although text messages sent by U.S. officialsÂ â and released by Democrats last week â appeared to echo the whistleblower complaint and detail concerns within the presidentâs own administration after the call with Zelensky. The House has already issued multiple subpoenas as part of its investigations, targeting high-profile officials including Vice President Mike Pence, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giuliani. The White House itself has also been subpoenaed for Ukraine-related documents. In her statement on Tuesday, Pelosi rejected the White Houseâs claims that the impeachment inquiry was out of bounds, calling those claims âmanifestly wrongâ and accusing Trump of âsimply another unlawful attempt to hide the facts of the Trump Administrationâs brazen efforts to pressure foreign powers to intervene in the 2020 elections.â âDespite the White Houseâs stonewalling, we see a growing body of evidence that shows that President Trump abused his office and violated his oath to âprotect, preserve and defend the Constitution,ââ Pelosi said. âThe White House should be warned that continued efforts to hide the truth of the Presidentâs abuse of power from the American people will be regarded as further evidence of obstruction.â âMr. President, you are not above the law,â the speaker continued. âYou will be held accountable.â

articles.title: Hillary Clinton Taunts âObsessedâ Donald Trump: âObviously, I Can Beat Him Againâ
articles.subtitle: âMaybe there does need to be a rematch.â
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Hillary ClintonÂ on Tuesday joked about running against Donald Trump again during an interview with âPBS NewsHourâ host Judy Woodruff, and dinged the president for losing the popular voteÂ to her in the 2016 election. Trump on Tuesday morning suggested on Twitter that his 2016 Democratic rival âshould enter the race to try and steal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren.â Clinton later fired back: In the interview with Woodruff, Clinton said it âtruly is remarkable how obsessed he remains with me, but this latest tweet is so typical of him.â âNothing has been more examined and looked at than my emails, we all know that. So, heâs either lying or delusional, or both,â she continued.Â âThere was no subpoena as he says in a tweet this morning, so, maybe there does need to be a rematch. I mean, obviously, I can beat him again.â Clinton added: âBut you know, just, seriously, I donât understand, I donât think anybody understands, what motivates him other than personal grievance, other than seeking adulation.â Check out the interview below.Â (Clintonâs comments are around the 38:45 mark.)

articles.title: Elizabeth Warrenâs Climate Justice Plan Aims To Keep Water Public, Study Pollution More
articles.subtitle: The Democratic presidential hopeful is adopting much of what former candidate Jay Inslee put out.
articles.author: Alexander C. Kaufman
articles.content: Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren released a sweeping climate justice plan on Wednesday morning, vowing to ramp up research on the health effects of pollution and discourage the transfer of public water services to for-profit companies. The 12-page memo marks the Massachusetts senatorâs eighth climate-related proposal since launching a presidential campaign built on an ambitious slate of policy plans at the start of the year. The latest proposal collects much of Warrenâs existing ideas on improving racial equity and reducing pollution and reframes them in what looks like an ambitious, nearly 5,900-word blueprint on how to implement a Green New Deal. âJustice cannot be a secondary concern â it must be at the center of our response to climate change,â Warren wrote in the memo. âThe Green New Deal commits us to a âjust transitionâ for all communities and all workers. But we wonât create true justice by cleaning up polluted neighborhoods and tweaking a few regulations at the EPA.â The document borrows heavily from the plan laid out by former climate candidate Jay Inslee, who quit the Democratic presidential primary in August to run for reelection as Washingtonâs governor, including efforts to quantify pollution inequity between communities and apply that data to decisions on where to invest Green New Deal money. Warren also proposes turning the White HouseÂ Council on Environmental Quality, a currently sleepy office tasked with coordinating public health policy across federal agencies, into an environmental justice hub. The Warren plan offers fewer wonky details on which agencies should do what work than the Inslee proposal did. But notably included in the senatorâs release are calls to increase research funding at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and to overhaul drinking water infrastructure, putting an end to the privatization of water delivery. Under her administration, Warren would âfully fundâ the CDCâs âenvironmental health programs, such as childhood lead poisoning prevention, and community health investigationsâ and would âprovide additional grant funding for independent research into environmental health effects.â Her campaign declined to share an exact dollar figure. Itâs a relatively novel idea to include the CDC in a campaign climate plan, something the other leading environmental champions in the race have omitted so far. Yet itâs likely to be popular. In February, representatives from four dozen public health groups sent a letter to House lawmakers pleading for an increase in federal funding for the CDCâs âcritically underfundedâ lead and climate programs. The CDC is the fourth-most favorably viewed federal agency and has some of the most bipartisan support, a Pew Research Center poll found in September. Yet the CDCâs operating budget fell nearly $1 million between the 2018 and 2019 fiscal years. Warrenâs plan goes beyond just researching the effects of lead poisoning. Citing the recent lead contaminations in the drinking water of Flint, Michigan, and Newark, New Jersey, she said her administration would âend decades of disinvestment and privatization of our nationâs water system â our government at every level should invest in safe, affordable drinking water for all of us.â Ramping up federal spending on water infrastructure is a staple of Democratic campaigns at this point, particularly as Newarkâs former mayor, now-Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.), is running for the presidential nomination. But curtailing the transfer of control of public services from government agencies to private companies is another issue altogether. The private water industry serves 73 million Americans, according to National Association of Water Companies data. For-profit water services put public health at risk, a 66-page paper by University of Louisville law professor Craig Anthony Arnold argues, because the profit motive incentivizes companies to provide better services to customers who pay more and to maintain infrastructure with an eye to the length of the firmâs contract. Detroitâs debt-choked public utility threatened to shut off water to nearly 17,500 households that were behind on bills last year, only to decrease the shutoff rate 70% this year. In the timing of the 2018 shutoffs, just as the city was looking to privatize its utility, the left-wing think tank Centre for Research on Globalization sawÂ an effort to streamline a troubled facility before selling it off to profiteers. Other cities are actively opposing such privatization. Last November, Baltimore became the first big city in the United States to ban water privatization with an amendment to its charter. Wednesdayâs proposal did not make clear whether a Warren White House would take explicit steps to discourage municipalities from switching to private water. But the campaign said an influx of federal funding to overhaul water infrastructure should make switching to private water services far less appealing. Income and race are strong indicators of how much pollution exposure Americans can expect to face. Black neighborhoods, on average, have air thatâs 48% more polluted than that in white neighborhoods, an NAACP report found last year, and Black Americans are 75% more likely to live in neighborhoods abutting industrial sites. The journal Environmental Research published a study last year that determined Black, Hispanic and poor students face the highest risks of inhaling toxic pollutants in crumbling schools across the country.

articles.title: Facebook Refuses To Pull Trump Campaign Ad That Falsely Accuses Biden Of Corruption
articles.subtitle: Joe Biden has slammed Facebook for allowing the spread of an âobjectively falseâ ad. The clip has already been viewed on Facebook millions of times.
articles.author: Dominique Mosbergen
articles.content: A video ad that falsely accuses Joe Biden of withholding $1 billion in aid to Ukraine to benefit his son has been viewed on Facebook millions of times since its release last month by President Donald Trumpâs reelection campaign. Biden, whoâs vying for the Democratic presidential nomination, has urged Facebook to take the ad down, arguing that it spreads âobjectively false informationâ and âpoisons the public discourse.â But Facebook, which has come under scrutiny for its role in spreading misinformation during the 2016 presidential election, has reportedly refused to pull the video, citing its âfundamental belief in free expressionâ and ârespect for the democratic process.â The New York Times, which first reported Facebookâs denial of Bidenâs request, reported Tuesday that the social media giant had sent a letter to the former vice president, saying the ad did not violate company policies. âOur approach is grounded in Facebookâs fundamental belief in free expression, respect for the democratic process, and the belief that, in mature democracies with a free press, political speech is already arguably the most scrutinized speech there is,â Katie Harbath, Facebookâs head of global elections policy, said in the letter, per the Times. Harbathâs letter echoed a similar sentiment expressed last month by Nick Clegg, a former U.K. deputy prime minister who is now a Facebook vice president, who said in aÂ speechÂ in Washington that itâs not Facebookâs ârole to intervene when politicians speak.â The Biden campaign slammed Facebookâs decision as âunacceptable.â The dissemination of âobjectively false information to influence public opinion poisons the public discourse and chips away at our democracy,â Biden campaign spokesman TJ Ducklo told CNN in a statement. âWhether it originates from the Kremlin or Trump Tower, these lies and conspiracy theories threaten to undermine the integrity of our elections in America. It is unacceptable for any social media company to knowingly allow deliberately misleading material to corrupt its platform.â The Trump ad being contested pushes a conspiracy theory that Biden â according to a narrator in the clip â âpromised Ukraine $1 billion if they fired the prosecutor investigating his sonâs company.â While it is true that the elder Biden, then serving as vice president, told Ukrainian leaders in 2016Â to fire a top prosecutor if they wanted to get the aid, thereâs no evidence that this demand had anything to do with his son, Hunter. The ad has also run on Twitter and YouTube, both told the Times that the ad complied with company policies. Bidenâs campaign told CNN that it âwould not rule out sending similar lettersâ to other social media sites requesting the adâs removal from their platforms. On TV, the ad has run on Fox News, which â like Facebook â denied a Biden campaign request to block the clip. CNN, however, has refused to run the ad. Explaining that decision, a CNN spokesman said last week that the video âmakes assertions that have been proven demonstrably false by various news outlets, including CNN.â Facebook has come under fire from the Democratic National Committee, as well as other 2020 presidential hopefuls, for their refusal to block false statements or ads from political candidates. Democratic National Committee CEO Seema Nanda told CNN last week that Facebook was allowing Trump âto mislead the American people on their platform unimpeded.â On Monday, Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) â who, along with Biden, is considered a front-runnerÂ for the Democratic nomination for president â criticized Facebookâs policies in a series of tweets. âThe public deserves to know how Facebook intends to use their influence in this election,â Warren wrote. âFor instance, Trump and Zuckerberg met at the White House two weeks ago. What did they talk about?â she added in a subsequent tweet. Warren suggested that Facebook had tweaked misinformation policies to exempt politicians from fact-checking after this meeting with Trump. As Reuters noted, Warren has not offered any evidence to support this claim. âThereâs no indication that Zuckerberg or Facebook executives have come to terms with the role their unpreparedness playedâ in the spread of misinformation during the 2016 election, Warren wrote. âNor have they shown that they understand what needs to be done to prevent another attack in the 2020 election.â

articles.title: How Trump And Facebook Are Cashing In On The Impeachment News
articles.subtitle: Unbound by truth on one of the worldâs most powerful advertising platforms, Trumpâs anti-impeachment ads are drawing in donors with clickbait disinformation.
articles.author: Jesselyn Cook
articles.content: âLEARN THE TRUTH,â President Donald Trumpâs campaign declared in a Facebook ad that launched last week. âJoe Biden PROMISED Ukraine $1 BILLION DOLLARS if they fired the prosecutor investigating his sonâs company.â Facebook users were outraged: âWhat Biden did is what Congress should be investigating,â one wrote. âKillary/Biden/Obama and their dealings for self enrichment needs to be thoroughly investigated,â added another. âTruth/facts are all that matter.â The premise of the still-active ad is false: Thereâs no evidence that Trumpâs potential 2020 presidential rival, former Vice President Joe Biden, pressured Ukraine to fire its prosecutor general for reasons relating to his son Hunter Biden. But facts like that arenât important â at least not to Facebook. Late last month, as Democrats announced a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump over his own dealings with Ukraine, Facebook quietly tweaked the language of its misinformation policy, effectively giving political advertisers a public green light to spread blatant lies. Trumpâs team, which has since been pumping big moneyÂ into a barrage of Facebook ads urging people to donate to his âOfficial Impeachment Defense Task Force,â is doing just that: A number of its latest ads have featured calculated falsehoodsÂ â the kind that are designed to provoke people to click âShareâ and pull out their wallets. The strategy seems to be working. Over the past couple of weeks, the Trump campaign has welcomed a flood of new donors helping to bring in millions of dollars, and Trumpâs approval rating recently reached its highest level this year. âFacebook is the presidentâs platform of choice for advertising. His supporters are very much on Facebook, and his campaign has spent so much money trying to rally his base to defend him,â said Kyle Tharp, communications director of Acronym, a progressive digital political strategy organization. âItâs the M.O. of the Trump campaign to capitalize on these big, cultural breaking news moments for its own financial gain.â Until recently, Facebookâs misinformation policy page stated that ads with âdeceptive, false, or misleading contentâ were prohibited, but the page has since been updated to state that only ads featuring âclaims debunked by third-party fact checkersâ are prohibited, as first reported by journalist Judd Legum in his newsletter Popular Info. Itâs a subtle but important distinction that now makes clear a loophole for politicians, as Facebook âexempts politicians from our third-party fact-checking program,â per the siteâs vice president of global affairs, Nick Clegg (a former politician).Â âWe donât believe that itâs an appropriate role for us to referee political debates and prevent a politicianâs speech from reaching its audience and being subject to public debate and scrutiny.â Essentially, politicians can officially lie to voters with impunity in paid ads on one of the worldâs largest advertising platforms. âBy profiting off politicians selling false statements to the public, Facebook is complicit in the erosion of our civic health, discourse and democracy,â Gaurav Laroia, senior policy counsel at Free Press, said in a statement. âThe company should show some courage and stand up for the truth â at least in its advertising policies.â According to Facebook, its stance on misinformation in political ads is nothing new. The company maintains it has long sold ads to politicians without holding them to a standard of truth, and that it recently updated the language of its policy to make this clear. Although regulations for ads in newspapers and broadcast media are often poorly enforced, news outlets have pushed back against ads containing fake news: CNN recently refused to air two of Trumpâs campaign ads, including one that the network said âmakes assertions that have been proven demonstrably false by various news outlets.â And, unlike some Facebook ads, those featured in newspapers and on television and radio are subject to public scrutiny by journalists and others. Micro-targeted Facebook ads, or âdark ads,â which are tailored for specific audiences, can escape such scrutiny because theyâre not always visible to or accessible by the general public. Facebook rolled out a searchable library of ads to address concerns surrounding transparency this year, but the library includes limited information, and researchers and reporters have criticized it for being incomplete. And, as the 2016 election demonstrated, print and broadcast advertising have slipped behind the remarkable reach and impact of their digital counterpart. Facebook in particular played an extraordinary role in Trumpâs victory that year, in large part by housing covert disinformation campaigns by Russian operatives and by allowing Trumpâs team to engage in micro-targeting and voter suppression tactics. The Trump campaign has long used âmisleading, false and defamatoryâ messaging in its political communications with voters, both online and offline, Tharp said. But now, with Facebookâs public blessing and an unparalleled investment in impeachment-related ads on the 2-billion-user platform, the gloves are officially off. âThe way that Facebook prioritizes content delivery makes it so that inflammatory content really works,â Tharp noted. âIt spreads like wildfire on the site.â Facebook has had a consistently troubled relationship with the truth. Despite its repeated vows to crack down on fake news, the company has maintained that demonstrably false content is not necessarily subject to deletion on its platform. Earlier this year, it let a video that was maliciously edited to make House Speaker Nancy Pelosi seem drunk go viral under its watch. Trumpâs deceptiveÂ attack ad against Biden â which is one of multiple anti-impeachment ads the Trump campaign bought to push false narratives about the former vice president â was debunked by at least two Facebook-approved fact-checkers (this was done independently from Facebookâs fact-checking program, however, which does not apply to politicians). The ad has garnered hundreds of thousands of views on the site while Trumpâs campaign manager, Brad Parscale, celebrates an influx of donations. Facebook did take down an earlier version of that ad â not because it was peddling a flagrant lie but because it contained a transcription of Biden saying the phrase âson of a bitch,â which violates Facebookâs ad policy against profanity. (The new version of the ad censors the text to sayÂ âb*tch.â) Facebookâs rising dominance as a news source also lends legitimacy to the ads it hosts, even though advertisers have been relieved of any obligation to accuracy. Sixty-seven percent of its users are exposed to news on the platform, and 43% use it to seek news out, according to a Pew Research Center study published last year. The companyâs policy to accept politiciansâ money for ads promoting fake news is especially beneficial for Trump: Heâs a master at spreading lies to benefit himself politically, and his presidency has demonstrated just how vulnerable American democracy is to disinformation on Facebook. The platform provides an ideal environment for incendiary, clickbait falsehoods by rewarding them with unwavering impunity. By paying Facebook millions of dollars to run an onslaught of anti-impeachment ads â including ones promoting blatant lies â Trumpâs campaign âhas been able to really adeptly take advantage of [the impeachment news] for fundraising purposes,â said Tharp. âThis election is going to be one in the margins, and whoever can really engage their base is going to have the advantage.â

articles.title: Khashoggiâs Murder Should Have Made Saudi Arabia A Pariah. 7 Men Made Sure That Didnât Happen.
articles.subtitle: Meet the key figures behind the scenes, from a journalist-turned-lobbyist to an evangelical writer, in the effort to preserve the kingdomâs image after the killing.
articles.content: Illustration by Paul Ryding for HuffPost Saudi government officials killed Washington Post writer Jamal Khashoggi and then cut up his body with a bone saw, leaving his remains in a still unknown location, a little over a year ago. Their boss, Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, will soon host some of the richest and most powerful people in the world to talk about how great his country is at an event dubbed âDavos in the Desert,â and he can still count President Donald Trump as a friend, even after the CIA concluded that he likely ordered the murder. Despite global uproar last year, justice has been at best delayed in the Khashoggi case. âThough little progress has been made until now, it does not have to remain this way,â Khashoggiâs fiancÃ©e at the time of his death, Hatice Cengiz, wrote in the Post in late September. âI continue to hope the United States decides to stand for what is right. In the meantime, I will continue seeking justice for Jamal â and hope that people and governments the world over will join me in my quest.â Saudi Arabia and its de facto ruler, the prince colloquially known as MBS, have used that borrowed time to shore up their image on the world stage. High-profile backing from Trump has helped. But itâs the less flashy work that has counted even more. Itâs people like the ones below â letâs call them the Saudi Seven â whom Cengiz and human rights groups will have to confront if thereâs any hope for accountability. Khashoggiâs murder âgoes beyond religion, language or geography,â she wrote. âIt is a matter of humanity.â These are the people who have made it possible so far for Saudi Arabia to remain a member of the international community in relatively good standing â instead of a government shunned for the brutal murder, within another countryâs borders, of a citizen who sought refuge abroad. On April 18, 2018, Brad Klapper ended a career of more than a decade in journalism and became a paid agent for the government of Saudi Arabia. Klapper left his job as a national security editor at The Associated Press to become a senior vice president for media relations at the lobbying firm Qorvis, which the Saudis hired after 15 of their citizens helped to kill more than 3,000 people on Sept. 11, 2001. Within months, Klapper was helping the Saudis respond to their biggest public relations problem since the 9/11 attacks: the murder of a fellow journalist, Khashoggi. Qorvis is likely the most important node in Saudi Arabiaâs sprawling network of influence in the United States. The firm stuck with the kingdom even as, particularly following the Khashoggi killing, similar companies have said they will no longer represent Riyadh, and itâs been rewarded for it. The company earned close to $19 million from the Saudis in the six months after the murder, an amount lobbying expert Ben Freeman of the Center for International Policy said is more than half of what the Saudis normally spend across all their agents in a whole year. Qorvis also gained three new contracts linked to Saudi government money in the spring of 2019. At a challenging time for the company and its client, Klapper is a rare and valuable asset: Someone who influential journalists, lawmakers and government officials know from long experience, which makes them likely to treat outreach from him differently than that from other Saudi mouthpieces. He spent 13 years at the outlet that revealed the Saudis â and Qorvis â were secretly paying U.S. veterans to lobby against a bill supported by the families of 9/11 victims, after all. âThe Saudis have amassed quite the collection of folks whoâve gone through the revolving door in all the places of power in D.C.,â Freeman said. âHaving folks like that on your payroll really opens a lot of doors that wouldnât be open for the Saudis and can really transcend having a toxic reputation which I think the Saudis do now.â Former elected officials seeking roles like Klapperâs have to wait one year before they can lobby their erstwhile colleagues, a period during which the relationship can adjust to a new normal.
