articles.content: A jury on Wednesday convicted aÂ racist former New Jersey police chiefÂ who allegedly slammed a handcuffed Black teenagerâs head into a metal doorjamb on one count of lying to the FBI, but said they were deadlocked on federal civil rights and hate crimes charges. Former Bordentown Township Police Chief Frank Nucera was the first law enforcement officer to face a federal hate crimes charge in more than a decade. Nucera was recorded by his own officers as he went on racist rants against nonwhite citizens and declared then-candidate Donald Trump the âlast hope for white people.â Nucera thought that Black people should âstay the fuck out of Bordentown,â compared them to ISIS and animals, said they had âno valueâ and should be mowed down by a firing squad. Nuceraâs legal team conceded that Nucera used âugly, embarrassing, disgusting words,â but contended that there was no firm evidence he hit Timothy Stroyeâs head against a doorjamb while the Black 18-year-old was handcuffed, despite the fact that two Bordentown Township police officers testified that Nucera did just that. Justice Department prosecutors, Nucera attorney Rocco Cipparone told jurors in his opening statement, âwant you to turn criminal justice into social justice.â On Monday, the fourth day of deliberations, jurors hearing the case in Camden told U.S. District Judge Robert Kugler they were deadlocked on the charges against Nucera. But they continued deliberating on Monday afternoon after Kugler asked them to keep trying to reach a verdict. The case against Nucera came to fruition a few months after TrumpÂ joked about slamming handcuffed suspectsâ headsÂ in a speech before police officers. During the Trump administration, the Justice Department has backed away from investigating patterns of police misconduct in law enforcement organizations.

articles.title: Bipartisan Group Of Lawmakers Blasts NBA For Caving To China
articles.subtitle: âYour statements come at a time when we would hope to see Americans standing up and speaking out,â the legislators wrote in a letter.
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: A bipartisan group of lawmakers said Wednesday they were deeply concerned that the NBA had kowtowed to China after the organization apologized for an executiveâs comments supporting protestors in Hong Kong. âIt is outrageous that the NBA has caved to Chinese government demands for contrition,â the group, which included Rep. Tom Malinowski (D-N.J.), Rep. Mike Gallagher (R-Wis.), Sen. Ben Sasse (R-Neb.) and Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.), wrote in a letter addressed to NBA Commissioner Adam Silver. âNBA players have a rich history of speaking out on sensitive topics of social justice and human rights inside the United States, and the NBA takes pride in defending their right to do so.â âYet while it is easy to defend freedom of speech when it costs you nothing, equivocating when profits are at stake is a betrayal of fundamental American values.â The letter was also signed by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), Rep. Jim Banks (R-Ind.), Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) and Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas). The lawmakersâ statement comes less than a week after the Houston Rocketsâ general manager, Daryl Morey, posted a tweet in support of the democracy protests in Hong Kong, reading: âFight for freedom, stand with Hong Kong.â The short-lived note prompted widespread anger in mainland China, where Communist Party leaders have ignited nationalist sentiment to encourage opposition to demonstrationsÂ related to Hong Kongâs autonomy. Morey quickly deleted the message and issued an apology, but within days Chinaâs state broadcaster said it would stop showing Rockets games in the country and sponsors began suspending their contracts with the NBA. The team has been wildly popular in China, in large part because it drafted Yao Ming in 2002. The Washington Post noted that the NBA has since become the countryâs most popular sports league. The NBA, which makes hundreds of millions of dollars in annual revenue in China, scrambled to contain the fallout. In a statement, the league said it recognized âthat the views expressed by Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey have deeply offended many of our friends and fans in China, which is regrettable.â A separate message in Chinese went further, saying the NBA was âextremely disappointedâ in Moreyâs âinappropriate remarks.â The response prompted its own backlash in the U.S., and lawmakers quickly lambasted the NBA for failing to defend free speech. Many called out Silver, the leagueâs commissioner, for trying to have it both ways while attempting to batten down the organizationâs business interests. The lawmakers on Wednesday urged the NBA to take action to defend the rights of its players and staff, including steps to support their ability to express their opinions âno matter the economic consequences.â They also urged Silver to call Chinaâs bluff and refuse to air NBA activities in the country until government-owned broadcasters end their own boycott. âYour statements come at a time when we would hope to see Americans standing up and speaking out in defense of the rights of the people of Hong Kong,â the lawmakers wrote. âYou have more power to take a stand than most of the Chinese governmentâs targets and should have the courage and integrity to use it.â Read the full letter below:

articles.title: Trump Defends Wife Of U.S. Diplomat Suspected In Death Of British Teen
articles.subtitle: The president appeared to say he has also driven on the wrong side of the road in a foreign country.
articles.author: Sara Boboltz
articles.content: President Donald Trump on Wednesday addressed the transatlantic controversy over a U.S. diplomatâs wife who allegedlyÂ fatally hit a British motorcyclist while driving on the wrong side of the road and who subsequently fled the U.K. Emphasizing that Anne Sacoolas, who is married to diplomat Jonathan Sacoolas, made a mistake, Trump said his administration is âgoing to speak to her ... so there can be some healing.â He did not provide further details. The family of motorcyclist Harry Dunn, 19, has been pleading with American leadership to waive the diplomatic immunity afforded to Anne Sacoolas due to her husbandâs position. Dunnâs mother, Charlotte Charles, told Sky News that her sonâs Aug. 27 death had left the family âutterly broken.â British Prime Minister Boris Johnson brought up the subject during a Wednesday call with Trump, fulfilling a pledge to do soÂ that he made earlier in the week. âA terrible accident occurred,â Trump told reporters gathered in the White House. âThe person driving the car â they know it was, and they have that on camera â a young man was killed on his motorcycle,â Trump continued, without elaborating on any apparent video evidence.Â âSounds like instantly killed,â he added. The president then seemingly admitted that he has also driven on the wrong side of the road in a foreign country. âThe woman was driving on the wrong side of the road â and that can happen!â Trump said. âThose are the opposite roads, it happens. I wonât say it ever happened to me, but it did. When you get used to one system and then youâre all of a sudden on the other system where youâre driving, it happens. You have to be careful.â Some British politicians have joined the chorus of British citizens demanding Sacoolas be brought back to the U.K. for police questioning. Trump ventured thatÂ âfrankly a lot of Americans feel the same wayâ about the situation and want to help the Dunn family heal. He did not address the status of Sacoolasâ diplomatic immunity. When British police spoke with Sacoolas after the collision, she told them she had no plans to leave the country, the authorities said. Police attempted to proceed with their investigation through the proper channels by applying for a diplomatic immunity waiver with the U.S. Embassy, which would allow them to question their suspect. The embassy, however, immediately relocated the Sacoolas family to the U.S. and denied the waiver request. Per the 1961 Vienna Convention, diplomats and their close family members are not subject to the foreign laws, and the U.S. State Department said it rarely waives the privilege in cases like this. Although there was some confusion this week over whether Sacoolas qualifies for diplomatic immunity, HuffPost confirmed her status with the U.K.âs Foreign Office. In a statement this week, the family said Dunnâs mother would like to meet Sacoolas and âgive her a hug.â âShe made a mistake that night,â the family said of Sacoolas. âWe all make mistakes.â

articles.title: Biden Campaign Skewers New York Times For Helping Trump Spread Debunked Conspiracy
articles.subtitle: The Times was criticized for prioritizing âsensationalismâ over âtruthâ in its spread of a âbaseless conspiracy theoryâ about Biden and Ukraine.
articles.author: Dominique Mosbergen
articles.content:
Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Bidenâs campaign has excoriated The New York Times for helping to spread what it described as a âbaseless conspiracy theoryâ advanced by President Donald Trump and his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, and for prioritizing sensationalism over âtruth and judiciousness.â âAre you truly blind to what you got wrong in 2016,â Bidenâs deputy campaign manager Kate Bedingfield wrote in a Wednesday letter addressed to the Timesâ executive editor Dean Baquet. âOr are you deliberately continuing policies that distort reality for the sake of controversy and the clicks that accompany it?â Hereâs the letter Biden deputy campaign manager @KBeds sent NYT editor Dean Baquet. âAre you truly blind to what you got wrong in 2016, or are you deliberately continuing policies that distort reality for the sake of controversy and the clicks...?â https://t.co/fCJ8Ii32Ds pic.twitter.com/DoVzSm5MXI The letter, obtained by Oliver Darcy, a senior media reporter at CNN, accused the Times of âactive participationâ in the âsmear campaignâ against Biden concocted by Trump and his allies. The Trump camp has been pushing a conspiracy theory for months about Bidenâs alleged corruption in his dealings with Ukraine. They claim Biden, during his tenure as vice president, withheld $1 billion in aid to Ukraine to compel the countryâs firing of a top prosecutor in order to protect his son, Hunter Biden. While itâs true that Biden, following a foreign policy position of the Obama administration, urged Ukrainian leaders to oust the prosecutor, Viktor Shokin, thereâs no evidence that he did it to help his son. Despite the facts, the Times still disseminated this conspiracy theory, Bedingfield said. She pointed specifically to aÂ widely criticizedÂ articleÂ published in the paper on May 1 that said in its headline that Biden was facing âconflict of interest questionsâ regarding Ukraine that were âbeing promoted by Trump and allies.â The story, written by reporter Ken Vogel and freelance writer Iuliia Mendel, described how Biden had appealed to Ukrainian leaders for Shokinâs ouster and how his son Hunter Biden had a âstake in the outcomeâ as he was on the board of Burisma, a Ukrainian energy company that had been in Shokinâs âsights.â Vogelâs and Mendelâs story included a line stating that âno evidence has surfaced that the former vice president intentionally tried to help his son by pressingâ for Shokinâs dismissal. However, as The Washington Postâs Erik Wemple pointed out at the time, that caveat comes 19 paragraphs into the story. âIn those first 19 paragraphs is a knot of details bound to be mangled by cable-news hosts and pundits in the coming months,â Wemple, the Postâs media critic, wrote in a column. In her letter to Baquet, Bedingfield pointed out that the Timesâ reporting had promptly been challenged by Bloomberg News, which said the investigation into Burisma had been âdormantâ at the time Biden was discussing Shokinâs future with Ukrainian leaders. Bedingfield also noted that Mendel, one of the co-authors of the Times story, joined the Ukrainian government as a spokesperson for the president of UkraineÂ just weeks after the article was published. Conservative author Peter Schweizer gets top billing in the New York Times today! pic.twitter.com/dqcNamHKuc Bidenâs campaign also took issue with an op-ed critical of the Bidens published in the Times on Wednesday by author Peter Schweizer, who was lambasted by Bedingfield as a âdiscredited, right-wing polemicist.â Schweizer âhas been one of the top people pushing the claim that Biden abused his office,â Darcy wrote in CNNâs Reliable Sources newsletter,Â adding that Schweizer â a senior contributor at right-wing site Breitbart â previously pushed the debunked conspiracy theory about Hillary Clinton benefiting from a âpay-for-playâ scheme involving uranium reserves. Government Accountability Institute President @PeterSchweizer revealed the Joe and Hunter Biden corruption scandals in Ukraine and China over a year and a half ago. The Establishment Media is finally catching upâand blocking and tackling for the Bidens. https://t.co/HIg2vxW4Vb In response to the Biden campaignâs letter, the Times defended its coverage of Biden and his son as âfair and accurate.â The TimesÂ âwill continue to cover Joe Biden with the same tough and fair standards we apply to every candidate in the race and weâre happy to sit down with Biden advisers anytime to discuss news coverage,â a spokesman told Darcy, adding that Schweizerâs op-ed had been published in the Opinion section of the newspaper, âwhere their mission is to invite intelligent discussion on a range of opinions and ideas.â Bedingfieldâs dressing-down of the Times follows two other letters sent this week by the Biden campaign to Facebook and Twitter. In those letters, Bidenâs team criticized the companies for allowing a Trump campaign video ad that pushes the Biden-Ukraine conspiracy to run on their platforms â and urged them to block the clip. Facebook has refused to remove the ad, citing a âfundamental belief in free expressionâ and ârespect for the democratic process.â Twitter has yet to respond publicly to the request. The dissemination of âobjectively false information to influence public opinion poisons the public discourse and chips away at our democracy,â Biden campaign spokesman TJ Ducklo said in a statement about the ad to CNN. âWhether it originates from the Kremlin or Trump Tower, these lies and conspiracy theories threaten to undermine the integrity of our elections in America,â Ducklo added. As NBC Newsâ Dylan Byers reported Wednesday, Facebook and Twitter arenât the only platforms that have continued to air Trumpâs Biden-Ukraine ad despite its unfounded content. CNN is the only media or tech company thatâs banned the ad from its airwaves, Byers said. NBC News, ABC News and YouTube are among the organizations that have not. These are the media/tech companies that have banned Trumpâs misleading Biden/Ukraine ad: 

â¢ CNN

These are the ones that have not banned it:

â¢ Fox News
â¢ MSNBC/NBC
â¢ ABC
â¢ CBS
â¢ Facebook
â¢ Google/YouTube
â¢ Twitter

articles.title: Trump On Abandoning Kurdish Forces: The Kurds Didnât Help Us In WWII
articles.subtitle: The president, on the same day Turkey moved forward on them in Syria, defended his decision to pull support for Kurdish fighters allied with the U.S.
articles.author: Carla Herreria
articles.content: President Donald TrumpÂ defended his controversial decision to yank support for U.S.-allied Kurdish fighters by noting that the Kurds didnât help the U.S. during World War II and the invasion of Normandy, known as D-day. âNow the Kurds are fighting for their land,â Trump told reporters at the White House on Wednesday. âAs somebody wrote in a very powerful article today, they didnât help us in the Second World War, they didnât help us with Normandy, as an example,â the president added. âTheyâre there to help us with their land, and thatâs a different thing.â While the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces didnât assist the U.S. in World War II, the Kurdish fighters have been a tremendous help to American troops fighting ISIS. Trump didnât provide the title of the article he referenced, though journalists noted that conservative opinion writer Kurt Schlichter recently published a column that noted the Kurdâs absence during D-day. Trump announced Sunday that the U.S. military would stand aside as Turkey moved forward with plans to invade northern Syria rather than defend the area alongside the Kurdish Syrian Democratic Forces. Defending his decision to abandon the Kurds, a major shift in U.S. policy, Trump suggested that the Kurds were only defending their land and said that the U.S. has spent âa tremendous amount of moneyâ to help Kurdish forces. Trump also told reporters:Â âWith all of that being said, we like the Kurds.â Turkey moved forward on the Kurdish forces in Syria by launching airstrikes and firing artillery on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. At least seven civilians and one Kurdish fighter were reportedly killed during the attacks. In response to the strikes, Trump denounced Turkeyâs offensive and said that the U.S. âdoes not endorse this attack and has made it clear to Turkey that this operation is a bad idea.â Earlier this week, he threatened to âtotally destroy and obliterateâ Turkeyâs economy if the country took any action that was âoff limits.â

articles.title: Cory Booker Unveils Plan To Pay College Athletes And âEnd Exploitation In Sportsâ
articles.subtitle: One of the proposals by the Democratic presidential candidate could shatter the NCAAâs âamateurâ model.
articles.author: Travis Waldron
articles.content: The fight to improve compensation and labor rights for college athletes has reached the 2020 Democratic presidential primary, thanks to the only candidate who was a major college athlete himself. New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, who played college football at Stanford University, on Thursday unveiled a sweeping plan that his campaign called an effort to âend exploitation in sports,â for college athletes, professional cheerleadersÂ and women in sports at the professional and amateur levels alike. As part of his plan, Booker pledged to back legislation in Congress that would allow all college athletes to earn money from their names, images and likenesses. That would provide a federal solution to an issue that has roiled major college sports for a decade, ever since former UCLA basketball player Ed OâBannon sued the NCAA for similar rights to profit from the money his name and image generated for his school and others. Such legislation would expand on a bill California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) signed into law last week. That law requires California schools to allow athletes to profit from their names, images and likenesses â through product endorsements and advertisements â starting in 2023, making it the first state to guarantee college athletes such rights. For Booker, though, the name, image and likeness issue could only mark the beginning of his efforts to reshape college sports. Part of his detailed plan calls for establishing a federal commission that would oversee sports in the U.S., a promise likely to set off alarm bells at the NCAAâs Indianapolis headquarters. As president, the document states, Booker âwould instruct federal antitrust agencies to use all of the enforcement tools at their disposal, including investigations and weighing in on key cases with [friend of the court] briefs, to crack down on practices that exploit and harm athletes in college and professional sports.â That pledge â if Booker were to follow through on it â could drastically alter the landscape of college sports, and send the NCAAâs anachronistic version of âamateurismâ the way of the Wing-TÂ formation used in old-fashioned football games. A number of lawyers, athletes and reformists have long seen antitrust law as the best legal avenue for winning wholesale change to the NCAAâs modelÂ and providing the compensation and labor rights for the athletes that lawmakers like Booker increasingly believe they deserve. Their basic argument â that the NCAA and its member schools have illegally conspired to artificially suppress the market value of college athletesâ labor â has found a receptive audience in federal courts, which have repeatedly found the NCAA in violation of antitrust laws. But judges have also stopped short of overhauling the NCAA, and have instead relied on piecemeal changes that leave amateurism altered but largely intact. Federal law enforcement agencies like the Department of Justice and FBI have also been loathe to use antitrust law against the NCAA, even when the opportunity has presented itself. The governmentâs recent landmark case against alleged corruption in college basketball, for instance, offered a prime opportunity for the federal agencies to go after the NCAA on antitrust grounds. Instead, they effectively took the side of the NCAA and its member universities and merely played whack-a-mole against the black market the NCAAâs own rules has created. Booker, though, seems willing to change that calculus. The DOJ has threatened the NCAA with antitrust scrutiny before, and the mere possibility that the feds might be serious has led to immediate rule changes to benefit athletes. No major antitrust cases face the NCAA at present, but labor lawyers who have argued the biggest previous cases on the amateurism issue havenât closed the door on future legal action. A president ready to back an antitrust fight, or even lead one, against the NCAA could hasten the sort of large-scale reform that many see as inevitable. That sort of reform, to the NCAA and other powerful governing bodies that oversee sports in the U.S., is central to Bookerâs broader plan to alter the world of athletics as president. Itâs a fight he sees as linked to the larger discussions of economic exploitation, gender discrimination and social justice causes that have been central to the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. âThe systemic problems in sports are issues of economic justice and fairness,â Booker said in a statement. As a football player at Stanford, Booker âwitnessed firsthand how college athletics uses free and cheap labor to extract value from young people â particularly Black men, who make up a disproportionate share of athletes in revenue-generating sports â to the tune of billions of dollars in profits,â his campaign said in releasing his plan. As president, Booker would establish the U.S. Commission on Integrity in Sports and have it address many of the most controversial and exploitative practices that have drawn attention and scrutiny in recent years. Issues tackled by the commission would include wage theft, unfair labor practices, health concerns, gender discrimination and the sexual abuse of athletes that has been widespread in U.S. Olympic programs. âFor too long, we have allowed exploitative practices in professional and college sports to fester â somehow treating sports as different from our broader economy,â he said. âBut sports at these levels is a multi-billion dollar business. Just as we shouldnât accept collusion, wage theft, and a massive gender pay gap in any other industry, we shouldnât accept them in sports.â A litany of government departments â including Labor, Education, Health and Human Services, and Justice â as well as numerous congressional committees are charged with overseeing youth, amateur and professional sports in the U.S. Bookerâs commission would seek to bring them together under one umbrella, allowing current and former athletes, policy experts and academics, lawmakers and government officials to jointly oversee and reform the NCAA, the U.S. Olympic Committee and other national governing bodies in the sports world. Bookerâs plan takes special aim at college sports, with compensation and labor rights at center stage. He would charge the commission with making recommendations for providing college athletes the right to unionize â as Northwestern University football players tried, unsuccessfully, to do in 2015 â and devising a compensation model for the athletes. But Booker also wants the commission to address other key issues college athletes have raised, in areas where studies have shown the NCAAâs policies inadequate. His plan would work to improve access to quality health care for athletes, particularly those suffering concussions and brain injuries; enhance their opportunities to cover medical costs stemming from sports-related injuries; give athletes more transfer rights between schools, and prod the NCAA to improve their educational outcomes. The plan calls on the NCAA and member schools to annually report data ârelating to athletesâ educational outcomes, health and safety, freedom to choose their desired course of study, and other key measures of athletesâ well beingâ to the Department of Education. Along with its focus on college athletics, Bookerâs plan promises action on other topics that have emerged in womenâs sports in recent years, including the U.S. womenâs national soccer teamâs equal pay battle against the U.S. Soccer Federation, the wage and hour complaints cheerleaders have filed against NFL and NBA teams, and the sexual abuse scandals that have rocked USA Gymnastics and the U.S. Olympic Committee. Bookerâs plan also would strengthen compliance requirements for Title IX, the 1972 gender equity law, to boost opportunities for women in scholastic sports. Booker also said his support for legislation to provide federal employment protections to LGBTQ+ people would bolster efforts to prevent discrimination against them in sports. And he would crack down on potentially collusive anti-worker efforts to suppress protests from Black NFL players like former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick.

articles.title: âThe Whistleblower Is Not The Storyâ: Lawyers Defend Client As Trump Rages About âScamâ
articles.subtitle: The anonymous person has ânever worked for or advisedâ a political campaign, the attorneys said.
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.content: Attorneys for the whistleblower who first filed the complaint about President Donald Trumpâs July call with the leader of Ukraine defended their client in a statement Wednesday night amid ongoing efforts by the White House to undermine the personâs reputation. In the statement, attorneys Andrew Bakaj and Mark Zaid wrote that the whistleblower, who remains anonymous, has ânever worked for or advised a political candidate, campaign, or partyâ and said the personâs entire government career has been spent in âapolitical, civil servant positions.â Both the White House and Republican lawmakers have latched on to a Aug. 26 letter written by the intelligence community inspector general, Michael Atkinson, in which he wrote that the whistleblower had âsome indicia of an arguable political bias â¦ in favor of a rival political candidate.â CNN later reported that that âindiciaâ was that the whistleblower is a registered Democrat, but that news has only inflamed Trumpâs efforts to attack the person. âIn light of the ongoing efforts to mischaracterize whistleblower #1âs alleged âbiasâ in order to detract from the substance of the complaint, we will attempt to clarify some facts,â the pair wrote, later noting that: âThe whistleblower is not the story. To date, virtually every substantive allegation has been confirmed by other sources.â The president has moved to cast the complaint and the House impeachment inquiry as a âcoupâ and another âwitch huntâ meant to overturn the 2016 election. He furthered those claims Wednesday on Twitter, writing that the whistleblower had a âconflict of interestâ and questioning why âthis scamâ was moving forward. âI think it is important to find out who that person is,â Trump said Wednesday, according toÂ Politico. âI do not know why a person that defrauds at the American public should be protected.â Atkinson himself, however, vetted the whistleblowerâs complaint and determined that the claims â centered on Trumpâs July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky â were âurgent and credible.â A reconstruction of the call released by the White House confirmed that there were several instances of Trump pressuring Zelensky to investigate his top political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden, and his son Hunter Biden. Bakaj and Zaid wrote Wednesday that the whistleblower had come into contact with presidential candidates but noted that their client worked in the executive branch and had met individuals âfrom both parties in their roles as elected officials â not as candidates.â âThe whistleblower voluntarily provided relevant career information to the [inspector general] in order to facilitate an assessment of the credibility of the complaint,â they wrote. The Washington Post reported this week that House Democrats are trying to determine what steps they can take to protect the whistleblowerâs identity, including masking the personâs voice and appearance from Republican colleagues when the person testifies. A person familiar with those discussions told the Post that some Democrats are worried Trumpâs allies in Congress could leak the whistleblowerâs identity.

articles.title: On A Train Wreck Day For Trump, âWomen For Trumpâ Tries To Spin An Alternative World
articles.subtitle: Second Lady Karen Pence came to the Twin Cities ahead of Trump with a softer sell than the president is likely to use at a Thursday rally.
articles.author: S.V. Date
articles.content: ST. PAUL, Minn. â President Donald Trumpâs Wednesday featured explanations for his failure to protect Kurdish allies in Syria, new questions about an impeachment inquiry centered on his dealings with Ukraine and, to cap it off, fresh accusations of sexual misconduct. A thousand miles west of Washington, though, none of that seemed to matter. âThe president has empowered women like no other,â said Second Lady Karen Pence, explaining that she understood a lot of women might be âon the fenceâ about voting for Trump next year. âHe cares about meeting them where it counts: in their pocketbooksâ¦. Look at the job rate for women. You have to vote for Donald Trump.â The wife of Vice President Mike Pence was headlining a âWomen for Trumpâ discussion with Trumpâs daughter-in-law Lara Trump and Trump campaign spokeswoman Kayleigh McEnany on the eve of the presidentâs planned Minneapolis rally Thursday. Trump in his 2Â½ years in office has been bleeding support from women voters â particularly suburban, college-educated women who have historically favored Republicans. Wednesdayâs event was among a series his campaign is planning to try to reverse the trend. Nancy Vergin, 66, was among the 250 or so women who came out to hear the trio at a meeting room at a train and bus depot in St. Paul. âOur president has been exemplary,â she said, sporting a Trump T-shirt, Trump pendant, Trump earrings and a red Trump safety vest adorned with both the âMake America Great Againâ slogan of 2016 and the âKeep America Greatâ one for 2020. âI canât believe how much he has accomplished.â Trumpâs rally Thursday will be his first since the House began its impeachment inquiry after the Ukraine scandal broke, which revealed that the president had asked a foreign leader to investigate his top political rival. And it comes as a new book reportedly adds dozens of names to the list of women who have accused Trump of sexual misconduct. His campaign has been looking for states it might win in 2020 that failed to swing his way in 2016, particularly in the event Trump loses Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin, three states that gave him the presidency with a combined 77,744-vote margin. Minnesota, New Hampshire and Nevada top that list, although his campaign officials claim that New Mexico is also a possibility. Karen Pence told the St. Paul audience that they should remind friends and neighbors who were uneasy about supporting Trump because of his language and behavior that he treats his daughter Ivanka well. âThe respect he has for his daughter, itâs amazing,â Pence said. And Lara Trump said their best argument was probably what the presidentâs tenure has already done for women. âIf you think that things are going better for you than they were, thatâs all you need to know.â A dozen miles away on the opposite side of the Mississippi River, Lindsay Nelson is precisely the sort of woman the Trump campaign is hoping to win over. The 30-year-old IT consultant was walking past the Target Center arena after work Wednesday and not planning to attend Trumpâs rally there Thursday. She was, however, planning to vote for Trump after not having voted at all in 2016. âI think the changes in the economy have been really good,â she said, adding that sheâs not bothered by Trumpâs controversial words and deeds. âI think itâs just a game. Itâs just a gimmick.â Nelson conceded, though, that she may be an anomaly, at least in her social circle. âMost of the women I know donât think the way I do.â

articles.title: Christians Plan National Day Of Prayer To Support Trump Impeachment Inquiry
articles.subtitle: Progressive Christians across the country are asking Congress to shed the âlight of truthâ on Trump.
articles.author: Carol Kuruvilla
articles.content: Progressive Christian leaders are calling for a national day of prayer this Sunday to show support for a fair and openÂ impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine. Over 100 leaders from evangelical, mainline Protestant, and historically black congregations, among others, have signed a letterÂ pledging to pray on Oct. 13 that the impeachment probe led by House Democrats shines âthe light of truthâ on the president. âJesus taught us that only the truth will set us free,â Rev. Adam Russell Taylor, executive director of the Christian organization Sojourners, told HuffPost. âThe deflection, lies, and conspiracy theories promulgated by the Administration and the Presidentâs most loyal Congressional allies represent an assault on truth.â âThis perilous moment calls for bold action from both religious and civic leaders who must put country and the common good over partisanship, the pursuit of truth over lies, and morality and accountability over fear and short-term political calculation,â Taylor said. The impeachment inquiry is looking into allegations, backed up by Trumpâs own words, that the president sought political favors from Ukraine to help his 2020 reelection campaign. Trump has called the congressional investigation a âwitch huntâ and the White House announcedÂ Tuesday that it will not cooperate with the probe. The presidentâs close evangelical advisers have issued dire warnings about the Houseâs efforts. Texas pastor Robert Jeffress suggested that America will face a âCivil War-like fractureâ if Trump is ultimately removed from office, while evangelist Franklin Graham predicted that âour country could begin to unravel.â But the Christians who signed up to support this Sundayâs day of prayer believe that an impeachment inquiry is a moral necessity, according to a letter released Tuesday by Red Letter Christians, a religious movement that is helping to organize the event. The idea for a national day of prayer arose organically last week at a Red Letter Revival event in Goldsboro, North Carolina, according toÂ Rev. Peter G. Heltzel, a professor at New York Theological Seminary who helped put together the letter.Â Heltzel said that attendees at the social justice-focused event, which was planned as a counter-rally to the Greenville stop on Grahamâs âDecision Americaâ tour, were appalled by the âhypocrisy of the religious rightâ on the impeachment issue. Leaders like Graham are mistakenly leading American evangelicals to believe that their loyalty to the president comes before their loyalty to Christ, said Heltzel, who identifies as evangelical. But Christians are called to âseek first the kingdom of God and Godâs justice,â he said. âIn this current moment, with the impeachment inquiry, Jesusâs claim that he is the way, the truth and the life is also a call to prophetic holiness, in the sense of both speaking truth to power and demanding that authorities are truthful in their words and actions as they govern,â Heltzel said. Members of Congress invited to attend local congregations for National Day of Prayer for Impeachment Inquiry. #PrayForTruth pic.twitter.com/ZC6kgpxdNy On Sunday, organizers of the national day of prayer are asking Christian leaders to read the letter out loud to their congregations. Participants are also inviting their local congressional representatives to attend services so that the congregation can pray for them. The letter insists that âthis is not a matter of partisanship, but of deepest principle.â Nonetheless, many of the signatories are heavyweights in the progressive Christian community â including Rev. Dr. William Barber II and Rev. Liz Theoharis, leaders of the Poor Peopleâs Campaign; Rev. Jim Wallis of Sojourners;Â Bishop Gene Robinson, the first openly gay Episcopal bishop;Â Rev. Traci Blackmon of the United Church of Christ; and Lisa Sharon Harper, writer and activist at FreedomRoad.us. Sister Simone Campbell, a Catholic social justice activist known for her work with Nuns on the Bus, told HuffPost that she signed the letter because the Trump administrationâs âundermining of truth and civilityâ shocks her conscience. She said that the presidentâs âobsession with winningâ makes her doubt that he will ever focus on the needs of the American people. âThis behavior on the part of the administration with regards to Ukraine evidences their lack of concern for the people of this nation. They only care about winning an election,â Campbell said. âWinning is about power, not the common good.â Iâm joining faith leaders from across the nation today to pray for House leadership & the impeachment inquiry. Please invite your Congressional rep to church this Sunday & pray for them. #PrayForTruth https://t.co/Wv9xFj3sd4 Since winning aboutÂ 81% of the white evangelical vote in 2016, Trump has depended on white evangelical leaders to defend his more controversial policies and rhetoric. Roughly 7 in 10 white evangelicals told the Pew Research CenterÂ in March that they approve of the way Trump is handling his job. Part of the impetus behind the letter was to counter the idea that all evangelicals are unquestionably loyal to the president.Â Rev. Laura Sumner Truax, senior pastor of Chicagoâs LaSalle Street Church and a self-described âprogressive evangelical,â said sheâs weary of Trumpâs âbraggingâ about evangelicalsâ support and upset that people like Graham and Jeffress are seen as spokespeople for the group. Truax said she signed the letter because she wanted to show that thereâs a broad network of people of faith whose religious beliefs have led them to a very different opinion of the president. âIf weâre not willing to hold him accountable to the oath of office he swore in 2017, our silence comes at the expense of the most vulnerable, of those whose truth will no longer be honored,â she said. The pastor said that her congregation plans to read the letter, pray for Trump and pray that their representatives will seek the truth âwherever it may lead.â

articles.title: Girls Confront Canadian PM Justin Trudeau Over His Blackface Scandals
articles.subtitle: âBut did you paint your nose and your hands brown?â they asked the Liberal leader.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Twin sisters gave Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau a grilling over his recent blackface scandals. The young girls asked Trudeau âwhy did you paint your face brown?â in the latest episode of TV personality Jessi Cruickshankâs Facebook Watch show âNew Mom, Who Dis?â Trudeau replied to what appeared to be a question he expected: Oh, um, it was something I shouldnât have done because it hurt people. Itâs not something that you should do, and that is something that I learned. I didnât know it back then, but I know it now, and Iâm sorry I hurt people. âBut did you paint your nose and your hands brown?â the girls responded. Trudeau said: U-hum, yeah. And it was the wrong thing to do, and I had a good conversation with my kids around taking responsibility for mistakes and making sure that weâre always sticking up for each other and not teasing each other, and being respectful towards each other. âSorry that I hurt you as well,â Trudeau added. âIâm sorry that I hurt kids who get to face teasing and discrimination because of the color of their skin. Thatâs just not right in this country, or anywhere around the world. We all have to work together to make sure it doesnât happen, okay?â Check out the clip here: The Liberal leader, currently running for reelection, was engulfed in controversy last month with the resurfacing of old video and photographs of him wearing offensive makeup on various occasions. âIt is something absolutely unacceptable to do,â he said, in one of the multiple apologiesÂ he issued. âIt is something that people who live with the kind of discrimination that far too many people do â because of the color of their skin or their history, or their origins, or their language or their religion â face on a regular basis.Â And I didnât see that from the layers of privilege that I have and for that Iâm deeply sorry.â

articles.title: Pete Buttigieg Unveils Sweeping LGBTQ Policy To Tackle Inequality
articles.subtitle: The Democratic presidential contender aims to revamp health care, tackle HIV/AIDS and overturn the transgender military ban.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: Democratic White House hopefulÂ Pete Buttigieg on Thursday unveiled a sweeping plan to overturn institutionalized discrimination against the LGBTQ community through legal protections, affordable health care and ending President Donald Trumpâs transgender military ban. Buttigiegâs policy rollout, titled âBecoming Whole: A New Era for LGBTQ+ Americans,â proposes nearly two dozen initiatives aimed at tackling inequality of marginalized groups from the classroom to the workplace. Its prime objectives include securing passage of the Equality Act, which would remedy the gap in federal civil rights laws by explicitly banning discrimination based on gender and sexual orientation. The bill, passed by the House in May but stalled in the Senate, seeks to balance the scales for the LGBTQ+ community in all parts of public and commercial life, including housing, employment, credit, education and government-funded programs. The Trump administrationÂ opposes it. The plan by Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Indiana, would add a third, non-binary gender option, âX,â to the U.S. passport program, following a wave of states that have updated theirÂ driverâs licenses to include the new category. He also vows to rescind the Trump administrationâs restriction on transgender military service, which took effect in April. The policy bars any openly transgender or transitioning person from enlisting, and discharges those already in the military who openly identify themselves as such. According to a Public Religion Research Institute poll conducted the month the rule was implemented, 63% of Americans supported transgender military service. Those agreeing included 47% of the Republicans surveyed â a 10% uptick from the organizationâs findings in August 2017. On health care, theÂ Medicare for All Who Want It plan Buttigieg previously unveiled would provide coverage of gender-affirming treatments and surgical procedures, which currently may not be covered depending on the type of insurer and the state in which a patient is enrolled in coverage. Though the Affordable Care Act outlaws health insurance discrimination based on gender identity, legal fights have ensued at state and local levels over the matter. Included in Buttigiegâs health care proposal would be coverage of pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP, the drug that protects high-risk individuals from contracting HIV. Data released earlier this year by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that in 2017, only 35% of gay and bisexual men at risk of HIV were using PrEP, a number the agency said was âtoo low.âÂ Overall, according to the federal government, âof the estimated 1 million Americans at substantial risk for HIV and who could benefit from PrEP, less than 1 in 4 are actually using this medication.â A major complication is that PrEP, branded as Truvada and manufactured by Gilead Sciences, can cost up to $2,000 per month. The federal government has attempted to obtain patents for the drug, spurring a challenge in AugustÂ by Gilead. Buttigiegâs Becoming Whole initiative sets a goal of endingÂ HIV/AIDS by 2030. While that goal has also been adopted by Trump, in 2018, the president fired all members of his HIV/AIDS councilÂ who hadnât already resigned in protest of his health policies, virtually shuttering operations for more than a year. New staffers were not announced until March. Further signaling a lack of attention to the epidemic, the White House Office of National AIDS Policy has been inactive, having had no director since Amy Lansky stepped down in 2017. Buttigieg pledged to revitalize the office as president. The release of his expansive list of initiatives comes as he prepares to join eight other Democratic presidential candidates Thursday night for CNNâs LGBTQ town hall in Los Angeles; others slated to appear include former Vice President Joe Biden and Sens. Elizabeth WarrenÂ of Massachusetts and Kamala HarrisÂ of California. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) was scheduled to participate in the forum, but canceled after suffering a heart attack last week. He is expected to return to the campaign trail soon.

articles.title: Susan Rice Slams Donald Trump Over Syria: âBlood Is Going To Beâ On His Hands
articles.subtitle: âWeâve crossed a rubicon here [...] that I think is going to haunt us for decades to come,â said the Obama-era national security adviser.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Former national security adviser Susan Rice on Wednesday night slammed President Donald TrumpÂ for withdrawing support for the Kurds in northern Syria and essentially allowing Turkey to attack Americaâs battlefield allies. âAs somebody wrote in a very powerful article today, they didnât help us in the second World War, they didnât help us with Normandy for example,â Trump said earlier in the day of the Kurds, who fought alongside American troops against the so-called Islamic State. âTheyâre there to help us with their land, and thatâs a different thing.â Rice, who served under former President Barack Obama, responded with a blistering question on CNNâs âAnderson Cooper 360Â°.â âWhat is he smoking?â she asked host Cooper. âI mean, the Kurds were the pointy end of the spear who fought ISIS on our behalf. They bled and died because they believed in the partnership they had established with the United States and we just threw them under the bus in 24 hours. Itâs appalling, itâs disgraceful,â Rice said. âAnd then today, when the Turks quite predictably are bombing the bejeezus out of Syria and Trump allegedly orders the U.S. military not to come to their defense, not to protect them. Weâve crossed a Rubicon here of the trail that I think is going to haunt us for decades to come,â she continued. âWe are handing over our Kurdish allies to slaughter, and that blood is going to be on Donald Trumpâs hands.â Rice earlier accused Trump of making U.S. foreign policy all about himself. âItâs appalling. It is so much worse than I imagined. Every day a lie, a disparagement and a trashing of the institutions and the norms that we all believe have held us together,â she said. âAnd what is so extraordinary is itâs all about him. We talk about foreign policy, and he said his doctrine is America first, but I think weâre seeing it is really me first. And thatâs how he is governing. Everything is about him.â Check out the full interview here:

articles.title: Stephen Moore Goes Full Orwell In Head-Spinning Defense Of Trumpâs Latest Lies
articles.subtitle: Stephen Moore says Trump might say things that are untrue, but that doesnât make them lies.
articles.author: Ed Mazza
articles.content:
A former adviser toÂ Donald Trump chastised the president for saying âthings that are false,â but refused to call them lies. In an interview with Al Jazeeraâs âHead to Head,â Stephen Moore, a Trump campaign adviser in 2016 who later worked with the White House,Â admitted that the president doesnât always tell the truth. âI think when Trump says things that are false, that does undermine his presidential authority and I wish he wouldnât do it,â Moore said. âHe should stop saying things that are untrue.â Yet Moore, who was tapped by Trump for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board earlier this year but withdrew his nomination after fierce bipartisan opposition, wouldnât use the âLâ word. âSo heâs a liar?âÂ host Mehdi Hasan asked. âIâm never going to say that,â Moore said.Â He called Trump an âexaggeratorâ instead. Hasan offered some quick examples of Trump lies that werenât exaggerations. Moore just threw up a hand and said: âI donât know about that.â Although The Washington Post has documented more than 12,000 false or misleading claims by Trump since he took office, many of the people working with the president wonât acknowledge a single one of them. Kayleigh McEnany, press secretary for Trumpâs 2020 reelection campaign, told CNN over the summer that Trump never lies.Â Larry Kudlow, director of the National Economic Council, insisted in July that âthe president doesnât make things up.â Even Fox Business host Stuart Varney said thatÂ Trump has never told a lie to the American people. Later in the same segment, Moore claimed that Trump âprobablyâ has a 180 IQ and boasted of the presidentâs âbreadth of knowledge about world affairs.â âI want a guy who says it like it is,â Moore said. âAnd sometimes, does he stick his foot in his mouth? Yeah.â But Hasan wouldnât let the IQ comment go. âThis is a man who thinks wind turbines cause cancer,âÂ Hasan said. âThinks you can stop a hurricane with a nuclear weapon. Thinks you need ID to buy a box of cereal. Thinks England and Great Britain are the same thing.â âI donât know,â Moore said. âIâm not here to defend everything Donald Trump says.â See more of their exchange below: Stephen Moore, Trump adviser: âHe should stop saying things that are untrue.â
Me: âBut he does say things that are untrue.â
Moore: âHe does.â
Me: âSo heâs a liar?â
Moore: [laughs] Iâm never gonna say that.â

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Releases Plan For LGBTQ Rights And Equality
articles.subtitle: The 2020 candidate said she would reverse Trumpâs transgender military ban on day one of a Warren administration.
articles.author: Antonia Blumberg
articles.content: Democratic presidential candidateÂ Elizabeth WarrenÂ released a wide-ranging LGBTQ policy plan on Thursday morning, vowing to enact measures and funnel resources toward fighting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender expression. In a 12-page memo, the Massachusetts senator outlined dozens of ways a Warren administration would âfight for LGBTQ+ equality in solidarity with the leaders and organizers who have been at the helm from the very beginning.â The measures include things like working to pass the Equality Act, which would extend civil rights protections to LGBTQ people, and amending the Religious Freedom Restoration Act to ensure it canât be used to discriminate against LGBTQ people. Warren said she would reverse the Trump administration policy that bans transgender people from serving in the military, as well as appoint a special envoy to the State Department to oversee LGBTQ human rights. âI have opposed the Trump Administrationâs shameful ban on transgender service members from the start, and I will reverse it on Day One,â the senator wrote in her plan. Warrenâs plan highlights the recent murders of transgender people in the U.S., most of them trans women of color, and states âit is time for a president to say their names and honor their memory.â The senator included a number of measures aimed at reducing violence against trans women of color, including reversing the Department of Housing and Urban Developmentâs proposal to allow homeless shelters to deny transgender people access to their services. Warren released the plan ahead of her participation in a Thursday town hall hosted by CNN and the Human Rights Campaign that will focus on issues affecting the LGBTQ community. The senator is also expected to join the Las Vegas Pride Parade on Friday. Thursdayâs plan comes on the heels of a sweeping climate justice proposal Warren released on Wednesday and which reads as an ambitious blueprint of how to implement a Green New Deal. Like her LGBTQ plan, Warrenâs climate proposal looks at addressing the intersections of multiple issues â in this case how race and privilege play into conversations about the environment. âJustice cannot be a secondary concern â it must be at the center of our response to climate change,â Warren wrote in the memo.

articles.title: White House Aides Avoid Media Amid Impeachment Storm
articles.subtitle: Itâs a well-worn strategy: Senior officials conveniently manage to be elsewhere when major controversies engulf the White House.
articles.content: WASHINGTON (AP) â Theyâve skipped the high-profile Sunday TV shows and avoided driveway chat sessions with reporters. Few who are typically eager to defend the president have appeared at all on television this month. White House officials close to President Donald Trump are pulling off a disappearing act, remaining largely absent from public view â in the middle of the storm over impeachment. âWe invited the White House on to answer questions on the show this morning,â CNNâs Jake Tapper explained to his viewers on Sundayâs âState of the Union.â â³They did not offer a guest.â Itâs a well-worn strategy in the Trump White House: Senior officials conveniently manage to be elsewhere when major controversies engulf the building. The frequent absences of Jared Kushner, the Republican presidentâs son-in-law and senior adviser, and presidential daughter Ivanka Trump during moments of consequence have long been a running joke among their detractors. Their detours included a trip to Florida during the partial government shutdown. Plenty of others have jumped town during tense moments. As Trump struggled with mounting Republican defections over his decision to declare a national emergency to pay for the stalled border wall, acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney wasnât at the Capitol cajoling his former colleagues or in the West Wing making calls. Instead, he was in Las Vegas for an annual friends and family getaway. More recently, embattled national security adviser John Bolton scheduled a trip to Mongolia while Trump became the first sitting U.S. president to set foot in North Korea, a gesture that didnât sit well with Bolton, who would leave the administration a few months later. Indeed, knowing âwhen to be out of townâ was one of the top nuggets of advice that Kevin Hassett, the presidentâs former top economic adviser, said heâd received from a predecessor and had to offer his successor. The White House did not respond to questions about the tactic Wednesday. But even when theyâre in Washington, many of the White Houseâs most visible officials have been staying out of public view, letting the presidentâs indignant Twitter feed and his frequent commentary drive the public conversation. That includes White House spokesman Hogan Gidley, a frequent guest on Fox News shows and the gaggles with reporters that often follow on the White House driveway. White House counselor Kellyanne Conway, an aggressive defender of the president, has not made an appearance on the driveway since a highly contentious Sept. 27 gaggle in which she berated reporters and dismissed a question about whether the White House was organizing an impeachment war room. âIâm the only person out here taking your questions,â Conway noted then. She did, however, appear at an event with first lady Melania Trump, speaking with teens and young adults about their experiences with electronic cigarettes and vaping. Appearances have come instead from lower-profile staffers, including the vice presidentâs chief of staff, Marc Short; the acting director of Office of Management and Budget, Russell Vought; and economic adviser Larry Kudlow, who tried to stay out of the controversy. Heâs said repeatedly that questions about Ukraine and the presidentâs efforts to dig up damaging information about former Vice President Joe Biden are way out of his lane. Adding to the vacuum is the continued lack of White House briefings. White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham has yet to hold one. âItâs surprising that theyâre not using the many levers on the most powerful communications platform in the world, which is the White House,â said Joe Lockhart, who served as press secretary during the impeachment of President Bill Clinton . He said that the White House is losing out on effective platforms to try to drive its message. âNobody is vouching for him or validating him and filling in the blanks,â Lockhart said of Trump. Many aides to the president have grown reluctant to speak out on Trumpâs behalf for fear the president will then contradict them. Instead, they allow the president to set the dayâs message on his Twitter feed and vigorously defend himself. But one of the reasons Clintonâs impeachment strategy was effective, Lockhart said, was that the president almost never talked about the impeachment drama. He relied on his lawyers, his communications staff and outside allies to make the case for him. âThe president shouldnât be his own defender,â Lockhart said. âThe president should be focused on doing the job of the president.â But unlike Clinton, Trump has another tool at his disposal: a massive and well-funded campaign operation that has vigorously defended the president on Twitter and cut a series of ads that paint the impeachment inquiry as nothing more than a Democratic âcoupâ aimed at overturning the results of the 2016 election. Another ad released Wednesday focuses on allegations against Biden and his son Hunter, which the president and his allies have been pursuing despite lacking evidence of any wrongdoing. Tim Murtaugh, the Trump campaignâs communications director, said the campaign team speaks with its counterparts at the White House every day and work in tandem. âAt all times we take our lead from the White House,â he said. âThe president is our boss, and we are an extension of him. We make all of our decisions accordingly.â ___ Follow Colvin on Twitter at https://twitter.com/colvinj

articles.title: George Conway Cracks Thereâs Really Only 1 Way The GOP Will Turn On Donald Trump
articles.subtitle: Kellyanne Conwayâs husband also tore into the people who remain silent on Trump in a wide-ranging new interview.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: George Conway thinks he knows how to get Republicans in the Senate to finally turn on President Donald Trump and agree with impeachment. And it involves a secret ballot in the Senate and a trap door. âI think if they could push a button secretly and just sort of like, it would be a trap door and heâd just fall in and you wouldnât hear from again, absolutely,â the attorney joked in a new episode of former U.S. Attorney Preet Bhararaâs podcast âStay Tuned With Preet.â âFrom what Iâve heard, people would just wish heâd go away,â added Conway, who despite being married to White House counselor Kellyanne Conway, has become a frequent and harsh critic of the Trump administration. In the wide-ranging interview, Conway predicted the likelihood of Trumpâs impeachment is âpretty much 100%,â gave Attorney General Bill Barr an âFâ grade and lamented the GOPâs lacking of a voice of reason. Conway also took aim at the people who continue to serve and support Trump, remaining silent in face of things they disagree with. âItâs one of the mysteries to me about this era,â Conway said. âNow, I get there are people who are not in a position to say or do anything there because theyâre junior or theyâre not in a financial position of comfort. Theyâre vulnerable in some fashion. But there are people whose livelihoods donât depend on this. âThere are people, for example, who are no longer running for reelection in Congress. There are people who are independently wealthy. There are people who can just go back to the private sector,â he continued. âInstead of making all these political calculations, although I think the calculation they should be making is heâs going to be gone at some point and thereâs going to be a reckoning and history isnât going to be kind to people who said nothing or stood up for Trump,â he added. Check out the full interview below. Conwayâs comments on the trap door begin at the 50-minute mark.

articles.title: Susan Collins Is Fundraising Off Her Brett Kavanaugh Vote: âFar Leftâ Coming After Me
articles.subtitle: The GOP senatorâs vote to confirm a man accused of sexual assault to the Supreme Court sparked outrage. Now sheâs using it to raise money.
articles.author: Hayley Miller
articles.content: Sen. Susan Collinsâ vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, despite the allegations of sexual misconduct against him and his anti-abortion views, enraged Democrats and womenâs rights advocates nationwide. A year later, the Maine Republican is boasting about her key role in securing his spot on the bench to raise money for her 2020 reelection campaign. âSupreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh is yet again under attack by the Far Left,â stated a Collins fundraising email sent Sept. 19. âThe Far Left is so determined to further their political agenda, they wonât hesitate to ruin someoneâs life in the process.â âWhile Justice Kavanaugh is in their crosshairs, they are also targeting me. Thatâs why I need your help right now,â the email continued with a link to donate to her campaign, which she has not yet formally announced. Kavanaugh was sworn in as Supreme Court justice on Oct. 6, 2018, just hours after the Senate voted to confirm him 50-48. Less than two weeks earlier, Christine Blasey Ford testified before Congress that Kavanaugh, when they were both teenagers in high school, sexually assaulted her at a party. She said he locked her in a room, climbed on top of her and attempted to remove her clothes as his friend watched. Kavanaugh and the friend laughed as he pinned her down and covered her mouth so she couldnât scream, Ford testified. She was able to escape but the alleged assault caused emotional stress for years, Ford said.Â Another woman, Deborah Ramirez, accused Kavanaugh of thrusting his penis in her face during a college party. Kavanaugh has vehemently denied any allegations of sexual misconduct. Collins was generally considered one of three swing votes in Kavanaughâs confirmation.Â The others were Sens. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska), who voted âpresent,â and Joe Manchin (W.Va.), the only Democrat to vote in favor of Kavanaugh. After several days of hemming and hawing, and hundreds of sexual assault survivors and their allies converging on Capitol Hill to protest Kavanaugh, Collins announced on the Senate floor that she would cast her vote in his favor, thereby cementing his seat on the Supreme Court. Her vote drew instant outrage from womenâs rights activists and Maine Democrats who had previously supported Collins, a self-proclaimed pro-choice moderate they believed would break from the rest of the Republican Party on Kavanaughâs confirmation. Within weeks, a crowdfunding campaign raised millions of dollars toward whoever would nab the Democratic nomination in the race to unseat Collins in 2020. Several Democrats have announced campaigns, including Maine House Speaker Sara Gideon; attorney Bre Kidman; and Betsy Sweet, a womenâs rights lobbyist and a former Maine gubernatorial candidate. Two independents â Tiffany Bond and Danielle VanHelsing â have also launched bids. Despite the backlash, Collinsâ pivotal vote also proved lucrative to her own campaign. She raised more money in the months following Kavanaughâs confirmation than sheâs raised in any other quarter her entire career, though the vast majority of the contributions came from out-of-state donors. In another recent fundraising email, Collinsâ campaign lamented the culture created by the âradical leftâ that made Republican students âafraidâ to express their views on college campuses. âThis fear comes from the same type of bullying the left sent my way after my vote for Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh,â according to the email sent Sept. 16. âPlease donate today to help me fight back against the radical left.â A direct mailer, also sent by Collinsâ campaign in September, dubbed her vote to confirm Kavanaugh as âthe right thing to doâ and warned that âfar left extremistsâ were out for revenge. âCasting that vote unleashed a hornetsâ nest of stinging attack ads and more are on the way,â the campaign wrote. âIâm asking for your help ... I really need it now.â To compliment her campaign mailers,Â Collins attended a lavish fundraiser on Oct. 2 in Orange County, California, that hailed her as the âhero of the Kavanaugh confirmation.â Asked about the fundraising technique, a spokesman for her campaign told HuffPost in an email: âOpponents raised $2 million to try and buy Senator Collinsâ vote, and they have since raised at least $2 million more off âthe Kavanaugh vote,â so this line of criticism doesnât even pass the straight face test.â Her Democratic challengers are also shining a light on her Kavanaugh vote, hoping to mobilize the Mainers still feeling betrayed by Collins a year later. âSusan Collins still says she doesnât regret her vote to confirm him,â stated a fundraising email for Gideonâs campaign sent Oct. 6. âShe even said she was âsadâ that her support for Kavanaugh cost her votes.â âWell weâre sad too,â the email continued. âSad that we have a Senator who puts Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump before Mainers.Â But we have a chance to change that.â This story has been updated with comment from Collinsâ campaign.

articles.title: Giuliani Associates Who Targeted Biden Arrested On Campaign Finance Charges
articles.subtitle: Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, who helped Giuliani investigate Joe Biden, donated to Donald Trumpâs presidential campaign.
articles.content: Two associates of President Donald Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giuliani are in law enforcement custody and have been indicted on federal campaign finance charges for allegedly making fraudulent straw donations and funneling foreign money to support Trump and Republican Party candidates. Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, who helped Giuliani investigate allegations against Joe Biden and his son Hunter, are accused of illegally funding American political campaigns.Â The Wall Street Journal, which firstÂ reportedÂ the arrests, said that Parnas and Fruman had donated to Trumpâs campaign as well as a pro-Trump super PAC. The charges emerged from the Southern District of New York, but a Justice Department spokesman said the duo would appear at the federal courthouse in Alexandria, Virginia, at 2 p.m., before U.S. Magistrate Judge Michael S. Nachmanoff. U.S. Attorney Geoff Berman said at a press conference Thursday that Parnas and Fruman both had one-way international tickets when they were arrested, and that the investigation is ongoing.Â Giuliani had lunch with the duo at the Trump International Hotel just hours before their scheduled flight, according to the Journal. Separately on Thursday, House Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry into TrumpÂ issued subpoenas to Parnas and FrumanÂ demanding documents related to their work with Giuliani. Before the two were arrested, House investigators had requested that Parnas appear for a deposition Thursday, and Fruman for one on Friday, but their counsel said Tuesday that they would decline. The indictment alleges that Parnas and Fruman committed to raising more than $20,000 for a sitting U.S. congressman, and that Parnas âmet with Congressman-1 and sought Congressman-1â²s assistance in causing the U.S. Government to remove or recall the then-U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine.â âCongressman-1â is former Rep. Pete Sessions (R-Texas), who sent a letter to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo asking for Marie Yovanovitch to be removed as U.S. ambassador to Ukraine after his meeting with Parnas, according to the Texas Observer. Parnas and Fruman are alleged to have concocted a straw donation scheme to hide their political contributions and give in excess of the campaign contribution limits. A $325,000 donation to the pro-Trump super PAC America First Action was made in the name of Global Energy Producers LLC, a shell corporation purporting to be engaged in the liquified natural gas business, according to the indictment. Donations made to Republican Party candidates in Parnasâ name were actually funded by Fruman, prosecutors allege.Â It is illegal to make a campaign contribution in someone elseâs name.Â These donations included maximum $2,700 contributions to Sessions and House Republican Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.). Prosecutors say the illegal foreign donations made through Parnas and Fruman went to âpoliticians and candidates for federal and state office.â The indictment refers to specific donations to two Nevada state Republican Party politicians. State campaign finance records show the only two Nevada candidates to receive such contributions were gubernatorial candidate Adam Laxalt and attorney general candidate Wes Duncan. The Nevada contributions were allegedly made as part of a failed attempt to secure licenses for a legal cannabis business venture. The foreign donor â who is only identified as Foreign National-1 and described as a âRussian citizen and businessmanâ â allegedly wanted to remain anonymous due to âhis Russian roots and current political paranoia about it.â The campaign finance allegations against Parnas and Fruman were first flagged to authorities by the Campaign Legal Center, a nonprofit campaign finance watchdog, in a complaint filed with the Federal Election Commission in July 2018. âThe public is now learning just how dangerous dark money can be in U.S. elections, including the potential for illegal foreign funds, which DOJ says were used here,â Trevor Potter, Campaign Legal Center president and former counsel to Sen. John McCain, said in a statement. âThe fact that these two individuals were working with Giuliani and Ukrainian government officials to alter U.S. policy in that country will obviously be relevant to the impeachment investigation.â The indictment also names businessmen David Correia and Andrey Kukushkin as defendants. All four defendants are U.S. citizens. Parnas and Kukushkin were born in Ukraine, while Fruman was born in Belarus. Read the indictment below. This story has been updated with comment from the Campaign Legal Center and additional information.

articles.title: GOP Rep. John Shimkus Slams Trump Over Syria Withdrawal
articles.subtitle: âPull my name off the âI support Donald Trumpâ list,â Shimkus said.
articles.author: Ryan Grenoble
articles.content: President Donald Trumpâs support among Republicans is eroding amid fallout from his surprise withdrawal of troops from Kurdish-held northern Syria. On Thursday, he lost Rep. John Shimkus (R-Ill.), who told KMOX Radio heâs no longer backing Trump because of the decision. âIâm heartbroken,â Shimkus, who represents Illinoisâ deep-red 15th District, said. âIn fact, I called my chief of staff in D.C.; I said âpull my name off the âI support Donald Trumpâ list.ââ âWe have just stabbed our allies in the back,â he said. âThe Kurds go back all the way to the first Gulf War.â Shimkus, who isnât running for reelection in 2020, emphasized Kurdish loyalty to the U.S. and American causes over the years, and the importance of honoring that history. This has âshocked, embarrassed and angered me,â he said. âItâs terrible. Itâs despicable. I donât have enough words... Iâm embarrassed by it and Iâm saddened for the Kurdish people.â Shimkus later clarified in a statement that while heâs âasked that my name be removed from [the Trump] campaignâs official list of supporters,â he will nevertheless âcontinue to support the presidentâs domestic policy agenda.â Trump on Sunday abruptly announced a complete withdrawal of U.S. troops from northern Syria, in a widely condemned decisionÂ that caught his own officials off guard. Soon after, Turkey began to attack the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces in the region. Turkey considers the U.S.-allied forces a terrorist group. âTurkey is a NATO ally but they have been transforming over the last 10, 15 years to a more totalitarian, Islamic-type state,â Shimkus said. â[Turkish PresidentÂ Recep Tayyip Erdogan]Â has had some relations with the Kremlin and Putin. We are very concerned about that. Theyâre still NATO allies, theyâre still in the tent, but this is embarrassing.â

articles.title: Veteran Congresswomanâs Retirement Could Open Door For Progressive Newcomer
articles.subtitle: Rep. Nita Lowey, a New York Democrat, already faced a primary challenge from attorney Mondaire Jones.
articles.author: Daniel Marans
articles.content: Rep. Nita Lowey, an influential New York Democrat, announced on Thursday that she will not seek reelection next year after 16 terms in Congress. Her retirement creates a power vacuum in one of the Empire Stateâs safe blue seats that could benefit progressive lawyerÂ Mondaire Jones.Â Jones, who is 32, African American and gay, had already launched a primary challenge against the 82-year-old Lowey in July. There were some signs earlier that Lowey was trying to cover her left flank. She endorsed an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump in late July, three weeks after Jones, an impeachment proponent, entered the race. (Lowey cited special counsel Robert Muellerâs testimony before Congress as the factor that pushed her to embrace another investigation.) For his part, Jones had blasted Lowey, chair of the House Appropriations Committee, for backing a February spending bill that granted the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency $1.4 billion in new funding. He also faulted the congresswoman for past votes in support of the Iraq War and a 1996 law that barred the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriage, as well as her opposition to the Iran nuclear deal. But on Thursday, Jones was gracious. âAs a trailblazer for women and minorities such as myself, Congresswoman Lowey set an example and has made it easier for people like me to run for office,â he said in a statement. Jones, the son of a struggling single mother in Rockland County, New York, rose from a childhood on public assistance to earn degrees from Stanford and Harvard Law. He quit his job as an attorney in the Westchester County Law Department to run for Congress, where he hopes to focus on the unmet challenges of middle- and working-class families in the increasingly diverse suburbs north of New York City. He told the regional news outlet City & StateÂ that heâs now one of the millions of Americans without health insurance, which adds a personal element to his support for a single-payer health care program like âMedicare for All.â âWe need bold, progressive leadership in Congress: guaranteed health care, a Green New Deal, student debt forgiveness, and a full restoration of the State and Local Tax Deductions (SALT) for families in Westchester and Rockland,â Jones said in his Thursday statement. âThereâs never been an openly gay, black member of Congress â because people like me donât usually get anywhere close. But weâre about to make history.â Jones, who has rejected corporate PAC donations, raised over $218,000 in the third quarter of 2019. Thatâs over $100,000 more than middle school principal Jamaal Bowman, who launched a primary challenge to Rep. Eliot Engel (D) in June in a neighboring district.Â And nearly two-thirds of Jonesâ haul came in increments of less than $200. Although it is generally easier for a newcomer to prevail in a contest for an open congressional seat, Jones is likely to face a more competitive field in Loweyâs absence. The district includes Chappaqua, the wealthy Westchester suburb where Bill and Hillary Clinton live, prompting immediate speculation that Chelsea Clinton, their daughter, might jump into the race. New York state Senate Majority Leader Andrea Stewart-Cousins represents parts of Westchester County as well. Her backing could give a contender an instant leg up in the Democratic primary. On its face, New Yorkâs 17th Congressional District looks like challenging terrain for any progressive Democrat. It is home to some of the countryâs wealthiest suburbs, as well as its most insular ultra-Orthodox Jewish enclaves. Jones, a churchgoing Baptist, has taken steps to portray himself as less radical than some other primary challengers to Democratic incumbents. He is not endorsed by Justice Democrats, the upstart group whose support helped propel Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to an upset win in the June 2018 primary. A spokesperson for Justice Democrats didnât respond to a question as to whether Jones had sought their endorsement. In addition,Â Jonesâ focus on restoring the state and local tax deduction is a nod to the more affluent suburban voters of New York who lost out in the 2017 Trump tax cuts. Kristen Zebrowski Stavisky, chairwoman of the Rockland County Democratic Party, called Lowey one of the âreal female trailblazersâ in Congress. The veteran lawmaker played an outsize role in helping Democrats retake the House in last yearâs election, Stavisky said. (Lowey contributed $410,000 to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee from her own war chest in the 2018 election cycle, according to official election filings.)
