Iâm very angry at you people right now,â Trump said of the freshman congresswoman. âShe is a disgrace to our country, and she is one of the big reasons that I am going to win and the Republican Party is going to win Minnesota.â Trump regularly turned from the teleprompter during the event, saying it was âmuch better when I go off-script.â During one such instance, he also acted out a bizarre conversation between former FBI agent Peter Strzok and FBI attorney Lisa Page. Thursdayâs rally was emblematic of Trumpâs latest attempts to turn the momentum behind the impeachment inquiry to favor his own political agenda. The White House has refused to comply with the Houseâs investigations, and the presidentâs campaign has been fundraising en masse since Pelosi first announced the impeachment proceedings. House Democrats, however, have remained undeterred, firing off subpoenas targeting many current and former Trump administration officials while telling the president that no one is above the law. This article has been updated with a reaction from Biden.

articles.title: Joe Biden Recalls âGay, Gay Bathhouses,â 24/7 Sex, And People Are So Confused
articles.subtitle: The former vice president reminisced about âgay bathhousesâ and âround-the-clock sexâ at the LGBTQ town hall on CNN.
articles.author: Josephine Harvey
articles.content: On prime-time television Thursday night, Joe Biden reminisced about a time when LGBTQ discourse was all about âgay bathhousesâ and âround-the-clock sexâ â and viewers were not sure how to feel about it. The former vice president made the comments to CNNâs Anderson Cooper, who was moderating the Los Angeles town hall event, a forum for nine Democratic presidential candidates to discuss LGBTQ issues. After going on a tangent about stereotypes surrounding gay people, Biden concluded with a reflection on how the discourse about homosexuality had changed in recent years, compared with about two decades ago: âRemember, Anderson? Back 15, 20 years ago, when we talked about this in San Francisco, it was all about,Â well, gay bathhouses.Â It was all about round-the-clock sex.Â Come on, man.Â Gay couples are more likely to stay together longer than heterosexual couples,â he said. On a more serious note, Biden also discussed curtailing foreign assistance to countries who discriminate against LGBTQ citizens, the importance of passing the Equality Act in order to reduce hate crimes and protecting transgender peopleâs right to join the military. At one point, he referenced a time when he âcame outâ but rolled with the joke and walked across the stage to put his arm around Cooper, who is gay. âWell, that would be news,â Cooper joked back. âI kind of figured it out a while ago.â People on Twitter were very confused by, well, all of it. Although, there was one resounding thing viewers could agree with that they wanted out of this: A remix of âgay, gay, gay bathhouses.â It was quickly delivered:

articles.title: Trump Rips Rep. Ilhan Omar As âFraudâ And âDisgraceâ During Rally In Her District
articles.subtitle: President Donald Trump ranted against the Minnesota Democrat and vowed to prevent more Somalian refugees from entering the U.S.
articles.author: Carla Herreria
articles.content:
President Donald Trump slammed Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) while speaking at a rally in her home state on Thursday, calling her a âfraudâ and âdisgrace to our country.â âHow the hell did that ever happen,â Trump said of Omarâs election to Congress in 2016.Â âHow do you have such a person representing you in Minnesota?â President denounced Omar, a Somali American lawmaker, as an âAmerica-hating socialistâ and criticized her for using the phrase âsome people did somethingâ as she spoke about how the reaction to 9/11 affected the Muslim community in the U.S. Trump also described Omar as a âdisgrace to our country.â His campaign held his rally in the Target Center in downtown Minneapolis, which is part of Omarâs voting district. âHow do you have such a person representing you in Minnesota? She is a disgrace to our country,â he said, adding that she was the reason he was going to win Minnesotaâs vote for reelection in 2020. Omar won the 5th Congressional District by a wide margin in the 2018 election. My goodness â Trump is now diving into conspiracy theories about Ilhan Omarâs marital status he read on a right-wing blog. Completely unhinged. pic.twitter.com/kjy3qCwK5i Omar is one of four Democratic congresswomen of color whom Trump sparred with this summer. The so-called âsquadâ included Omar as well as Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) and Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.). Later in his rally Thursday night, Trump vowed to stop Somali refugees from coming into the country. Minneapolis has one of the largest populations of Somali refugees in the country. Trump vows to crack down on Somali refugees in a city with one of the largest Somali populations in the country pic.twitter.com/xXM3pffCef âFor many years, leaders in Washington brought large numbers of refugees to your state from Somalia without considering the impact on schools, communities and taxpayers,â Trump said. âI promise you as president, I would give local communities a greater say in refugee policy and put in place enhanced vetting and responsible immigration controls.â In response, Omar called Trumpâs attacks âxenophobicâ and called for her supporters to donate to her campaign. Trump âshouted xenophobic conspiracy theories about me,â she tweeted Thursday night. At his rally just now, Trump called me an âAmerica-hating socialistâ and a âdisgrace.â He shouted xenophobic conspiracy theories about me. He scolded my district for voting for me.

His hate is no match for our movement. Stand with me by donating now: https://t.co/QdUrT9zJsr pic.twitter.com/Ik8I9zlRTf

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Drops A Total Zinger About Marriage At LGBTQ Town Hall
articles.subtitle: The presidential candidate had a sassy response for those who say marriage is between âone man and one woman.â
articles.author: Josephine Harvey
articles.content: Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) may as well have dropped the mic Thursday night after delivering a lippy response to a question about traditional views on marriage. Morgan Cox, chair of the Human Rights Campaign board of directors, asked the 2020 presidential candidate how she would respond if an âold-fashionedâ supporter approached her on the campaign trail and said: âMy faith teaches me that marriage is between one man and one woman.â âWell, Iâm going to assume itâs a guy who said that, and Iâm going to say, âthen just marry one woman.â Iâm cool with that,â Warren fired back. âAssuming you can find one.â The audience erupted with cheers and laughter: In response to a follow-up question from CNN moderator Chris Cuomo, Warren said that, despite growing up in a conservative household, she couldnât really recall a time where she felt differently about same-sex marriage. She cited the lyrics of a song she learned in church:Â âThey are yellow, black and white. They are precious in his sight Jesus loves all the children of the world.â She said that, although her exposure to same-sex couples was gradual during her upbringing in Oklahoma, the hatefulness that could be directed at the gay community shocked her, particularly from people of faith. Warren also tackled how Democrats could expect to pass the Equality Act, medical care for transgender people in the military and correctional facilities, cost-reduction for HIV medications, and decriminalizing HIV transmission, among other topics. She had just released a wide-ranging LGBTQ policy plan Thursday morning.

articles.title: The Minnesota Congresswoman Who Can Criticize Israel
articles.subtitle: St. Paulâs Betty McCollum is radically progressive on U.S. policy toward Israel. Why donât you ever hear about it?
articles.author: Jessica Schulberg
articles.content: Over the past few years, one member of Congress has stood up to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), denounced Israelâs policies, which she likened to âapartheid,â and pushed laws that would place humanitarian conditions on U.S. military aid to Israel. Human rights advocates praise her, and she is popular in her progressive district. But she is neither the face of the progressive left nor the bogeyman of Fox News. Unless youâve lived in Minnesota â or read MinnPost â thereâs a good chance youâve never heard of her. Her name is Betty McCollum, and she has represented St. Paul for almost 20 years. President Donald Trump â who loves to attack Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.), one of the first Muslim congresswomen, for her criticism of Israel â has never once tweeted McCollumâs name. That the Democratic congresswoman who leads the vanguard of progressive U.S. policy toward Israel in Congress is not the subject of constant bad-faith attacks from the right is a testament to her pragmatism. But it also exposes the inconsistency of the outrage campaign directed at Omar and the other members of the so-called âSquad,â a group of progressive first-term lawmakers who are all women of color. âRep. Omar has a history of launching virulent anti-Semitic screeds,â Trump claimed at a campaign rally in Minneapolis on Thursday. âShe is a disgrace to our country and she is one of the big reasons that I am going to win and the Republican Party is going to win Minnesota in 13 months,â he continued. Trumpâs attacks on the Squad, which also includes Reps. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.), Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) and Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.), âare intentionally done to rile up the racist instincts of a portion of his base,â said Dylan Williams, of the left-leaning pro-Israel group J Street. âThis double standard thatâs being applied to these congresswomen is very clear, and itâs not a standard that has been applied to other congressional critics of Israeli policy and the occupation.â Omar, who is Black, Muslim and an immigrant from Somalia, represents âa perfect storm of characteristics that they could try to attack and portray as the problem to a white evangelical base,â said Yousef Munayyer, the executive director of the U.S. Campaign for Palestinian Rights. âRep. McCollum,â Munayyer added, âdidnât fit the poster.â McCollum, who grew up in South St. Paul, trained as a social studies teacher. After she graduated, she had a hard time finding full-time work, so she took on long-term substitute teaching jobs and worked part-time at Sears. In 1984, McCollumâs toddler daughter fractured her skull falling off a playground slide that didnât have enough sand at its base. The girl recovered quickly, but the city didnât do anything about the playground until after McCollum pushed for it at a City Council meeting â a victory that prompted her to run for local office. She served on the City Council and in the Minnesota statehouse before she was elected to Congress in 2000. There is no one moment that prompted McCollum to become one of the most outspoken members of Congress on Israel and Palestine. She tends to talk about the conflict as just one of the many human rights crises bedeviling the world. As a lawmaker, she has shown a particular interest in policy aimed at protecting vulnerable kids: She has worked to provide HIV-AIDS assistance to orphans, prevent child marriageÂ and fix crumbling schools for Native American children. In 2006, representatives of groups that provide humanitarian assistance to Palestinians warned McCollum of a looming humanitarian disaster. At the time, lawmakers were preparing to vote on the Palestinian Anti-Terrorism Act, a bill ostensibly intended to isolate Hamas, the group that has been designated by Israel and the U.S. as a terrorist organization and that had recently won a majority in the Palestinian parliament. The bill, humanitarian workers explained, would make it harder for aid organizations to provide lifesaving medical care to Palestinians. McCollum listened and was one of two members who voted against advancing the bill out of committee. The bill, which was backed by AIPAC, passed easily in the House. But McCollumâs dissenting vote set her up for a feud with one of the most powerful lobbying groups in the country. On a Friday after the vote, McCollumâs chief of staff, Bill Harper, got a phone call from Amy Rotenberg, an AIPAC member who had met with McCollum on behalf of the organization. McCollumâs âsupport for terrorists will not be tolerated,â Rotenberg said, according to Harper.Â Rotenberg,Â who declined an interview, described Harperâs characterization of the conversation as a âserious distortion.â âBill Harperâs description of the conversation with me was false in 2006 and it is false now,â Rotenberg wrote. McCollum was shocked. She wrote a letter to AIPACâs executive director slamming the group for attempting to use âthreat and intimidation to stifle legitimate policy differences.â She banned AIPAC representatives from her offices pending a formal apology from the lobbying group. It was a lonely time to go up against AIPAC. J Street, the left-leaning alternative to AIPAC, didnât exist yet. Members told McCollum that she had âwritten her death sentence,â she said. âI went, âOK, if I lose an election over standing up for medical supplies for kids, OK, Iâm ready to go!ââ McCollum said. âWhen I came back, the whisper kind of was, âYou can survive!ââ McCollum never got a public apology, but she did eventually let AIPAC representatives back into her office. âBut they donât bully her or do what they do to other members,â said Brad Parker, a senior adviser at Defense for Children International Palestine. McCollum wins reelections in her progressive district by huge margins â she received 91% of the vote in the 2018 primary and beat her Republican opponent by 36 percentage points. She has no interest in running for Senate, she said. In 2015, when a group of activists started organizing in opposition to Israelâs military detention of Palestinian children, McCollumâs office was one of the first places they visited on Capitol Hill. Palestinian human rights is an outlier issue on Capitol Hill â âYou donât even have access to a lot of offices; they donât want to deal with Palestinian organizations,â said Parker, whose group briefed McCollumâs team on the issue. âThose barriers donât exist with Betty.â They showed McCollumâs team aÂ 2013 UNICEF report that described Israeli soldiers removing Palestinian kids from their homes in the middle of the night, blindfolding them and taking them to an interrogation center. The kids were beaten, deprived of sleep and forced to sign confessions in a language they did not understand, without a lawyer present, the report said. âItâs like, âWait a second. Weâre giving money, the U.S. government, to UNICEF, to do this report â and weâre giving money to the Israeli government to do the things that the report is about,ââ Harper, McCollumâs chief of staff, said. âWhatâs wrong with this picture?â The U.S. currently gives Israel $3.8 billion a year in military aid. Since World War II, it has received more U.S. foreign assistance than any other country, according to the Congressional Research Service. Most countries that receive U.S. assistance are subject to extensive restrictions on how the aid is used. But for Israel, much of the money goes directly into its Ministry of Defense, with little American oversight, Harper said. In 2017, McCollum introduced a bill to block U.S. aid to Israel from being used to âsupport the military detention, interrogation, abuse, or ill-treatment of Palestinian children in violation of international humanitarian law.â She reintroduced the bill in April, this time with language that would amend the so-called Leahy law, which prohibits the U.S. from providing military assistance to foreign governments that commit âa gross violation of human rights.â The current bill would also set aside money to fund nongovernmental organizations that provide physical, psychological and emotional treatment for Palestinian children who have been detained by the Israeli military. Last March, the Minnesota delegation of American Muslims for Palestine traveled to Washington to meet with McCollum and talk about her bill. At the end of the meeting, McCollum tweeted out a picture of her posing with the group. The congresswoman didnât think much of it â she tweets pictures of groups she meets with all the time. But Palestinian activists are used to being ignored by their elected officials, AMP chapter lead Mariam El-Khatib said. When El-Khatib saw the tweet, she thought, âWow, she doesnât mind being associated with AMP or Palestinians doing this kind of work.â The bill has 21 co-sponsors, all Democrats. Two additional Democrats withdrew their names as co-sponsors. When Rep. Debbie Dingell (D-Mich.) pulled her name, she tweeted that her âheart has always been with the children of Palestineâ and that she was pushing leadership âhardâ for a vote on a âresolution supporting a two-state solution.â McCollum pushed back: âRep. Dingell removed her name from HR 2407, calling it âcounterproductive to a peaceful, two-state solution,ââ McCollum tweeted. âDoes ongoing U.S. funding for Israeli military detention and abuse of Palestinian children promote peace or human rights violations?â McCollum estimates that if all of the members who told her in private they liked the bill were willing to support it publicly, sheâd have another 20 co-sponsors. But she also knows the bill has almost no chance of making it out of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, headed by the staunchly pro-Israel Rep. Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.) â much less becoming law. Engel and DingellÂ did not respond to requests for comment. âItâs the obvious bill that still wonât get passed,â said Jaylani Hussein, head of the Minnesota chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations. Last year, McCollum accepted an award from the U.S. Campaign for Palestinian Rights. During her acceptance speech, she described Israelâs nation-state law â which reserves the right to self-determination in Israel for Jewish people â as a system of apartheid. For a sitting member of Congress to use the word âapartheidâ in reference to Israel is radical â almost inconceivable. But her comments attracted almost no national attention. With the exception of fringe actors, such as Zionist Organization of American President Mort Klein, most of the people from the pro-Israel community who weighed in on her speech offered measured criticism. Steve Hunegs, of the Jewish Community Relations Council of Minnesota and the Dakotas, expressed disappointment with her word choice and her decision to attend the event, but he also emphasized her past support for a two-state solution. He didnât accuse her of anti-Semitism. McCollum thinks the conversation about Israel is shifting among her colleagues. The leadership of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu â who has vowed to annex parts of the West Bank â has Democrats concerned that prospects for a two-state solution are disappearing. Without a two-state solution, âdo we have apartheid in Israel?â McCollum asked. âDo we have something similar to Jim Crow laws, which we had a struggle with in this country and weâre still facing the repercussions that are with race relations? Do we not say anything?â The conversation is slowly shifting, but itâs not hard to imagine what would have happened if Omar, the congresswoman who represents the district across the river from McCollumâs, had used the word âapartheidâ in reference to Israel. Like McCollum, Omar has spoken out against the influence of AIPAC and criticized the right-wing government in Israel. But, unlike the more senior lawmaker, Omarâs critics usually assume the worst interpretation of her words. In the week immediately following Omarâs âItâs all about the Benjamins, babyâ tweet â an observation that members of Congress are willing to infringe on Americansâ right to criticize Israel because of money directed their way by pro-Israel lobbyists â Omar was roundly accused of trafficking in anti-Semitic tropes about the influence of wealthy Jews. Her name was mentioned in 21 Fox News shows, 51 CNN shows and five MSNBC shows, The Intercept reported. Her name also appeared in nearly 500 newspaper articles, according to a Lexis Nexis search. Omar apologized after the âBenjaminsâ tweet and said she was grateful for colleagues and allies who educated her on the âpainful history of anti-Semitic tropes.â Later that month, she spoke at a progressive policy town hall about her fear that her legitimate criticisms of Israel will be misconstrued as anti-Semitism because she is Muslim. She asked why she is allowed to criticize the influence of the National Rifle Association and Big Pharma but not the influence of the pro-Israel lobby. But people paid attention to only one line in her remarks: âI want to talk about the political influence in this country that says it is OK for people to push for allegiance to a foreign country.â Omar was talking about an effective political lobbying operation â one that includes plenty of evangelical Christians and is opposed by lots of American Jews. But Omarâs critics, including some liberals, insisted she was questioning the loyalty of American Jews. New York magazineâs Jonathan Chait proclaimed she no longer deserved âthe presumption of good faith,â and Engel accused her of âinvoking a vile anti-Semitic slur.â Within days, the House passed a resolution condemning all forms of anti-Semitism, listing âaccusations of dual loyaltyâ alongside the neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, and the massacre at a synagogue in Pittsburgh. McCollumâs staff say that the reason she doesnât evoke the same reactions as Omar is because she is careful with her words and has spent years cultivating close relationships in Congress, including with leadership and members on the other side of the political spectrum. McCollum works âexcruciatinglyâ hard to make sure that what she says about Israel is âbased on evidenceâ and is backed on reports, Harper said. She goes out of her way to make clear that she is not attacking Jews or Israelis, but the policies of a government, Harper continued. I asked more than a dozen policy advocates and Capitol Hill staffers who work on Israeli-Palestinian issues about the disparate treatment between McCollum and Omar. All of them agreed that McCollum is careful and that she benefits from close relationships with her colleagues. But racism and Islamophobia are also part of the reason why Omar faces vitriolic backlash every time she weighs in on Israel while McCollum has gone relatively unnoticed, almost all of the advocates and Capitol Hill staffers said. âUndoubtedly, Rep. McCollum is one of the leading human rights champions on Palestinian human rights on the Hill, consistently for years, without fail,â said Beth Miller, the government affairs manager at Jewish Voice for Peace. âThe fact that she has never been attacked in the way that Reps. Tlaib and Omar have been speaks to the racism and Islamophobia that is very present in this conversation.â Even if Omar used the same language that McCollum has in criticizing Israel, she would still be maligned as an anti-Semite, Munayyer argued. âYou can try to be as careful as you want with your language, obviously itâs important that everyone should be careful with their language on this issue,â he said, âbut when no matter what you say, youâre being attacked because of who you are. Itâs not about what youâre saying, itâs about you having a voice on this issue.â From the outside, McCollum and Omar seem like the perfect duo to bring real change to the U.S. conversation around Israel: a veteran lawmaker who has goodwill among her colleagues and a fiery newcomer who isnât afraid of raising hell. âPeople like Reps. Omar and Tlaib â and, to a certain degree, Bernie Sanders â are bringing much-needed attention to the occupation in ways that weâve never seen before in Congress. But you also need workhorses like Rep. McCollum to quietly build consensus around legislation,â a senior Democratic Hill staffer said. âAs in any movement, the two roles are complementary. You canât make real change without both an inside and an outside strategy.â Omar, who, through a spokesperson, declined an interview, is a co-sponsor of McCollumâs bill â but most of the time, the two members do their own thing. âIlhan is on the other side of the Mississippi River, and we talk sometimes in the break room in between votes,â McCollum said, adding that the same was true with Omarâs predecessors. But, at times, McCollum has seemed visibly annoyed with Omar and the controversies that surround her. In March, McCollum put out a rare statement on her Minnesota colleague: âRep. Omar has the right to speak freely, and she also must take responsibility for the effect her words have on her colleagues, her constituents, and the policies Democrats seek to advance,â McCollum said. âDemocrats have an important agenda to advance and for any Member of Congress to be successful it takes the support of at least 217 colleagues to pass a bill. No one does this job alone.â McCollumâs chief of staff put it more bluntly, âMy own take on it is that she really derailed a lot of our work,â Harper said. But as anyone who has tried to talk, write or argue about Israel and the Palestinians knows, thereâs no way to do it that will please everyone. âGiven how detached the D.C. debate on Israel-Palestine is from the actual reality of what goes on there, there may be no way we move this debate closer to reality in a way that avoids tension entirely,â said Matt Duss, a foreign policy adviser to Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.). âWe just have to do our best to be as honest and sensitive and constructive as we can, but itâs a debate we need to have.â This article has been updated to include a more extensive quote from Amy Rotenberg.

articles.title: Donald Trump Belittles BeyoncÃ©, Jay-Z, Bruce Springsteen And Invokes Fansâ Fury
articles.subtitle: âItâs time to get in impeachment formation,â one person responded on Twitter. âYouâll NEVER be The Boss,â added another.
articles.author: Lee Moran
articles.content: Hip-hop and rock fans united in their condemnation of Donald Trump after the president went after BeyoncÃ©, Jay-Z and âThe Bossâ Bruce Springsteen during a campaign rally in Minneapolis on Thursday night. Trump bragged about the size of the crowds he attracted during the 2016 campaign and mocked his then-Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, who had a series of high-profile musicians perform at her events. âI didnât need BeyoncÃ© and Jay-Z,â said Trump. âAnd I didnât need little Bruce Springsteen and all of these people.â Trump then claimed, without offering any evidence, that musicians like Springsteen would sing two songs at Clintonâs rallies before leaving and taking most of the crowd, while âshe is still talking in front of the same lousy crowd.â The three artists havenât responded publicly to Trumpâs comments. Springsteen has previously said Trump is âdeeply damaged at his core,â but predicted heâll win reelection in 2020. Jay-Z has called Trump a âsuperbug.â Trumpâs comments were condemned on Twitter, where one person backed BeyoncÃ© by saying said âitâs time to get in impeachment formationâ and another showed support for Springsteen by telling Trump âyouâre President of the United States but youâll NEVER be The Boss.â Democratic 2020 presidential candidate Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) also chimed in: Trump has evoked BeyoncÃ©âs name. If he thought Democrats were after jinx Whew. Wait till he meets the Bey-Hive.

articles.title: Trumpâs Not Rolling With GOP Theory He Was âJokingâ About China Probing Bidens
articles.subtitle: Republicans defended the presidentâs suggestion that China should investigate Joe Biden as a joke. But Trump isnât laughing.
articles.author: Josephine Harvey
articles.content: President Donald Trump was given a chance Thursday to say whether hisÂ suggestionÂ that China investigate his political rival Joe Biden was a joke â and he passed. Trump, asked by reporters on the White House lawn if he had meant his comments in jest, replied: âChina has to do whatever they want. If they want to look into something, they can look into it. If they donât want to look into it, they donât have to.â He added: âFrankly, as far as Iâm concerned, if China wants to look into something, I think thatâs great. And if they donât want to, I think thatâs great too. Thatâs up to China.â Trump told reporters last week that China should start an investigation into Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden. He made the comments amid impeachment proceedings prompted by his July 25 phone call with Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which he requested that foreign governmentâs aid in digging up dirt on Biden. Multiple Republican lawmakers, when asked if they believed Trumpâs China comments were appropriate,Â defended them as being a joke, including Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio.), Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.), and Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.). âDo you really think he was serious about thinking that China is going to investigate the Biden family?â Jordan said last week. McCarthy commented: âYou watch what the president said, heâs not saying China should investigate.â The presidentâs exact words were: âChina should start an investigation into the Bidens.â Trumpâs response on Thursday did not suggest he was joking about China. CNN reported last week thatÂ Trump raised the topic of Bidenâs political prospects during a June 18 phone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping, according to sources familiar with the call. The call record was stored on the same highly secure White House computer system used to house the summary of Trumpâs Ukraine call. Trumpâs entreaties to China followed GOP questions over Hunter Bidenâs position on the board of a Chinese private equity fund in 2013, while his father was the vice president. He accompanied his father on an official trip to China during that time.

articles.title: Trump vs. The Constitution: In Impeachment Inquiry, Trump Insists Heâs Above The Law
articles.subtitle: Faced with an impeachment inquiry, President Donald Trump has openly defied the core constructs of the Constitution.
articles.content: NEW YORK (AP) â Donald Trump has spent his time in office trying to bend the conventions of the American presidency to his will. Now he appears to be trying to override a core principle of democracy: that no one is above the law. Faced with an impeachment inquiry, Trump has openly defied the core constructs of the Constitution. He chafes at the idea of co-equal branches of government and rejects the Houseâs right to investigate him. He has deployed a convoluted logic in which he has declared that the courts canât investigate him because as president he cannot be charged with a crime but also that Congress cannot impeach him because its inquiry is politically illegitimate. Itâs a âheads he wins, tails you loseâ formulation. âItâs anathema to his character and his life story to be checked and balanced by anything,â said presidential historian Jon Meacham, a professor at Vanderbilt University. âThe Constitution was formed to contain appetite. And we now have the president who is driven entirely by appetite.â In a scathing eight-page letter this week, the Republican presidentâs lawyers served notice there will be no cooperation with the impeachment inquiry. Trumpâs White House has ignored document requests and subpoenas. It readily invokes executive privilege â going so far as to argue that the privilege extends to informal presidential advisers who never held White House jobs. And his team all but dares Democrats to hold them in contempt. The impeachment standoff follows a pattern Trump has established throughout his presidency as he has jettisoned experienced advisers and flouted conventions. The fact that he survived the special counselâs Russia investigation without paying much of a political penalty left him all the more emboldened. One day after Robert Muellerâs faltering testimony brought an end to that threat, Trump unleashed a new one by asking Ukraineâs president to investigate his political foe Joe Biden. That prompted the fast-moving impeachment inquiry that Trump now resists. After two weeks of a listless and unfocused response to the impeachment probe, the White House letter to Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi this week was a declaration of war. While it was filled with dubious legal arguments, its intent was clear: Trump would not play ball, claiming that the game was rigged against him. As for all the subpoenas flying from House Democrats, an exasperated Trump said Thursday, âYouâre running a country, I just donât think that you can have all of these people testifying about every conversation youâve had.â And as for the Democrats, Trump claimed Wednesday theyâre the ones playing dirty âbecause they have a tiny margin in the House.â âThey have eviscerated the rules,â he said. âThey donât give us any â any fair play. Itâs the most unfair situation people have seen.â The Constitution gives the House âthe sole power of impeachment.â But it confers that authority without providing any guidelines, which the White House has seized upon in demanding that Pelosi call for a vote to authorize the inquiry as happened in the last two impeachment inquiries. No vote is required, and Trumpâs strategy risks further provoking Democrats in the impeachment probe, setting up court challenges and the potential for lawmakers to draw up an article of impeachment for obstructing their investigations. âThe president does not have all-consuming power,â said Nick Ackerman, a member of the Watergate prosecution team that investigated President Richard Nixon. âWe play by certain rules, and we expect the rule of law to apply. We donât have checks and balances if he ignores them. That itself is an impeachable defense, which is what Nixon faced.â It is unclear whether Democrats would wade into a lengthy legal fight with the administration over documents and testimony or if they would just move straight to considering articles of impeachment. Trump, for his part, has never been one to rely on legality or logic in making his arguments. In the last week alone, he called for the impeachment of Sen. Mitt Romney and Rep. Adam Schiff â events that canât occur â and in part justified his decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Syria, leaving the Kurds vulnerable to Turkish attacks, by saying the Kurds did not assist at Normandy during World War II. Since taking office, he has taken repeatedly taken unilateral action to defy Congress and push the limits of his own power, declaring a national emergency so he could divert funds for a border wall and taking executive action to try to halt immigration from several Muslim-majority nations. Trump on Thursday punctuated a tweet about unfair media coverage with four words that seemed to sum up his entire viewpoint of the American system: âOh well, Iâm President!â The Constitution was built to withstand tests like this. âBoth the strength of the American system and one of its most frustrating aspects is that itâs incredibly difficult to do anything quickly, particularly bad things, which the founders believed would happen more often than good things,â Meacham said. âChecks and balances were created so one bad actor could not dominate the proceedings. We now have that bad actor.â ___ EDITORâS NOTE â Jonathan Lemire has covered politics and the White House for The Associated Press since 2013. ___ Follow Lemire on Twitter at http://twitter.com/@JonLemire

articles.title: Germany Shooter âWould Have Killed More Peopleâ With Access To Better Guns
articles.subtitle: The gunman accused of killing two people outside a Halle synagogue was using homemade firearms â a far cry from military-grade weaponry common in the U.S.
articles.author: Andy Campbell
articles.content: The man accused of shooting two people to death in Halle, Germany, this week shares a lot of characteristics with American mass shooters: Heâs a bigot with delusions of grandeur, and is part of an online community that fervently supports his hate. But one thing that set him apart â and likely curbed the death toll in Wednesdayâs shootings outside a synagogue â was his choice of weapons. Police say he was armed with homemade guns that jammed repeatedly during the attack. American mass killers, on the other hand, typically strike with a cache of military-grade, semiautomatic weaponry. Thatâs in part due to Germanyâs strict gun laws. Had the Halle shooter had access to better guns, the bloodshed could have been much worse, experts said. âItâs clear that if he had access to better weapons, the body count would have been higher,â said Vegas Tenold, a journalist and author with the Anti-Defamation Leagueâs Center on Extremism. Tenold tweeted a photo of the shooterâs slam-bang tube, adding, âThis is a direct result of Germanyâs strict gun laws.â The shooter, in a gruesome, 36-minute video livestreamed on Twitch, used his improvised guns to kill two people after failing to get inside a synagogue filled with Yom Kippur worshippers. His guns â including a so-called slam-bang tube and a homemade 9mm rifle â repeatedly jammed or failed to fire as he attempted to shoot. He said he wanted to prove the effectiveness of rudimentary weapons in a country that makes it hard to obtain semiautomatic guns. The shooter in Germany used home made weapons that were low quality and misfired repeatedly. This is a direct result of Germanyâs strict gun laws. If he had had access to better weapons he would have killed more people. pic.twitter.com/Mo13zRtTJ4 Germany has some of the worldâs strictest gun laws. All gun ownership is heavily regulated,Â and each legal purchase comes with a background check that considers addiction, mental health history, and criminal record. Gun buyers under 25 have to pass a psychological exam, and semiautomatic gun ownership requires special authorization. German gun laws were tightened after school shootings in 2002 and 2009. In turn, shooting incidents dropped dramatically, according to The Washington Post. Illegal weaponry and DIY guns are still a threat across much of Europe. But shooters need criminal connections to get their hands on semiautomatic firepower that is commonplace in America, said Nils Duquet, a weapons expert in Belgium with Flemish Peace Institute. âIf you want to buy an illegal gun in Europe, whatâs important is having the right networks. For assault rifles, you need better criminal connections,â Duquet told The Washington Post.Â âBut there are many hot spots in Europe where you can try, and that is whatâs worrying.â Americaâs gun laws, along with war-torn Yemenâs, are the worldâs loosest. The U.S. isÂ averaging more than one mass shooting per day this year. According to the nonprofit Gun Violence Archive, 329 mass shootings â defined as an incident in which four people or more are shot, excluding the shooter â have occurred in the U.S. in 2019. Military-grade, semiautomatic rifles are often easier to obtain in the U.S. than handguns, and they kill twice as many people as other types of weapons,Â according to researchers. âActive shooters are hell-bent on killing people,â Dr. Adil Haider, a trauma surgeon who was the lead author of a 2018 study on weapons used in âactive shooterâ incidents, told The Associated Press. âThe big difference â and this is not such a big surprise â is if you give them a semiautomatic, theyâre able to shoot twice the number of people.â

articles.title: U.S. Judge Blocks Trump Rule Limiting Visas, Green Cards For Poor Immigrants
articles.subtitle: Experts warned the rule could discourage immigrants from seeking help, including for their U.S. citizen children.
articles.content: NEW YORK (Reuters) - A U.S. federal judge in New York on Friday temporarily blocked a Trump administration rule that would deny permanent residency to certain aspiring immigrants deemed likely to require government assistance in the future. The rule, which was finalized in August, vastly expanded who could be considered a possible âpublic chargeâ from someone who would be primarily dependent on the government to someone who might at some point need government help such as food stamps or housing vouchers. The Department of Homeland Security rule, pushed by Trumpâs leading aide on immigration, Stephen Miller, was due to go into effect on Oct. 15. It will now be on hold while legal challenges against it proceed. Judge George Daniels of the Southern District of New York, issued a nationwide block of the rule, writing that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims and would suffer âirreparable harmâ if the rule were to go into effect. He wrote the government had failed to demonstrate why the current approach was inadequate. The rule, if it is ultimately allowed to go into effect, could be the most drastic of the Trump administrationâs policies targeting the legal immigration system, experts have said. Â The government has argued the rule is necessary to better ensure that immigrants will be self-sufficient. âThe public charge standard was never intended to exclude working class immigrants from developing countries,â said Charles Wheeler, an attorney with the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, which is a plaintiff in the case. âThis ruling confirms that the American dream remains open to them.â Reporting by Jonathan Stempel, Daniel Trotta and Kristina Cooke. Editing by Chris Reese and Cynthia Osterman.

articles.title: Trump Vows To Put A Man On The Moon. Someone Should Introduce Him To Buzz Aldrin.
articles.subtitle: And heâs going to end âsocialism,â he promises supporters at Louisiana rally.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: President Donald Trump made two head-turning promises at his Louisiana campaign rally Friday: Heâs going to put an end to socialism â and put a man on the moon. The crowd in Lake Charles roared. Two problems: What socialism is he talking about? Social Security? His $28 billion in subsidies to his âpatriot farmersâ to help them survive his trade war with China? And 12 Americans have already walked on the moon, beginning in 1969 with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin. Trump actually has met Aldrin, but apparently they didnât discuss the moonwalk. Twitter wits were flying high over the apparent gaffe.

articles.title: Jury Hangs On Hate Crime, Civil Rights Charges Against Racist New Jersey Police Chief
articles.subtitle: A judge declared a mistrial after the jury was unable to reach a verdict on two counts against Frank Nucera, who was found guilty of lying to the FBI.
articles.author: Ryan J. Reilly
articles.content: All 12 jurors deliberating the case against racist former New Jersey police chief Frank Nucera agree that heâs a liar: Theyâve already convicted him of lying to the FBI. The former Bordentown Township police chief concedes he went on racist rants about nonwhite citizens that his underlings recorded. Two of his own officers testified under oath in federal court that Nucera slammed a Black teenagerâs head into a metal doorjamb, and Nucera didnât take the stand in his own defense. But a jury was unable to reach a verdict on two other charges â hate crime assault and deprivation of civil rights under color of law â that were directly related to the head slam his officers say he committed. U.S. District Court Judge Robert Kugler of Camden declared a mistrial on those two counts on Friday.Â U.S. Attorney Craig CarpenitoÂ announcedÂ after the mistrial that theyâd retry Nucera on the outstanding counts. The jury began deliberations last Wednesday, and had held discussions for over 40 hours.Â The Philadelphia InquirerÂ reportedÂ that a white juror âstood in the jury box with his hands crossed when the panel solemnly filed into the courtroomâ to deliver the verdict on the lying charge this week. The case against Nucera illustrated the challenges in holding officers accountable. Nearly two decades ago, according to The Trentonian, former Bordentown Township police officer Evan Jones says he was pushed out of the force after he filed an excessive force complaint about Nucera with the Burlington County Prosecutorâs Office.Â Current Bordentown Township Police Chief Brian Pesce testified that he had âlost all trust and confidenceâ that complaints about Nucera would be handled appropriately, and told the FBI that a former Burlington County Prosecutor told him to âlet sleeping dogs lieâ when he learned Nucera was under FBI investigation. Judge Kugler, according to the Inquirer, gave federal prosecutors until Nov. 13 to decide whether they would go to trial once again on the remaining counts. Nuceraâs attorney said theyâll assess their options on the lying to the FBI conviction, and that Nucera âalways... regrettedâ making those âugly and embarrassingâ comments.â âHeâs held his head high throughout this process,â said Rocco Cipparone. âHeâs handled it with grace and dignity.â This has been updated with Carpenitoâs announcement that prosecutors will retry Nucera.

articles.title: A Progressive Congressmanâs Oversight Of Donald Trump Inspires Challenge From The Left
articles.subtitle: Oregon Rep. Peter DeFazio checks a lot of liberal boxes. But challenger Doyle Canning thinks heâs going easy on the president.
articles.author: Daniel Marans
articles.content: The case for some progressive primary challenges is obvious. Those are the races where an incumbent Democrat in a safe seat has racked up a conservative voting record out of step with their constituents, used their seat for self-enrichment, or otherwise lost touch with their district. The theory behind challenging Rep. Peter DeFazio, 72, who has, since 1987, represented a seat in rural Oregon that now leans just barely Democratic, is more complex. DeFazio, who now serves as chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, is a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus and longtime supporter of, among other progressive touchstones, âMedicare for All,â single-payer health care. But Doyle Canning, a 39-year-old community organizer and attorney who has announced a primary challenge against DeFazio, insists that the veteran congressman is past his expiration date. Canning, who hails from the liberal college town of Eugene, has some standard policy differences with DeFazio. Unlike the incumbent congressman in Oregonâs 4th Congressional District, she supports House Democratsâ legislation banning military-style âassaultâ rifles. She is also refusing to accept contributions from corporate political action committees, something DeFazio receives in abundance. Her hardest-hitting critique, however, is that as a committee chair, DeFazio has been milquetoast in his dealings with, and oversight of, the Trump administration. âThis race is about the future â of our district, of the country and of the Democratic Party,â Canning told HuffPost. âAnd we need leadership that is willing to take a stand against the corruption of the Trump administration.â DeFazioâs Transportation Committee is charged with oversight of federal government buildings, including the building that houses the Trump International Hotel in Washington; airplane manufacturers and the Federal Aviation Administration; and the conduct of the Secretary of Transportation. At one point or another in the past year, DeFazio has faced accusations of falling short in each of those three areas. DeFazio provided a lengthy statement defending his committeeâs oversight; HuffPost also spoke to committee staff about their work. âI am running aggressive investigations to get answers about any number of Trump administration actions that fall within my Committeeâs jurisdiction,â he said. Following a second major Boeing plane crash in March, which killed over 150 people, the Federal Aviation Administration grounded three of the manufacturerâs commercial airliners. The tragic crash prompted major questions about why the FAA, under Transportation Secretary Elaine Chaoâs supervision, had failed to prevent the crashes. At the time, DeFazio suggested he would stop at nothing to obtain relevant communications about the scandal from both Boeing and the FAA. By early May, it emerged that Boeing knew about the absence of a warning light in one of the deadly planes, but delayed informing authorities, because it considered the light an optional feature available to customers paying a higher premium. But later that month, at a hearing on the crashes with Trumpâs acting head of the FAA, DeFazio admitted that he still didnât have the documents and did nothing to indicate he plans to use his subpoena power to get them. âIâm hoping that they will provide the documents we have requested voluntarily and in the not-too-distant future,â he said. In a May essay, Jeff Hauser, executive director of the Revolving Door Project, which monitors executive branch corruption, accused DeFazio of taking a softer line than Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who chairs the subcommittee on aviation and space. âWe have had no serious inquiry into the collapse of government oversight of planes,â Hauser told HuffPost. Boeingâs CEO Dennis Muilenburg is due to testify before DeFazioâs committee on Oct. 30 â more than seven months after the plane crash that prompted the FAA to ground planes. Matt Stoller, author of the forthcoming bookÂ âGoliath: The 100-Year War Between Monopoly Power and Democracy,â characterized DeFazioâs chairmanship unfavorably when compared to, among other colleagues, Rhode Island Rep. David Cicillineâs chairmanship of the House Judiciary Committeeâs antitrust panel. âCicilline is doing a great job investigating big tech. DeFazio needs to show that same urgency in investigating Boeing,â said Stoller, a former congressional aide, who now serves as a fellow at the antitrust-focused Open Markets Institute. âBeing the party of the people means carrying on the legacy of [former California Rep.] Henry Waxman and [former Arkansas Rep.] Wright Patman, people who knew how to uncover the secrets powerful people donât want the public to know.â Members of DeFazioâs committee staff told HuffPost that they are now sifting through hundreds of thousands of documents that they have obtained since May from both Boeing and the FAA. To call Muilenburg, the Boeing CEO, before the committee prior to obtaining those documents would waste the opportunity to grill him in a more informed way, they argued. They also said that forcing disclosure of documents through subpoenas could have delayed the process further by tying the committee up in court with legal challenges. Hauser did not buy those arguments. He maintains that there is no way to know whether documents shared voluntarily are as definitive as those that Boeing and the FAA would reveal if they had no choice. And he noted that the committee could have called Muilenburg in early on, when the political urgency was greatest, then recalled him a second time once the committee had assembled more documents. âBoeing is definitely happy with Chairman DeFazioâs oversight,â Hauser said. âThe question is whether Chairman DeFazio is happy about that.â In his statement to HuffPost, DeFazio said that he was prioritizing substance over style. He noted that the has already held three hearings on the crashes, which have featured current and former Boeing employees, FAA officials and whistleblowers. âMy record on safety and oversight is vast and determination dogged,â he said, citing his work on the ValuJet crash in the 1990s. âAnyone who knows my record knows that I fight for real results, not empty rhetoric.â Then there is the matter of DeFazioâs relative inactivity in response to Secretary Chaoâs shady conduct. Chao is both the daughter of James Chao, a major Chinese shipping magnate, and the wife of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.). Politico reported in May that Chao has made a series of appearances indirectly promoting the company her father founded while serving as head of a federal agency overseeing the declining U.S. shipping industry in direct competition with companies like her familyâs. Another Politico report just last week found that 25% of Chaoâs meetings with local officials were with people from Kentucky, the state her husband represents in the Senate. The House Oversight and Reform Committee, which has broad supervision of the executive branch, has initiated an investigation into Chaoâs conduct related to her familyâs company, sending a letter to Chao in mid-September demanding documents related to her communication with the company. But DeFazioâs transportation committee, which has a narrower focus on Chao and her agency, has yet to pursue comparable action. The Transportation and Infrastructure Committee staff members who spoke to HuffPost said that given the committeeâs resources it is letting the Oversight Committee take the lead on investigating Chaoâs ethical queries, though it is acting in a supporting capacity. DeFazioâs committee is also in touch with the Department of Transportationâs inspector general to decide its next steps. Hauser, of the Revolving Door Project, considers it âfecklessâ that DeFazio has not called on Chao to testify before the committee either about Boeing, her own conduct or any other matter. (Committee staff said they would not hesitate to call Chao before the committee if they considered it necessary.) Critics of DeFazioâs tenure felt as though they had come across the secret to his motives in a Washington Post article at the end of August, which addressed a supposed lack of progress in the Transportation and Infrastructure Committeeâs investigations into the Trump International Hotel in Washington. Trump built the hotel in the Old Post Office Building, which he is leasing from the federal government. That means that DeFazioâs panel has oversight over Trumpâs apparent use of the hotel as a vehicle for self-enrichment over the course of his presidency. In the Post story, Rep. Dina Titus (D-Nev.), chair of the subcommittee overseeing the hotel, suggested that DeFazio was treading carefully in his investigations into the hotel in the hopes of negotiating infrastructure legislation with Trump. Titus subsequently took back the remarks, claiming the article âmischaracterizesâ the progress that DeFazioâs committee has made. Shortly after the Post story came out, Titus joined a press release with DeFazio âcorrecting the recordâ on the committeeâs work. The heart of the investigation, which began after Trump was elected in November 2016, entails requiring the General Services Administration, the agency that manages federal government buildings, to conduct an audit of the hotel. In his statement to HuffPost, DeFazio said that the GSA has handed over thousands of documents, but is still withholding many. He has given the administration a deadline to hand over the remainder and he will ânot hesitateâ to use his subpoena power to compel their release. The challenge for Canning is making the charges against DeFazio stick in a largely rural district that Democrats are hanging on to by a thread. Oregonâs 4th covers a large tract of land in the southwestern corner of the state, which was once home to a thriving timber industry. Eugene, which is home to the University of Oregon, and Corvallis, which is home to Oregon State, are blue dots in a sea of rural red terrain. As rural Oregon, like rural America, has trended away from Democrats, DeFazio has defied the fate of national Democrats. In 2016, DeFazio was re-elected by 16 percentage points, but Hillary Clinton edged out Trump in the same district by a mere 0.1 points. Canning, whose husband works at the University of Oregon, in many ways embodies the political leanings of the districtâs liberal population hubs. She is a co-founder of the Center for Story-Based Strategy, a nonprofit that seeks to advance progressive causes through storytelling, and she has previously worked for an environmental justice organization that fights the racially disparate impacts of ecological depradation. Like many Democrats furious about Trumpâs corruption and racism, Canning is calling for a sense of urgency to match the moment, including ruling out any significant cooperation with the administration until Trump is impeached. She took DeFazio to task on Twitter for suggesting that work on a federal highway bill, which would necessarily be bipartisan in order to pass, would proceed apace. DeFazio campaign manager Carly Gabrielson dismissed the criticism as contrary to Canningâs goals of taking action against climate change. âUnder the Chairmanâs direction, the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee is moving legislation to implement the goals of the Green New Dealâ goals that Doyle Canning claims to share, yet at the same time she believes that business should stop while Congress investigates Trump?â Gabrielson said. âYou canât have it both ways, and frankly itâs an absurd position.â HuffPost pressed Canning on the difficulty of prevailing against DeFazio in a rural swing seat. Canning responded that, like many progressive challengers before her, she is betting that a principled fighter is capable of expanding the electorate by turning out nonvoters. Among other groups, she wants to appeal to the growing number of eligible Latinx voters who moved to the district for work. âWeâre building a coalition of the new face of the Democratic Party,â she said. âItâs younger, itâs more diverse, itâs more feminist, and it looks different than it did in â86.â

articles.title: WeWork Is Closing Its Private School In New York City After This Year
articles.subtitle: Since 2018, the troubled office space company has operated an expensive private school in Manhattan.
articles.author: Rebecca Klein
articles.content: WeWork informed parents on Friday that it would no longer operate its private school in Manhattan after the 2019-20 school year, HuffPost has learned. âWeWork will continue to operate WeGrow through the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year, providing a quality education and classroom experience for all students,â a WeWork spokesperson said in a statement. âAs part of the companyâs efforts to focus on its core business, WeWork has informed the families of WeGrow students that we will not operate WeGrow after this school year.â âWeWork and the families of WeGrow students are engaging in discussions with interested parties regarding plans for WeGrow for the following school year,â the spokesperson added. The small New York City private school has been open since 2018 and costs between $22,000 and $42,000 a year in tuition, depending on the age of the student. Its website calls it a âconscious entrepreneurial school,â offering students mentorship from WeWork employees, weekly trips to a farm, daily meditation and yoga, while preaching lofty goals about nurturing studentsâ souls. HuffPost spoke with several people close to the school in the past few weeks to get a better sense of the institution. They described a school that is run like the company of WeWork, subject to constant changes or âdisruption,â sometimes without full consideration for the children these changes impact. However, they also described an idealistic learning space, where children for the most part seem to be happy and thriving. According to one former employee, the company recently redesigned part of the school, which they speculated cost up to several million dollars (a spokesperson for WeWork did not respond to questions about this). The school is a casualty of the companyâs new efforts to downsize after the implosion of its planned public offering and a staggering reduction in its valuation. The past few weeks have been chaotic for the company, which rents out shared workspaces to businesses and entrepreneurs. Its CEO and co-founder Adam Neumann stepped down and there are rumors of mass layoffs that could impact thousands of employees. Amid the chaos, WeGrow parents wondered whether the school would even make it through the year, lining up backup options in case of an abrupt shuttering. âParents and administrators are exploring all options to keep WeGrow open,â said parent Jessica Ducroux on Friday morning. The school was the brainchild of WeWork co-founder and chief brand and impact officer Rebekah Neumann, who served as the schoolâs CEO before stepping down from her roles at the company with her husband, Adam. Indeed, WeGrow mimicked WeWork, as the schoolâs day to day was sometimes rejiggered on short notice, which could be incompatible with the needs of children, sources said. The WeWork spokesperson did not comment on this characterization of school life at WeGrow. A representative for the Neumanns did not immediately have comment. But by its second year, the schoolâs enrollment had grown to about 100 students, including a number of children whose parents worked for the company. In 2018, Rebekah Neumann called the school â and the ability to bring company employees closer to their children â part of WeWorkâs core goals, according to CNN. âWe want to make a world where people can work to make a life and not just a living, but thatâs part of a larger, more holistic mission to elevate the worldâs consciousness, to create a world where people are happy and fulfilled and living in a sharing state,â she said. Indeed, the school employs staffers with titles like âcreative expressions managerâ and âmanager of wisdom cultures.â In recent weeks, teachers have worked to shield kids from the disarray enveloping the larger company, according to a WeGrow parent. This parent praised the school for nurturing childrenâs social-emotional development, as opposed to perpetuating a rat race focused on test scores and achievement, and worries that the schoolâs true successes â its focus on mindfulness and community building â will be overshadowed by schadenfreude over WeWorkâs shortcomings. The school â like WeWork spaces â emphasizes design, and is complete with âmodular classrooms, tree houses and a vertical farm,â per the schoolâs website. WeGrow is one of WeWorkâs auxiliary offerings. The company also rents out furnished apartments and has a gym. Rebekah Neumann appears to have had high ambitions for the institution, previously telling CNN that she hoped a WeGrow would operate in every city where thereâs a WeWork office. âIt will eventually be able to sustain independently for sure,â she said at the time.

articles.title: U.S. Public Lands Chief Says His Positions On Climate, Immigrants Donât Matter
articles.subtitle: Bureau of Land Management acting director William Perry Pendley repeatedly dodged questions at an environmental journalism conference.
articles.content: FORT COLLINS, Colo. â William Perry Pendley, the controversial acting director of the Bureau of Land Management, told a room full of journalists on Friday that his opinions on climate change and immigrants are âirrelevantâ to his job overseeing 245 million acres of public land. Speaking on a panel at the Society of Environmental Journalistsâ annual conference, Pendley, a conservative lawyer who has spent his career fighting federal land protections and environmental regulation, sparred repeatedly with reporters. He refused to comment about his past statements that cast doubt on basic climate science and compared immigrants to a âcancer.â He also repeatedly responded to questions by saying, âI disagree with your premise.â As recently as February, Pendley compared the climate crisis to a âunicornâ because âneither exists.â Asked to clarify his position on Friday, he deferred to his boss, Interior Secretary David Bernhardt, a former oil lobbyist who has said he hasnât lost sleep over soaring atmospheric carbon dioxide and blamed Congress for his own inaction on the climate.Â Bernhardt had been scheduled to appear at the conference but canceled. âIâm not a scientist, Iâm a lawyer,â Pendley said. âI defer to the secretary. Heâs been very clear on this subject. He believes that climate change is real, that mankind has an impact, that weâre unable to project future climate conditions, but that we need to understand the consequences.â Asked again about his own views, Pendley balked: âNope, Iâm not going to clarify. Those are my personal opinions,â he said. âIâm a Marine. I follow orders.â Pendley added that he has not been briefed on climate impacts to Americaâs public lands in the three months heâs been acting head of theÂ  BLM. In 2007, Pendley referred to undocumented immigrants as âspreading like a cancerâ in a fundraising mailer for his legal fundÂ resurfaced by CNN this week. When pressed on Friday about the statement, Pendley brushed off the question entirely. âMy personal opinions are irrelevant,â he said. âI have a new job now. Iâm a zealous advocate for my client. My client is the American people and my bosses are the president of the United States and Secretary Bernhardt. What I thought, what I wrote, what I did in the past is irrelevant. I have orders, I have laws to obey, and I intend to do that.â Pendley didnât hesitate, though, to slamÂ Democratic presidential candidates who have pledged to stop new fossil fuel leasing on public lands for fossil fuel development if elected. âSuch a policy would be absolutely devastating; it would be absolutely devastating not just to the American West, but to the entire country,â he said.Â Â Leaving fossil fuels in the ground, he added, would be âabsolutely insaneâ and âa terrible blow to the American people.â The room, as moderators requested, refrained from clapping or booing throughout the panel, which included a gas company executive, the Fort Collins mayor, an American Indian studies academic, an environmentalist and a representative of the outdoor recreation industry. But at one point, the audience in the packed auditorium at Colorado State University gasped as Pendley abruptly interrupted a Denver Post reporter as she asked a follow-up question, saying, âYou want to ask a question and get an answer or do you want to keep talking?â Pendley was asked about the BLMâs decision in May to scrub language about land stewardship from its news releases, which now exclusively highlights the economic value of Americaâs public lands. He initially shrugged and whispered inaudibly to Shea Loper, the U.S. government relations chief for the Canadian gas giant Encana Corp. He said he was unable to speak to the decision because it occurred before he arrived at the agency. âI canât respond to your question,â he said. âIâm sorry.â At the end of the discussion, panelists were asked what they view as the biggest threat facing public lands today. Pendley responded,Â âIâll get really in the weeds. I think the biggest issue I see is the wild horse and burro issue. We have 88,000 wild horses and burros on our Western federal lands. They are causing havoc on the lands.â

articles.title: Appeals Court Rules House Democrats Can Subpoena Trumpâs Financial Records
articles.subtitle: The 2-1 ruling went against the president, who was seeking to block a subpoena for documents, including tax returns, held by his accounting firm.
articles.author: Paul Blumenthal
articles.content: The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals on Friday upheld a subpoena that House Democrats sent to President Donald Trumpâs accounting firm for his financial records and tax returns. The court issued a 2-1 rulingï»¿Â that the House Oversight & Reform Committee has the constitutional authority to investigate wrongdoing by the president of the United States and can therefore subpoena his financial records in pursuit of that investigation. The subpoena was initially filed by the committee to Mazars LLP, the presidentâs accounting firm, as part of its pursuit to evaluate and update existing ethics legislation. It came after former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen told the committee that the president routinely manipulated his finances to obtain loans and evade taxes. Lawyers for the committee argued that the pursuit of these documents was part of its legislative function as it evaluated new executive branch financial disclosure and conflict of interest laws. Trumpâs personal lawyers intervened to argue that the House did not have a legitimate legislative purpose in pursuing the documents from the accounting firm and that the only valid way to subpoena any document connected to the president was through an impeachment. The two judges who voted to uphold the subpoena â David Tatel, appointed by President Bill Clinton, and Patricia Millett, appointed by President Barack Obama â ruled that the committee was acting under its legislative function in pursuit of potential legislation. They also ruled that the committee issued its subpoena under valid authority granted by House Rules and the Constitution. In doing so, Tatel and Millett upheld multiple precedents enabling congressional investigations into the executive branch that could uncover law-breaking and other wrongdoing. The judges knocked down arguments made by Trumpâs lawyers that the public statements of committee members showed the committee was not pursuing a legitimate legislative purpose, but rather an unconstitutional law-enforcement action targeting the president. âFollowing that course, we conclude that the public record reveals legitimate legislative pursuits, not an impermissible law-enforcement purpose, behind the Committeeâs subpoena,â Tatel and Millett wrote. âAs a result, we need not decide precisely what deference we owe Congress, as we would reach the same conclusion absent any deference at all.â They also found that the committee was pursuing legislation that could be enacted. Trumpâs lawyers tried to argue that the legislation would be found unconstitutional and therefore was not legitimate. â[W]e detect no inherent constitutional flaw in laws requiring Presidents to publicly disclose certain financial information. And that is enough,â the majority opinion reads. Their ultimate conclusion: âAt bottom, this subpoena is a valid exercise of the legislative oversight authority because it seeks information important to determining the fitness of legislation to address potential problems within the Executive Branch and the electoral system; it does not seek to determine the Presidentâs fitness for office.â Judge Neomi Rao, a Trump appointee, issued a dissent that broke with long-standing Supreme Court precedent by arguing that Congress has no right to investigate the president except under its impeachment authority. â[A]llegations of illegal conduct against the President cannot be investigated by Congress except through impeachment,â Rao wrote in her dissent. Such a determination would overturn a 1962 Supreme Court precedent that âa congressional committee which is engaged in a legitimate legislative investigation need not grind to a halt whenever...crime or wrongdoing is disclosed.â âThe dissent would reorder the very structure of the Constitution,â Tatel and Millett argue in their majority opinion. âThroughout history, the Constitution has left to Congress the judgment whether to commence the impeachment process. But the dissentâs approach would not even allow Congress to make the quintessentially legislative judgment that some concerns about potential misconduct or illegality are better addressed through oversight and legislation than impeachment.â If Raoâs opinion overturned past precedent, Congress would be left with no recourse to investigate impeachable executive branch officials for wrongdoing unless it immediately opens an impeachment inquiry. This would gut congressional investigatory powers and tilt the balance of power between the branches of government even further to the benefit of the executive branch. House Democrats previously leaned on this case as an argument against pursuing impeachment earlier in 2019. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) argued that Democrats needed to pursue the presidentâs documents through the courts as part of the ordinary course of business. A whistleblowerâs disclosure that Trump pressured the president of Ukraine to interfere in the 2020 election, however, changed that equation. The House is now engaged in an impeachment inquiry. This decision is expected to be appealed to the Supreme Court, to which Trump has appointed two justices: Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, an ally of Trumpâs, was asked in 2018 whether the courts would allow House Democrats to obtain the presidentâs tax returns. âThen theyâll be trapped into appealing to the Supreme Court, and weâll see whether or not the Kavanaugh fight was worth it,âÂ Gingrich replied.

articles.title: Trump Trashes Impeachment, Bidens, Media At Louisiana Rally
articles.subtitle: The president met a sympathetic audience in Louisiana.
articles.content: LAKE CHARLES, La. (AP) â President Donald Trump on Friday pressed his argument that the House impeachment inquiry is nothing more than a new attempt to overturn his election based on âa lot of crap.â Trump found a sympathetic audience in Louisiana, where an arena packed with his supporters roared at his profane denunciations of the proceedings hundreds of miles away in the nationâs capital. âTheyâve been trying to stop us for more than three years with a lot of crap,â he said, referring to the investigation into Russian election interference that concluded earlier this year. âThey know they canât win on Election Day so theyâre pursuing an illegal, invalid and unconstitutional, bullsâ- impeachment,â the president thundered at his second political rally in as many days. Trump also pressed his unproven claims against Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and his son Hunter, who sat on the board of a Ukrainian gas company when Biden was vice president. Trump complained about a double standard in news media coverage. He said if any of his children were similarly accused, the media wouldnât call the allegations unsubstantiated â âThey would be saying, âWhereâs the nearest cell?ââ There has been no evidence of wrongdoing by either Joe Biden or Hunter Biden. House Democrats have opened an impeachment inquiry over Trumpâs dealings with Ukraine, in which he asked that countryâs president during a telephone call in July to investigate Biden. An intelligence community whistleblower complained that Trump was abusing his office for personal political gain. Trump insists he didnât do anything wrong and has called the conversation with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy âperfect.â Zelenskiy has said he was not pressured by Trump. Trump claimed Democrats are ârage filledâ and have opened the impeachment inquiry because they âhave gone completely insaneâ in their ânonstop battleâ to overturn the 2016 presidential election result. âNancy Pelosi hates the United States of America, or she wouldnât be doing this,â Trump said of the Democratic speaker of the House, who had long resisted calls to initiate impeachment proceedings. Pelosi has said âno one is above the lawâ and Trump must be held accountable for actions that she says jeopardize U.S. national security, the integrity of American elections and the Constitution. Trump came to Louisiana to unite a squabbling Republican Party against the Deep Southâs only Democratic governor, hoping to keep John Bel Edwards from notching a primary win in Saturdayâs election. Republican loyalties are split between two major candidates: Ralph Abraham, a third-term congressman and physician from rural northeast Louisiana, and Eddie Rispone, a businessman and longtime political donor from Baton Rouge who is making his first bid for office. Both Republican candidates claim long-term support from Trump. âTomorrow, youâve got to vote John Bel Edwards out,â Trump said, criticizing the Democrat as bad for the state. âIf he doesnât get 50%, then one of our two great candidates will win that.â The president is not endorsing either GOP candidate to maximize chances that Edwards will fall below the 50% vote threshold needed to avoid a runoff, according to a White House aide and a campaign aide, both of whom asked for anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss strategy. Trump plans to endorse whichever GOP candidate makes it to a runoff against Edwards, the aides said. In Louisiana, all candidates run against each other, regardless of party, on the same primary ballot. With polls showing Edwards well in the lead, national Republicans have bombarded the state with millions in advertising and visits from Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and Donald Trump Jr. to urge anti-Edwards votes and force a Nov. 16 runoff. Trump acknowledged the reality of college football season in the South and urged everyone to vote before they head to Saturdayâs big matchup between Louisiana State University and Florida State. He said people should vote before they go to the game, otherwise they will feel guilty and âit will ruin your entire afternoon.â Trump called Edwards âa liberal Democrat who has sold you out,â even though Edwards isnât the type of liberal with whom the president usually clashes. He described Abraham and Rispone, the two Republican candidates, as âpro-jobs, pro-worker, pro-family, pro-life, and theyâre pro-Louisiana energy if thatâs OK.â Trump also kept up a sports theme by inviting the winners of the 2019 Little League World Series to the stage. Trump met in the Oval Office earlier Friday with members of the Eastbank All-Stars and invited them to fly home aboard Air Force One. The team is based in suburban New Orleans. Trump said he had become accustomed to watching Japan win the event. âBut this year you have the world champions,â he told the rally crowd before introducing the players one by one. ___ Associated Press writer Kevin Freking in Washington contributed to this report. __ Follow Darlene Superville and Melinda Deslatte on Twitter at:Â http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap and http://twitter.com/melindadeslatte

articles.title: A Lot Of Trumpâs Ukraine Conspiracy Theories Come From One Right-Wing Columnist
articles.subtitle: Thereâs a direct line between John Solomonâs shaky allegations and the presidentâs brain.
