articles.content: Many of the allegations and fuzzy âfactsâ that President Donald Trump and his allies have cited to defend pressuring Ukraine to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden gained traction in the press thanks to one journalist: John Solomon, whose stories and columns in The Hill have made him a Fox News regular (and now a contributor). Solomon, who announced plans to leave The Hill last month, is now under fire â as he has been in the past â for deviations from normal journalistic practice. In search of a convenient narrative, Solomon has embraced questionable sources and even shared a pre-publication copy of one story with a Ukrainian American businessman who federal authorities now say was illegally trying to influence American politics. Solomonâs articles are emblematic of the way the right-wing news pipeline to Trump functions: Shaky allegations get picked up by eager partisan journalists, who are then featured on Fox News where they grab the attention of the president. Last week, Solomon defended his decision to send a draft of a March 26 story on a Ukrainian anti-corruption organization to three Trump-associated operatives hours before its publication. The draft of his story â titled âUS Embassy pressed Ukraine to drop probe of George Soros group during 2016 electionâ â was shown to Lev Parnas, an Ukrainian American associate of Rudy Giulianiâs who was arrestedÂ Thursday on charges of campaign finance violation, as well as frequent Fox News guestsÂ Joseph diGenova and Victoria Toensing. Solomon suggested this was part of his fact-checking process even though the story did not appear to concern those three beyond their interest in potentially damaging information about Trumpâs opponents. âI typically spend a long period of time before any column or news story fact-checking information with numerous people,âÂ Solomon tweeted. But Solomonâs dedication to âfact-checking information with numerous peopleâ didnât appear to extend to a main subject of his story, the Anti-Corruption Action Centre, which he suggested was âcollaborating with FBI agentsâ who were investigating Trumpâs then-campaign chair Paul Manafort. Solomon also suggested that AntAC, a Ukrainian organization, avoided an investigation because of the support of the Obama administration and billionaire George Soros, a common bogeyman for conservatives and target for conspiracy theorists. (AntAC receives funding from Sorosâ Open Society Foundations, as well as from the U.S. government and a range of other donors.) Solomon never reached out to AntAC for comment about allegations made to him by former Ukrainian prosecutor general Yuri Lutsenko, according to AntACâs executive director, Daria Kaleniuk. (Solomonâs story states that he repeatedly reached out to AntAC and Open Society Foundations, although he does not specify when.)Â And unlike the Republican operatives, Kaleniuk said AntAC received no draft of the article before The Hill published it. âI wonder why the same approach was not given to me, as he was naming my organization and he was actually sliming it,â Kaleniuk told HuffPost. Solomon did initially contact Kaleniuk in October 2018, many months before publishing his column in The Hill, saying he was âworking on a story for publication Monday about the DOJâs Kleptocracy Project and its success in Ukraine.â He asked for comment on a number of questions, including about connections between AntAC, Sorosâ foundation and the FBI. Kaleniuk said she found the questions biased and conspiratorial and did not respond. Solomon did not publish anything to do with the Kleptocracy Project or Ukraine in the weeks after his email, according to The Hillâs archives. After Solomonâs story ran in March, Kaleniuk contacted The Hillâs editors requesting an opportunity to comment on the allegations against her organization. But her rebuttal clearly didnât get as much traction: The Hillâs website says that Solomonâs original piece had over 36,000 shares, while Kaleniukâs piece had just 118. A Twitter search of accounts run by The Hill or The Hillâs opinion section didnât turn up any links to Kaleniukâs piece, though the accounts did promote Solomonâs work. Solomon did not respond to a voicemail message and multiple emails from HuffPost. Editors at The Hill did not respond to requests for comment. Solomon has defended his journalistic practices on Twitter. In a series of tweetsÂ this month, he said he would sometimes send people a âsummary of my reportingâ before publication. But according to the Daily Beast, what Solomon sent to Republican operatives hours before his Ukraine story was posted online was no âsummary.â It was a copy of his storyÂ â headline, lede, and paragraph after paragraph. Solomon also tweeted that this was part of a fact-checking process that he had followed at every job heâd held, âstarting when I was a young reporter at AP and continuing today at The Hill.â It is common for journalists to send a list of fact-checking questions to a subject of an article. But sharing full, unpublished drafts â especially with partisan political operatives who are not directly involved in the story â is a violation of journalistic standards that wouldnât fly at his previous publications. âAP standards prohibit any behavior or activity that creates a conflict of interest, including sharing unpublished drafts of stories with sources,â a spokesperson for the Associated Press told HuffPost. Solomon said that he had over âthree dozen communications over three days involved in the fact checking process for that particular story.â He said his fact-checking process could catch mistakes and lead to better context and comments. Solomonâs reporting has been a cause of concern for newsroom staff at The Hill, who have criticized his work for bias and shared their unease at his close ties to Trump associates. Over a dozen staff members sent a memo to The Hillâs management complaining about Solomonâs stories and accusing him of leaving out important context that didnât fit his theories, The Washington Post reported last year. HuffPost last year debunked a misleading piece by Solomon that suggested FBI agents whoâd exchanged anti-Trump text messages had leaked anti-Trump material to the media. They had not. Solomon was shifted to the role of âopinion contributorâ following the staffersâ memo, according to The Daily Beast, while Solomon claimed he had requested the change. Questions have also been raised about the sources Solomon has used for his columns. His March series of stories on Ukraine â a country with complex politics he had little prior history of covering â carried a wide range of claims against U.S. Democratic officials and Obama-era appointees. He suggested that Ukrainian officials, urged along by then-U.S. Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch, conspired with Democrats to influence the 2016 presidential election and release damaging information against Trump. He also contended that then-Vice President Biden pressured the Ukrainian government to fire prosecutor general Viktor Shokin in order to quash an investigation into his son Hunter Biden, who had business ties in Ukraine. (Shokin was, in fact, widely criticized for not pushing corruption cases hard enough.) One of the main sources named in Solomonâs series on Ukraine was Yuri Lutsenko, who served as prosecutor general after Shokin.Â Many journalists, foreign policy experts and activists who focus on Ukraine have criticized the idea of treating Lutsenko as a reliable source, saying that he, too, is a discredited figure who has been an impediment to anti-corruption efforts. After the Trump administration recalled Ambassador Yovanovitch, Lutsenko texted AntACâs Kaleniuk to brag about how he had gotten rid of the organizationâs ally. LutsenkoÂ has also repeatedly backtracked on his various claims, including telling the Los Angeles Times in late September that he never found any evidence of wrongdoing by the Biden family. Ukrainian authorities announced on Tuesday that they have launched a criminal investigation into Lutsenko over his alleged links to illegal gambling. Lutsenko, who traveled to the United Kingdom days before the announcement, has denied any wrongdoing. Nonetheless, Solomon boosted Lutsenkoâs conspiracy claims against the Bidens, Yovanovitch and Clinton not only in his columns for The Hill but also on Sean Hannityâs Fox News show, which often serves as a direct pipeline to Trump. The president has tweeted about Solomon at least four times this year, usually in connection with the columnistâs Fox News appearances. After Solomon was on Hannityâs program in March, Trump tweeted, âJohn Solomon: As Russia Collusion fades, Ukrainian plot to help Clinton emerges.â He was quoting the headline of Solomonâs March 20 column, which was based on an interview with Lutsenko. Appearing alongside Solomon on Fox News that evening were diGenova and Toensing, two of the political operatives to whom he emailed his draft of a later March column. Solomon was back on Fox News nine days later, suggesting to host Laura Ingraham that Democrats were attempting to hide a conspiracy between Clinton and Ukrainian officials to target Trump during the 2016 campaign. âThatâs what they donât want people to start digging into,â Solomon said. âYouâre digging in it. Iâve been reading your reporting on that,â Ingraham responded. âWe look forward to the next report.â

articles.title: Rudy Giuliani Reportedly Under Investigation For Links To U.S. Ambassadorâs Recall
articles.subtitle: Prosecutors are looking into whether Giuliani violated lobbying laws that protect the government from covert foreign influence, The New York Times reported.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: Federal prosecutors are investigating PresidentÂ Donald Trumpâs personal attorney Rudy Giulianiâs links to the sudden recall in May of the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, The New York Times reported Friday. Manhattan investigators are looking into whether Giuliani violated lobbying laws that protect the U.S. government from covert foreign influence, sources told the Times. CNN and Bloomberg reported Thursday that federal prosecutors were also examining Giulianiâs financial dealings with associates Igor Fruman and Lev Parnas, who were arrested Thursday on charges that they secretly funneled Russian money to groups that support Trump and other GOP candidates. Marie Yovanovitch, the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, testified before House impeachment investigators Friday that she was âincredulousâ when she was âabruptlyâ recalled from her post in May. Trump had pressed for her ouster for months as Yovanovitch was accused of disloyalty, which was categorically untrue, according to her prepared statement obtained by The Washington Post. âAs best as I can tell,â the âunfounded and false claimsâ were pressed by âpeople with clearly questionable motives,â Yovanovitch said in her statement. âI do not know Mr. Giulianiâs motives for attacking me,â she told lawmakers. âBut individuals who have been named in the press as contacts of Mr. Giuliani may well have believed that their personal financial ambitions were stymied by our anti-corruption policy in Ukraine.â Trump referred to Yovanovitch in his controversial phone call in July with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky, which has revealed in a whistleblower complaint and has become the focus of an impeachment inquiry. He called her âbad newsâ and said that YovanovitchÂ  âis going to go through some things.â Trump pressed Zelensky in the July 25 call to launch an investigation into his political rival Joe Biden and Bidenâs son â while the White House was withholding military aid to Ukraine. Giuliani has admitted that he, Fruman and Parnas were out to gather damaging information about Yovanovitch and other Trump targets. Federal law requires U.S. citizens to disclose to the Justice Department contacts with the American government or media at the direction of foreign government officials or politicians. Giuliani has insisted the law does not apply to his activities because he was working on behalf of Trump, not for foreign officials.

articles.title: Man Who Claimed To Be Kamala Harrisâ Lover Now Says It Was All Fake
articles.subtitle: Sean Newaldass said he thought the California senator was fictional, but now he plans to vote for her.
articles.author: David Moye
articles.content: A man who claimed earlier this week that he had been paid for sex by presidential candidate Kamala Harris now says he was hired for an acting role. Oh, and he claims now that he thought Harris was a fictional person, according to an exclusive interview with the Daily Beast. On Wednesday, 26-year-old personal trainer Sean Newaldass participated in a news conference organized by Jacob Wohl and Jack Burkman, two far-right conspiracy theorists who are already known for pushingÂ fraudulent claims. Newaldass read from a fact sheet about his alleged relationship with the California senator, which can be seen here,Â and claimed he and HarrisÂ had a total of 11 âsexual encountersâ in hotels in Iowa; Washington, D.C.; and New York City, according to the Daily Dot. Check out this video of the news conference â which is hilarious in its ineptness. On Friday, Newaldass told a much different story than the one he told on Wednesday. He said Wohl and Burkman hired him after he answered a CraigsList adÂ seeking a âmale actorâ for âperformance art in DC.â Newaldass said he believed the news conference was actually an audition for a Spike TV show that no longer exists. In fact, he had no clue Harris was a politician, much less a potential presidential candidate. âI thought I was acting for a role in a movie, like a role in a TV series,â Newaldass told the Daily Beast. âI thought everything was staged, Iâm thinking everyone is an actor.â Even more important:Â âIâm completely oblivious to who [Harris] is,â Newaldass told the Daily Beast. Later in the interview, Newaldass admitted heâs researched Harris since the news conference and now says he plans to vote for her. However, Newaldass said he regrets his part in the attempted smear because, like Harris, he is of mixed Indian and Caribbean ancestry. âThatâs whatâs hurtful, because Iâm hurting my own ethnicity,â Newaldass said. Newaldass said he was supposed to receive $500 for his services but hasnât yet. When the Daily Beast reached out to Wohl for his reaction, he responded cryptically with a laughing crying face emoji. HuffPost reached out to Wohl, but he didnât immediately respond. The smear against Harris was the latest to backfire for Wohl and Burkman. Earlier this month, the two dirty tricksters attempted to smear Sen.Â Elizabeth WarrenÂ of Massachusetts as a âcougarâ by holding a news conference with a former Marine in his mid-20s who claimed he had a paid sexual affair with Warren, 70, that included bondage. Warren got the last laugh with a witty response that embraced her âcougarâ past, telling the world it made her who she is.

articles.title: Major Muslim Civil Rights Group Rips Trumpâs âVileâ And âDisturbingâ Refugee Rant
articles.subtitle: The Council on American-Islamic Relations condemned the presidentâs Minnesota rally speech in which he targeted the stateâs Somali refugee population.
articles.author: Amy Russo
articles.content: The countryâs largest Muslim civil rights organization has condemned President Donald Trumpâs âvileâ and âcorrosiveâ fearmongering aimed at Somali refugees during his campaign rally in Minnesota on Thursday night. The Council on American-Islamic RelationsÂ and its Minnesota chapter slammed Trumpâs speech in Minneapolis in which he singled out the stateâs Somali-born Democratic Rep. Ilhan Omar as an âAmerica-hating socialistâ before broadening his attacks to the local Somali refugee population as a whole. âLast nightâs racist rant targeting Somali-Americans is just the latest example of Donald Trumpâs use of white supremacist and anti-immigrant rhetoric to advance his twisted political agenda by dividing our nation along racial, ethnic and religious lines,â Nihad Awad, CAIRâs national executive director, said in a statementÂ Friday. âIt is all the more disturbing that the almost all-white audience welcomed this overt racism and that Republican political leaders remain silent or even support such bigotry.â During his speech at Minneapolisâ Target Center, Trump prompted boos from the audience when he said the stateâs Somali refugees had been welcomed by Washington politicians âwithout considering the impact on schools and communities and taxpayers.â Continuing, he boasted of his plan to slash refugee resettlement by nearly 85% from 2016 levels, declaring that âin the Trump administration, we will always protect American families first, and that has not been done in Minnesota.â âWeâve also implemented the strongest screening and vetting mechanisms ever put into place,â he added. âWe are keeping terrorists, criminals and extremists the hell out of our country.â Rebuking Trumpâs scare tactics, Awad warned of their consequences. âTrumpâs vile views and policies are having a corrosive effect on the ties that bind our nation together, and if left unchecked by those who value American traditions of inclusion and mutual respect, will do untold damage to our democracy,â he said. Jaylani Hussein, executive director of CAIRâs Minnesota branch, also called out the presidentâs âhate rhetoric,â raising concerns that it âplaces the entire Somali community in Minnesota and nationwide in danger from the growing white supremacist movement that looks to him for validation and encouragement.â Awad and Husseinâs remarks added to criticism from Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Amy Klobuchar, who also represents Minnesota. âImmigrants and refugees have helped make our state a wonderful place to live and work â which is far more than this President has done,â she tweeted Thursday. âStop using immigrants and refugees as political pawns!â Another 2020 hopeful, former Rep. Beto OâRourke (D-Texas) echoed Klobucharâs remarks, tweeting that next week, Trump will bring âthis same message of hateâ at his Dallas rally next week, though OâRourke plans to hold a counter-rally titled âRally Against Fearï»¿â to âshow he doesnât represent our country.â

articles.title: Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan Is Out After Just 6 Months
articles.subtitle: McAleenan struggled to mesh with the Trump administration.
articles.author: Mary Papenfuss
articles.content: After six months on the job, Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan stepped down Friday. President Donald Trump said in a tweet that McAleenan was leaving to âspend more time with his family and go into the private sector.â Trump said McAleenan âhas done an outstanding job .... We have worked well together with Border Crossings being way down.â The president added: âCongratulations Kevinâ and said he would be announcing a new acting secretary next week. McAleenanâs fit with the Trump administration was reportedly rocky from the start. He was quoted by The Washington Post in a story early this month that he was struggling to control the department among Trumpâs political appointees in senior roles. âWhat I donât have control over is the tone, the message, the public face and approach of the department in an increasingly polarized time,â McAleenan told the Post. âThatâs uncomfortable, as the accountable senior figure.â The Post described him as increasingly isolated and overshadowed by others more âeffusiveâ in their praise of Trump. He was never formally nominated for the job. McAleenan thanked the president in a tweet Friday for the âopportunity to serve alongside the men and women of the Department of Homeland Security.â He said with Trumpâs support, âwe have made tremendous progress mitigating the border security and humanitarian crisis we faced this year.â In a longer attached statement, he cited success in reducing unlawful crossings, partnering with other governments to âcounterâ human smugglers and âaddress the causes of migration.â He vowed to cooperate in a âsmooth transition.â On Monday, McAleenan left the stage at a Georgetown University immigration conference when demonstrators shouted him down, chanting: âImmigrants are under attackâ and âChildren are under attack.â McAleenan took over the department after Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen was forced out in the spring, reportedly after she refused to reinstate Trumpâs policy of separating migrant children from their families.
